court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether to stay the operation and execution of Full Court orders made 30 April 2009 pending an application for special leave to appeal to the High Court
Whether the circumstances were exceptional such that a stay was necessary to preserve the subject matter of the litigation
Costs of the stay application
facts: Final property orders were made at first instance by Mushin J on 19 March 2008.
The Full Court made orders on 30 April 2009 dismissing the wife's appeal, save for slight adjustments due to a mathematical error.
The wife sought a stay until the hearing of her High Court special leave application (understood to be filed 26 May 2009).
A stay would effectively continue the trial judge's stay made 16 May 2008.
The property included real estate in Melbourne (net value stated to be approximately $200,000) and funds invested in India (approximately $500,000).
The trial orders required both parties to sign documents to repatriate the investment moneys from India to Australia for division pursuant to the property orders.
The wife remained living in the matrimonial home (net value stated to be $194,195).
The husband lived in a property that was encumbered for an amount exceeding its value.
The husband opposed the grant of a stay and asserted prejudice from further delay in receiving his entitlement.

asset_pool: Melbourne real estate with total net value stated to be approximately $200,000 (including a matrimonial home with net value stated to be $194,195)
Funds invested in India stated to be approximately $500,000
Reference to a life insurance policy raised by the wife (treatment/value not set out in these reasons)
Allegations by the wife of undisclosed bank accounts (not determined in this stay decision)
future_needs: Wife asserted her medical condition was not properly considered in the underlying property proceedings (not determined in this stay application).
just_equitable: The stay decision did not revisit the just and equitable merits of the underlying property orders; it concerned whether execution should be stayed pending special leave.
living_arrangements: Wife living in the matrimonial home.
Husband living in a house encumbered beyond its value.

child_ages: One son referred to as being 14 years old.

outcome_orders: The application for a stay of the orders of the Full Court made 30 April 2009 was dismissed.
The applicant (wife) was ordered to pay the costs of the respondent (husband) to be assessed.
Publication under the pseudonym was approved pursuant to s 121(9)(g) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

description: The decision applies the High Court principles governing an exceptional, discretionary stay pending a special leave application. The Full Court treated the stay as an extraordinary remedy requiring exceptional circumstances, including a demonstrated need to preserve the subject matter of litigation and a sufficient prospect that special leave would be granted. The husband’s demonstrated prejudice from continued delay in receiving his entitlement, and the absence of evidence that the wife’s special leave prospects were substantial or that execution would make any later success nugatory, were central to refusing a stay.
pivotal_findings: The wife made no submission identifying public importance, special features, or important questions of law sufficient to support a conclusion of a substantial prospect that special leave would be granted.
Granting a stay would cause the husband substantial prejudice because he remained without the Indian funds to which he was entitled under property orders made in March 2008.
The husband’s financial position and housing circumstances (encumbrance exceeding value) supported the finding of prejudice, while the wife remained in the matrimonial home.
Repatriation of funds from India was necessary for the husband to receive the property settlement he was entitled to (figure stated as $257,911).
The circumstances relied on by the wife were not exceptional as required for the extraordinary remedy of a stay and were not shown to be necessary to preserve the subject matter of the litigation.
This was not a case where, if the wife later succeeded on special leave and appeal, she could not obtain a further share of property.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (publication/pseudonym order noted).

Stay principles drawn from High Court authorities (as summarised in Petrotimor Companhia de Petroleos SARL v Commonwealth of Australia [2003] FCAFC 82; including considerations of preserving subject matter, substantial prospect of special leave, loss/prejudice to respondent, and balance of convenience).

reasons_rationale: A stay pending special leave is an extraordinary remedy requiring demonstrably exceptional circumstances and a need to preserve the subject matter of the litigation.
The wife did not demonstrate a substantial prospect of special leave being granted or identify matters of public importance or significant legal questions.
The balance of convenience favoured the husband due to substantial prejudice from continued non-receipt of funds and prolonged delay since the 2008 property orders.

The court was not satisfied that execution of the orders would render any later successful appeal nugatory, as the wife could still potentially obtain an adjusted property share if ultimately successful.
uncertainties: The detailed terms of the underlying 19 March 2008 property orders (including precise division methodology and treatment of alleged non-disclosure and insurance) were not set out in full in this stay judgment.
The ultimate outcome of the wife's special leave application to the High Court is not stated.

The existence and status of Indian proceedings was contested in submissions; the reasons refer to an understanding from the earlier Full Court judgment about an Indian High Court order restraining operation of accounts pending Australian adjudication.

summary_text:
- Fact: Final property orders were made at first instance by Mushin J on 19 March 2008.
- Fact: The Full Court made orders on 30 April 2009 dismissing the wife's appeal, save for slight adjustments due to a mathematical error.
- Fact: The wife sought a stay until the hearing of her High Court special leave application (understood to be filed 26 May 2009).
- Fact: A stay would effectively continue the trial judge's stay made 16 May 2008.
- Fact: The property included real estate in Melbourne (net value stated to be approximately $200,000) and funds invested in India (approximately $500,000).
- Fact: The trial orders required both parties to sign documents to repatriate the investment moneys from India to Australia for division pursuant to the property orders.
- Fact: The wife remained living in the matrimonial home (net value stated to be $194,195).
- Fact: The husband lived in a property that was encumbered for an amount exceeding its value.
- Fact: The husband opposed the grant of a stay and asserted prejudice from further delay in receiving his entitlement.

- Issue: Whether to stay the operation and execution of Full Court orders made 30 April 2009 pending an application for special leave to appeal to the High Court
- Issue: Whether the circumstances were exceptional such that a stay was necessary to preserve the subject matter of the litigation
- Issue: Costs of the stay application

- Asset Pool: Melbourne real estate with total net value stated to be approximately $200,000 (including a matrimonial home with net value stated to be $194,195)
- Asset Pool: Funds invested in India stated to be approximately $500,000
- Asset Pool: Reference to a life insurance policy raised by the wife (treatment/value not set out in these reasons)
- Asset Pool: Allegations by the wife of undisclosed bank accounts (not determined in this stay decision)
- Future Needs: Wife asserted her medical condition was not properly considered in the underlying property proceedings (not determined in this stay application).
- Just & Equitable: The stay decision did not revisit the just and equitable merits of the underlying property orders; it concerned whether execution should be stayed pending special leave.
- Child Ages: One son referred to as being 14 years old.

- Outcome: The application for a stay of the orders of the Full Court made 30 April 2009 was dismissed.
- Outcome: The applicant (wife) was ordered to pay the costs of the respondent (husband) to be assessed.
- Outcome: Publication under the pseudonym was approved pursuant to s 121(9)(g) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

- Reasons: A stay pending special leave is an extraordinary remedy requiring demonstrably exceptional circumstances and a need to preserve the subject matter of the litigation.
- Reasons: The wife did not demonstrate a substantial prospect of special leave being granted or identify matters of public importance or significant legal questions.
- Reasons: The balance of convenience favoured the husband due to substantial prejudice from continued non-receipt of funds and prolonged delay since the 2008 property orders.
- Reasons: The court was not satisfied that execution of the orders would render any later successful appeal nugatory, as the wife could still potentially obtain an adjusted property share if ultimately successful.

- Pivotal Finding: The wife made no submission identifying public importance, special features, or important questions of law sufficient to support a conclusion of a substantial prospect that special leave would be granted.
- Pivotal Finding: Granting a stay would cause the husband substantial prejudice because he remained without the Indian funds to which he was entitled under property orders made in March 2008.
- Pivotal Finding: The husband’s financial position and housing circumstances (encumbrance exceeding value) supported the finding of prejudice, while the wife remained in the matrimonial home.
- Pivotal Finding: Repatriation of funds from India was necessary for the husband to receive the property settlement he was entitled to (figure stated as $257,911).
- Pivotal Finding: The circumstances relied on by the wife were not exceptional as required for the extraordinary remedy of a stay and were not shown to be necessary to preserve the subject matter of the litigation.
- Pivotal Finding: This was not a case where, if the wife later succeeded on special leave and appeal, she could not obtain a further share of property.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (publication/pseudonym order noted).
- Statutory Pivot: Stay principles drawn from High Court authorities (as summarised in Petrotimor Companhia de Petroleos SARL v Commonwealth of Australia [2003] FCAFC 82; including considerations of preserving subject matter, substantial prospect of special leave, loss/prejudice to respondent, and balance of convenience).

- Uncertainties: The detailed terms of the underlying 19 March 2008 property orders (including precise division methodology and treatment of alleged non-disclosure and insurance) were not set out in full in this stay judgment.
- Uncertainties: The ultimate outcome of the wife's special leave application to the High Court is not stated.
- Uncertainties: The existence and status of Indian proceedings was contested in submissions; the reasons refer to an understanding from the earlier Full Court judgment about an Indian High Court order restraining operation of accounts pending Australian adjudication.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether the Chief Federal Magistrate erred in the exercise of discretion by refusing to stay parenting orders pending determination of the substantive parenting appeal
Whether insufficient weight was given to the risk that the child’s relationship/attachment to the respondent would increase, potentially rendering any successful substantive appeal nugatory
Whether inappropriate weight was given to the perceived attachment between the child and the respondent and to parties’ discussions about co-parenting
Whether the Chief Federal Magistrate inadequately assessed the merits/arguability of the substantive appeal grounds in deciding the stay application
How the child’s best interests were to be weighed in a stay application, including the desirability of limiting changes to the child’s arrangements
Costs of the stay appeal
facts: The parties were formerly in a same-sex relationship (met 1998; intimate relationship commenced September 2001; separated November 2006).
The child, A, was aged 3 years 4 months at the time of the Full Court reasons.
A was conceived by artificial conception procedures undertaken by the mother in March/April 2005; pregnancy in May 2005; birth in February 2006.
The respondent was involved in many aspects of the artificial reproduction program.
The mother moved into the respondent’s home in January 2006 in preparation for and following A’s birth.
After disagreements about parenting, the mother and child went to live with the mother’s parents in November 2006.
From late 2006 to September 2007 the respondent had visits with A including overnight visits; thereafter the mother reduced visits to daytime only.
The last time the respondent saw A until interim orders in August 2008 was 16 February 2008.
Interim orders in August 2008 provided for A to spend three hours each Saturday with the respondent.

After final parenting orders made 9 February 2009, A’s time with the respondent increased progressively; from 11 April 2009 A began spending six hours each alternate Saturday, with further progression to overnight time every third weekend (10:00am Saturday to 4:00pm Sunday).
The mother filed a substantive appeal against the 9 February 2009 parenting orders on 20 February 2009.
The mother applied on 11 March 2009 (as amended 13 March 2009) for a stay of the time-with orders (or alternatively a substantial reduction).
Chief Federal Magistrate Pascoe refused the stay on 9 April 2009.
The mother appealed the refusal of the stay; the stay appeal was heard with the substantive appeal, but the Full Court determined the stay appeal.

living_arrangements: After November 2006 the mother and child lived with the mother’s parents.

relationship_length: Parties were in a relationship of some nature until separation in November 2006 (intimate relationship commenced September 2001).

child_ages: A: 3 years 4 months (at time of appeal reasons)
current_arrangements: Following interim orders (August 2008) A spent three hours each Saturday with the respondent.

Following final orders (9 February 2009), time increased; from 11 April 2009 A spent six hours each alternate Saturday, progressing to overnight time every third weekend (10:00am Saturday to 4:00pm Sunday).
caregiver_history: The mother gave birth to and raised A; the respondent was involved in conception arrangements and cared for A during the relationship and after separation, including overnight periods (late 2006 to September 2007).
There was a gap of about six months in A’s relationship with the respondent after the mother stopped contact (referred to in stay reasons).
safety_concerns: The mother raised concerns about an incident on 7 March 2009; the Chief Federal Magistrate found there was no danger to the child arising from that incident (as characterised in the stay appeal grounds).
The mother asserted the child was stressed and unwilling to visit the respondent; these matters were raised as grounds in the stay appeal.
child_views: The mother asserted the child was asking why she had to go (spend time with the respondent).
allegations: Mother alleged potential detriment to the child if time-with orders continued but were later reversed on appeal.
Mother alleged the Chief Federal Magistrate wrongly relied on an asserted attachment and gave insufficient weight to the risk the appeal would be rendered nugatory if attachment increased.
Mother alleged the child experienced stress and unwillingness to visit under existing orders.
expert_evidence: Court-appointed family consultant Martin O’Grady observed the relationship between the respondent and the child; the Chief Federal Magistrate relied on observations despite Mr O’Grady’s incorrect assumption that both parties were parents.
best_interests: Chief Federal Magistrate found it was in A’s best interests to spend time with the respondent on a graduated basis leading to overnight time once a month.
In refusing the stay, Chief Federal Magistrate considered it potentially more harmful for A to have another break in the relationship with the respondent, given prior interruption.
Full Court accepted the Chief Federal Magistrate considered the child’s best interests and the disruption associated with stopping or significantly limiting time.
orders: This appeal concerned a stay only; the Full Court dismissed the stay appeal and left the 9 February 2009 parenting orders operating pending the substantive appeal.

incidents: An incident on 7 March 2009 was raised by the mother as relevant to safety/anxiety; the Chief Federal Magistrate found no danger to the child arising from it (per grounds and discussion).

outcome_orders: The appeal against the refusal to stay Order 1 of the orders of Chief Federal Magistrate Pascoe of 9 April 2009 was dismissed.
The respondent’s costs of the stay appeal were reserved to be dealt with at the same time as the Full Court deals with the costs of the substantive appeal.

description: The Full Court treated the stay decision as a discretionary judgment and applied appellate restraint principles. The legal significance lies in how the Court balanced the risk of an appeal being rendered nugatory (via further bonding/attachment under increasing time arrangements) against the child’s best interests and the disruption of interrupting an established relationship. The Court endorsed an approach that, in parenting matters, preserving a pre-order ‘status quo’ is not automatic; the child’s welfare and the practical effects of change are central. The case also highlights that, even where a party is found not to be a legal parent (as found in the substantive proceedings in relation to s 60H), the court may still consider best interests factors when that person seeks orders as a person concerned with the child’s care, welfare and development (s 65C(c)), for the purpose of evaluating time-with orders and associated stay applications.
pivotal_findings: No appealable error of discretion was established in the Chief Federal Magistrate’s refusal of a stay.

The Chief Federal Magistrate considered the child’s best interests and found that stopping or significantly limiting time would risk greater disruption, including another break in the child’s relationship with the respondent.

The Chief Federal Magistrate was entitled to treat the relationship as warm and significant based on the family consultant’s observations, notwithstanding the consultant’s mistaken assumption about parentage.
The Full Court accepted that the stay application largely challenged weight and evaluative judgments, which is generally insufficient to demonstrate appellate error in a discretionary decision.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC (best interests considerations)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60H (parentage in artificial conception circumstances; relevant to the substantive proceedings context)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65C(c) (standing of a person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child to apply for parenting orders)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval of publication under pseudonym; noted)

reasons_rationale: A stay is discretionary; the applicant bears the onus and mere filing of an appeal is insufficient.
The Chief Federal Magistrate weighed the competing hardships and the balance of convenience, including whether refusal of a stay could render an appeal nugatory.
The Chief Federal Magistrate found continuation of time was in the child’s best interests and that a further break in the relationship could be more harmful.
The Full Court found the Chief Federal Magistrate considered and analysed the child’s circumstances and did not ignore relevant post-order events.
The stay appeal was essentially an attack on weight; the Full Court found no relevant discretionary error under appellate principles.
uncertainties: The substantive appeal outcome is not provided in this text; only the stay appeal is determined.
Detailed evidence about the 7 March 2009 incident and the child’s expressed views is not set out in the provided text beyond the grounds and general references.

The Full Court references the Chief Federal Magistrate’s finding in the substantive proceedings that the respondent was not a parent for the purposes of s 60H, but the detailed reasoning for that finding is not included here.

- Issue: Costs of the stay appeal

- Child Ages: A: 3 years 4 months (at time of appeal reasons)
- Current Arrangements: Following interim orders (August 2008) A spent three hours each Saturday with the respondent.
- Current Arrangements: Following final orders (9 February 2009), time increased; from 11 April 2009 A spent six hours each alternate Saturday, progressing to overnight time every third weekend (10:00am Saturday to 4:00pm Sunday).
- Safety Concerns: The mother raised concerns about an incident on 7 March 2009; the Chief Federal Magistrate found there was no danger to the child arising from that incident (as characterised in the stay appeal grounds).

- Best Interests: Full Court accepted the Chief Federal Magistrate considered the child’s best interests and the disruption associated with stopping or significantly limiting time.

- Incidents: An incident on 7 March 2009 was raised by the mother as relevant to safety/anxiety; the Chief Federal Magistrate found no danger to the child arising from it (per grounds and discussion).

- Outcome: The appeal against the refusal to stay Order 1 of the orders of Chief Federal Magistrate Pascoe of 9 April 2009 was dismissed.
- Outcome: The respondent’s costs of the stay appeal were reserved to be dealt with at the same time as the Full Court deals with the costs of the substantive appeal.

- Reasons: The Full Court found the Chief Federal Magistrate considered and analysed the child’s circumstances and did not ignore relevant post-order events.

- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval of publication under pseudonym; noted)

- Uncertainties: The substantive appeal outcome is not provided in this text; only the stay appeal is determined.
- Uncertainties: Detailed evidence about the 7 March 2009 incident and the child’s expressed views is not set out in the provided text beyond the grounds and general references.
- Uncertainties: The Full Court references the Chief Federal Magistrate’s finding in the substantive proceedings that the respondent was not a parent for the purposes of s 60H, but the detailed reasoning for that finding is not included here.

- Pivotal Finding: The Chief Federal Magistrate considered the child’s best interests and found that stopping or significantly limiting time would risk greater disruption, including another break in the child’s relationship with the respondent.
- Pivotal Finding: The Chief Federal Magistrate was entitled to treat the relationship as warm and significant based on the family consultant’s observations, notwithstanding the consultant’s mistaken assumption about parentage.
- Pivotal Finding: The Full Court accepted that the stay application largely challenged weight and evaluative judgments, which is generally insufficient to demonstrate appellate error in a discretionary decision.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC (best interests considerations)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60H (parentage in artificial conception circumstances; relevant to the substantive proceedings context)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65C(c) (standing of a person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child to apply for parenting orders)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval of publication under pseudonym; noted)

- Uncertainties: The substantive appeal outcome is not provided in this text; only the stay appeal is determined.
- Uncertainties: Detailed evidence about the 7 March 2009 incident and the child’s expressed views is not set out in the provided text beyond the grounds and general references.
- Uncertainties: The Full Court references the Chief Federal Magistrate’s finding in the substantive proceedings that the respondent was not a parent for the purposes of s 60H, but the detailed reasoning for that finding is not included here.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Parenting orders appeal concerning proposed international relocation of a very young child to New Zealand
Whether the Federal Magistrate erred by addressing s 65DAA (substantial and significant time) before considering s 60CC best interests factors
Whether there was an evidentiary basis (without expert evidence) to find the child’s relationship with the father would be adversely affected by relocation
Whether insufficient weight was given to the mother’s role as primary carer and the impact on her happiness and financial circumstances if relocation refused
Whether the Federal Magistrate made weekend/special day time orders not sought and/or causing unfairness, including lack of Mother’s Day provision
Costs of the appeal under s 117(1)
facts: The child (C) was born in January 2006 and was nearly 22 months old at the time of the hearing before the Federal Magistrate.
The parties lived together from July 2004, moved to Brisbane in December 2004, and separated finally in March 2007.
The mother is New Zealand-born and had lived in Australia since November 1998; she said it was always her intention ultimately to return to New Zealand.
The father is England-born, lived in New Zealand for significant periods, and had lived in Australia since July 1999; he worked full time as a service manager.
The mother ceased paid employment during pregnancy and had not returned to paid employment after the child was born.
The child lived with the mother and spent significant time with the father under June 2007 consent orders, including multiple weekly occasions and 3 overnight stays per fortnight.

child_ages: Child born January 2006; nearly 22 months old at the first instance hearing (and about 2 years old when reasons described the child’s age).
current_arrangements: Under June 2007 consent orders: each Tuesday 5.30pm–7.00pm; alternate weekends 5.30pm Friday–4.30pm Sunday (or Monday if public holiday); and in the intervening week Thursday 5.30pm–8.00am Friday (overnight).
This meant the child spent 3 nights per fortnight overnight with the father and saw the father on seven days each fortnight.
caregiver_history: The child was primarily cared for by the mother, with significant involvement by the father.
Both parties were found to have good parenting skills and to have a good relationship with the child.
availability: Father worked full time as a service manager; mother was not in paid employment after the birth at the time described.

International travel costs were beyond the parties’ capacity; even with assistance from the mother’s parents, proposed time in Australia would be limited (relevantly described as four periods of one week per year during the next two years).
safety_concerns: Violence or abuse were noted as not relevant in this case.
child_views: No child views were referred to; the child was very young.
allegations: The mother alleged error in reasoning approach and weight given to her circumstances, and alleged procedural unfairness regarding certain time orders.
No allegations of family violence or abuse were raised as relevant.
expert_evidence: No independent children’s lawyer was appointed and no expert report/family report was prepared.

The Full Court noted it would have been appropriate/preferable to have expert evidence of the type discussed in McCall & Clark, but found its absence did not vitiate the Federal Magistrate’s findings on the evidence available.
best_interests: The Federal Magistrate (as upheld on appeal) treated the child’s benefit of a meaningful relationship with both parents as important and accepted the father-child relationship was excellent.

A key best-interests finding was that the mother’s relocation proposal would significantly reduce frequent and regular time with the father (from weekly time to limited annual blocks), likely adversely affecting the relationship, and would not allow the father’s involvement in the child’s daily routine and significant events as contemplated by substantial and significant time.
The court considered practical difficulty/expense of international time and the parties’ limited capacity to fund travel, supporting refusal of relocation.

The mother’s claimed isolation was weighed against findings that she had family and friends in Brisbane, her parents visited regularly, she was resilient and likely to obtain employment, and she could receive childcare support (including from paternal grandmother) with the father offering to contribute to childcare costs.
orders: Relocation to New Zealand was refused at first instance; the child was to live with the mother in Brisbane and spend substantial and significant time with the father (orders substantially reflecting the father’s sought regime).

On appeal, by consent, an additional order was made for Mother’s Day: if the child was spending time with the father on Mother’s Day, that time be suspended and the child spend not less than four hours with the mother on Mother’s Day.

outcome_orders: Appeal dismissed (appeal against orders of Federal Magistrate Howard made 26 February 2008).
No order as to costs of the appeal.
By consent, the 26 February 2008 orders were varied by adding Order 11A for Mother’s Day time (minimum 4 hours with the mother if otherwise with the father).

description: This appeal confirms that in international relocation parenting disputes the paramount consideration remains the child’s best interests (s 60CA). While a logical sequencing is to make s 60CC findings before applying s 65DAA, a different structure will not be appealable error unless it demonstrates failure to consider mandatory factors or inadequate reasons. The case illustrates that for a toddler already enjoying frequent, regular time with a parent, a proposed shift to limited annual blocks of time overseas can rationally support a finding that the meaningful relationship would likely be adversely affected, even without expert evidence, provided the finding is grounded in the existing care pattern and practical realities of travel, cost, and the child’s developmental stage.
pivotal_findings: The child was very young and was already spending frequent and regular time with the father (including overnights) and was thriving in that routine.
The mother conceded the father-child relationship was “fantastic” and there was no dispute that a meaningful relationship with both parents was in the child’s best interests.

The relocation proposal would materially reduce time with the father from weekly contact to limited annual visits (described in the reasons as four one-week periods per year during the next two years), making the child’s time with the father more akin to “holidaying” and limiting involvement in daily routine and significant events.
Neither parent had the financial capacity to fund international travel; reliance on third-party funding (mother’s parents) did not remove the practical constraint.

The Federal Magistrate weighed the mother’s claims of isolation and improved life in New Zealand against findings of social/family supports in Brisbane, regular visits from her parents, likely employability, availability of childcare support, and the father’s willingness to assist with childcare costs.
No procedural unfairness arose from the Friday-night order complained of, because it was sought in the father’s outline of case document.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CA (paramountcy of best interests)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60B (objects and principles)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2) and s 60CC(3) (primary and additional best interests considerations)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 61DA (presumption of equal shared parental responsibility)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65DAA (consideration of equal time/substantial and significant time; reasonable practicability)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 69ZX(1)(d) (court power to obtain evidence, referenced via McCall & Clark discussion)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(1) (costs discretion)

reasons_rationale: The Full Court held that although the structure of the Federal Magistrate’s reasons risked an appearance of pre-determination, on a fair reading he considered the relevant s 60CC factors and evidence and provided adequate reasons.

No appealable error was shown in the finding that relocation would adversely affect the father-child relationship, given the undisputed high-quality relationship, the child’s young age, the current weekly routine, and the stark reduction in time under the relocation proposal combined with practical and financial travel constraints.

The court rejected the challenge that insufficient weight was given to the mother’s circumstances; the assessment was discretionary and the Federal Magistrate weighed available supports and prospects in Brisbane against the claimed benefits of New Zealand.
The procedural fairness complaint about orders not sought failed because the relevant time arrangement was sought in the father’s filed outline of case.
Costs: despite dismissal, the appeal was brought bona fide and the mother’s limited means (Centrelink/child support) were considered; no costs order was made.
uncertainties: The Full Court decision summary does not reproduce the full text of the primary orders made on 26 February 2008 beyond the Mother’s Day variation and some discussion of time structure; precise detailed parenting order terms are not fully set out in the provided text.

No expert evidence was before the Federal Magistrate; while the Full Court noted such evidence would have been preferable, the precise developmental/attachment evidence was not available and was not determinative on appeal.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from refusal to grant a stay of interim spousal maintenance orders pending determination of a substantive appeal
Whether the Federal Magistrate failed to give reasons for refusing the stay (not pursued)
Whether alleged change in the husband’s financial circumstances (claimed unemployment) was properly considered in the stay application
Whether alleged jurisdiction/forum issues arising from Polish proceedings should have affected the stay decision
Whether the Federal Magistrate correctly applied the discretionary principles governing stay applications, including nugatory appeal and hardship considerations
Whether the merits/arguability of the proposed substantive appeal were properly weighed on the stay application
facts: The parties commenced living together in December 2003, married in November 2005, and separated in March 2008.
They moved from Australia in 2005 due to the husband’s employment with a business described as L Corporation.
At separation they were living in Poland.
There is one child of the marriage, aged 4 years at the time of the judgment, living in Poland with the husband.
The wife returned to Australia in December 2008.
The wife commenced proceedings in Poland in October 2008 for parenting orders and spousal maintenance; supervised time orders were made on 4 December 2008.
The evidence about the status/outcome of Polish maintenance proceedings was unclear and considered unreliable for the stay issue.
Before returning to Australia the wife became pregnant to Mr B; the baby was due in September 2009.
The wife and Mr B gave evidence that they were friends and not in a relationship.

On 9 April 2009, the Federal Magistrate made interim spousal maintenance orders requiring periodic payments of $650 per week (or $2,817 per month) and a lump sum of $43,000, with a potential $20,000 reduction if specified stored furniture/personal items were delivered to the wife.
The husband filed a substantive appeal on 1 May 2009 against the 9 April 2009 maintenance orders.
On 14 May 2009, the Federal Magistrate dismissed the husband’s application to stay the 9 April 2009 orders pending appeal.
The husband asserted in May 2009 that he had become unemployed and could not meet the ordered payments, claiming he would have to live off capital.

living_arrangements: Child lives in Poland with the husband; wife lives in Australia.

need: The interim orders were characterised as for the maintenance of the wife, including a lump sum component; the Full Court accepted the lump sum order related to maintenance.
capacity_to_pay: At the earlier stage (7 April 2009) the husband deposed he was able to meet any interim maintenance order that might be made.

On 13 May 2009 the husband asserted he had become unemployed and could not meet the weekly payments and would need to live off capital; the Federal Magistrate was sceptical about the reliability/detail of this updated financial information.
The Federal Magistrate considered the husband had funds or equivalent assets to satisfy the lump sum order when addressing whether refusal of a stay would render an appeal nugatory.
statutory_factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 77A (raised on appeal in context of lump sum maintenance/property characterisation; not raised below and not accepted as a basis for stay).
income_expenses: The husband relied on an unfiled affidavit and financial statement sworn 13 May 2009 asserting unemployment; the Federal Magistrate found the information lacked clarity and detail and counsel could not clarify expenses.
The wife’s evidence included lifestyle-based material relevant to the husband’s capacity, which the husband had not challenged at the substantive interim hearing.
earning_capacity: Husband claimed redundancy/unemployment in May 2009 and difficulty obtaining another job in the financial climate; little objective detail was provided.
relationship_length: Cohabitation from December 2003; marriage from November 2005; separation March 2008.
standard_of_living: The wife relied on knowledge of the parties’ lifestyle together in Poland as part of her evidence about the husband’s capacity to pay.

child_ages: One child aged 4 years.
current_arrangements: Child lives in Poland with the husband.

outcome_orders: Appeal against the refusal to stay Orders 5, 6 and 7 of the Federal Magistrate’s orders of 9 April 2009 dismissed.
The husband to pay the wife’s costs of and incidental to the appeal as agreed and failing agreement, as assessed.
Publication under pseudonym approved pursuant to Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g).

description: This decision confirms the discretionary nature of a stay pending appeal in interim spousal maintenance matters. The Full Court focused on whether the applicant for a stay demonstrated a sound basis, including a real risk that the appeal would be rendered nugatory, and a proper balancing of hardship. The Court also treated late-raised legal/contention points (forum/jurisdiction and s 77A characterisation) as carrying little weight on a stay appeal where they were not properly raised or evidenced at first instance. Reliability and detail of asserted financial change were pivotal; the applicant’s earlier stance that he could pay, combined with limited objective evidence of unemployment and unclear financial material, undermined the stay case.
pivotal_findings: The Federal Magistrate gave reasons and correctly identified and applied the established principles for stay applications as a discretionary exercise.
The Federal Magistrate took the husband’s asserted changed financial circumstances into account but was entitled to give them limited weight due to lack of objective detail and doubts about accuracy.
The husband had not filed an application to vary the interim maintenance orders based on alleged unemployment, and his stay application effectively relied on a prospective/undeveloped appeal point.
The Federal Magistrate was entitled to conclude the wife would suffer greater hardship than the husband if a stay were granted.
Payment under interim maintenance orders could be accounted for later in property proceedings as a post-separation contribution, reducing concerns about irretrievability.

Alleged Polish proceedings issues were not clearly raised below, were evidentially unclear, and were viewed as more a forum point than a jurisdictional bar; they did not demonstrate appealable error in the stay decision.

Arguments about s 77A notation and characterising the lump sum as property rather than maintenance were not raised before the Federal Magistrate and were not a proper foundation for the stay; the lump sum order was clearly for maintenance.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 77A
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g)

reasons_rationale: No appealable error was established in the Federal Magistrate’s discretionary refusal of a stay.
The stay principles were correctly stated and applied, including assessment of hardship, risk of rendering the appeal nugatory, and an assessment of whether the appeal had arguable merit.
The husband’s asserted unemployment and inability to pay was inadequately evidenced and internally inconsistent with his earlier sworn position that he could meet any interim maintenance order.
The Federal Magistrate’s preference for the wife’s position on hardship, and scepticism about the husband’s financial material, were open on the evidence.

The husband’s additional arguments (Polish proceedings/forum and s 77A characterisation) were either not properly raised at first instance, uncertain on the evidence, or insufficiently connected to demonstrating a proper basis for a stay.
uncertainties: Status and outcome of the Polish maintenance proceedings were unclear on the evidence before the Full Court.
The husband’s precise financial circumstances following the claimed unemployment were unclear due to lack of objective detail and confusing expense information.
Any mathematical error alleged in the Federal Magistrate’s asset assessment was not established to the Full Court’s satisfaction and was not shown to amount to appealable error.

- Outcome: Appeal against the refusal to stay Orders 5, 6 and 7 of the Federal Magistrate’s orders of 9 April 2009 dismissed.
- Outcome: The husband to pay the wife’s costs of and incidental to the appeal as agreed and failing agreement, as assessed.
- Outcome: Publication under pseudonym approved pursuant to Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g).

- Reasons: No appealable error was established in the Federal Magistrate’s discretionary refusal of a stay.
- Reasons: The stay principles were correctly stated and applied, including assessment of hardship, risk of rendering the appeal nugatory, and an assessment of whether the appeal had arguable merit.
- Reasons: The husband’s asserted unemployment and inability to pay was inadequately evidenced and internally inconsistent with his earlier sworn position that he could meet any interim maintenance order.
- Reasons: The Federal Magistrate’s preference for the wife’s position on hardship, and scepticism about the husband’s financial material, were open on the evidence.
- Reasons: The husband’s additional arguments (Polish proceedings/forum and s 77A characterisation) were either not properly raised at first instance, uncertain on the evidence, or insufficiently connected to demonstrating a proper basis for a stay.

- Pivotal Finding: The Federal Magistrate gave reasons and correctly identified and applied the established principles for stay applications as a discretionary exercise.
- Pivotal Finding: The Federal Magistrate took the husband’s asserted changed financial circumstances into account but was entitled to give them limited weight due to lack of objective detail and doubts about accuracy.
- Pivotal Finding: The husband had not filed an application to vary the interim maintenance orders based on alleged unemployment, and his stay application effectively relied on a prospective/undeveloped appeal point.
- Pivotal Finding: The Federal Magistrate was entitled to conclude the wife would suffer greater hardship than the husband if a stay were granted.
- Pivotal Finding: Payment under interim maintenance orders could be accounted for later in property proceedings as a post-separation contribution, reducing concerns about irretrievability.
- Pivotal Finding: Alleged Polish proceedings issues were not clearly raised below, were evidentially unclear, and were viewed as more a forum point than a jurisdictional bar; they did not demonstrate appealable error in the stay decision.
- Pivotal Finding: Arguments about s 77A notation and characterising the lump sum as property rather than maintenance were not raised before the Federal Magistrate and were not a proper foundation for the stay; the lump sum order was clearly for maintenance.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 77A
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g)

- Uncertainties: Status and outcome of the Polish maintenance proceedings were unclear on the evidence before the Full Court.
- Uncertainties: The husband’s precise financial circumstances following the claimed unemployment were unclear due to lack of objective detail and confusing expense information.
- Uncertainties: Any mathematical error alleged in the Federal Magistrate’s asset assessment was not established to the Full Court’s satisfaction and was not shown to amount to appealable error.

summary_sections.text:
- Fact: The parties commenced living together in December 2003, married in November 2005, and separated in March 2008.
- Fact: They moved from Australia in 2005 due to the husband’s employment with a business described as L Corporation.
- Fact: At separation they were living in Poland.
- Fact: There is one child of the marriage, aged 4 years at the time of the judgment, living in Poland with the husband.
- Fact: The wife returned to Australia in December 2008.
- Fact: The wife commenced proceedings in Poland in October 2008 for parenting orders and spousal maintenance; supervised time orders were made on 4 December 2008.
- Fact: The evidence about the status/outcome of Polish maintenance proceedings was unclear and considered unreliable for the stay issue.
- Fact: Before returning to Australia the wife became pregnant to Mr B; the baby was due in September 2009.
- Fact: The wife and Mr B gave evidence that they were friends and not in a relationship.
- Fact: On 9 April 2009, the Federal Magistrate made interim spousal maintenance orders requiring periodic payments of $650 per week (or $2,817 per month) and a lump sum of $43,000, with a potential $20,000 reduction if specified stored furniture/personal items were delivered to the wife.
- Fact: The husband filed a substantive appeal on 1 May 2009 against the 9 April 2009 maintenance orders.
- Fact: On 14 May 2009, the Federal Magistrate dismissed the husband’s application to stay the 9 April 2009 orders pending appeal.
- Fact: The husband asserted in May 2009 that he had become unemployed and could not meet the ordered payments, claiming he would have to live off capital.

- Issue: Appeal from refusal to grant a stay of interim spousal maintenance orders pending determination of a substantive appeal
- Issue: Whether the Federal Magistrate failed to give reasons for refusing the stay (not pursued)
- Issue: Whether alleged change in the husband’s financial circumstances (claimed unemployment) was properly considered in the stay application
- Issue: Whether alleged jurisdiction/forum issues arising from Polish proceedings should have affected the stay decision
- Issue: Whether the Federal Magistrate correctly applied the discretionary principles governing stay applications, including nugatory appeal and hardship considerations
- Issue: Whether the merits/arguability of the proposed substantive appeal were properly weighed on the stay application

- Need: The interim orders were characterised as for the maintenance of the wife, including a lump sum component; the Full Court accepted the lump sum order related to maintenance.
- Capacity to Pay: At the earlier stage (7 April 2009) the husband deposed he was able to meet any interim maintenance order that might be made.
- Capacity to Pay: On 13 May 2009 the husband asserted he had become unemployed and could not meet the weekly payments and would need to live off capital; the Federal Magistrate was sceptical about the reliability/detail of this updated financial information.
- Capacity to Pay: The Federal Magistrate considered the husband had funds or equivalent assets to satisfy the lump sum order when addressing whether refusal of a stay would render an appeal nugatory.
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 77A (raised on appeal in context of lump sum maintenance/property characterisation; not raised below and not accepted as a basis for stay).

- Child Ages: One child aged 4 years.
- Current Arrangements: Child lives in Poland with the husband.

- Outcome: Appeal against the refusal to stay Orders 5, 6 and 7 of the Federal Magistrate’s orders of 9 April 2009 dismissed.
- Outcome: The husband to pay the wife’s costs of and incidental to the appeal as agreed and failing agreement, as assessed.
- Outcome: Publication under pseudonym approved pursuant to Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g).

- Reasons: No appealable error was established in the Federal Magistrate’s discretionary refusal of a stay.
- Reasons: The stay principles were correctly stated and applied, including assessment of hardship, risk of rendering the appeal nugatory, and an assessment of whether the appeal had arguable merit.
- Reasons: The husband’s asserted unemployment and inability to pay was inadequately evidenced and internally inconsistent with his earlier sworn position that he could meet any interim maintenance order.
- Reasons: The Federal Magistrate’s preference for the wife’s position on hardship, and scepticism about the husband’s financial material, were open on the evidence.
- Reasons: The husband’s additional arguments (Polish proceedings/forum and s 77A characterisation) were either not properly raised at first instance, uncertain on the evidence, or insufficiently connected to demonstrating a proper basis for a stay.

- Pivotal Finding: The Federal Magistrate gave reasons and correctly identified and applied the established principles for stay applications as a discretionary exercise.
- Pivotal Finding: The Federal Magistrate took the husband’s asserted changed financial circumstances into account but was entitled to give them limited weight due to lack of objective detail and doubts about accuracy.
- Pivotal Finding: The husband had not filed an application to vary the interim maintenance orders based on alleged unemployment, and his stay application effectively relied on a prospective/undeveloped appeal point.
- Pivotal Finding: The Federal Magistrate was entitled to conclude the wife would suffer greater hardship than the husband if a stay were granted.
- Pivotal Finding: Payment under interim maintenance orders could be accounted for later in property proceedings as a post-separation contribution, reducing concerns about irretrievability.
- Pivotal Finding: Alleged Polish proceedings issues were not clearly raised below, were evidentially unclear, and were viewed as more a forum point than a jurisdictional bar; they did not demonstrate appealable error in the stay decision.
- Pivotal Finding: Arguments about s 77A notation and characterising the lump sum as property rather than maintenance were not raised before the Federal Magistrate and were not a proper foundation for the stay; the lump sum order was clearly for maintenance.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 77A
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g)

- Uncertainties: Status and outcome of the Polish maintenance proceedings were unclear on the evidence before the Full Court.
- Uncertainties: The husband’s precise financial circumstances following the claimed unemployment were unclear due to lack of objective detail and confusing expense information.
- Uncertainties: Any mathematical error alleged in the Federal Magistrate’s asset assessment was not established to the Full Court’s satisfaction and was not shown to amount to appealable error.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from interlocutory interim property settlement order funding litigation expenses
Correct legal test and approach for interim property orders under s 79 and s 80(1)(h) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether 'compelling circumstances' is required as a threshold for an interim property order
Whether trial judge erred by focusing on costs budget/necessity rather than s 79(4) considerations and the 'adjustment/claw-back' issue
Quantum: whether $1 million was manifestly inadequate and whether $5 million should have been ordered
facts: Parties married in early 1994 and separated in January 2005; divorced February 2006.
One child of the marriage, born June 1996, is autistic and lives with the Wife in Adelaide.
Husband moved to Hong Kong at separation and continues to live there; Wife and child remain in Adelaide.
Property and parenting proceedings commenced in 2005 and have been protracted, with at least 40 interim applications since February 2005.
Significant dispute about the extent and value of assets: Husband contended assets around $60-80 million; Wife contended assets in the hundreds of millions.
Key controversy concerned alleged non-disclosure by the Husband and valuation of interests including gambling-related enterprises; a single expert valuer (Ms E) was appointed but report delayed.

asset_pool: Asset pool was not finally determined; competing positions ranged from about $60-80 million (Husband/single expert figure referenced) to 'hundreds of millions' (Wife).
Single expert valuation report (Ms E) pending at relevant times; valuation delays contributed to adjournments.
At separation Wife held approximately $6,723,695 in bank accounts (later significantly reduced).
contributions: Not determined; substantive contributions were not adjudicated in this interim appeal.
Wife had primary care of the child (autistic) who lived with her; any parenting/care contributions were noted but not assessed for s 79(4) purposes in final terms.
future_needs: Not finally determined; trial judge referred to possibility (raised by Husband) that Wife might later seek a further s 75(2) adjustment due to spending on legal costs, but treated that as speculative at interim stage.
Wife’s immediate need identified was funds to conduct litigation and prepare for trial (including parenting evidence).
just_equitable: Full Court held interim order under s 79/s 80(1)(h) requires consideration of s 79(4) (briefly) and satisfaction that it is just and equitable; the key practical inquiry included whether the applicant is likely to receive sufficient property at final hearing to 'cover the advance' and whether the advance can be adjusted/treated as part of entitlement ('claw-back' issue).

Full Court found trial judge erred by treating 'compelling circumstances' as a necessary threshold and by failing to address s 79(4) factors when quantifying the interim payment, instead undertaking an assessment of what costs were 'needed'.
living_arrangements: Wife and child lived in Adelaide; Husband lived in Hong Kong.

relationship_length: Marriage from early 1994 to separation January 2005.

child_ages: Child born June 1996 (approximately 13 at time of appeal decision in 2009).
current_arrangements: Child lived with the Wife in Adelaide.
caregiver_history: Wife was the child's primary carer post-separation (as indicated by the child's residence with her).
availability: Husband lived in Hong Kong; Wife in Adelaide.
expert_evidence: Single expert valuation (Ms E) in financial proceedings; independent children's expert (Dr C) referenced in connection with the Independent Children's Lawyer.
best_interests: Final parenting issues were pending and being heard under Division 12A; this appeal did not determine best interests or final parenting arrangements.

outcome_orders: Leave granted to the Wife to amend the orders sought in the Amended Notice of Appeal (deleting references requiring use of funds for costs and deleting proposed allocation determination at trial).
Leave granted to appeal against Strickland J's interlocutory order made 24 September 2008.
Appeal allowed.
Order 1 made on 24 September 2008 set aside.
Within 30 days the Husband to pay to the Wife's solicitors on behalf of the Wife $5,000,000 by way of interim property settlement.
Costs of leave application and appeal to be determined on written submissions timetable; parties given liberty to file/serve submissions and replies within specified periods.

description: This decision clarifies the correct analytical approach and source-of-power discipline for interim funding orders in Family Court litigation, particularly where framed as interim property settlement under s 79 with enabling power in s 80(1)(h). The Full Court emphasised that the key threshold is whether it is appropriate in the interests of justice to make an interim property order (not a rigid 'compelling circumstances' test), and that the substantive exercise must be anchored to s 79(4) considerations and the capacity to treat the advance as part of the applicant’s likely final entitlement (the adjustment/claw-back issue). The case is significant in preventing trial courts from using an interim s 79 order as a de facto costs-budget control mechanism and in underscoring the importance of identifying the statutory source of power because it determines preconditions and considerations (s 79 vs s 117 vs s 74).
pivotal_findings: The trial judge erred in principle by treating 'compelling circumstances' as a required constraint rather than asking whether it was appropriate in the interests of justice to make an interim order.

The trial judge accepted the Wife had very limited funds, needed funds to take the matter to trial, and the Husband had capacity to pay; these findings supported the procedural threshold for an interim order.
There was no issue that sufficient property remained to meet both parties' legitimate expectations at final hearing if the $5 million advance were made (claw-back/adjustment feasibility).

The trial judge miscarried in quantifying the order by attempting a costs assessment and failing to address s 79(4) factors, and by not accounting for existing legal debts which materially reduced the effective amount available for future costs.

Given the uncontested likelihood the Wife would receive at least the amount advanced in final property settlement, the Full Court held the interim payment should not be deferred and ordered the $5 million sought.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(1), s 79(2), s 79(4) (property settlement power and mandatory considerations)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 80(1)(h) (enabling power to make orders pending disposal of proceedings; interim property orders)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 94AA(1) (leave requirement for appeal from interlocutory order)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors, via s 79(4)(e))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 and s 117(2A) (alternative source of power for interim litigation funding/costs orders, discussed but not applied here)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) ss 72 and 74 (spousal maintenance power as possible alternative basis for litigation funding, discussed)

reasons_rationale: The Full Court stressed that when making interim provision for litigation expenses it is essential to identify the statutory source of power, because it determines preconditions and relevant considerations.

For interim property orders under s 79/s 80(1)(h), the overarching procedural question is whether it is appropriate in the interests of justice to exercise the power before the final hearing; 'compelling circumstances' is not a necessary legal requirement.

At the substantive stage, the court must consider the s 79 framework (with limits appropriate to interim context), including the adjustment/claw-back issue: the advance must be capable of being taken into account as part of the applicant’s likely final property entitlement and not imperil legitimate expectations.

The trial judge’s approach wrongly used 'compelling circumstances' to narrow both the decision to entertain the application and the quantum, and wrongly undertook a detailed inquiry into what further work should be done rather than focusing on the s 79 analysis and whether the advance could be accommodated within the likely entitlement.

Given findings that the Wife needed funds, lacked funds, the Husband could pay, and remaining property was sufficient, the Full Court re-exercised discretion and ordered $5 million as interim property settlement.
uncertainties: Final asset pool value was unresolved and remained in dispute (tens of millions versus hundreds of millions).
Final property division percentages and contributions/future needs assessments were not determined in this interim appeal.
Parenting issues and final parenting orders were not determined; proceedings were ongoing.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether the wife required leave under s 44(3) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) to institute property settlement proceedings out of time when the claim was raised in a Response to the husband’s parenting application (operation of s 44(2))
Whether the Federal Magistrate erred by effectively determining the merits of the s 79 property claim when deciding the s 44(3) leave/hardship application
Costs: husband’s cross-appeal against refusal of costs order at first instance
Costs certificates under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)
facts: The parties began cohabiting in August 1993, married in March 1997, separated on 28 February 2002.
There are two children: B born August 1999 and C born July 2001.
Divorce became absolute on 24 March 2005; the 12-month limitation for Part VIII proceedings expired about 23/24 March 2006.
Neither party commenced property proceedings within 12 months after divorce.
On 23 March 2007 the husband filed an application in the Federal Magistrates Court seeking parenting orders.
On 23 April 2007 the wife filed a Response seeking parenting orders and also property orders and an order granting leave to bring property proceedings out of time.

asset_pool: First instance findings (for the leave hearing) included: T property valued about $420,000, half interest in two cars estimated $26,500, less ANZ mortgage about $320,678 (net about $125,822 before considering any asserted debt to husband’s father).

Husband asserted an additional liability to his father of $140,000 (comprised of $120,000 mortgage reduction payment and $20,000 for a motorcycle), linked to an asserted agreement for repayment on sale of the property.
Husband’s superannuation approximately $20,000; wife’s superannuation approximately $7,000; wife sought a split to equalise superannuation (about $6,500 transfer).
The Full Court did not determine the final asset pool; it remitted the property case for rehearing.
contributions: Parties lived from 1994 in a house at Y owned by husband’s maternal grandfather; wife made contributions to that property and to care of the children (as recorded in background).

Husband inherited Y property from grandfather’s will after his death in March 2003 and sold it in April 2004 for $240,000; proceeds applied toward purchase of T property for $400,000 with bank borrowings.
Full Court did not make contribution findings for s 79; any contribution assessment was left to remitted proceedings.
future_needs: First instance referenced wife being employed with income about $1,000 per week (financial statement) in the context of hardship; Full Court did not determine s 75(2) adjustments.
Full Court did not make findings on future needs for the purposes of a property division outcome; matter remitted.
just_equitable: Federal Magistrate suggested (in the leave context) that even if s 79 proceedings were heard he would not make an award because it would not be just and equitable given prejudice to the husband’s father; Full Court did not determine that issue for s 79 and treated such comments as not determinative of the property proceedings.
Full Court emphasised the s 44(3) inquiry is distinct from a full s 79 determination.
living_arrangements: Husband’s father moved into a flat attached to the T property in May 2005 and was said to have an arrangement to live there as long as he wished.
Husband had re-partnered with a Ms A; first instance accepted Ms A was co-mortgagor and treated her as having half interest in the cars for the leave assessment.
existing_agreements: Husband and his father asserted an agreement that father could live in the T property and would be repaid $140,000 from sale proceeds; treated by the Federal Magistrate as a liability for the leave decision.
No binding financial agreement (prenup/postnup) under Part VIIIA was identified in the reasons.

child_ages: B born August 1999
C born July 2001
current_arrangements: Parenting issues arising from the husband’s March 2007 application were resolved before the property/leave hearing at first instance.

outcome_orders: Leave to appeal granted to the wife against Order 1 made by Brewster FM on 27 February 2008; appeal allowed; that order set aside.
Husband’s cross-appeal (costs) dismissed.
Wife’s application for property settlement and any cross-application by the husband remitted to the Federal Magistrates Court for determination by a Federal Magistrate other than Brewster FM.
Costs certificate granted to the appellant (wife) under s 9 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
Costs certificate granted to the respondent (husband) under s 6 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
Publication approved under pseudonym pursuant to s 121(9)(g) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

description: The case clarifies the interaction between the 12-month limitation in s 44(3) and the respondent’s ability under s 44(2) to include in an answer/response an application for any decree or declaration, even where the new claim is a property settlement claim raised in response to a parenting application. The Full Court treated the issue as a preliminary question of law and held the wife did not require leave because s 44(2) operates "notwithstanding" s 44(3). It also addressed the proper character of a s 44(3) hearing, cautioning against conducting it as a de facto final s 79 property hearing; the correct focus is hardship and whether there is a reasonable claim to be heard, with procedure kept appropriately summary.
pivotal_findings: The wife’s property claim was filed as part of a Response to the husband’s parenting application; such a Response constitutes an "answer" for the purposes of s 44(2).

Section 44(2) permits a respondent, in an answer to an application, to include an application for any decree or declaration under the Act notwithstanding the limitation provisions in s 44(3) and (3A).
Berta & Berta (1988) FLC 91-916 was applied as binding authority supporting the breadth of s 44(2); the Court extended its reasoning to an answer to a parenting application.
Because leave was not required, Brewster FM’s dismissal of the s 44(3) leave application was set aside and the substantive property proceedings were remitted for rehearing.

The Federal Magistrate’s approach of effectively running a s 79 case to determine hardship was identified as misconceiving the distinct nature of s 44(3) applications (although ultimate appeal disposition turned on s 44(2)).
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 44(2) (respondent may include application for any decree or declaration notwithstanding s 44(3)/(3A))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 44(3) and s 44(4) (time limit and hardship threshold for leave)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 (property settlement proceedings remitted; not determined on appeal)
Acts Interpretation Act 1901 (Cth) s 15AA (purposive interpretation referenced in reasoning)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (publication under pseudonym)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6 and 9 (costs certificates)

reasons_rationale: The Full Court held the wife did not require s 44(3) leave because her property application was included in her Response to the husband’s initiating parenting application, engaging s 44(2) which operates notwithstanding s 44(3).

The Court relied on the breadth of the words "any decree or declaration" and the express "notwithstanding" clause, and applied the Full Court authority in Berta & Berta; the term "answer" was given its ordinary meaning of reply/response.
Given the legal error, the refusal of leave order was set aside and the property dispute was remitted for determination; the Court avoided expressing views on the merits of the property division.
The husband’s cross-appeal on costs failed consequentially once the wife succeeded on appeal.
Costs certificates were granted because the appeal succeeded on a question of law.
uncertainties: No final property settlement outcome was determined; the asset pool, valuation disputes, treatment of the asserted father’s debt, contributions, and any s 75(2) adjustment remain for rehearing.
The Full Court did not determine parenting arrangements because those issues had been resolved prior to the hearing.
Any findings made by the Federal Magistrate about the substantive property outcome were treated as not determinative and were not endorsed by the Full Court.

summary_text:
- Fact: The parties began cohabiting in August 1993, married in March 1997, separated on 28 February 2002.
- Fact: There are two children: B born August 1999 and C born July 2001.
- Fact: Divorce became absolute on 24 March 2005; the 12-month limitation for Part VIII proceedings expired about 23/24 March 2006.
- Fact: Neither party commenced property proceedings within 12 months after divorce.
- Fact: On 23 March 2007 the husband filed an application in the Federal Magistrates Court seeking parenting orders.
- Fact: On 23 April 2007 the wife filed a Response seeking parenting orders and also property orders and an order granting leave to bring property proceedings out of time.

- Issue: Whether the wife required leave under s 44(3) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) to institute property settlement proceedings out of time when the claim was raised in a Response to the husband’s parenting application (operation of s 44(2))
- Issue: Whether the Federal Magistrate erred by effectively determining the merits of the s 79 property claim when deciding the s 44(3) leave/hardship application
- Issue: Costs: husband’s cross-appeal against refusal of costs order at first instance
- Issue: Costs certificates under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)

- Asset Pool: First instance findings (for the leave hearing) included: T property valued about $420,000, half interest in two cars estimated $26,500, less ANZ mortgage about $320,678 (net about $125,822 before considering any asserted debt to husband’s father).
- Asset Pool: Husband asserted an additional liability to his father of $140,000 (comprised of $120,000 mortgage reduction payment and $20,000 for a motorcycle), linked to an asserted agreement for repayment on sale of the property.
- Asset Pool: Husband’s superannuation approximately $20,000; wife’s superannuation approximately $7,000; wife sought a split to equalise superannuation (about $6,500 transfer).
- Asset Pool: The Full Court did not determine the final asset pool; it remitted the property case for rehearing.
- Contributions: Parties lived from 1994 in a house at Y owned by husband’s maternal grandfather; wife made contributions to that property and to care of the children (as recorded in background).
- Contributions: Husband inherited Y property from grandfather’s will after his death in March 2003 and sold it in April 2004 for $240,000; proceeds applied toward purchase of T property for $400,000 with bank borrowings.
- Contributions: Full Court did not make contribution findings for s 79; any contribution assessment was left to remitted proceedings.
- Future Needs: First instance referenced wife being employed with income about $1,000 per week (financial statement) in the context of hardship; Full Court did not determine s 75(2) adjustments.
- Future Needs: Full Court did not make findings on future needs for the purposes of a property division outcome; matter remitted.
- Just & Equitable: Federal Magistrate suggested (in the leave context) that even if s 79 proceedings were heard he would not make an award because it would not be just and equitable given prejudice to the husband’s father; Full Court did not determine that issue for s 79 and treated such comments as not determinative of the property proceedings.
- Just & Equitable: Full Court emphasised the s 44(3) inquiry is distinct from a full s 79 determination.

- Child Ages: B born August 1999
- Child Ages: C born July 2001
- Current Arrangements: Parenting issues arising from the husband’s March 2007 application were resolved before the property/leave hearing at first instance.

- Outcome: Leave to appeal granted to the wife against Order 1 made by Brewster FM on 27 February 2008; appeal allowed; that order set aside.
- Outcome: Husband’s cross-appeal (costs) dismissed.
- Outcome: Wife’s application for property settlement and any cross-application by the husband remitted to the Federal Magistrates Court for determination by a Federal Magistrate other than Brewster FM.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the appellant (wife) under s 9 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the respondent (husband) under s 6 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
- Outcome: Publication approved under pseudonym pursuant to s 121(9)(g) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

- Reasons: The Full Court held the wife did not require s 44(3) leave because her property application was included in her Response to the husband’s initiating parenting application, engaging s 44(2) which operates notwithstanding s 44(3).
- Reasons: The Court relied on the breadth of the words "any decree or declaration" and the express "notwithstanding" clause, and applied the Full Court authority in Berta & Berta; the term "answer" was given its ordinary meaning of reply/response.
- Reasons: Given the legal error, the refusal of leave order was set aside and the property dispute was remitted for determination; the Court avoided expressing views on the merits of the property division.
- Reasons: The husband’s cross-appeal on costs failed consequentially once the wife succeeded on appeal.
- Reasons: Costs certificates were granted because the appeal succeeded on a question of law.

- Pivotal Finding: The wife’s property claim was filed as part of a Response to the husband’s parenting application; such a Response constitutes an "answer" for the purposes of s 44(2).
- Pivotal Finding: Section 44(2) permits a respondent, in an answer to an application, to include an application for any decree or declaration under the Act notwithstanding the limitation provisions in s 44(3) and (3A).
- Pivotal Finding: Berta & Berta (1988) FLC 91-916 was applied as binding authority supporting the breadth of s 44(2); the Court extended its reasoning to an answer to a parenting application.
- Pivotal Finding: Because leave was not required, Brewster FM’s dismissal of the s 44(3) leave application was set aside and the substantive property proceedings were remitted for rehearing.
- Pivotal Finding: The Federal Magistrate’s approach of effectively running a s 79 case to determine hardship was identified as misconceiving the distinct nature of s 44(3) applications (although ultimate appeal disposition turned on s 44(2)).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 44(2) (respondent may include application for any decree or declaration notwithstanding s 44(3)/(3A))
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 44(3) and s 44(4) (time limit and hardship threshold for leave)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 (property settlement proceedings remitted; not determined on appeal)
- Statutory Pivot: Acts Interpretation Act 1901 (Cth) s 15AA (purposive interpretation referenced in reasoning)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (publication under pseudonym)
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6 and 9 (costs certificates)

- Uncertainties: No final property settlement outcome was determined; the asset pool, valuation disputes, treatment of the asserted father’s debt, contributions, and any s 75(2) adjustment remain for rehearing.
- Uncertainties: The Full Court did not determine parenting arrangements because those issues had been resolved prior to the hearing.
- Uncertainties: Any findings made by the Federal Magistrate about the substantive property outcome were treated as not determinative and were not endorsed by the Full Court.
