court: Family Court of Australia, Full Court
issues: Appeal against parenting orders granting time and communication between a child and a non-parent with no biological connection
Whether a person without biological connection can obtain parenting orders under Part VII and s 65C(c) as a person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child
Whether the trial judge erred by not considering whether no parenting order should be made
Whether the trial judge erred by using parts of s 60CC that refer to parents, in a case involving a non-parent applicant
facts: The mother (aged 43 at trial) is the child’s biological mother; the child was conceived by artificial insemination using sperm from an unknown donor and born in February 2006.
The mother and the applicant had an intimate same-sex relationship; they lived together for about 10–11 months commencing shortly before the child’s birth and separated in November 2006.

The applicant (aged 61 at trial) was involved in the fertility clinic process from August 2004, including signing consent forms for the mother’s artificial insemination procedures, and was present for the birth and immediate hospital stay.

After separation, time between the child and the applicant reduced progressively: from agreed overnight arrangements to supervised/limited contact, then to monthly contact by early 2008, before interim orders restored regular time.

child_ages: Child B born February 2006; almost 3 years old at the final hearing (2008); about 3 years old at the time of first instance orders (February 2009).
current_arrangements: At first instance: child to live with the mother; mother to have sole parental responsibility.

Time with the applicant: commenced as short weekly periods and increased over about 8 months to each third weekend of the month (10:00am Saturday to 4:00pm Sunday), plus limited special occasions and telephone communication.
caregiver_history: Mother was the child’s primary carer; applicant had substantial involvement around birth and during the cohabitation period (about 10–11 months) and claimed reduced work hours to assist with care during the child’s first 10 months.
Post-separation, the mother progressively reduced the child’s time with the applicant until interim court orders reinstated regular time.
availability: Mother described as a full-time mother at trial; had trained and previously worked in a profession until 2005.
Applicant lived in a warehouse apartment complex with adult children and grandchildren in the same complex; no detailed work availability findings beyond her evidence of reduced work hours earlier.
safety_concerns: Mother raised safety concerns about the applicant’s behaviour and home environment, including an alleged incident of the applicant throwing/smashing a plate in the child’s presence and asserted household hazards (stairs, furniture, sink edges, dog control), and concerns about the applicant’s past mental health (self-cutting, dissociative state; historic psychiatric admission in 1986).
The trial judge treated the plate incident as isolated and was not satisfied that interaction would expose the child to harm at a level constituting psychological harm; time was ordered unsupervised.
child_views: The child was very young; no independent views were reported.
allegations: Applicant sought declaration of parentage under s 69VA and inclusion on the child’s birth certificate, plus equal shared parental responsibility and time orders.
Mother opposed any order for the child to spend time with the applicant and contended no parenting order was necessary as she was the only parent.
expert_evidence: A single expert appointed under Family Law Regulations 1984 (Cth) reg 7 prepared a report dated 10 November 2008 after interviews/observations on 5 November 2008.

Expert observed a warm and significant relationship between the child and the applicant, describing 'attachment' not in a clinical sense but as strength of bond/interaction; recommended gradual increase in time if time orders were made.

Expert mistakenly assumed the parties were in a de facto relationship/that the applicant had parental status; in oral evidence made concessions but said views likely would not change; trial judge gave weight to observations of the child-applicant relationship and some weight to psychiatric-history considerations.
best_interests: Full Court affirmed best interests as paramount consideration (s 60CA) and that no hierarchy of applicants is created by s 65C; after threshold standing, the question is what orders (including possibly none) are in the child’s best interests.

Key best-interests factors relied on at first instance included the child’s warm relationship with the applicant, benefit of additional significant attachments, child’s relationships with applicant’s extended family, and the mother’s concession that exposure to a different style of adult/child interaction could be beneficial, balanced against conflict risks and the applicant’s psychological history.
orders: Full Court did not alter the parenting orders; the appeal against orders providing time/communication and related provisions was dismissed.

incidents: Mother alleged aggressive behaviour by the applicant including an incident of throwing/smashing a plate in the child’s presence; other alleged safety hazards in the applicant’s home; allegation child left alone in bath at six months; concerns about applicant’s dog and home layout.
Applicant’s historical mental health concerns included self-cutting/dissociation and a psychiatric admission in 1986.
child_exposure: Trial judge found the plate incident was isolated and did not find the parties would negatively interact in front of the child to a level causing psychological harm.
safety_plan: Expert referred to a possible 'care and safety plan' but neither party sought such a plan; no plan was ordered.

outcome_orders: Appeal dismissed.

Parties granted liberty to file written submissions on costs of the appeal on a specified timetable (appellant within 21 days; respondent within 21 days thereafter; appellant reply within 7 days thereafter), with service dates endorsed.
Publication under the pseudonym approved pursuant to s 121(9)(g) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

description: The decision confirms that non-parents (including former same-sex partners with no biological connection) can obtain parenting orders if they meet the standing threshold in s 65C(c) and if orders are in the child’s best interests under s 60CA. The Full Court rejected arguments that s 65C creates a hierarchy privileging parental applicants, and endorsed using the s 60CC framework with appropriate qualifications for non-parent cases, relying particularly on the breadth of s 60CC(3)(m). The case also illustrates appellate restraint in discretionary parenting decisions and in challenges to the weight given to expert evidence.
pivotal_findings: The first instance finding that the parties were not in a de facto relationship at the time of conception (thus the applicant was not a parent under s 60H) was not challenged on appeal and set the legal context as a non-parent application for time.
The applicant was found to be a person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child (s 65C(c)), enabling her to seek parenting orders.
The trial judge considered and rejected the mother’s proposal that no order be made for time with the applicant, relying on evidence of a warm relationship and ongoing significance to the child.
Family violence/safety concerns were assessed, with the plate incident treated as isolated and insufficient to justify supervised time or no contact.

Expert evidence: despite the expert’s mistaken assumption about the legal relationship status, the trial judge permissibly relied on observed interaction and relationship quality; the misdescription of the expert as a 'clinical psychologist' was held not to be material.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CA (best interests paramount)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65C(c) (standing for a person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2) and s 60CC(3), especially s 60CC(3)(b) and s 60CC(3)(m) (broad relevant matters)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60B(1)–(2) (objects and principles as guidance, including reference to other significant persons)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60H (artificial conception and 'other intended parent'—discussed in reasons as legislative context)

reasons_rationale: A two-step approach is appropriate for non-parent applicants: (1) standing as a person concerned with the child’s care, welfare or development (s 65C(c)), then (2) what orders (including none) are in the child’s best interests.
Section 65C does not create a hierarchy of applicants; once standing is established, the case is determined under s 60CA with guidance from s 60B and considerations in s 60CC.
The Chief Federal Magistrate did consider and reject the mother’s contention that no orders should be made for the applicant; the reasons showed an evaluative best-interests assessment.

Use of the s 60CC structure was permissible with appropriate qualifications; parent-specific factors were not treated as mandatorily applicable, and relevant matters could be considered through other provisions including s 60CC(3)(m).

Expert-evidence complaints did not reveal appealable error: mistaken assumptions and the 'clinical psychologist' label were not material to the outcome; the judge’s reliance on observed interaction and graduated time recommendations was within discretion.
uncertainties: The Full Court noted potential legislative ambiguity about whether an 'other intended parent' under s 60H is a 'parent' for all Part VII purposes, and observed further legislative amendment may be needed; however that question was not determinative on this appeal because the applicant was found not to satisfy s 60H on the facts.

The Full Court observed that the first instance orders granting the mother sole parental responsibility and the child living with the mother were arguably unnecessary given s 61C, but those orders were not sought to be set aside on appeal.

- Reasons: Expert-evidence complaints did not reveal appealable error: mistaken assumptions and the 'clinical psychologist' label were not material to the outcome; the judge’s reliance on observed interaction and graduated time recommendations was within discretion.

- Pivotal Finding: The first instance finding that the parties were not in a de facto relationship at the time of conception (thus the applicant was not a parent under s 60H) was not challenged on appeal and set the legal context as a non-parent application for time.
- Pivotal Finding: The applicant was found to be a person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child (s 65C(c)), enabling her to seek parenting orders.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge considered and rejected the mother’s proposal that no order be made for time with the applicant, relying on evidence of a warm relationship and ongoing significance to the child.
- Pivotal Finding: Family violence/safety concerns were assessed, with the plate incident treated as isolated and insufficient to justify supervised time or no contact.
- Pivotal Finding: Expert evidence: despite the expert’s mistaken assumption about the legal relationship status, the trial judge permissibly relied on observed interaction and relationship quality; the misdescription of the expert as a 'clinical psychologist' was held not to be material.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CA (best interests paramount)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65C(c) (standing for a person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2) and s 60CC(3), especially s 60CC(3)(b) and s 60CC(3)(m) (broad relevant matters)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60B(1)–(2) (objects and principles as guidance, including reference to other significant persons)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60H (artificial conception and 'other intended parent'—discussed in reasons as legislative context)

- Uncertainties: The Full Court noted potential legislative ambiguity about whether an 'other intended parent' under s 60H is a 'parent' for all Part VII purposes, and observed further legislative amendment may be needed; however that question was not determinative on this appeal because the applicant was found not to satisfy s 60H on the facts.
- Uncertainties: The Full Court observed that the first instance orders granting the mother sole parental responsibility and the child living with the mother were arguably unnecessary given s 61C, but those orders were not sought to be set aside on appeal.

summary_sections.text:
- Fact: The mother (aged 43 at trial) is the child’s biological mother; the child was conceived by artificial insemination using sperm from an unknown donor and born in February 2006.
- Fact: The mother and the applicant had an intimate same-sex relationship; they lived together for about 10–11 months commencing shortly before the child’s birth and separated in November 2006.
- Fact: The applicant (aged 61 at trial) was involved in the fertility clinic process from August 2004, including signing consent forms for the mother’s artificial insemination procedures, and was present for the birth and immediate hospital stay.
- Fact: After separation, time between the child and the applicant reduced progressively: from agreed overnight arrangements to supervised/limited contact, then to monthly contact by early 2008, before interim orders restored regular time.

- Issue: Appeal against parenting orders granting time and communication between a child and a non-parent with no biological connection
- Issue: Whether a person without biological connection can obtain parenting orders under Part VII and s 65C(c) as a person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child
- Issue: Whether the trial judge erred by not considering whether no parenting order should be made
- Issue: Whether the trial judge erred by using parts of s 60CC that refer to parents, in a case involving a non-parent applicant

- Child Ages: Child B born February 2006; almost 3 years old at the final hearing (2008); about 3 years old at the time of first instance orders (February 2009).
- Current Arrangements: At first instance: child to live with the mother; mother to have sole parental responsibility.
- Current Arrangements: Time with the applicant: commenced as short weekly periods and increased over about 8 months to each third weekend of the month (10:00am Saturday to 4:00pm Sunday), plus limited special occasions and telephone communication.
- Safety Concerns: Mother raised safety concerns about the applicant’s behaviour and home environment, including an alleged incident of the applicant throwing/smashing a plate in the child’s presence and asserted household hazards (stairs, furniture, sink edges, dog control), and concerns about the applicant’s past mental health (self-cutting, dissociative state; historic psychiatric admission in 1986).
- Safety Concerns: The trial judge treated the plate incident as isolated and was not satisfied that interaction would expose the child to harm at a level constituting psychological harm; time was ordered unsupervised.
- Best Interests: Full Court affirmed best interests as paramount consideration (s 60CA) and that no hierarchy of applicants is created by s 65C; after threshold standing, the question is what orders (including possibly none) are in the child’s best interests.
- Best Interests: Key best-interests factors relied on at first instance included the child’s warm relationship with the applicant, benefit of additional significant attachments, child’s relationships with applicant’s extended family, and the mother’s concession that exposure to a different style of adult/child interaction could be beneficial, balanced against conflict risks and the applicant’s psychological history.

- Incidents: Mother alleged aggressive behaviour by the applicant including an incident of throwing/smashing a plate in the child’s presence; other alleged safety hazards in the applicant’s home; allegation child left alone in bath at six months; concerns about applicant’s dog and home layout.
- Incidents: Applicant’s historical mental health concerns included self-cutting/dissociation and a psychiatric admission in 1986.

- Outcome: Appeal dismissed.
- Outcome: Parties granted liberty to file written submissions on costs of the appeal on a specified timetable (appellant within 21 days; respondent within 21 days thereafter; appellant reply within 7 days thereafter), with service dates endorsed.
- Outcome: Publication under the pseudonym approved pursuant to s 121(9)(g) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

- Reasons: A two-step approach is appropriate for non-parent applicants: (1) standing as a person concerned with the child’s care, welfare or development (s 65C(c)), then (2) what orders (including none) are in the child’s best interests.
- Reasons: Section 65C does not create a hierarchy of applicants; once standing is established, the case is determined under s 60CA with guidance from s 60B and considerations in s 60CC.
- Reasons: The Chief Federal Magistrate did consider and reject the mother’s contention that no orders should be made for the applicant; the reasons showed an evaluative best-interests assessment.
- Reasons: Use of the s 60CC structure was permissible with appropriate qualifications; parent-specific factors were not treated as mandatorily applicable, and relevant matters could be considered through other provisions including s 60CC(3)(m).
- Reasons: Expert-evidence complaints did not reveal appealable error: mistaken assumptions and the 'clinical psychologist' label were not material to the outcome; the judge’s reliance on observed interaction and graduated time recommendations was within discretion.

- Pivotal Finding: The first instance finding that the parties were not in a de facto relationship at the time of conception (thus the applicant was not a parent under s 60H) was not challenged on appeal and set the legal context as a non-parent application for time.
- Pivotal Finding: The applicant was found to be a person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child (s 65C(c)), enabling her to seek parenting orders.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge considered and rejected the mother’s proposal that no order be made for time with the applicant, relying on evidence of a warm relationship and ongoing significance to the child.
- Pivotal Finding: Family violence/safety concerns were assessed, with the plate incident treated as isolated and insufficient to justify supervised time or no contact.
- Pivotal Finding: Expert evidence: despite the expert’s mistaken assumption about the legal relationship status, the trial judge permissibly relied on observed interaction and relationship quality; the misdescription of the expert as a 'clinical psychologist' was held not to be material.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CA (best interests paramount)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65C(c) (standing for a person concerned with the care, welfare or development of the child)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2) and s 60CC(3), especially s 60CC(3)(b) and s 60CC(3)(m) (broad relevant matters)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60B(1)–(2) (objects and principles as guidance, including reference to other significant persons)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60H (artificial conception and 'other intended parent'—discussed in reasons as legislative context)

- Uncertainties: The Full Court noted potential legislative ambiguity about whether an 'other intended parent' under s 60H is a 'parent' for all Part VII purposes, and observed further legislative amendment may be needed; however that question was not determinative on this appeal because the applicant was found not to satisfy s 60H on the facts.
- Uncertainties: The Full Court observed that the first instance orders granting the mother sole parental responsibility and the child living with the mother were arguably unnecessary given s 61C, but those orders were not sought to be set aside on appeal.

court: Family Court of Australia, Full Court (single judge appeal jurisdiction) at Parramatta
issues: Leave to appeal from interlocutory (interim) spousal maintenance orders
Whether the Federal Magistrate made material factual errors affecting discretion
Whether the Federal Magistrate erred in law in assessing the wife's capacity to support herself
Whether the Federal Magistrate erred in assessing the husband's capacity to pay (including payment from capital/borrowings secured against property)
facts: The parties married in March 1979 and separated in August 2008.
There are two children of the marriage, both adults at the time of the interim hearing (aged 18 and 19 years).
The wife lived in rented premises with the two adult children; the husband remained in the former matrimonial home.
The wife had not been in employment for 26 years.

asset_pool: Three real properties referred to in the appeal reasons, including: the former matrimonial home occupied by the husband; a property at "F" (jointly owned, with rental held in an agent/trust account); a property at "R" (owned solely by the husband, with substantial equity, and treated as within his unfettered control).
Rental income streams from the "F" and "R" properties (amounts not fully quantified in the appeal reasons, except that the rental directed to wife totalled $465 per week).
A bank account issue: a balance of $1,749 at hearing was accepted on tendered statement; husband asserted the wife earlier swore to $10,192.
contributions: No final findings on property contributions; matter was interlocutory focused on interim maintenance.
Background noted that the business was previously jointly operated by both parties, and the husband continued to operate it post-separation.
Wife had not worked for 26 years (implicitly reflecting homemaker/other non-income contributions, but not quantified or determined).
future_needs: Wife found unable to support herself adequately on an interim basis and lacking capacity for appropriate gainful employment (as found by the Federal Magistrate and not displaced on appeal).
Husband’s claimed cashflow left limited surplus if his asserted income and non-discretionary expenses were accepted; however, husband had access to equity/capital resources through property.
just_equitable: No just and equitable final property division undertaken; the appeal concerned interim maintenance and whether interim payments could be sourced from capital/borrowings.
The appeal reasons emphasise interim orders do not finally determine Part VIII property entitlements and can be revisited at final hearing.
living_arrangements: Husband occupied the former matrimonial home.
Wife rented accommodation and lived with the two adult children.

need: The wife was found (interim) to be unable to support herself adequately and to satisfy the statutory threshold for spousal maintenance (described as s 72B in the reasons).
The Federal Magistrate accepted the wife reasonably required $1,034 per week but ordered $905 per week as reasonable and appropriate in the circumstances.

The Federal Magistrate excluded or reduced certain claimed expenses as discretionary and apportioned many expenses to reflect the presence of adult children, but did not apportion rent due to lack of evidence of cheaper premises or children's capacity to contribute.
capacity_to_pay: On the husband’s own financial statement, after excluding discretionary items, only about $70 per week remained from asserted weekly income.
The Federal Magistrate accepted an averaging approach to income (including prior years where income had been split between the parties) and noted increased tax if income was no longer split.

Despite difficulty finding capacity from income alone, the Federal Magistrate found the husband had capacity through property resources and control of assets, including the ability to borrow secured over property or sell assets if necessary.
The appeal court held the capacity to meet interim maintenance is not confined to periodic income and may be met from capital or borrowings against capital assets.
statutory_factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) spousal maintenance threshold referred to as s 72B in the reasons (wife unable to support herself adequately).
Interim nature of the proceedings and discretionary character of the order (appellate restraint; error of principle/substantial injustice framework).
income_expenses: Husband’s asserted income and expenses were assessed; excluding discretionary personal expenditure left an asserted surplus of approximately $70 per week.
Wife’s claimed weekly needs were assessed; after adjustments, the court accepted a higher need figure than claimed ($1,034 accepted; $905 ordered).
Wife received $465 per week in rental income directed from properties, with husband to pay the balance to total $905 per week.
earning_capacity: Wife: found to have no capacity for appropriate gainful employment on an interim basis (reasons stated by Federal Magistrate; not detailed in appeal reasons).
Husband: self-employed; income difficult to ascertain; some doubt about accuracy of asserted position, not testable on interim evidence.
relationship_length: Marriage from March 1979 to separation in August 2008 (approximately 29 years).
standard_of_living: Interim maintenance set to provide the wife with a reasonable standard of living in all the circumstances; $905 per week described as reasonable.
The Federal Magistrate noted the importance of the wife having sufficient funds to live in the meantime pending final financial proceedings.

child_ages: Two adult children aged 18 and 19 years at the time of the interim proceedings.
current_arrangements: Adult children lived with the wife in rental premises.

outcome_orders: Husband’s application for leave to appeal filed 22 December 2008 dismissed.
Husband ordered to pay the wife’s costs of and incidental to the application in the sum of $4,000.
Husband given 60 days to pay the wife’s costs.
Interim spousal maintenance orders made by the Federal Magistrate on 17 December 2008 (including $905 per week and direction of rental income) remained in effect.

description: This appeal illustrates the appellate restraint applied to discretionary interim spousal maintenance decisions, particularly where evidence is untested and the first instance judge adopts a pragmatic approach to capacity. A key legal significance is confirmation that a payer’s "capacity" for interim maintenance is not limited to periodic income and can include the ability to borrow against or realise capital assets, especially where one party has control of substantial equity and the applicant otherwise lacks access to income streams. Minor factual misstatements will not justify intervention unless material to the exercise of discretion or productive of injustice.
pivotal_findings: The proceeding was interlocutory and determined on documents without cross-examination, limiting the ability to resolve contested financial accuracy.
The wife was found unable to support herself adequately and to meet the statutory threshold for spousal maintenance on an interim basis.
There was doubt about the husband’s true financial position, but that doubt could not be resolved at interim stage.

Even if the husband’s income position made payment difficult, the husband had effective control over at least one substantial equity asset (the "R" property) such that he could borrow or sell to meet interim obligations.
The Federal Magistrate’s refusal to apportion rent was open because there was no evidence of cheaper accommodation or the adult children’s capacity to contribute.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 72B (as referenced in the reasons) regarding inability to support oneself adequately as the threshold for spousal maintenance.
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) Part VIII (not applied to determine property entitlements at interim stage; noted that final implications remain to be determined).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (pseudonymation/publication approval noted).

Appellate principles for leave to appeal and discretionary error: Adam P Brown Male Fashions Pty Ltd v Philip Morris Inc (1981) 148 CLR 170; Rutherford and Rutherford (1991) FLC 92-255; De Winter & De Winter (1979) FLC 90-605.

reasons_rationale: The court held no proposed ground of appeal had merit and that minor factual errors did not vitiate the discretion exercised.
The husband did not establish error of principle or that the Federal Magistrate failed at law to assess either party’s capacity relevantly.
The court accepted that an interim maintenance order may be met from capital or borrowings against capital assets; capacity is not confined to income.
The complaint that the order was manifestly excessive failed because the Federal Magistrate relied on capital resources and rental direction, not merely periodic income.
On rent apportionment, the absence of evidence about cheaper premises or the adult children’s ability to contribute meant the Federal Magistrate’s approach was open.
uncertainties: The reasons do not set out a complete balance sheet valuation of the asset pool; only general references to properties, equity, and rental income are provided.
Wife’s incapacity reasons are not detailed in the appeal reasons beyond the conclusion of no capacity for appropriate gainful employment.
The husband’s true income and financial position were expressly not determined due to untested evidence.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from property adjustment orders under s 79: whether errors in the asset/liability schedule and agreed values vitiated the exercise of discretion
Whether the trial judge failed to determine an identified disputed item: losses/negative value of the H Trust (discretionary trust controlled by husband)
Whether losses from the wife’s restaurant business should be added back or attributed solely to the wife on Kowaliw principles
facts: The parties cohabited for about 10 years 9 months (described as about 11 years), married March 1998, separated December 2005, divorced April 2007.
There were no children of the marriage; the wife had children from prior relationships and her youngest lived with the parties during the marriage.
At trial, Carmody J adjusted property interests and ordered lump sum spousal maintenance; the husband appealed.

asset_pool: Primary judge treated net pool as $4,638,597 including superannuation; Full Court noted agreed corrections produce about $4,188,183 (difference about $450,414).

Pool errors included: furniture addition error; incorrect inclusion of goodwill in professional practice trust figure; incorrect B family trust value; superannuation figure error; incorrect partial property settlement add-back amount; incorrect retained earnings tax figure.

Disputed inclusions/exclusions included: increase in husband’s Suncorp borrowings post-separation; treatment of negative value/losses in H Trust arising from post-separation transactions; treatment of restaurant losses.
contributions: Primary judge found the husband owned more than 90% of initial property and that this represented nearly 35% of current net value of the non-superannuation pool.

Husband’s initial contributions included the matrimonial home (valued about $300,000-$330,000 in 1995; agreed $1,350,000 at trial), a 50% interest in a second Gold Coast property bought in 1994, and other chattels.

Wife’s initial position included ownership of a Gold Coast property sold in 1997 (net proceeds partly used to fund her half share of the M apartment), and she had debts/claims including tax debt later forgiven on hardship grounds and a liquidator’s claim.
future_needs: Primary judge made a 7.5% adjustment for s 75(2) factors in the wife’s favour, referring to age (mid-50s), wife’s health issues and limited physical/psychological capacity for gainful employment, limited employability at 57, and disparity in financial positions.
Husband proposed retirement within 2 years and had stress/hypertension issues noted by the primary judge.
Full Court considered the s 75(2) assessment could not be realistically assessed in isolation from correct pool size and correct contribution findings.
just_equitable: Primary judge stated he needed to be satisfied orders were just and equitable in real money terms, but Full Court found the discretion was vitiated due to significant pool errors and flawed contribution evaluation.
Full Court noted that a 10% overvaluation of the pool may have affected the s 75(2) adjustment and overall outcome, and could not be treated as de minimis.
living_arrangements: Wife remained in occupation of the matrimonial home after separation.
H Trust held a third Gold Coast property acquired post-separation as the husband’s residence (as described in the materials).
existing_agreements: No binding financial agreement was described.
Some asset values and add-backs were agreed at trial but were incorrectly recorded in the judgment schedule.

need: Wife sought spousal maintenance of $500 per week for 12 months (plus other claimed support relating to home expenses and restaurant/lease expenses).
Primary judge referred to wife’s financial statement estimating expenditure of $725 per week (without restaurant assistance) and noted wife’s part-time income and restaurant operation.
capacity_to_pay: Primary judge found husband had no capacity to pay from income due to unchallenged partnership losses, but had some capacity based on his assessed share of assets.
Full Court held the reasons did not properly disclose consideration of wife's property entitlement when assessing maintenance and did not explain quantification of the $40,000 lump sum.
statutory_factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 74 (maintenance power)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (factors), s 75(3) (disregard income-tested pensions/benefits)

Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 80 (maintenance orders), s 83 and s 83(2) (variation), and the need to consider s 79 property outcomes in maintenance assessment (Clauson & Clauson; Bevan; Pastrikos; Anast; Little).
income_expenses: Wife’s stated expenditure about $725 per week (excluding restaurant assistance) was referenced by the primary judge.
Primary judge took into account that a boarder in the home should contribute to utility costs.
Husband’s income position was said to be affected by partnership losses; cash flow deterioration described as possibly temporary.
earning_capacity: Husband had substantial earning capacity from professional practice (historical taxable income figures noted).
Primary judge found wife had limited physical and psychological capacity for gainful employment and limited employability given age and health.
health_care: Primary judge noted wife’s health problems (not disputed) affecting capacity for employment.
Primary judge noted husband’s stress and hypertension.
relationship_length: Cohabitation/marriage totalled about 11 years (described as 10 years 9 months, 'say eleven years').
standard_of_living: No detailed standard of living findings were specified beyond references to improved lifestyle during the relationship and assessment of weekly expenses.

outcome_orders: Appeal allowed.
Matter remitted for hearing by a Judge in the Brisbane Registry.
Either party may apply for costs of the appeal by written submissions within 21 days; other party to respond within 14 days; reply within 7 days.
Publication under the pseudonym approved pursuant to s 121(9)(g) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

description: The Full Court identified appealable error in the primary judge’s property discretion due to significant misstatement of the asset pool and failure to determine a clearly identified disputed trust loss issue, together with an inadequately reasoned and improperly weighted contribution assessment. It also found error of principle in the lump sum spousal maintenance award because the primary judge did not demonstrate consideration of the wife’s property entitlement when assessing maintenance need and quantification. Despite both parties seeking re-exercise, the Full Court held that the absence of necessary findings and post-trial developments prevented it from safely re-exercising the discretion, requiring remittal for rehearing.
pivotal_findings: The asset/liability schedule contained non-trivial agreed errors; corrected pool (including superannuation) was about $4,188,183 rather than $4,638,597, a difference of about $450,414 (about 10%), vitiating the discretionary exercise.
The trial judge identified H Trust losses as an issue but failed to deal with whether the trust’s negative value/losses should be included in the pool; this omission was appealable error.

No appealable error was shown in the trial judge’s treatment of restaurant losses under Kowaliw: wife’s operation of the business did not fall within the exceptions (deliberate diminution or reckless/negligent/wanton conduct).

The contribution assessment was 'plainly wrong' because the primary judge failed to properly evaluate and weigh the husband’s substantial initial and ongoing financial contributions (including pre-existing practice and key properties) and relied too heavily on broad fairness/partnership notions; the reasoning involved too great a leap from qualitative findings to a 25% contribution outcome for the wife.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79, including s 79(2) (just and equitable) and s 79(4) (contributions factors)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs adjustment) and s 75(3)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 74, s 80, s 83 and s 83(2) (spousal maintenance framework)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 94(2) (Full Court powers on appeal, re-exercise vs remittal)

reasons_rationale: Pool errors were significant (about $450,414) and not de minimis; the Full Court could not assume the same contribution and s 75(2) outcomes would have been reached on a correctly stated pool.
Failure to determine the H Trust loss issue (after identifying it) was an omission of a material issue requiring determination and constituted appealable error.

Restaurant losses: the trial judge was entitled to find the wife’s conduct was commercial ineptness rather than deliberate or reckless dissipation under Kowaliw exceptions; therefore sharing losses was within discretion.

Contribution assessment: the primary judge did not make sufficient evaluative findings about the husband’s contributions and did not properly weigh the husband’s initial and ongoing contributions; the approach reflected a misunderstanding of precedent and an excessive leap from narrative to percentage outcome.
uncertainties: Final property division percentages and dollar outcomes will be re-determined on rehearing; Full Court did not re-exercise discretion.
Whether H Trust negative value/losses should be included in the asset pool was not determined and requires findings (including disclosure and reasonableness of post-separation transactions).
Treatment of the husband’s post-separation Suncorp borrowings and any add-backs/dissection was not finally determined.

summary_text:
- Fact: The parties cohabited for about 10 years 9 months (described as about 11 years), married March 1998, separated December 2005, divorced April 2007.
- Fact: There were no children of the marriage; the wife had children from prior relationships and her youngest lived with the parties during the marriage.
- Fact: At trial, Carmody J adjusted property interests and ordered lump sum spousal maintenance; the husband appealed.

- Issue: Appeal from property adjustment orders under s 79: whether errors in the asset/liability schedule and agreed values vitiated the exercise of discretion
- Issue: Whether the trial judge failed to determine an identified disputed item: losses/negative value of the H Trust (discretionary trust controlled by husband)
- Issue: Whether losses from the wife’s restaurant business should be added back or attributed solely to the wife on Kowaliw principles

- Asset Pool: Primary judge treated net pool as $4,638,597 including superannuation; Full Court noted agreed corrections produce about $4,188,183 (difference about $450,414).
- Asset Pool: Pool errors included: furniture addition error; incorrect inclusion of goodwill in professional practice trust figure; incorrect B family trust value; superannuation figure error; incorrect partial property settlement add-back amount; incorrect retained earnings tax figure.
- Asset Pool: Disputed inclusions/exclusions included: increase in husband’s Suncorp borrowings post-separation; treatment of negative value/losses in H Trust arising from post-separation transactions; treatment of restaurant losses.
- Contributions: Primary judge found the husband owned more than 90% of initial property and that this represented nearly 35% of current net value of the non-superannuation pool.
- Contributions: Husband’s initial contributions included the matrimonial home (valued about $300,000-$330,000 in 1995; agreed $1,350,000 at trial), a 50% interest in a second Gold Coast property bought in 1994, and other chattels.
- Contributions: Wife’s initial position included ownership of a Gold Coast property sold in 1997 (net proceeds partly used to fund her half share of the M apartment), and she had debts/claims including tax debt later forgiven on hardship grounds and a liquidator’s claim.
- Future Needs: Primary judge made a 7.5% adjustment for s 75(2) factors in the wife’s favour, referring to age (mid-50s), wife’s health issues and limited physical/psychological capacity for gainful employment, limited employability at 57, and disparity in financial positions.
- Future Needs: Husband proposed retirement within 2 years and had stress/hypertension issues noted by the primary judge.
- Future Needs: Full Court considered the s 75(2) assessment could not be realistically assessed in isolation from correct pool size and correct contribution findings.
- Just & Equitable: Primary judge stated he needed to be satisfied orders were just and equitable in real money terms, but Full Court found the discretion was vitiated due to significant pool errors and flawed contribution evaluation.
- Just & Equitable: Full Court noted that a 10% overvaluation of the pool may have affected the s 75(2) adjustment and overall outcome, and could not be treated as de minimis.

- Need: Wife sought spousal maintenance of $500 per week for 12 months (plus other claimed support relating to home expenses and restaurant/lease expenses).
- Need: Primary judge referred to wife’s financial statement estimating expenditure of $725 per week (without restaurant assistance) and noted wife’s part-time income and restaurant operation.
- Capacity to Pay: Primary judge found husband had no capacity to pay from income due to unchallenged partnership losses, but had some capacity based on his assessed share of assets.
- Capacity to Pay: Full Court held the reasons did not properly disclose consideration of wife's property entitlement when assessing maintenance and did not explain quantification of the $40,000 lump sum.
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 74 (maintenance power)
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (factors), s 75(3) (disregard income-tested pensions/benefits)
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 80 (maintenance orders), s 83 and s 83(2) (variation), and the need to consider s 79 property outcomes in maintenance assessment (Clauson & Clauson; Bevan; Pastrikos; Anast; Little).

- Outcome: Appeal allowed.
- Outcome: Matter remitted for hearing by a Judge in the Brisbane Registry.
- Outcome: Either party may apply for costs of the appeal by written submissions within 21 days; other party to respond within 14 days; reply within 7 days.
- Outcome: Publication under the pseudonym approved pursuant to s 121(9)(g) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

- Reasons: Pool errors were significant (about $450,414) and not de minimis; the Full Court could not assume the same contribution and s 75(2) outcomes would have been reached on a correctly stated pool.
- Reasons: Failure to determine the H Trust loss issue (after identifying it) was an omission of a material issue requiring determination and constituted appealable error.
- Reasons: Restaurant losses: the trial judge was entitled to find the wife’s conduct was commercial ineptness rather than deliberate or reckless dissipation under Kowaliw exceptions; therefore sharing losses was within discretion.
- Reasons: Contribution assessment: the primary judge did not make sufficient evaluative findings about the husband’s contributions and did not properly weigh the husband’s initial and ongoing contributions; the approach reflected a misunderstanding of precedent and an excessive leap from narrative to percentage outcome.

- Pivotal Finding: The asset/liability schedule contained non-trivial agreed errors; corrected pool (including superannuation) was about $4,188,183 rather than $4,638,597, a difference of about $450,414 (about 10%), vitiating the discretionary exercise.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge identified H Trust losses as an issue but failed to deal with whether the trust’s negative value/losses should be included in the pool; this omission was appealable error.
- Pivotal Finding: No appealable error was shown in the trial judge’s treatment of restaurant losses under Kowaliw: wife’s operation of the business did not fall within the exceptions (deliberate diminution or reckless/negligent/wanton conduct).
- Pivotal Finding: The contribution assessment was 'plainly wrong' because the primary judge failed to properly evaluate and weigh the husband’s substantial initial and ongoing financial contributions (including pre-existing practice and key properties) and relied too heavily on broad fairness/partnership notions; the reasoning involved too great a leap from qualitative findings to a 25% contribution outcome for the wife.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79, including s 79(2) (just and equitable) and s 79(4) (contributions factors)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs adjustment) and s 75(3)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 74, s 80, s 83 and s 83(2) (spousal maintenance framework)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 94(2) (Full Court powers on appeal, re-exercise vs remittal)

- Uncertainties: Final property division percentages and dollar outcomes will be re-determined on rehearing; Full Court did not re-exercise discretion.
- Uncertainties: Whether H Trust negative value/losses should be included in the asset pool was not determined and requires findings (including disclosure and reasonableness of post-separation transactions).
- Uncertainties: Treatment of the husband’s post-separation Suncorp borrowings and any add-backs/dissection was not finally determined.

court: Family Court of Australia (Full Court)
issues: Parenting orders involving international relocation (child living in Dubai; father sought return to Brisbane)
Whether the Federal Magistrate properly applied s 65DAA (equal time / substantial and significant time; reasonable practicability)
Whether the Federal Magistrate properly considered the primary consideration of a meaningful relationship (s 60CC(2)(a))
Whether findings about impact on mother’s parenting and child’s routines were supported by evidence
Whether finding that father would not support child’s relationship with mother (if child lived in Brisbane) was supported by evidence
facts: The parties had an 18-month relationship and never married.
They are parents of a boy, G, aged 4 years at the appeal; he was born in Australia.
In October 2005 the mother left Australia with G (then about 6 months old) to Dubai for a planned December 2005 wedding; the relationship ended and the wedding did not occur.
The mother remained living in Dubai with G (with a period of about six months in Sri Lanka, then back to Dubai).
The United Arab Emirates is not a party to the Hague Convention on International Child Abduction.

child_ages: G was 4 years old at the appeal (born during parties' relationship).
G was about 2 years and 6 months at the first instance trial (October 2007 hearing).
G was about 6 months old when he left Australia with the mother (October 2005).
current_arrangements: At trial and appeal, G lived with the mother in Dubai.
Mother worked in Dubai; child was cared for by a carer during work hours.
Father spent limited time with G via periodic travel to Dubai; no overnight time had occurred since separation at the time of first instance reasons.
caregiver_history: After birth in Brisbane, the paternal grandmother assisted the mother for a period.
Father assisted with child care outside work hours before October 2005.
Following October 2005, mother became the primary carer in Dubai; father’s involvement was through infrequent visits.
availability: Father had tenured employment and gave evidence about limits on annual leave and cost affecting ability to travel to Dubai multiple times per year.
Father proposed funding and practical support to facilitate mother’s re-establishment in Brisbane.
Mother had employment and visa status in Dubai and wished to remain there.
safety_concerns: First instance court recorded neither party alleged ongoing intimidation, harassment or violence.
No unacceptable risk of abuse, neglect or domestic violence was asserted as a determinative issue.
allegations: Father alleged mother impeded the relationship and return proceedings, including leaving Sri Lanka (a Hague Convention country) during Hague proceedings and returning to Dubai (non-Convention country).
Mother disputed father’s characterisation and asserted she would return to Australia if the child were ordered to do so.
expert_evidence: No Family Consultant report, single expert report, or Independent Children’s Lawyer was involved at first instance.

Full Court expressed the view that international relocation cases warrant serious consideration of appointing a single expert and/or an Independent Children’s Lawyer, especially where the child is very young.
best_interests: Full Court held the Federal Magistrate did not adequately consider and weigh how the child could develop and maintain a meaningful relationship with the father on the Dubai proposal.
Full Court preferred a 'prospective approach' to s 60CC(2)(a): consider how orders can be framed to ensure, if in best interests, the child has a meaningful relationship with both parents.

Full Court found inadequate consideration of s 65DAA requirements (equal time / substantial and significant time and reasonable practicability) in weighing the competing proposals and practical consequences.
orders: Appeal allowed; first instance parenting orders set aside (subject to a stay delaying the setting aside until re-listing).
Matter remitted for rehearing at first instance before a different judicial officer.
Full Court declined to re-exercise discretion due to insufficient findings and elapsed time since trial; also noted lack of expert evidence and issues about enforceability in Dubai.

outcome_orders: The appeal be allowed.
Subject to the stay, the orders made by Federal Magistrate Slack on 21 December 2007 be set aside.
The matter be remitted for rehearing at first instance other than before Federal Magistrate Slack.
Costs certificate granted to the appellant father pursuant to s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of the costs of the appeal.
Costs certificate granted to the respondent mother pursuant to s 6 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of the costs of the appeal.
Costs certificates granted to each party pursuant to s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of the costs of the new trial ordered.

description: The Full Court treated the matter as an international relocation parenting appeal requiring strict compliance with the shared parental responsibility framework. It clarified that, once equal shared parental responsibility is ordered, the court must actively and realistically consider (and weigh) equal time and, if not, substantial and significant time, including reasonable practicability, as part of evaluating relocation proposals. It also endorsed a 'prospective approach' to 'meaningful relationship' under s 60CC(2)(a), requiring analysis of how orders can facilitate the child developing a meaningful relationship with both parents (not merely describing the present state of attachment). The appeal succeeded because the first instance reasons did not demonstrate proper weighing of these statutory imperatives or key practicalities (travel limits, financial support for return, and feasibility of either parent relocating). The matter was remitted rather than re-determined due to inadequate findings, the passage of time, and the absence of expert/ICL assistance in a case with significant long-term consequences and enforcement issues in a non-Hague jurisdiction.
pivotal_findings: The Federal Magistrate failed to properly consider and record conclusions on equal time or substantial and significant time (and to weigh these against relocation advantages/disadvantages) after ordering equal shared parental responsibility.

The Federal Magistrate did not adequately address how the child could develop a meaningful relationship with the father if the child lived in Dubai and the father remained in Australia, including the benefit to the child of the opportunity to form that relationship.

Insufficient attention was given to reasonable practicability, including the father’s limits on travel (leave and cost) and the father’s proposed financial assistance to facilitate the mother returning to Brisbane.
Findings about the mother’s parenting being adversely impacted by living in Brisbane, and that changes to routine would have an implied adverse impact, were not adequately supported by evidence.
The finding that the father would not support the child’s relationship with the mother if the child lived in Brisbane and the mother remained in Dubai lacked a clear evidentiary basis.
Further evidence sought to be adduced did not meet the threshold that it would likely have produced a different result at trial; application refused.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CA (best interests paramount)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60B (objects and principles, including meaningful involvement)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2)(a) and s 60CC(3) (best interests considerations; meaningful relationship)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 61DA (presumption of equal shared parental responsibility)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65DAA, including s 65DAA(5) (mandatory consideration of equal time / substantial and significant time and reasonable practicability)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 69ZX(1)(d) and s 69ZX(3) (court’s powers in child-related proceedings; relevant to expert/other evidence discussion)

reasons_rationale: The first instance reasons did not demonstrate that the statutory pathway in s 65DAA was properly applied after an order for equal shared parental responsibility, including the necessary weighing of equal time or substantial and significant time options and reasonable practicability.

The Federal Magistrate did not adequately consider the child’s benefit in developing a meaningful relationship with the father, particularly given the child’s young age and limited past time with the father, and did not show how the Dubai-based orders would foster that relationship.

Key practical constraints were not properly addressed, including the father’s capacity to travel to Dubai four times a year and the father’s proposed financial assistance to facilitate the mother’s re-establishment in Brisbane.

Certain adverse findings (mother’s parenting capacity if in Brisbane; impact of routine change; father not supporting mother-child relationship if child in Brisbane) were not sufficiently supported by evidence and contributed to appealable error.
Given inadequate findings, lack of expert assistance, enforcement concerns in Dubai, and the passage of time, remittal for rehearing was required rather than the Full Court re-exercising discretion.
Applications to adduce further evidence were refused because the evidence would not have produced a different result at trial and was not relevant to a re-exercise of discretion on appeal.
uncertainties: The Full Court noted a lack of evidence about enforceability of parenting orders in Dubai (a non-Hague Convention jurisdiction).

No expert evidence or Independent Children’s Lawyer was involved at first instance; the Full Court indicated such evidence/assistance may be important in international relocation cases involving a very young child.
Because the matter was remitted, final parenting arrangements were not determined by the Full Court and were left for rehearing (including any interim arrangements on re-listing).

- Fact: The parties had an 18-month relationship and never married.

- Child Ages: G was 4 years old at the appeal (born during parties' relationship).

- Outcome: The appeal be allowed.
- Outcome: Subject to the stay, the orders made by Federal Magistrate Slack on 21 December 2007 be set aside.
