court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal against property settlement orders: whether the trial judge erred by failing to include the husband's interest in the Pittman Family Trust (PFT) in the s 79 property pool
Whether the husband's trust interests (income and capital) were 'property' under s 4/s 79 or merely a financial resource under s 75(2) or an expectancy
Whether the contribution findings and s 75(2) adjustment were affected by the erroneous property pool
Cross-appeal: whether the trial judge erred in assessing contributions and the size of the s 75(2) adjustment
facts: The parties married in mid 1982 and lived abroad (mainly USA) until late 1992.
They had one child (a daughter) born in late 1989; after birth the wife was primarily engaged in the child's care while the husband worked.
From late 1992 the family lived in Perth; the husband worked in his family business (the Pittman Group) and also received trust distributions; the wife cared for the child and maintained the home.
In April 2001 the wife and child moved to the USA; the husband did not join them; separation was treated as April 2002.

asset_pool: Trial judge identified non-trust net assets of $8,638,079 as 'Asset Pool A'.
Trial judge listed the PFT separately as 'Asset Pool B' and attributed to the husband an estimated value of $62,750,000 (25% of KPMG valuation of $251 million as at 30 June 2007).
KPMG valuation referred to the trust as having $110,612,816 in cash management accounts (as per the report referenced by the trial judge).

On appeal, the Full Court held the husband's interest in the PFT (income and capital entitlements) should have been included as property available for division; the matter was remitted for rehearing so no final recalculated pool was determined by the Full Court.
contributions: Trial judge found contributions while living in the USA (early marriage period) were equal.
Trial judge found overall contributions in Australia prior to separation were equal.

Trial judge found post-separation (about six years) the husband's financial contributions outweighed the wife's; during that time the pool increased by about $6 million and the husband received distributions of over $10 million in total.
Trial judge assessed contributions to date of trial as 60% in the husband's favour (for the non-trust pool).
future_needs: Trial judge made a significant adjustment in favour of the wife due to her age, health problems, lack of employment prospects, and reasonable standard of living in the circumstances of the family.
Trial judge took into account the husband's ongoing secure financial future (including trust income stream).
Trial judge applied an adjustment of 40% in favour of the wife under s 75(2), resulting in 80/20 of the non-trust pool.
Full Court held future needs under s 75(2) would need to be reassessed in light of inclusion of the PFT as property.
just_equitable: Trial judge concluded justice and equity could be met through presently available (non-trust) assets and refused an adjournment under s 79(5); she cross-checked that the wife would receive about 11% of the combined present value of both pools (non-trust pool plus the $62.75m trust interest as she scheduled it).

Full Court held the trial judge erred by excluding the PFT interest from the divisible property pool; because the pool was erroneous, the contribution and s 75(2) assessments could not stand and required rehearing.
living_arrangements: After separation the wife and child lived in the United States; the wife was the sole carer from 2002.
The husband remained in Australia and relied on trust income; child had no contact with him since mid 2003.
The trial judge considered (erroneously) a separate post-trial phase linked to the child starting university/college; the Full Court noted contributions are usually assessed to trial.

need: At first instance the wife sought spousal maintenance of $2,000 per week (and also adult child maintenance).
Trial judge made a spousal maintenance order (Order 5), but on appeal no ground or submissions were directed to that order.
capacity_to_pay: Trial judge found the husband relied on trust income post-separation and had a secure income stream at least short to medium term (relevant to capacity, though not addressed substantively on appeal).
statutory_factors: s 75(2) matters were considered at first instance for property adjustment; the appellate decision did not make substantive maintenance findings.
income_expenses: Trial judge found the wife had not earned income since at least early 2006 and was totally dependent on the husband for living expenses.
Trial judge found the husband relied on trust distributions for income post-separation.
earning_capacity: Trial judge referred to the wife's lack of employment prospects.
health_care: Trial judge referred to the wife's health problems (details not specified in the provided text).
relationship_length: Marriage commenced mid 1982; parties lived together about 20 years before separation (separation treated as April 2002).
standard_of_living: Trial judge considered the standard of living reasonable for the wife in the circumstances of this family as part of s 75(2) assessment.

child_ages: One child (daughter) born in late 1989.
current_arrangements: From 2002 the child lived with the wife in the United States; the husband had no contact since mid 2003 but paid child support.
At around the time of trial the child was commencing university and moving to live in college (as referred to in the trial judge's reasons).
caregiver_history: Wife was primary caregiver after the child's birth and was sole carer post-separation.

outcome_orders: Appeal allowed.
Cross-appeal allowed.
Orders 2 and 5 made by Crisford J on 16 October 2008 set aside.
Applications heard 21-25 and 28 July 2008 remitted for rehearing by a judge other than Crisford J.

description: This Full Court decision turns on classification of trust entitlements in property settlement. The Court held that where amendments to a family trust create fixed/irrevocable entitlements to income and to a share of capital, that interest can constitute 'property' for s 79 purposes (not merely a financial resource). Excluding such an interest from the pool was a central error, especially given the disparity between the trust interest (tens of millions) and the non-trust pool (about $8.6m). Because the trial judge’s contributions and s 75(2) adjustment were undertaken against an erroneous pool, the Full Court considered it inappropriate to simply apply the existing percentages to the enlarged pool; a full rehearing was required.
pivotal_findings: The husband had irrevocable entitlement to trust income and had been irrevocably appointed (with his mother and two brothers) to the trust capital on vesting day, giving him a present entitlement in reversion within the meaning of s 4.
The vesting day was tied to the death of the first to die of the husband or either of two brothers (making vesting contingent but not rendering the entitlement a mere expectancy).
Any uncertainty about ultimate value (e.g., possible dilution by adding beneficiaries) did not prevent categorisation as property; it went to value, not character.
Lack of control over the trust by the husband did not negate the existence of his entitlement and therefore did not prevent the interest being property.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4 (definition of 'property' including entitlement in possession or reversion)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 (alteration of property interests; requirement to identify property pool and make just and equitable orders)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) (assessment of contributions, including s 79(4)(a)-(c))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors relevant to adjustment)

reasons_rationale: The trial judge did not definitively determine whether the husband's PFT interest was property; the Full Court considered the issue needed to be answered because of the magnitude of the trust interest relative to other assets.
The Full Court found the trust amendments created irrevocable entitlements to income and to a share of capital, making the interest 'property' capable of division.
Uncertainty in ultimate value or potential dilution of the share was insufficient to deny categorisation as property.
The husband’s lack of unfettered control over trust assets did not affect the existence of his entitlement.
uncertainties: The Full Court did not determine a new asset pool value including the PFT interest, nor any final percentage split, because the matter was remitted for rehearing.
The precise content of Orders 1, 3 and 4 at first instance was not set out in the provided text; they were not disturbed on appeal.
The appellate reasons note it was unclear whether KPMG valued the husband's interest specifically or the trust as a whole, but no valuation challenge was pursued.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from property settlement orders made in the Family Court of Western Australia
Whether the trial judge's s 75(2) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) adjustment gave sufficient weight to the proportion of time children lived with the father
Whether a 10% s 75(2) adjustment in favour of the wife was outside the reasonable exercise of discretion
Challenges to findings concerning the husband's resignation from employment and his earning capacity (ultimately not determinative of the s 75(2) adjustment)
facts: The parties married in 1986 and separated in early 2005 (approximately 19-year relationship).
There were four children: S (18), J (16), N (10) and R (8) at the time of judgment.
After separation the wife and children initially lived in rental accommodation; the husband remained in the mortgage-free matrimonial home.
J returned to live with the husband in early 2006; S later lived with her boyfriend's family; N and R primarily lived with the wife.

asset_pool: Trial judge found total asset pool value: $938,665.

Included: former matrimonial home (free of encumbrance at separation; later sold), superannuation interests (subject to splitting order), savings withdrawn by husband post-separation ($56,024 add-back), superannuation drawdown ($20,000 add-back), household furniture, motor vehicle, and other assets referred to in the Full Court's table.
The Full Court proceeded on the basis that the home had been sold and the superannuation splitting order had already been implemented; it adjusted distribution via proceeds of sale.
contributions: Contributions to date of separation were found to be equal (not contested).

Post-separation, the trial judge found the wife made the greater contribution due to her financial struggle supporting herself and children in rented accommodation and her primary care for N and R, while the husband remained in the mortgage-free home and ceased employment in April 2006.
Overall contributions assessed by the trial judge as 52% wife and 48% husband; Full Court upheld this assessment as within discretion.
future_needs: s 75(2) considerations focused primarily on the care, accommodation and maintenance responsibilities for N and R and the effect of child support arrangements.

The Full Court accepted the wife bore a greater proportion of the burden of maintaining N and R while no child support was being exchanged under the parties' agreement (at least while current parenting arrangements continued).
The Full Court considered the husband would have substantial care (about 40% of time) and accommodation responsibility for N and R and ongoing responsibility for J while he remained dependent.
Health: neither party found to have health problems impacting work; husband's high blood pressure not supported by medical evidence.
just_equitable: The Full Court held the trial judge's 10% s 75(2) adjustment produced an excessive disparity (20% value effect; about $187,733) given other s 75(2) factors largely balanced and the husband's significant care time.
The Full Court determined a 4% s 75(2) adjustment (8% disparity; about $75,093) was appropriate, leading to an overall 56/44 division and found that outcome just and equitable.
living_arrangements: Wife lived in rental accommodation with the children after separation.
Husband remained in the former matrimonial home (mortgage-free).
At trial and thereafter, J resided with the husband; N and R resided primarily with the wife but spent substantial time with the husband.
existing_agreements: Interim consent parenting orders at trial commencement: J to reside with husband; N and R to reside with wife; husband to have N and R five nights per fortnight and half school holidays; J to spend time with wife in accordance with his wishes.
Agreement noted that while current parenting arrangements continued, neither party would pursue the other for child support.
Superannuation splitting order had been implemented before the appeal was determined.

need: Wife commenced proceedings seeking spousal maintenance but was not pursuing the application at trial.
income_expenses: Wife's income noted as $664 gross per week from employment as an education assistant.
Husband previously earned about $750 gross per week before resignation; trial judge later assessed earning capacity at $850-$950 gross per week from full-time work.
earning_capacity: Trial judge found husband could earn $45,000-$50,000 per annum if he returned to former employer and assessed weekly earning capacity $850-$950 gross; Full Court held these findings were open but were not relied upon in the critical s 75(2) adjustment reasoning.
health_care: Husband asserted high blood pressure but no medical evidence was produced; neither party found to have health problems impacting work.
relationship_length: Lengthy relationship/marriage of approximately 19 years.
standard_of_living: The parties enjoyed a modest but reasonable standard of living during the relationship.

current_arrangements: Consent orders: J to reside with husband; N and R to reside with wife.
Husband to have N and R five nights each fortnight (after school Wednesday to school Monday) and half of school holidays.
J to spend time with the wife in accordance with J's wishes.
caregiver_history: At separation, wife initially cared for all four children; later J moved to live with husband and S moved out; wife continued to primarily care for N and R.
availability: Husband resigned from work in 2006 asserting desire to be available for J; trial judge found resignation was strongly motivated by reducing financial obligations though influenced by caring for J.
Wife worked 35 hours per week and trial judge found those hours enabled her to meet needs of N and R.
safety_concerns: J described as having severe behavioural problems; reference in evidence to issues including alleged sexual abuse issues and other behavioural difficulties; no parenting determination made on safety issues in this appeal.
child_views: J to spend time with the wife in accordance with his wishes (indicating J's wishes relevant to time with mother).
allegations: Husband asserted need to supervise J due to behavioural problems; wife alleged husband's resignation was to avoid financial obligations.
orders: No new parenting orders were made on the appeal; consent parenting orders were noted as existing and relevant to the s 75(2) analysis.

incidents: Husband alleged J had behavioural issues including an incident of punching his mother (raised in submissions), but not determined as a family violence finding within this appeal.
police_court: Husband asserted J had been arrested for stealing (raised in submissions).

outcome_orders: Appeal allowed.

Order 1 of Crooks J's orders of 16 April 2008 varied: net proceeds of sale of the specified Western Australian property to be disbursed by paying agent's commission and reasonable sale expenses, then paying the wife 61% of the proceeds, and the balance to the husband.
No order as to costs of the appeal.
Costs certificate granted to the appellant husband pursuant to s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of costs incurred in the appeal.

description: The Full Court intervened on discretionary error in the trial judge's s 75(2) adjustment. While accepting the contribution findings and most factual findings (including earning capacity), it held the 10% adjustment produced an excessive money-value disparity and insufficiently accounted for the father's substantial care time and shared maintenance burden under the parties' arrangements. The case underscores the need to assess the practical monetary impact of percentage adjustments and to avoid characterising one party as having the 'sole burden' of child support where time and expenses are substantially shared.
pivotal_findings: The children (N and R) spent substantial time with the husband (about 40% including holidays), meaning the wife's care and maintenance burden was greater but not exclusive.
The 10% s 75(2) adjustment created a 20% value disparity (about $187,733) which the Full Court found outside the reasonable ambit of discretion on the facts.
Other s 75(2) factors were largely balanced; the main differentiators were relative child care/maintenance responsibilities and the history of minimal child support after the husband ceased work.
The contributions assessment (52/48) was within discretion and was not disturbed.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 (property settlement discretion; consideration of contributions and other factors).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors; adjustment considered and recalibrated on appeal).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval of publication under pseudonym).
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) s 6 and s 9 (costs certificates).

reasons_rationale: Appellate intervention warranted because the trial judge's 10% s 75(2) adjustment produced a money-value disparity outside the reasonable exercise of discretion (House v The King; Norbis v Norbis principles).

The trial judge at times overstated the wife's responsibility as the 'sole burden' of supporting N and R despite substantial time spent with the husband and an agreement that neither party would pursue child support while current parenting arrangements continued.
The Full Court emphasised that s 75(2) percentage adjustments must be evaluated for their monetary impact; a 10% adjustment translates to a 20% disparity in value between parties.

A 4% s 75(2) adjustment was assessed as appropriate given the shared care (around 40% with father), the wife's greater maintenance burden absent child support, and the husband's ongoing responsibilities for J.

Implementation practicality: rather than undo an already-implemented superannuation split, the Court adjusted the distribution of the home sale proceeds to achieve the intended overall 56/44 division.
uncertainties: Exact net sale proceeds of the home at the time of appeal were not stated; the Court used trial-time valuations and noted the home sold for more but net amount was unknown.
The continuing dependency and employment prospects of J were disputed, but the Full Court accepted the trial judge's inference that J would be looking for work as open on the evidence.
Extent of the husband's actual expenses for children and how the child support agreement operated in practice beyond the stated arrangement was not quantified.

- Asset Pool: Included: former matrimonial home (free of encumbrance at separation; later sold), superannuation interests (subject to splitting order), savings withdrawn by husband post-separation ($56,024 add-back), superannuation drawdown ($20,000 add-back), household furniture, motor vehicle, and other assets referred to in the Full Court's table.
- Asset Pool: The Full Court proceeded on the basis that the home had been sold and the superannuation splitting order had already been implemented; it adjusted distribution via proceeds of sale.
- Contributions: Contributions to date of separation were found to be equal (not contested).
- Contributions: Post-separation, the trial judge found the wife made the greater contribution due to her financial struggle supporting herself and children in rented accommodation and her primary care for N and R, while the husband remained in the mortgage-free home and ceased employment in April 2006.
- Contributions: Overall contributions assessed by the trial judge as 52% wife and 48% husband; Full Court upheld this assessment as within discretion.
- Future Needs: s 75(2) considerations focused primarily on the care, accommodation and maintenance responsibilities for N and R and the effect of child support arrangements.
- Future Needs: The Full Court accepted the wife bore a greater proportion of the burden of maintaining N and R while no child support was being exchanged under the parties' agreement (at least while current parenting arrangements continued).
- Future Needs: The Full Court considered the husband would have substantial care (about 40% of time) and accommodation responsibility for N and R and ongoing responsibility for J while he remained dependent.
- Future Needs: Health: neither party found to have health problems impacting work; husband's high blood pressure not supported by medical evidence.
- Just & Equitable: The Full Court held the trial judge's 10% s 75(2) adjustment produced an excessive disparity (20% value effect; about $187,733) given other s 75(2) factors largely balanced and the husband's significant care time.
- Just & Equitable: The Full Court determined a 4% s 75(2) adjustment (8% disparity; about $75,093) was appropriate, leading to an overall 56/44 division and found that outcome just and equitable.
- Need: Wife commenced proceedings seeking spousal maintenance but was not pursuing the application at trial.

- Child Ages: S: 18
- Child Ages: J: 16
- Child Ages: N: 10
- Child Ages: R: 8
- Current Arrangements: Consent orders: J to reside with husband; N and R to reside with wife.
- Current Arrangements: Husband to have N and R five nights each fortnight (after school Wednesday to school Monday) and half of school holidays.
- Current Arrangements: J to spend time with the wife in accordance with J's wishes.
- Safety Concerns: J described as having severe behavioural problems; reference in evidence to issues including alleged sexual abuse issues and other behavioural difficulties; no parenting determination made on safety issues in this appeal.
- Incidents: Husband alleged J had behavioural issues including an incident of punching his mother (raised in submissions), but not determined as a family violence finding within this appeal.

- Outcome: Appeal allowed.
- Outcome: Order 1 of Crooks J's orders of 16 April 2008 varied: net proceeds of sale of the specified Western Australian property to be disbursed by paying agent's commission and reasonable sale expenses, then paying the wife 61% of the proceeds, and the balance to the husband.
- Outcome: No order as to costs of the appeal.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the appellant husband pursuant to s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of costs incurred in the appeal.

- Reasons: Appellate intervention warranted because the trial judge's 10% s 75(2) adjustment produced a money-value disparity outside the reasonable exercise of discretion (House v The King; Norbis v Norbis principles).
- Reasons: The trial judge at times overstated the wife's responsibility as the 'sole burden' of supporting N and R despite substantial time spent with the husband and an agreement that neither party would pursue child support while current parenting arrangements continued.
- Reasons: The Full Court emphasised that s 75(2) percentage adjustments must be evaluated for their monetary impact; a 10% adjustment translates to a 20% disparity in value between parties.
- Reasons: A 4% s 75(2) adjustment was assessed as appropriate given the shared care (around 40% with father), the wife's greater maintenance burden absent child support, and the husband's ongoing responsibilities for J.
- Reasons: Implementation practicality: rather than undo an already-implemented superannuation split, the Court adjusted the distribution of the home sale proceeds to achieve the intended overall 56/44 division.

- Pivotal Finding: The children (N and R) spent substantial time with the husband (about 40% including holidays), meaning the wife's care and maintenance burden was greater but not exclusive.
- Pivotal Finding: The 10% s 75(2) adjustment created a 20% value disparity (about $187,733) which the Full Court found outside the reasonable ambit of discretion on the facts.
- Pivotal Finding: Other s 75(2) factors were largely balanced; the main differentiators were relative child care/maintenance responsibilities and the history of minimal child support after the husband ceased work.
- Pivotal Finding: The contributions assessment (52/48) was within discretion and was not disturbed.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 (property settlement discretion; consideration of contributions and other factors).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors; adjustment considered and recalibrated on appeal).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval of publication under pseudonym).
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) s 6 and s 9 (costs certificates).

- Uncertainties: Exact net sale proceeds of the home at the time of appeal were not stated; the Court used trial-time valuations and noted the home sold for more but net amount was unknown.
- Uncertainties: The continuing dependency and employment prospects of J were disputed, but the Full Court accepted the trial judge's inference that J would be looking for work as open on the evidence.
- Uncertainties: Extent of the husband's actual expenses for children and how the child support agreement operated in practice beyond the stated arrangement was not quantified.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal principles: meaning of an appeal 'by way of rehearing' and whether to apply the law at the time of appeal or at the time of the primary decision
Same-sex parenting: whether each woman was a 'parent' of the other’s child under Part VII as at 18 July 2008
Whether alleged errors occurred in applying the Part VII 'legislative pathway' (equal shared parental responsibility; s 65DAA considerations)
Adequacy of reasons and alleged failure to consider relevant matters
Procedural fairness (use of an authority not provided to appellant)
Interlocutory/discretion issues: refusal to entertain oral s 65K application and adjournment
facts: The parties were in an intimate same-sex relationship and lived together from early 1994 until separation in April 2003.
Two children were born during the relationship: B (biological child of Ms Brockmann) and S (biological child of Ms Simpson).
Both children were conceived using IVF with the same sperm donor; the donor’s identity is unknown.
On separation Ms Brockmann left the home in northern NSW with B; Ms Simpson remained with S in the northern NSW home.
There were earlier consent parenting orders made soon after each child’s birth in the Local Court (Sydney) providing for joint responsibility.
Later parenting orders became unworkable after Ms Brockmann and B moved from northern NSW to Sydney; Ms Simpson commenced the proceedings leading to the 18 July 2008 orders.

living_arrangements: B lived with Ms Brockmann in Sydney; S lived with Ms Simpson in northern New South Wales (as per the primary orders appealed).
existing_agreements: Local Court consent orders (1997 for S; 1998 for B) providing for joint responsibility were made shortly after birth; later consent orders in the Federal Magistrates Court (15 April 2004) discharged previous orders made by that court (dispute as to effect on Local Court orders).

child_ages: B: 10 years (at time of primary reasons summarised; 'now 10')
S: 11 years (at time of primary reasons summarised; 'now 11')
current_arrangements: Following separation (April 2003): Ms Brockmann with B; Ms Simpson with S.
At time of 18 July 2008 orders: B to live with Ms Brockmann (Sydney) and S to live with Ms Simpson (northern NSW); each child to spend some time with the other household.
caregiver_history: B had lived primarily with Ms Brockmann since separation and was described as being removed from her primary carer if relocated.
S lived with Ms Simpson in northern NSW.
availability: Distance between Sydney and northern NSW created practical difficulties and expense for travel.
Ms Simpson was on a limited income affecting ability to fund frequent travel.
safety_concerns: No concerns about physical or psychological harm in the care of either party were identified by the Federal Magistrate.
Concerns were noted about S’s behaviour towards B; S was diagnosed with a form of Asperger’s Syndrome.
Historical allegations of drug use were raised but treated as no longer an issue on the evidence.
child_views: The Federal Magistrate considered evidence of the children’s views, relying on report writer observations; applied caution given B’s age.
The children did not express views about who they regarded as their 'parents'; the parties reported that during the relationship each child regarded both women as 'mother' (with nicknames).
allegations: Allegations that B had expressed wishes to live with each party were raised by both parties; the court treated statements to the report writer as most recent.
Allegations of past drug use by Ms Simpson (and mention that both women reported past drug use) were raised.
Concerns were raised about Ms Brockmann’s attitude to facilitating B’s relationship with Ms Simpson (including surname change issue).
Ms Brockmann had aggressive ovarian cancer; this was raised in connection with an attempted s 65K application.
expert_evidence: A family report writer met with the children and provided observations about their intelligence, articulation, and relationships with each adult.
The report writer expressed the view it was not wise to remove B from her primary carer and saw no reason to interfere with the nature/extent of B’s relationship with Ms Brockmann.
best_interests: The primary judge considered s 60CC factors and found Ms Simpson’s primary proposal (both children to live with her in northern NSW) would likely negatively affect B’s relationship with Ms Brockmann and was not supported by the report writer.
The court considered practicalities of distance and travel expense and the effect of change on each child’s circumstances.
The Full Court held there was no appellable error in the best-interests evaluation identified in the grounds advanced.
orders: Appeal outcome only: appeal dismissed; costs ordered against appellant.

Primary parenting orders are described in reasons as maintaining B with Ms Brockmann in Sydney and S with Ms Simpson in northern NSW with time in each other household; the appellate judgment did not set them aside.

outcome_orders: The appeal was dismissed.
The appellant (Ms Simpson) was ordered to pay the respondent’s (Ms Brockmann’s) costs of and incidental to the appeal, as agreed or otherwise assessed.
Publication under pseudonym approved pursuant to s 121(9)(g) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

description: The decision confirms that, on a Part X appeal 'by way of rehearing', the Full Court assesses whether the primary decision involved error by applying the law as it stood when the orders were made; later legislative amendments are relevant only if the appeal succeeds and the court re-exercises discretion or re-determines. Substantively, the Full Court upheld the approach that, pre-2008 amendments, a non-biological female partner in a same-sex relationship was not a 'parent' for Part VII purposes, and that Part VII remains workable in parent/non-parent disputes by using applicable best-interests factors (including the catch-all) rather than redefining 'parent'.
pivotal_findings: Intervening legislative change (amended s 60H commencing 21 November 2008) did not render the primary decision wrong; absent explicit retrospective intent affecting concluded litigation, the appeal required demonstration of error under the law at 18 July 2008.
The appeal was not a hearing de novo; the appellant had to 'get through the gate' by establishing error before any substitution based on current law could occur.
As at 18 July 2008, the appellant and respondent were not each a 'parent' of the other’s child for Part VII purposes; the primary judge’s conclusion on 'parent' was not shown to be wrong.

The 'legislative pathway' arguments dependent on both being parents (presumption of equal shared parental responsibility; s 65DAA pathway) failed once the non-parent finding stood; the primary judge was entitled to proceed by direct best-interests analysis.

Alleged errors regarding discharge of earlier joint responsibility orders did not materially affect the reasoning; any mistake did not operate against the appellant and the primary judge gave an alternative basis for declining equal shared parental responsibility.
No procedural unfairness arose from reference to H & J because the issue was one of pure law and was fully ventilated on appeal.
Refusal to entertain a late oral s 65K application (and related adjournment request) did not establish error or substantial hardship and was interlocutory in character.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) Part X (appeals), including s 93A(2) and s 94 (nature of appeal powers) as discussed via CDJ v VAJ and Allesch v Maunz

Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) Part VII: s 60B, s 60CC (best interests), s 60H (children born as a result of artificial conception procedures), s 61C, s 61DA (presumption of equal shared parental responsibility), s 65DAA (equal/substantial and significant time pathway), s 65K
Family Law Amendment (De Facto Financial Matters and Other Measures) Act 2008: commencement of amended s 60H on 21 November 2008 and the limited 'retrospectivity' in item 9 of Schedule 3A
Status of Children Act 1996 (NSW) s 14(1A) was raised but post-dated the primary decision and was not applied

reasons_rationale: The Full Court held that an appeal 'by way of rehearing' still requires demonstration of error; the correctness of the orders appealed is assessed against the law at the time of the primary decision, unless legislation clearly operates to retrospectively invalidate concluded applications of the former law.

The Amending Act’s application to children born before/on/after commencement did not indicate an intention to render incorrect earlier concluded decisions; it only meant the amended provision would apply if the same litigation were determined after commencement.

Under the pre-amendment s 60H and the authorities followed by the Federal Magistrate, the non-birth partner was not a 'parent' for Part VII, and Part VII could still be applied in parent/non-parent disputes without being unworkable.

Grounds alleging failure to consider children’s views and other relevant matters failed because the primary judge had addressed the children’s views through the report writer and considered the relevant circumstances; the children had not expressed views about legal parenthood.

Complaints about omissions in reasons regarding communication/information proposals failed because those matters were not pursued at trial by evidence or submissions; parties define issues for determination.
Procedural fairness challenge regarding reliance on H & J failed because the legal issue was fully addressable on appeal and was a live issue at trial.
Costs were ordered against the appellant having regard to the nature of the proceedings and the result under s 117(2A), despite the appellant’s modest means and legal aid.
uncertainties: Whether the 1997/1998 Local Court joint responsibility orders were technically discharged by later Federal Magistrates Court consent orders was not finally determined on appeal; the Full Court treated it as unnecessary to decide given lack of material impact.
The appellate reasons summarise but do not reproduce the detailed terms of the primary parenting time arrangements between households.

- Current Arrangements: Following separation (April 2003): Ms Brockmann with B; Ms Simpson with S.

- Reasons: Grounds alleging failure to consider children’s views and other relevant matters failed because the primary judge had addressed the children’s views through the report writer and considered the relevant circumstances; the children had not expressed views about legal parenthood.
- Reasons: Complaints about omissions in reasons regarding communication/information proposals failed because those matters were not pursued at trial by evidence or submissions; parties define issues for determination.
- Reasons: Procedural fairness challenge regarding reliance on H & J failed because the legal issue was fully addressable on appeal and was a live issue at trial.
- Reasons: Costs were ordered against the appellant having regard to the nature of the proceedings and the result under s 117(2A), despite the appellant’s modest means and legal aid.

- Pivotal Finding: Intervening legislative change (amended s 60H commencing 21 November 2008) did not render the primary decision wrong; absent explicit retrospective intent affecting concluded litigation, the appeal required demonstration of error under the law at 18 July 2008.
- Pivotal Finding: The appeal was not a hearing de novo; the appellant had to 'get through the gate' by establishing error before any substitution based on current law could occur.
- Pivotal Finding: As at 18 July 2008, the appellant and respondent were not each a 'parent' of the other’s child for Part VII purposes; the primary judge’s conclusion on 'parent' was not shown to be wrong.
- Pivotal Finding: The 'legislative pathway' arguments dependent on both being parents (presumption of equal shared parental responsibility; s 65DAA pathway) failed once the non-parent finding stood; the primary judge was entitled to proceed by direct best-interests analysis.
- Pivotal Finding: Alleged errors regarding discharge of earlier joint responsibility orders did not materially affect the reasoning; any mistake did not operate against the appellant and the primary judge gave an alternative basis for declining equal shared parental responsibility.
- Pivotal Finding: No procedural unfairness arose from reference to H & J because the issue was one of pure law and was fully ventilated on appeal.
- Pivotal Finding: Refusal to entertain a late oral s 65K application (and related adjournment request) did not establish error or substantial hardship and was interlocutory in character.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) Part X (appeals), including s 93A(2) and s 94 (nature of appeal powers) as discussed via CDJ v VAJ and Allesch v Maunz
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) Part VII: s 60B, s 60CC (best interests), s 60H (children born as a result of artificial conception procedures), s 61C, s 61DA (presumption of equal shared parental responsibility), s 65DAA (equal/substantial and significant time pathway), s 65K
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Amendment (De Facto Financial Matters and Other Measures) Act 2008: commencement of amended s 60H on 21 November 2008 and the limited 'retrospectivity' in item 9 of Schedule 3A
- Statutory Pivot: Status of Children Act 1996 (NSW) s 14(1A) was raised but post-dated the primary decision and was not applied

- Uncertainties: Whether the 1997/1998 Local Court joint responsibility orders were technically discharged by later Federal Magistrates Court consent orders was not finally determined on appeal; the Full Court treated it as unnecessary to decide given lack of material impact.
- Uncertainties: The appellate reasons summarise but do not reproduce the detailed terms of the primary parenting time arrangements between households.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal against final parenting orders
Whether the trial judge erred in findings about the mother's attitude to the child's relationship with the father (s 60CC(2)(a) and s 60CC(3)(c), (f), (i))
Whether the trial judge failed to adequately assess and weigh all best interests considerations and failed to give adequate reasons (s 60CC)
Whether the trial judge failed to address the mandatory requirements of s 65DAA (equal time / substantial and significant time; best interests and reasonable practicability)
facts: The parties commenced a relationship in May 2003; the child was born in December 2005 and was about 4 at appeal (less than 3 at June 2008 interim orders).
The mother was the principal carer after birth; maternal aunt moved to Sydney in March 2006 to assist with care and lived with mother and child.

Consent orders made 12 December 2006 allowed the mother to remove the child from Australia to live in Dubai for 13 months from on/after 27 December 2006; child to live with mother and spend reasonable time with father as agreed.

Mother and child moved to Dubai on 1 March 2007; mother signed an employment contract in Dubai shortly after arrival; move was financially driven and not alleged to be to thwart father-child relationship.

child_ages: Child born December 2005; about 4 years old at appeal (March 2010); about 3 years old at trial (Dec 2008)
current_arrangements: Interim month-about regime between Dubai (UAE) and Sydney from June 2008, involving monthly long-haul flights; described by the Full Court as unsatisfactory.
caregiver_history: Mother was the principal carer from birth.
Maternal aunt lived with mother and child from early 2006 and provided significant day-to-day assistance and care.
Father’s time with child increased significantly after June 2008 interim orders.
availability: Father worked in an international family business and travelled extensively, including multiple long overseas trips (including China, Italy).
Mother worked as an environmental engineer in Dubai; evidence discussed difficulties obtaining suitable employment in Sydney and financial impacts of returning.
safety_concerns: Police attended/complaints were made relating to incidents in February/March 2007; trial judge ultimately treated s 60CC(2)(b) as neutral and found no need to protect child from harm in the statutory sense.
Allegations about conflict and father’s behaviour; father admitted sending abusive SMS and refusing calls unless mother disclosed location on one occasion.
Mother raised allegations about father’s drug use; trial judge accepted father’s evidence of infrequent past use.
child_views: Trial judge treated s 60CC(3)(a) (child’s views) as neutral due to young age; appeal court agreed this was open.
allegations: Mother alleged father behaved inappropriately in Feb/March 2007 incidents and during visits to Dubai; father disputed aspects.

Father alleged mother restricted his time in Dubai and contributed to child’s distress at handovers; trial judge accepted father’s account on key points; Full Court found error in such findings given unchallenged evidence.

Dispute about mother’s non-disclosure of Dubai address (sealed to Court) and passport application without consulting father; trial judge inferred these reflected desire to diminish father’s role; Full Court found such inferences problematic given evidence.
expert_evidence: Family report dated 19 November 2008 by Dr E (family consultant); trial judge accepted all evidence and placed considerable weight on certain opinions.

Cross-examination revealed the consultant’s concerns about mother’s facilitation were primarily based on mother’s overseas relocation, and the assessment of father’s facilitation was largely based on father’s assertions and telephone contact.
best_interests: Full Court held the trial judge failed to properly consider, weigh, and assess all relevant s 60CC factors and to explain the balancing process and relative weight.

Full Court held errors were established regarding findings about the mother’s attitude/facilitation and omissions regarding mother’s proposals and evidence (including time with father in the UAE; mother’s evidence she would return to Sydney if child ordered to live with father; relationship with maternal aunt; child’s stronger attachment to mother).
Full Court found the trial judge failed to properly engage with s 65DAA requirements and reasonable practicability factors (including s 65DAA(5)).
orders: Appeal orders: final parenting orders of Stevenson J were discharged and the applications for final parenting orders remitted for redetermination before a different judge; rehearing recommended to be expedited.
Costs: no order as to costs under s 117; costs certificates granted to both parties for appeal and for rehearing.

incidents: Incident on 19 February 2007 at Sydney home; mother later reported to police; trial judge found father behaved inappropriately but treated incidents as occurring in an emotionally charged environment and not reflective of general behaviour.

Incident on 1 March 2007 at Sydney home; police attended; father attempted to prevent mother leaving for airport; evidence included father demanding mother sign a power of attorney and telling her she was not leaving until she did.
police_court: Police involvement/attendance in relation to February/March 2007 incidents; COPS entry referred to by trial judge.
Child was placed on and later removed from the Australian Federal Police Airport Watch List by interim orders (removed from list from 1 July 2008).
child_exposure: Allegations of arguments/conflict in child’s presence; evidence of distress at international changeovers; medical evidence about trauma during a flight was mentioned in appeal history.
safety_plan: Mother’s Dubai address was provided to the Court in a sealed envelope by interim order (only to be opened by order of a judge).

outcome_orders: The appeal was allowed; the parenting orders made 31 March 2009 by Stevenson J were discharged.
The applications for final parenting orders were remitted for redetermination (rehearing) before a judge other than Stevenson J in Sydney, and it was recommended the hearing be expedited.
No order as to costs between the parties under s 117 of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).
Costs certificates were granted to the appellant under s 9 and to the respondent under s 6 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the appeal.
Costs certificates were granted to each party under s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the rehearing.

description: This Full Court appeal emphasised that parenting decisions, especially in relocation/international living arrangements, must be determined by a structured application of the Family Law Act: properly considering and weighing all s 60CC best-interests factors, addressing parties’ actual proposals, and complying with the mandatory sequencing and findings required by s 65DAA when equal shared parental responsibility is ordered. The court found legal error where the primary judge accepted and weighted a family consultant’s opinions without adequate scrutiny of their foundations, drew adverse inferences about the mother’s facilitation based on incomplete consideration of evidence (including unchallenged third-party evidence), and failed to explain the balancing exercise or deal with the statutory conditions of reasonable practicability.
pivotal_findings: The trial judge’s adverse findings about the mother’s attitude to the father-child relationship were materially affected by overlooking/insufficiently weighing evidence, including the mother’s proposals for time in the UAE, evidence she would return to Sydney if necessary, and evidence about the child’s strong attachment to the mother and relationship with the maternal aunt.

The trial judge did not properly compare and evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of each party’s proposals, including the fact the father’s proposal (if mother stayed overseas) afforded the mother significantly less time than the mother proposed for the father.
The trial judge failed to give adequate reasons showing how competing s 60CC factors were weighed and balanced, contrary to established appellate principles on adequacy of reasons in parenting cases.

The trial judge failed to address mandatory requirements of s 65DAA, including assessment of best interests and reasonable practicability (and the s 65DAA(5) factors) for equal time/substantial and significant time outcomes, particularly in an international context.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CA
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2) and s 60CC(3), including s 60CC(3)(c), (d), (e), (f), (i), and s 60CC(4)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 61DA (presumption of equal shared parental responsibility)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65DAA (equal time / substantial and significant time; reasonable practicability factors in s 65DAA(5))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 (costs)

reasons_rationale: Errors were established in relation to the trial judge’s findings about the mother’s attitude and facilitation of the father-child relationship, including inappropriate/insufficient weighting and overlooking evidence relevant to s 60CC(2)(a) and s 60CC(3)(c), (f), (i).

The trial judge failed to adequately assess and weigh the relevant s 60CC best-interests considerations in the context of the parties’ proposals and failed to provide adequate reasons demonstrating the balancing exercise.

The trial judge failed to address the requirements of s 65DAA, including best interests and reasonable practicability for equal/substantial and significant time and the factors in s 65DAA(5), in circumstances where equal shared parental responsibility was ordered.

Because of identified errors and the difficulty of re-exercising discretion (including the need for potential further evidence and the impugned perceptions/findings), the matter was remitted for rehearing before a different judge, with expedition recommended.
Costs orders reflected the appeal succeeding on a question of law; costs certificates were appropriate under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act with no inter-party costs order under s 117.
uncertainties: The ultimate parenting outcome was not determined on appeal; final parenting arrangements were remitted for rehearing.

Some factual disputes (e.g., incidents in Dubai, extent of restrictions on father’s time, communication difficulties) were noted as contested; the Full Court identified errors in the trial judge’s treatment of parts of this evidence without finally determining all disputed facts.
The mother’s post-appeal evidence about redundancy and a potential job in Qatar was raised in the appeal process but did not result in a re-exercised final parenting determination by the Full Court.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether a post-divorce financial agreement misdescribed as made under s 90C could be treated/rectified as a s 90D financial agreement
Whether errors in annexed solicitor certificates (incorrect given names within clauses) could be rectified or otherwise satisfy s 90G requirements
Whether the agreement was binding under s 90G(1) and, if not, whether it should be declared binding under s 90G(1A) and (1B)
Whether reliance on extrinsic materials and the 2009 amending legislation was erroneous in determining rectification/binding issues
Costs certificates under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)
facts: Parties married in September 1989 and separated in March 2006; divorce became absolute in January 2009.
No children of the marriage.
On 27 July 2009 the parties executed a document headed 'Section 90C Financial Agreement' despite being divorced at the time.

The agreement provided the wife receive $28,000 and the husband retain remaining property, including a shop with upstairs residence and a separate residence property; properties were registered as tenants in common.
Annexed solicitor certificates correctly identified each client in introductory and acknowledgment parts, but in clauses describing advice referred to other given names ('Patricia' and 'Chris').

Wife later sought to resile and applied for declarations that the document was not a s 90D financial agreement or not binding under s 90G, alternatively to set it aside under s 90K, and sought s 79 property orders.

asset_pool: Cash payment to wife of $28,000 (cheque forwarded by husband and held pending proceedings).
Real property: shop with upstairs residence in B, Victoria.
Real property: husband's residence in W (location abbreviated in reasons).
Both properties were registered in joint names as tenants in common at the time.
just_equitable: Substantive s 79 property adjustment was not determined in this appeal; the controversy focused on the validity/binding effect of the financial agreement that would oust Part VIII jurisdiction if binding.
living_arrangements: Agreement contemplated husband retaining the property described as his place of residence.
existing_agreements: Document executed 27 July 2009 intended to operate as a Part VIIIA financial agreement; it incorrectly referenced s 90C and required consideration as a post-divorce (s 90D) agreement.
Parties were stated to have no other agreement in force pursuant to s 90B, s 90C or s 90D (as per clause 1).

relationship_length: Marriage from September 1989; separation March 2006; divorce absolute January 2009.

agreement_date: 27 July 2009 (post-divorce financial agreement document executed after divorce order)
legal_advice: It was uncontroversial that each party received legal advice and signed the annexed certificates acknowledging receipt and comprehension.

Trial judge found both parties intended to enter a binding financial agreement and that the wife received clear advice about adequacy and finality (findings were contested on appeal but largely upheld except as to binding certification requirements).

On appeal, one ground alleged the wife's solicitor did not advise on advantages; Full Court (Strickland J) rejected that ground, construing s 90G(1)(b) as permitting advice that there were no advantages if none were apparent.

outcome_orders: Time for filing a Notice of Appeal extended to 24 August 2010.
Appeal allowed.
Order 2 made by Young J on 30 June 2010 set aside.
Matter remitted to Young J to determine whether the agreement should be declared binding pursuant to s 90G(1A) and (1B) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).
No order as to costs of the appeal.
Costs certificates granted to the wife (s 9 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)) and to the husband (s 6) in respect of appeal costs.

description: The Full Court drew a key distinction between (1) whether a document is a 'financial agreement' under ss 90B/90C/90D (to which contract/equity principles, including rectification, can apply via s 90KA) and (2) whether the financial agreement is 'binding' so as to oust Part VIII jurisdiction under s 71A, which turns on compliance with s 90G or, failing that, a court declaration under s 90G(1A)/(1B). The misdescription of the agreement as under s 90C (instead of s 90D) was capable of rectification because it concerned the parties' common intention about the statutory category of agreement after divorce. By contrast, deficiencies in the face of the solicitor certificates relevant to s 90G were treated by the majority as not rectifiable by equitable doctrines because they go to the statutory precondition for ousting jurisdiction; instead, relief (if any) must come from the statutory 'unjust and inequitable' pathway in s 90G(1A). Murphy J additionally analysed complex transitional provisions (Items 8 and 8A of Schedule 5 to the 2009 amending Act) affecting how s 90G operates retrospectively for agreements made between 14 January 2004 and 4 January 2010.
pivotal_findings: The parties were divorced when they signed the agreement; therefore, the applicable provision for a financial agreement was s 90D, not s 90C.

The agreement recorded the parties' common intention to finally settle property and exclude Part VIII, and the s 90C references were treated as an error capable of correction to reflect that intention.

The solicitor certificates, on their face, referred to advice given to the correctly named party but then described advice as to the rights/advantages for different given names, creating a facial defect in meeting s 90G certification requirements.
The trial judge erred by purporting to rectify the solicitor certificates to satisfy s 90G(1) and by concluding the agreement was binding under s 90G(1) after such rectification.

The appropriate next step was remitter for consideration of whether the agreement should be declared binding under s 90G(1A) and (1B), including the 'unjust and inequitable' threshold (with the majority not determining that discretion on appeal).
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90D (requirements for post-divorce financial agreement, including being expressed to be made under that section)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1) (mandatory requirements for binding effect, including independent legal advice and signed statements/copies)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1A) and s 90G(1B) (court declaration making an otherwise non-compliant agreement binding if unjust and inequitable not to do so)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 71A (ouster of Part VIII in respect of matters covered by a binding financial agreement)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90KA (application of contract/equity principles to validity/enforceability/effect of financial agreements and purported contracts)

Federal Justice System Amendment (Efficiency Measures) Act (No 1) 2009 (Cth) Schedule 5 Items 8 and 8A (transitional/retrospective application of amendments to s 90G, discussed particularly by Murphy J)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9 (costs certificates)

reasons_rationale: Majority (Strickland and Murphy JJ) held that equitable rectification could correct the s 90C/s 90D misdescription because it concerned the agreement's proper statutory character reflecting the parties' common intention post-divorce.

Majority held that s 90G compliance is the statutory gateway for an agreement to be 'binding' and thus to oust Part VIII; defects in the solicitor certificates were not capable of rectification to manufacture compliance with s 90G(1).

Relief for non-compliance with s 90G(1) lies in the statutory mechanism of s 90G(1A)/(1B), requiring the court to be satisfied it would be unjust and inequitable if the agreement were not binding; that issue required remitter.
The Full Court declined to exercise the s 90G(1A) discretion because of limited/insufficient argument and uncertainty as to the evidence/considerations relevant to 'unjust and inequitable'.

May J dissented, preferring to treat the naming errors as correctable by reading the certificates as referring to the parties and, alternatively, considered the remedial provisions would render it unjust and inequitable for the agreement not to bind; however, the court's orders reflect the majority outcome allowing the appeal and remitting.

Costs: although no costs order was made for the appeal, costs certificates were granted because the appeal succeeded on a question of law and the matter was remitted for rehearing on the binding declaration issue.
uncertainties: Whether, on remitter, the agreement would be declared binding under s 90G(1A) and (1B), including how 'unjust and inequitable' would be applied to the particular non-compliance and the fairness/efficacy of the settlement.
Any ultimate property settlement under s 79 was not determined in this appeal and depended on whether the agreement would ultimately be binding or otherwise set aside/enforced.

summary_text:
- Fact: Parties married in September 1989 and separated in March 2006; divorce became absolute in January 2009.
- Fact: No children of the marriage.
- Fact: On 27 July 2009 the parties executed a document headed 'Section 90C Financial Agreement' despite being divorced at the time.
- Fact: The agreement provided the wife receive $28,000 and the husband retain remaining property, including a shop with upstairs residence and a separate residence property; properties were registered as tenants in common.
- Fact: Annexed solicitor certificates correctly identified each client in introductory and acknowledgment parts, but in clauses describing advice referred to other given names ('Patricia' and 'Chris').
- Fact: Wife later sought to resile and applied for declarations that the document was not a s 90D financial agreement or not binding under s 90G, alternatively to set it aside under s 90K, and sought s 79 property orders.

- Issue: Whether a post-divorce financial agreement misdescribed as made under s 90C could be treated/rectified as a s 90D financial agreement
- Issue: Whether errors in annexed solicitor certificates (incorrect given names within clauses) could be rectified or otherwise satisfy s 90G requirements
- Issue: Whether the agreement was binding under s 90G(1) and, if not, whether it should be declared binding under s 90G(1A) and (1B)
- Issue: Whether reliance on extrinsic materials and the 2009 amending legislation was erroneous in determining rectification/binding issues
- Issue: Costs certificates under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)

- Asset Pool: Cash payment to wife of $28,000 (cheque forwarded by husband and held pending proceedings).
- Asset Pool: Real property: shop with upstairs residence in B, Victoria.
- Asset Pool: Real property: husband's residence in W (location abbreviated in reasons).
- Asset Pool: Both properties were registered in joint names as tenants in common at the time.
- Just & Equitable: Substantive s 79 property adjustment was not determined in this appeal; the controversy focused on the validity/binding effect of the financial agreement that would oust Part VIII jurisdiction if binding.

- Agreement Date: 27 July 2009 (post-divorce financial agreement document executed after divorce order)
- Legal Advice: It was uncontroversial that each party received legal advice and signed the annexed certificates acknowledging receipt and comprehension.
- Legal Advice: Trial judge found both parties intended to enter a binding financial agreement and that the wife received clear advice about adequacy and finality (findings were contested on appeal but largely upheld except as to binding certification requirements).
- Legal Advice: On appeal, one ground alleged the wife's solicitor did not advise on advantages; Full Court (Strickland J) rejected that ground, construing s 90G(1)(b) as permitting advice that there were no advantages if none were apparent.

- Outcome: Time for filing a Notice of Appeal extended to 24 August 2010.
- Outcome: Appeal allowed.
- Outcome: Order 2 made by Young J on 30 June 2010 set aside.
- Outcome: Matter remitted to Young J to determine whether the agreement should be declared binding pursuant to s 90G(1A) and (1B) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).
- Outcome: No order as to costs of the appeal.
- Outcome: Costs certificates granted to the wife (s 9 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)) and to the husband (s 6) in respect of appeal costs.

- Reasons: Majority (Strickland and Murphy JJ) held that equitable rectification could correct the s 90C/s 90D misdescription because it concerned the agreement's proper statutory character reflecting the parties' common intention post-divorce.
- Reasons: Majority held that s 90G compliance is the statutory gateway for an agreement to be 'binding' and thus to oust Part VIII; defects in the solicitor certificates were not capable of rectification to manufacture compliance with s 90G(1).
- Reasons: Relief for non-compliance with s 90G(1) lies in the statutory mechanism of s 90G(1A)/(1B), requiring the court to be satisfied it would be unjust and inequitable if the agreement were not binding; that issue required remitter.
- Reasons: The Full Court declined to exercise the s 90G(1A) discretion because of limited/insufficient argument and uncertainty as to the evidence/considerations relevant to 'unjust and inequitable'.
- Reasons: May J dissented, preferring to treat the naming errors as correctable by reading the certificates as referring to the parties and, alternatively, considered the remedial provisions would render it unjust and inequitable for the agreement not to bind; however, the court's orders reflect the majority outcome allowing the appeal and remitting.
- Reasons: Costs: although no costs order was made for the appeal, costs certificates were granted because the appeal succeeded on a question of law and the matter was remitted for rehearing on the binding declaration issue.

- Pivotal Finding: The parties were divorced when they signed the agreement; therefore, the applicable provision for a financial agreement was s 90D, not s 90C.
- Pivotal Finding: The agreement recorded the parties' common intention to finally settle property and exclude Part VIII, and the s 90C references were treated as an error capable of correction to reflect that intention.
- Pivotal Finding: The solicitor certificates, on their face, referred to advice given to the correctly named party but then described advice as to the rights/advantages for different given names, creating a facial defect in meeting s 90G certification requirements.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge erred by purporting to rectify the solicitor certificates to satisfy s 90G(1) and by concluding the agreement was binding under s 90G(1) after such rectification.
- Pivotal Finding: The appropriate next step was remitter for consideration of whether the agreement should be declared binding under s 90G(1A) and (1B), including the 'unjust and inequitable' threshold (with the majority not determining that discretion on appeal).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90D (requirements for post-divorce financial agreement, including being expressed to be made under that section)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1) (mandatory requirements for binding effect, including independent legal advice and signed statements/copies)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1A) and s 90G(1B) (court declaration making an otherwise non-compliant agreement binding if unjust and inequitable not to do so)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 71A (ouster of Part VIII in respect of matters covered by a binding financial agreement)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90KA (application of contract/equity principles to validity/enforceability/effect of financial agreements and purported contracts)
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Justice System Amendment (Efficiency Measures) Act (No 1) 2009 (Cth) Schedule 5 Items 8 and 8A (transitional/retrospective application of amendments to s 90G, discussed particularly by Murphy J)
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9 (costs certificates)

- Uncertainties: Whether, on remitter, the agreement would be declared binding under s 90G(1A) and (1B), including how 'unjust and inequitable' would be applied to the particular non-compliance and the fairness/efficacy of the settlement.
- Uncertainties: Any ultimate property settlement under s 79 was not determined in this appeal and depended on whether the agreement would ultimately be binding or otherwise set aside/enforced.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether leave to appeal was required for an appeal from an interlocutory order granting leave under s 44(3) Family Law Act
Whether the Federal Magistrate erred in granting the husband leave under s 44(3) to institute s 79 property proceedings out of time
Meaning and application of 'hardship' under s 44(4) and the need to assess a prima facie case/prospects of success and likely costs
Exercise of discretion to extend time: delay, explanation, prejudice, merits, and conduct (including bankruptcy-related conduct)
facts: The parties married in September 1982 and separated in late 2001 (wife alleged separation point around 2002 in narrative); divorced February 2004.
The husband remarried in October 2004 and later divorced his second wife in June 2008.
The husband became bankrupt on his own petition in April 2005 and was discharged in April 2008.
The limitation period for commencing property proceedings expired about February 2005 (12 months after divorce).

asset_pool: At/around separation: pharmacy business in T (purchased shortly before separation; figures referenced include purchase about $443,000 plus stock $146,715 funded by a bank loan about $480,000); two vacant blocks of land in T (purchased for $300,000 funded by a loan of $210,000); boat (about $25,000); motor vehicle of little value; wife superannuation about $4,000; joint bank account about $10,000.
Wife’s August 2000 financial statement to bank: assets $859,778 and liabilities $466,711 (historic reference).

At hearing (leave application): wife owned pharmacy with business loan $953,000 and overdraft facility $100,000; two blocks in T valued about $500,000; home valued about $500,000 with mortgage about $227,000; boat with loan about $138,000; motor vehicle; superannuation about $4,000; asserted capital gains tax liability about $50,000.
Husband at hearing: income about $113,500 per annum; superannuation about $33,000; net assets about $17,000.
contributions: Marriage length about 23 years; parties had little assets at relationship commencement.
Wife studied and qualified as a pharmacist during marriage; worked in pharmacy business for years and was primary driver of acquisition and maintenance of pharmacy assets.
Husband performed some unqualified work in pharmacy and ran small businesses; claimed some income contributed to family but also used for flying lessons.
Wife asserted husband was main carer for daughter during a period while wife worked in pharmacy (about five years after 1994 purchase).
future_needs: Husband had obtained tertiary qualifications (Master’s) and employment in health and ageing with substantial income (stated $113,500).
Wife had significant business assets but also significant liabilities (business loan, overdraft, mortgage, boat loan, claimed CGT).
Child was 10 at separation and was 20 by the time of appeal; wife bore child’s costs throughout childhood.
just_equitable: The Full Court’s analysis was confined to whether leave should be granted to commence s 79 proceedings out of time, not a final s 79 alteration.

In assessing hardship, the Full Court considered it not apparent the husband would receive any net property/money after accounting for post-separation benefits received, wife’s sole child support, the aircraft/hangar concession, and likely litigation/valuation costs.
The Court considered it would be inappropriate to allow proceedings that could effectively assist the husband’s avoidance of creditors (in light of transfer/representations during bankruptcy).
living_arrangements: Post-separation the husband lived in a flat attached to the pharmacy in T for a period; later lived with wife in her Gold Coast home from about March to November 2005; wife then arranged and paid rent for a separate unit for about six months.
Husband asserted he moved in to assist with daughter’s care; wife asserted he moved in after separating from his second wife; both agreed he cared for the child during that period.
existing_agreements: Wife asserted an agreement around divorce that she would take sole financial responsibility for the child and husband would receive 30% of then assets; husband denied any agreement.

Email communications in 2006 referred to needing a written agreement about a later settlement despite not finalising within 12 months and to a 'total figure for payout' from which the wife was deducting payments.

income_expenses: Husband income stated at $113,500 per annum at time of hearing (relevant to his financial position).
earning_capacity: Husband obtained tertiary qualifications and employment in health and ageing; described as having substantial income.
health_care: Wife maintained husband on her private health insurance post-separation (benefit referenced in evidence).
relationship_length: Marriage from September 1982 to separation late 2001; described as a 23-year marriage.

child_ages: One child (daughter) born 1992; about 10 years old at separation; 20 years old at time of appeal.
caregiver_history: Wife said husband was main carer for their daughter during about five years after the 1994 pharmacy purchase while wife worked in the business.
After separation, the wife met all expenses for the child; husband made no financial contribution.
In 2005 period on the Gold Coast, husband cared for the child to some extent (not disputed).

outcome_orders: Wife granted leave to file an appeal from the Federal Magistrate’s orders made 3 September 2010.
Appeal allowed.
Husband’s application pursuant to s 44(3) Family Law Act for leave to commence proceedings out of time dismissed (re-determination/refusal).
Wife granted a costs certificate pursuant to s 9 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of appeal costs.

description: This appellate decision clarifies and applies the two-stage approach to s 44(3)/(4) applications: first, the statutory threshold of 'hardship' requiring a reasonable claim to be heard (including consideration of likely substantive outcome and likely costs); second, a discretion informed by delay, explanation, prejudice and conduct. The Full Court found the Federal Magistrate misapplied hardship by treating a 'reasonable expectation' of settlement as sufficient without assessing probable substantive outcome and costs. The Court then re-exercised discretion, concluding no hardship and, in any event, that discretion should be refused due to deliberate delay to avoid creditors/second spouse and potential prejudice to the wife arising from post-separation asset accumulation and refinancing.
pivotal_findings: The first instance approach to hardship was erroneous: finding hardship based on a 'reasonable expectation of property settlement' and potential home purchase did not address the required assessment of a prima facie claim/real probability of success and whether any substantive outcome would alleviate hardship, including likely trial costs.
The husband deliberately chose not to finalise property matters within time, including during bankruptcy, due to concern creditors would claim any settlement monies.
The husband delayed further until shortly after expiry of the period in which his second wife could bring property proceedings, supporting an inference of strategic delay.

The wife made significant post-separation payments/benefits to the husband (conceded around $197,000 plus other benefits) and provided sole financial support for the child; these facts materially reduced the likelihood that the husband would obtain any net property settlement if substantive proceedings were allowed.

A solicitor’s letter to the bankruptcy trustee recorded that the husband did not consider he had any interest in the T land and transferred any interest to discharge a liability to the wife; the husband later asserted an interest, and the Court treated allowing that claim as potentially assisting avoidance of creditors.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 44(3)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 44(4)(a)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 94AA(leave to appeal from interlocutory orders, as discussed by Young J)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) s 9

reasons_rationale: Leave to appeal was required because the order granting s 44(3) leave was interlocutory; leave granted because error of principle/substantial injustice was shown.

The Federal Magistrate failed to undertake the necessary assessment of hardship by considering probable substantive outcome and likely costs, and instead relied on an impermissible formulation (expectation of settlement/home purchase).

Even if hardship had been established, the discretion miscarried due to failure to adequately weigh the husband’s deliberate delay and conduct aimed at avoiding creditors and a potential claim by his second wife.

On re-exercise, the Full Court held hardship was not established because, given the modest pool at separation, extensive post-separation payments/benefits to husband, wife’s sole child support, wife’s concession about aircraft/hangar, and likely litigation costs, it was not apparent the husband would obtain any net benefit from substantive proceedings.
Prejudice considerations included the wife’s post-separation expansion/refinancing and the policy of finality in financial relations and limitation periods.
uncertainties: Exact composition and valuation of the parties’ overall property pool at the time of the s 44 application remained contested and would have required valuations at multiple points in time; the Full Court did not determine a final s 79 division.
Characterisation of post-separation payments (maintenance vs capital advances) was not finally determined; the Court assumed some could be maintenance for the limited hardship assessment.
Disputed aspects included the extent of the husband’s work in the pharmacy, funding sources for acquisitions, and some particular payments claimed by the wife.
