court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether it was just and equitable under s 79(2) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) to make any property settlement order where parties largely lived apart for about 18 years and husband had represented wife could keep Australian assets
Whether trial judge conflated s 79(2) (just and equitable to make an order) with s 79(4) (contributions and other factors) contrary to Stanford v Stanford
Whether trial judge erred by making no s 75(2) adjustment, including failing to consider husband’s accommodation/financial resource arising from cohabitation and occupancy of partner’s home
Whether artwork and jewellery should be included in the asset pool
Whether findings about certain post-1994 financial contributions (share proceeds/inheritance) were unclear or against weight of evidence
facts: Parties married in 1972 and had two sons born 1975 and 1976 (adults by trial).
At trial wife was 64 and husband 66; parties divorced 22 July 2010.
Parties had no significant assets at marriage; achieved financial success over about 20 years; suffered serious downturn in early 1990s.

In 1994 husband left, eventually settled in England and worked as a medical professional; parties thereafter largely lived separate lives but with some continuing interactions and shared property interests.
In 1995 husband gave wife power of attorney and told wife and others she could retain Australian property for herself and children; he would build life elsewhere.

asset_pool: Trial judge identified remaining assets and liabilities (net pool $1,069,000): M town property $2,000,000 less mortgage $1,206,000; husband’s vehicle $4,000; wife’s vehicle $14,000; wife’s household furniture/effects $20,000; remaining art collection $56,000; investment shares and banking $162,000; wife’s jewellery $19,000.
Trial judge excluded sold artwork and various 'incidental items' acquired over years of largely separate lives, except items traceable to marriage/capital pre-individual endeavours.

Trial judge proposed to quarantine 'investment shares and banking' ($162,000) to meet the portion of mortgage relating to the failed investment and sale costs, with any balance to be divided; he then treated remaining property for evaluation as $907,000.
contributions: Trial judge found contributions 1972-1994 were equal and provided the foundation for subsequent assets.
Trial judge recognised wife’s significant post-1994 contributions managing Australian assets and servicing loans, and that she had exclusive use/benefit of Australian property for many years.

Trial judge also found husband made periodic post-1994 financial and non-financial contributions, including deposits of share sale proceeds to joint accounts (around 2000 and again 2003), applying inheritance for wife’s benefit, depositing income when working in Australia (2001 and 2004), and contributing to 2004 renovations of M town property.

Full Court found uncertainty in trial judge’s reasoning and findings about extent/weight of husband’s post-1994 contributions (share proceeds/inheritance) and how they impacted the contribution assessment.
future_needs: Trial judge found no s 75(2) adjustment: parties similar ages (64/66), emerging health issues, reduced capacity, nearing end of working lives, and broadly similar earning capacity/incomes.

Full Court found trial judge erred by not taking into account, in s 75(2) analysis, his own finding that husband’s cohabitation/occupancy of partner’s home was a financial resource meeting accommodation needs (relevant to s 75(2)(b) and (m)).
just_equitable: Central dispute: whether it was just and equitable to make any s 79 order given long separation and husband’s repeated representations that wife could keep Australian property.

Trial judge concluded it was just and equitable to make an order and that parties should share fruits of 1972-1994 and consequences of post-1994 decisions; he considered wife had benefited from exclusive access and husband may have had greater entitlement earlier.
Full Court held trial judge conflated s 79(2) and s 79(4) and did not give independent consideration required by Stanford; representations and long delay were highly relevant to s 79 discretion.
Full Court found trial judge erred in stating there was 'no requirement' to consider representations, and gave undue weight against wife to lack of formalisation of informal arrangements.
living_arrangements: Parties largely lived apart for about 18 years; husband lived in England; wife lived in Australia in M town home.
Husband cohabited with partner in England from 2006; partner owned the home and husband contributed to household expenses.
existing_agreements: No binding financial agreement; husband gave wife power of attorney (1995) and made repeated representations that she could retain Australian property; arrangements were informal and not formally documented under Pt VIIIA.

child_ages: Two sons born 1975 and 1976 (adults by trial).

description: Decided appeal reasons identified appealable error but did not finally redetermine the property settlement; the Full Court stood the matter over for further submissions on redetermination and costs. The significance lies in applying Stanford v Stanford to require a genuine, separate consideration of s 79(2) before altering existing property interests, especially in atypical long-separation cases with representations/understandings about property.
pivotal_findings: Trial judge found husband repeatedly represented wife could keep Australian property and induced her to deal with assets as if hers.
Trial judge nevertheless treated representations as having no direct bearing on entitlement and proceeded to quantify contributions leading to 60/40 outcome before addressing s 79(2).

Full Court found conflation: trial judge’s prior findings and approach prevented proper account of relevant factors on s 79(2), including the significance of post-separation understandings/representations and long delay.
Full Court found error in s 75(2) reasoning: trial judge noted husband’s cohabitation/partner’s home as a resource but did not consider it in the s 75(2) assessment.
Full Court found error/uncertainty in contributions reasoning: lack of clear findings/quantification regarding share proceeds and inheritance and their role in contribution assessment.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(1) (power to alter interests), s 79(2) (just and equitable precondition), s 79(4) (mandatory factors including contributions), s 79(4)(e) incorporating s 75(2) matters
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2)(b) (income, property, financial resources, capacity for gainful employment) and s 75(2)(m) (financial circumstances of cohabitation)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (pseudonym/publication note)
High Court authority: Stanford v Stanford (2012) applied as controlling guidance on separation of s 79(2) and s 79(4) inquiries

reasons_rationale: Full Court accepted that s 79(2) and s 79(4) must not be conflated; trial judge’s reasoning suggested entitlement was assessed under s 79(4) and then effectively treated as sufficient to satisfy s 79(2).

Representations/understandings about post-separation property arrangements and the long delay in asserting a claim were relevant to the discretion whether it was just and equitable to make any order at all.
Trial judge erred by stating there was no requirement to consider representations; later references did not cure the inconsistency or ensure adequate weight.
Trial judge failed to explain the use of findings about husband’s cohabitation/partner’s home as a financial resource when assessing s 75(2), making reasoning unascertainable on that point.
Unclear path of reasoning on post-1994 contributions (share proceeds/inheritance) warranted allowing the related appeal ground.
uncertainties: Final property settlement outcome was not determined by the Full Court in this judgment; redetermination was stood over pending further submissions.
Quantification and impact of husband’s alleged share proceeds and inheritance contributions were not clearly articulated by the trial judge, contributing to appellate intervention.
Extent of any equitable interest of husband in partner’s English home was not determined; treated only as an unquantified financial resource.

- Issue: Whether artwork and jewellery should be included in the asset pool
- Issue: Whether findings about certain post-1994 financial contributions (share proceeds/inheritance) were unclear or against weight of evidence

- Asset Pool: Trial judge identified remaining assets and liabilities (net pool $1,069,000): M town property $2,000,000 less mortgage $1,206,000; husband’s vehicle $4,000; wife’s vehicle $14,000; wife’s household furniture/effects $20,000; remaining art collection $56,000; investment shares and banking $162,000; wife’s jewellery $19,000.
- Asset Pool: Trial judge excluded sold artwork and various 'incidental items' acquired over years of largely separate lives, except items traceable to marriage/capital pre-individual endeavours.
- Asset Pool: Trial judge proposed to quarantine 'investment shares and banking' ($162,000) to meet the portion of mortgage relating to the failed investment and sale costs, with any balance to be divided; he then treated remaining property for evaluation as $907,000.
- Contributions: Trial judge found contributions 1972-1994 were equal and provided the foundation for subsequent assets.
- Contributions: Trial judge recognised wife’s significant post-1994 contributions managing Australian assets and servicing loans, and that she had exclusive use/benefit of Australian property for many years.
- Contributions: Trial judge also found husband made periodic post-1994 financial and non-financial contributions, including deposits of share sale proceeds to joint accounts (around 2000 and again 2003), applying inheritance for wife’s benefit, depositing income when working in Australia (2001 and 2004), and contributing to 2004 renovations of M town property.
- Contributions: Full Court found uncertainty in trial judge’s reasoning and findings about extent/weight of husband’s post-1994 contributions (share proceeds/inheritance) and how they impacted the contribution assessment.
- Future Needs: Trial judge found no s 75(2) adjustment: parties similar ages (64/66), emerging health issues, reduced capacity, nearing end of working lives, and broadly similar earning capacity/incomes.
- Future Needs: Full Court found trial judge erred by not taking into account, in s 75(2) analysis, his own finding that husband’s cohabitation/occupancy of partner’s home was a financial resource meeting accommodation needs (relevant to s 75(2)(b) and (m)).
- Just & Equitable: Central dispute: whether it was just and equitable to make any s 79 order given long separation and husband’s repeated representations that wife could keep Australian property.
- Just & Equitable: Trial judge concluded it was just and equitable to make an order and that parties should share fruits of 1972-1994 and consequences of post-1994 decisions; he considered wife had benefited from exclusive access and husband may have had greater entitlement earlier.
- Just & Equitable: Full Court held trial judge conflated s 79(2) and s 79(4) and did not give independent consideration required by Stanford; representations and long delay were highly relevant to s 79 discretion.
- Just & Equitable: Full Court found trial judge erred in stating there was 'no requirement' to consider representations, and gave undue weight against wife to lack of formalisation of informal arrangements.
- Child Ages: Two sons born 1975 and 1976 (adults by trial).

- Reasons: Full Court accepted that s 79(2) and s 79(4) must not be conflated; trial judge’s reasoning suggested entitlement was assessed under s 79(4) and then effectively treated as sufficient to satisfy s 79(2).
- Reasons: Representations/understandings about post-separation property arrangements and the long delay in asserting a claim were relevant to the discretion whether it was just and equitable to make any order at all.
- Reasons: Trial judge erred by stating there was no requirement to consider representations; later references did not cure the inconsistency or ensure adequate weight.
- Reasons: Trial judge failed to explain the use of findings about husband’s cohabitation/partner’s home as a financial resource when assessing s 75(2), making reasoning unascertainable on that point.
- Reasons: Unclear path of reasoning on post-1994 contributions (share proceeds/inheritance) warranted allowing the related appeal ground.

- Pivotal Finding: Trial judge found husband repeatedly represented wife could keep Australian property and induced her to deal with assets as if hers.
- Pivotal Finding: Trial judge nevertheless treated representations as having no direct bearing on entitlement and proceeded to quantify contributions leading to 60/40 outcome before addressing s 79(2).
- Pivotal Finding: Full Court found conflation: trial judge’s prior findings and approach prevented proper account of relevant factors on s 79(2), including the significance of post-separation understandings/representations and long delay.
- Pivotal Finding: Full Court found error in s 75(2) reasoning: trial judge noted husband’s cohabitation/partner’s home as a resource but did not consider it in the s 75(2) assessment.
- Pivotal Finding: Full Court found error/uncertainty in contributions reasoning: lack of clear findings/quantification regarding share proceeds and inheritance and their role in contribution assessment.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(1) (power to alter interests), s 79(2) (just and equitable precondition), s 79(4) (mandatory factors including contributions), s 79(4)(e) incorporating s 75(2) matters
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2)(b) (income, property, financial resources, capacity for gainful employment) and s 75(2)(m) (financial circumstances of cohabitation)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (pseudonym/publication note)
- Statutory Pivot: High Court authority: Stanford v Stanford (2012) applied as controlling guidance on separation of s 79(2) and s 79(4) inquiries

- Uncertainties: Final property settlement outcome was not determined by the Full Court in this judgment; redetermination was stood over pending further submissions.
- Uncertainties: Quantification and impact of husband’s alleged share proceeds and inheritance contributions were not clearly articulated by the trial judge, contributing to appellate intervention.
- Uncertainties: Extent of any equitable interest of husband in partner’s English home was not determined; treated only as an unquantified financial resource.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from a declaration under s 90RD(1) that no de facto relationship existed for the purposes of the proceeding
Whether the Federal Magistrate applied the correct jurisdictional test for Part VIIIAB de facto financial matters (commencement date 1 March 2009)
Whether necessary jurisdictional factual findings were made (existence and breakdown of a de facto relationship; duration including aggregation to at least two years)
Whether the matter should be remitted for rehearing and whether costs certificates should be granted under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)
facts: The applicant sought relief connected with de facto property settlement jurisdiction (s 90SM) and sought a declaration as to the existence of a de facto relationship.
The parties had a relationship said to span periods between 1999 and August 2009 (as described in the lower court reasons).
In the Federal Magistrates Court, the respondent sought a declaration that a de facto relationship never existed for the purposes of the proceeding (s 90RD(1)).
On 16 December 2011, Coates FM declared under s 90RD(1) that a de facto relationship never existed between the parties for the purposes of the proceeding.

On appeal, the Full Court considered the jurisdictional framework arising from the 2008 Amendment Act introducing Part VIIIAB, the commencement date of 1 March 2009 (as validated in 2012), and the requirement that the de facto relationship not have broken down before commencement.
The appeal succeeded due to error concerning jurisdictional facts and/or absence of necessary findings, resulting in the lower court orders being set aside and the matter remitted.
outcome_orders: The appeal was allowed.
The orders made by Coates FM on 16 December 2011 were set aside.
The matter was remitted to the Federal Circuit Court for rehearing before a Judge other than Judge Coates.
Pursuant to s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth), the appellant was granted a costs certificate for costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
Pursuant to s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth), the appellant was granted a costs certificate for costs incurred in relation to the new trial ordered.
Pursuant to s 6 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth), the respondent was granted a costs certificate for costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
Pursuant to s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth), the respondent was granted a costs certificate for costs incurred in relation to the new trial ordered.

description: This is an appeal decision concerning jurisdictional facts for de facto property proceedings under Part VIIIAB. The Full Court held that the trial judge’s approach miscarried because the required jurisdictional test is not whether a de facto relationship existed on the commencement date (1 March 2009), but whether any de facto relationship broke down after commencement and otherwise met the statutory requirements (including duration, which may be met by aggregation). The error affected jurisdiction and required remitter. The case emphasises careful identification and findings on jurisdictional facts (relationship breakdown timing; whether a de facto relationship existed within s 4AA; and whether the two-year requirement in s 90SB is met, including aggregation).
pivotal_findings: The Federal Magistrate’s reasons did not make specific findings as to when any de facto relationship broke down, despite that being critical to whether the Act applied (relationship must not have broken down finally before 1 March 2009).

A de facto relationship need not be shown to exist on 1 March 2009 to enliven jurisdiction; the jurisdictional requirement is that the de facto relationship broke down after commencement, and the duration requirement may be met by aggregating periods of de facto relationship.

The Federal Magistrate’s concluding reasoning placed determinative emphasis on inability to 'detect' a de facto relationship 'as at 1 March 2009', which was treated as a misdirection as to jurisdictional fact (Murphy J), and in any event was insufficient given missing findings (Strickland J).

Given the lack of clear, determinative findings on the character and timing of the parties’ relationship, the Full Court considered the matter unsuitable for rehearing in the appellate court and ordered remitter for rehearing.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4AA (meaning of de facto relationship)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SB (conditions for making an order under s 90SM, including the at least two years requirement and aggregation concept)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SM (power to make property adjustment orders in de facto matters, if jurisdictional prerequisites satisfied)
Family Law Amendment (De Facto Financial Matters and Other Measures) Act 2008 (Cth) s 86 (Parts apply only where the de facto relationship did not break down before commencement)
Family Law Amendment (Validation of Certain Orders and Other Measures) Act 2012 (Cth) (validation of commencement date issues; commencement now validly 1 March 2009)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 (costs discretion; Full Court considered usual rule and did not award party-party costs, instead issuing Costs Act certificates)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9 (costs certificates for parties following appeal/new trial)

reasons_rationale: Jurisdiction in de facto financial matters depends on statutory jurisdictional facts, including that the de facto relationship broke down after 1 March 2009 and that the relationship meets the s 4AA definition and duration requirements under s 90SB (including aggregation).

The lower court’s reasoning treated existence of a de facto relationship on 1 March 2009 as crucial/determinative, which was an incorrect statement of the jurisdictional requirement (as discussed particularly by Murphy J).

Alternatively and additionally, the lower court failed to make necessary factual findings to support the declaration that a de facto relationship never existed for the purposes of the proceeding, including findings as to when any de facto relationship broke down (Strickland J).

Because of the nature of the factual disputes and the absence/uncertainty of primary findings, the appropriate course was to remit for rehearing before another judge rather than attempt an appellate rehearing.

Although the appeal succeeded, the Full Court did not order costs against the respondent; instead, it granted costs certificates to both parties under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act for the appeal and the rehearing.
uncertainties: The Full Court decision concerns jurisdiction and remitter; it does not determine whether a de facto relationship existed, its periods, or the final breakdown date.
No asset pool, contribution assessment, or property division outcome is determined in this appeal decision.
The ultimate s 90SM property settlement outcome (if any) remains to be determined on rehearing.

- Issue: Whether the matter should be remitted for rehearing and whether costs certificates should be granted under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)

- Reasons: Alternatively and additionally, the lower court failed to make necessary factual findings to support the declaration that a de facto relationship never existed for the purposes of the proceeding, including findings as to when any de facto relationship broke down (Strickland J).

- Reasons: Although the appeal succeeded, the Full Court did not order costs against the respondent; instead, it granted costs certificates to both parties under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act for the appeal and the rehearing.

- Pivotal Finding: The Federal Magistrate’s reasons did not make specific findings as to when any de facto relationship broke down, despite that being critical to whether the Act applied (relationship must not have broken down finally before 1 March 2009).
- Pivotal Finding: A de facto relationship need not be shown to exist on 1 March 2009 to enliven jurisdiction; the jurisdictional requirement is that the de facto relationship broke down after commencement, and the duration requirement may be met by aggregating periods of de facto relationship.
- Pivotal Finding: The Federal Magistrate’s concluding reasoning placed determinative emphasis on inability to 'detect' a de facto relationship 'as at 1 March 2009', which was treated as a misdirection as to jurisdictional fact (Murphy J), and in any event was insufficient given missing findings (Strickland J).
- Pivotal Finding: Given the lack of clear, determinative findings on the character and timing of the parties’ relationship, the Full Court considered the matter unsuitable for rehearing in the appellate court and ordered remitter for rehearing.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4AA (meaning of de facto relationship)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SB (conditions for making an order under s 90SM, including the at least two years requirement and aggregation concept)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SM (power to make property adjustment orders in de facto matters, if jurisdictional prerequisites satisfied)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Amendment (De Facto Financial Matters and Other Measures) Act 2008 (Cth) s 86 (Parts apply only where the de facto relationship did not break down before commencement)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Amendment (Validation of Certain Orders and Other Measures) Act 2012 (Cth) (validation of commencement date issues; commencement now validly 1 March 2009)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 (costs discretion; Full Court considered usual rule and did not award party-party costs, instead issuing Costs Act certificates)
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9 (costs certificates for parties following appeal/new trial)

- Uncertainties: The Full Court decision concerns jurisdiction and remitter; it does not determine whether a de facto relationship existed, its periods, or the final breakdown date.
- Uncertainties: No asset pool, contribution assessment, or property division outcome is determined in this appeal decision.
- Uncertainties: The ultimate s 90SM property settlement outcome (if any) remains to be determined on rehearing.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Leave to appeal against dismissal of application to discharge/vary child support departure orders
Whether there was a relevant change of circumstances affecting the father’s financial capacity such that the 2006 departure orders became unjust and inequitable

Whether the trial judge failed to consider relevant evidence about the father’s income, property, financial resources, liabilities and commitments under Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(2)(c)(ia)
Whether the trial judge properly considered the mandatory 'just and equitable' factors in s 117(4) and related provisions when making/maintaining periodic and school expense orders
Validity of order requiring father to pay half of children’s private school fees and education expenses and whether reasons were adequate
Treatment of child support and school fee arrears and enforcement/security orders over the father’s properties
facts: Parties married in 1991 and separated in August 2003; divorced.
Two children: M born 1998 and L born 2000.
Consent orders dated 19 September 2006 made property settlement and child support departure orders.

2006 child support departure orders required the father to pay $225 per week per child (indexed) and to pay the costs of the children’s private schooling at X School (tuition, textbooks, literacy/maths fees) while they attended from Kindergarten to Year 12.

The father later commenced proceedings (application filed 18 December 2008; amended culminating 26 April 2012) seeking to vary/discharge child support orders, asserting his income/assets had fallen dramatically.
The mother and children moved to Town B in February 2010 and lived with the maternal grandmother.

At first instance (Watts J, 2 November 2012), the father’s application to discharge 2006 orders was dismissed; arrears were declared and secured over two properties (O Street and N Road); and the father was ordered to pay half of the children’s private school fees and related expenses.

existing_agreements: 2006 consent property settlement: father transferred to mother his interest in W Street (sold; mother received $310,000 from proceeds of a different property as recorded) and transferred to her seven parcels of land in the United States (with a sharing mechanism if sold for more than US $1.7 million).
Otherwise each retained property in their own names and assumed sole liability for encumbrances secured thereon.

child_ages: M born 1998
L born 2000
current_arrangements: At first instance the children were to continue living with the mother, who had sole parental responsibility.

Time with father: one weekend each month travelling to where he lives; subject to conditions, one weekend a month in Town B; and time in school holidays (arrangements stated to continue until end of 2013 school holidays).
After that time period: the older child may elect whether to spend time with the father; if she decides not to, the younger child would see him only if she wants.
caregiver_history: The children lived with the mother; mother and children moved to Town B in February 2010 and lived with the maternal grandmother.
safety_concerns: Trial judge made a suite of injunctions designed to protect the children and promote their welfare (details not set out in the provided text).
child_views: Orders contemplated the older child’s election about spending time with the father after the end of the 2013 school holidays and the younger child’s wishes if the older child did not spend time.
expert_evidence: Independent Children’s Lawyer involved.
Single expert report by a psychiatrist contributed to resolution of many parenting issues.
best_interests: Parenting outcomes were agreed/resolved with professional assistance; trial judge’s orders kept the children living with the mother with limited time with the father.
orders: Parenting orders were made at first instance, including mother having sole parental responsibility and a structured time arrangement with the father (as summarised above).

outcome_orders: Leave to appeal granted against Orders 39–46 (inclusive) made 2 November 2012.
Appeal allowed in part.
Order 45 dated 2 November 2012 (father to pay one half of children’s private schooling tuition fees, textbooks, literacy/maths fees) set aside.

For the period commencing from 11 April 2012, Orders 39 and 42 dated 2 November 2012 were set aside to the extent they dismissed the father’s application to discharge Orders 3–6 dated 19 September 2006.
Outstanding child support applications as a consequence of the appeal remitted for rehearing before a judge other than Watts J.
No order as to the costs of the appeal.

description: The Full Court applied the statutory three-stage framework in Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117 (ground for departure; then 'just and equitable' under s 117(4); then 'otherwise proper' under s 117(5)). A decisive turning point was the father’s evidence of a major change in financial circumstances around 11 April 2012 (receivers appointed to entities tied to his principal asset), which the trial judge did not grapple with when assessing whether a post-2006 change made continued operation of the departure orders unjust and inequitable. The Full Court held that liabilities/commitments are relevant to the 'income, property and financial resources' inquiry for s 117(2)(c)(ia), consistent with Ross v McDermott, and that the trial judge failed to address mandatory s 117(4) factors when ordering school expense contributions (via s 124). The result was partial appellate intervention: the matter was remitted for rehearing limited to post-11 April 2012 periodic and non-periodic support issues, while earlier arrears findings largely stood.
pivotal_findings: The trial judge failed to consider significant relevant evidence about the father’s financial position, including detailed liabilities/commitments and the appointment of receivers on 11 April 2012 to Z and the P Suburb joint venture (the father’s asserted major asset).

The trial judge did not properly apply or explain the s 117(4) 'just and equitable' considerations (and related provisions) before refusing to discharge/vary post-11 April 2012 child support obligations and before making the school expenses order.

For the period prior to 11 April 2012, the father did not establish the relevant change in circumstances required to revisit the 2006 departure order; dismissal of retrospective variation up to 11 April 2012 was upheld (with only a de minimis post-change period noted).

Arrears for periodic child support accrued because the father unilaterally reduced payments; the trial judge’s approach to arrears and to unpaid 2009 school fees being added to arrears was not shown to warrant appellate intervention.
The enforcement-related order allowing application for sale was described as otiose (because enforcement rights existed anyway) but not wrongly made.
statutory_pivots: Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(1) and s 117(2)(c)(ia) (ground for departure based on income, property and financial resources of either parent)
Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(4) (mandatory 'just and equitable' considerations, including commitments and hardship) and s 117(5) ('otherwise proper')

Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) ss 118 and 124 (departure orders and orders for non-periodic payments/education costs), and associated provisions referred to in the reasons (ss 121, 123, 125, 129)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval of pseudonym/publication noted)

reasons_rationale: The Full Court held that, in varying/discharging an existing departure order, the Court must determine whether a relevant change of circumstances since the earlier order establishes a ground for departure; it rejected the father’s submission that change of circumstances was irrelevant.

The trial judge’s reasons showed uncertainty about the parties’ financial frankness, but did not engage with substantial evidence bearing on the father’s financial capacity and commitments, including receivership and detailed liabilities, amounting to failure to consider relevant evidence.

The trial judge failed to address the required statutory considerations in s 117(4) when determining whether it was just and equitable (and otherwise proper) to maintain/alter child support and to impose an order for shared private school expenses under s 124.

The school fees order was set aside because the statutory pathway (including s 124 incorporating s 117(4) factors) was not properly applied; omission under s 125 was treated as a slip-rule type issue but not determinative given broader errors.

Arrears and unpaid school fees were largely upheld because the father had taken 'the law into his own hands' by unilaterally reducing payments and because the relevant change in circumstances was found to occur only from 11 April 2012.
uncertainties: The Full Court decision remitted post-11 April 2012 child support and school expense issues for rehearing; final amounts/payments from that date were not determined in this judgment.
The exact quantum of the father’s income and the full value/net position of his retained assets were not precisely found, with credibility concerns noted in the trial judge’s findings.
The detailed content of the parenting injunctions and protective orders was not set out in the provided text.

summary_text:
- Fact: Parties married in 1991 and separated in August 2003; divorced.
- Fact: Two children: M born 1998 and L born 2000.
- Fact: Consent orders dated 19 September 2006 made property settlement and child support departure orders.
- Fact: 2006 child support departure orders required the father to pay $225 per week per child (indexed) and to pay the costs of the children’s private schooling at X School (tuition, textbooks, literacy/maths fees) while they attended from Kindergarten to Year 12.
- Fact: The father later commenced proceedings (application filed 18 December 2008; amended culminating 26 April 2012) seeking to vary/discharge child support orders, asserting his income/assets had fallen dramatically.
- Fact: The mother and children moved to Town B in February 2010 and lived with the maternal grandmother.
- Fact: At first instance (Watts J, 2 November 2012), the father’s application to discharge 2006 orders was dismissed; arrears were declared and secured over two properties (O Street and N Road); and the father was ordered to pay half of the children’s private school fees and related expenses.

- Issue: Leave to appeal against dismissal of application to discharge/vary child support departure orders
- Issue: Whether there was a relevant change of circumstances affecting the father’s financial capacity such that the 2006 departure orders became unjust and inequitable
- Issue: Whether the trial judge failed to consider relevant evidence about the father’s income, property, financial resources, liabilities and commitments under Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(2)(c)(ia)
- Issue: Whether the trial judge properly considered the mandatory 'just and equitable' factors in s 117(4) and related provisions when making/maintaining periodic and school expense orders
- Issue: Validity of order requiring father to pay half of children’s private school fees and education expenses and whether reasons were adequate
- Issue: Treatment of child support and school fee arrears and enforcement/security orders over the father’s properties

- Child Ages: M born 1998
- Child Ages: L born 2000
- Current Arrangements: At first instance the children were to continue living with the mother, who had sole parental responsibility.
- Current Arrangements: Time with father: one weekend each month travelling to where he lives; subject to conditions, one weekend a month in Town B; and time in school holidays (arrangements stated to continue until end of 2013 school holidays).
- Current Arrangements: After that time period: the older child may elect whether to spend time with the father; if she decides not to, the younger child would see him only if she wants.
- Safety Concerns: Trial judge made a suite of injunctions designed to protect the children and promote their welfare (details not set out in the provided text).
- Best Interests: Parenting outcomes were agreed/resolved with professional assistance; trial judge’s orders kept the children living with the mother with limited time with the father.

- Outcome: Leave to appeal granted against Orders 39–46 (inclusive) made 2 November 2012.
- Outcome: Appeal allowed in part.
- Outcome: Order 45 dated 2 November 2012 (father to pay one half of children’s private schooling tuition fees, textbooks, literacy/maths fees) set aside.
- Outcome: For the period commencing from 11 April 2012, Orders 39 and 42 dated 2 November 2012 were set aside to the extent they dismissed the father’s application to discharge Orders 3–6 dated 19 September 2006.
- Outcome: Outstanding child support applications as a consequence of the appeal remitted for rehearing before a judge other than Watts J.
- Outcome: No order as to the costs of the appeal.

- Reasons: The Full Court held that, in varying/discharging an existing departure order, the Court must determine whether a relevant change of circumstances since the earlier order establishes a ground for departure; it rejected the father’s submission that change of circumstances was irrelevant.
- Reasons: The trial judge’s reasons showed uncertainty about the parties’ financial frankness, but did not engage with substantial evidence bearing on the father’s financial capacity and commitments, including receivership and detailed liabilities, amounting to failure to consider relevant evidence.
- Reasons: The trial judge failed to address the required statutory considerations in s 117(4) when determining whether it was just and equitable (and otherwise proper) to maintain/alter child support and to impose an order for shared private school expenses under s 124.
- Reasons: The school fees order was set aside because the statutory pathway (including s 124 incorporating s 117(4) factors) was not properly applied; omission under s 125 was treated as a slip-rule type issue but not determinative given broader errors.
- Reasons: Arrears and unpaid school fees were largely upheld because the father had taken 'the law into his own hands' by unilaterally reducing payments and because the relevant change in circumstances was found to occur only from 11 April 2012.

- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge failed to consider significant relevant evidence about the father’s financial position, including detailed liabilities/commitments and the appointment of receivers on 11 April 2012 to Z and the P Suburb joint venture (the father’s asserted major asset).
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge did not properly apply or explain the s 117(4) 'just and equitable' considerations (and related provisions) before refusing to discharge/vary post-11 April 2012 child support obligations and before making the school expenses order.
- Pivotal Finding: For the period prior to 11 April 2012, the father did not establish the relevant change in circumstances required to revisit the 2006 departure order; dismissal of retrospective variation up to 11 April 2012 was upheld (with only a de minimis post-change period noted).
- Pivotal Finding: Arrears for periodic child support accrued because the father unilaterally reduced payments; the trial judge’s approach to arrears and to unpaid 2009 school fees being added to arrears was not shown to warrant appellate intervention.
- Pivotal Finding: The enforcement-related order allowing application for sale was described as otiose (because enforcement rights existed anyway) but not wrongly made.
- Statutory Pivot: Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(1) and s 117(2)(c)(ia) (ground for departure based on income, property and financial resources of either parent)
- Statutory Pivot: Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(4) (mandatory 'just and equitable' considerations, including commitments and hardship) and s 117(5) ('otherwise proper')
- Statutory Pivot: Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) ss 118 and 124 (departure orders and orders for non-periodic payments/education costs), and associated provisions referred to in the reasons (ss 121, 123, 125, 129)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval of pseudonym/publication noted)

- Uncertainties: The Full Court decision remitted post-11 April 2012 child support and school expense issues for rehearing; final amounts/payments from that date were not determined in this judgment.
- Uncertainties: The exact quantum of the father’s income and the full value/net position of his retained assets were not precisely found, with credibility concerns noted in the trial judge’s findings.
- Uncertainties: The detailed content of the parenting injunctions and protective orders was not set out in the provided text.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from dismissal of wife's application to declare a s 90C financial agreement non-binding or set aside
Whether the binding financial agreement complied with s 90G(1)(b) requirement for independent legal advice
Allocation and operation of the onus of proof concerning whether a financial agreement is binding
Whether reliance on a solicitor's certificate and recitals creates prima facie proof of advice and shifts an evidentiary burden
Appropriate appellate disposition: re-exercise discretion or remit for rehearing
Costs and costs certificates under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)
facts: The parties commenced cohabitation in 1984 and married in 1985.
They have two children: X born 1991 and Y born 1994.
The parties separated on 26 September 2008; the separation was initiated by the wife who had formed a new relationship.
Since separation the children have lived with the husband.
During the marriage the parties operated a business, L Pty Ltd.
On 29 September 2008 the husband transferred a large sum of money from the business account into an account in his sole name.
The parties negotiated a property settlement after separation, including discussions that the husband retain the business and the home.

asset_pool: Former matrimonial home (unencumbered) allocated to husband under the agreement
Business interests: L Pty Ltd allocated to husband under the agreement
Cash in bank (remainder) allocated to husband under the agreement; wife had received $40,000 already as part-payment
Superannuation: each party retained their own superannuation under the agreement
Shares: wife retained some shares under the agreement
Motor vehicle: wife retained a motor vehicle under the agreement
Furniture and chattels divided equally (half each) under the agreement
Values stated in reasons: wife received property valued at $185,000; husband received property valued at $995,000 (approx. 15%/85% split in husband's favour)
contributions: The parties operated a business during the marriage (L Pty Ltd), but the appeal decision does not determine respective contributions for final property adjustment.
just_equitable: The appeal did not determine a just and equitable final property division; it concerned whether the financial agreement was binding due to compliance with s 90G legal advice requirements.
living_arrangements: After separation, the children lived with the husband.
existing_agreements: Binding Financial Agreement under s 90C dated 24 November 2008 (execution dates: wife 24 November 2008; husband 27 November 2008).

The wife sought a declaration that the agreement is non-binding for non-compliance with s 90G(1)(b) (independent legal advice), alternatively to set aside for duress/unconscionable conduct; duress/unconscionability dismissal was not appealed.

relationship_length: Cohabitation commenced 1984; marriage 1985; separation 26 September 2008.

child_ages: X born 1991
Y born 1994
current_arrangements: Since separation the children have lived with the husband.

incidents: The wife alleged the husband threatened to disclose her private emails and said it would 'cost' her if she wanted 'out'; the husband denied ever threatening her.

legal_advice: Certificate annexed to the agreement signed by Mr York dated 24 November 2008 stating he provided the wife independent legal advice required by the Act.
Husband signed with Mr Turvey on 27 November 2008 who provided a similar certificate for the husband.
Dispute: wife asserted she did not receive the advice required by s 90G(1)(b) (effect on rights; advantages/disadvantages) before signing.
pressure_duress: At first instance the wife alleged duress and unconscionable conduct; those claims were dismissed and not appealed.

outcome_orders: The appeal be allowed.
The order made by Federal Magistrate Terry on 10 January 2012 be set aside.

The proceedings wherein the wife seeks a declaration that the agreement dated 24 November 2008 be declared non-binding be remitted to the Federal Circuit Court for rehearing by a judge other than Judge Terry.
There be no order as to costs.
Costs certificate granted to the appellant wife pursuant to s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of the costs incurred by the wife in relation to the appeal.
Costs certificate granted to the respondent husband pursuant to s 6 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of the costs incurred by the husband in relation to the appeal.

description: This appeal concerns the threshold requirements for a binding financial agreement, focusing on the correct allocation of the legal onus under s 90G and the evidentiary effect of a solicitor's certificate of advice. The Full Court held the trial decision was unsafe because the Federal Magistrate treated the wife as bearing the onus of proving she did not receive advice, contrary to later authoritative guidance in Hoult & Hoult. The case highlights that a certificate and recitals can constitute prima facie evidence of compliance, shifting only an evidentiary burden to the challenger, while the legal burden remains on the party asserting the agreement is binding. The matter was remitted because the misallocation of onus infected the fact-finding process and prevented reliable appellate re-exercise of discretion.
pivotal_findings: The Federal Magistrate erred by approaching the case on the basis that the wife bore the onus of proving she had not been provided with the requisite independent legal advice.
In light of Hoult & Hoult, the legal onus of establishing the agreement is binding (including proof of provision of advice) lies on the party seeking to rely on the agreement (here, the husband).

A solicitor's certificate and supporting recitals are prima facie evidence of compliance and can satisfy the proponent's initial onus, creating an inference the advice was given and shifting an evidentiary burden to the other party to throw compliance into doubt.

The wife adduced evidence denying receipt of the requisite advice; the solicitor was not called; and the solicitor's file note of the signing appointment did not indicate the advice was given; the husband conceded the requisite advice was not given at meetings he attended.
Given the wrong onus applied below, it was not apparent how the Federal Magistrate concluded the wife's evidence was insufficient; the decision was unsafe and had to be set aside.

The Full Court did not determine whether s 90G(1A) could save the agreement because it was not raised at first instance and was not decided; it rejected the suggestion the Federal Magistrate effectively made a finding under s 90G(1A)(c).
No appeal was pursued against the Federal Magistrate's dismissal of the alternative grounds alleging duress or unconscionable conduct; the remittal was confined to the non-binding (s 90G) issue.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90C
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1)(b)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1A)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K (referred to as distinct from s 90G(1A) issues)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (pseudonym/publication approval)

reasons_rationale: The appeal succeeded because the primary judge misapplied the onus of proof concerning whether the financial agreement was binding, rendering the decision unsafe.
Applying Hoult & Hoult, the party asserting the agreement is binding bears the legal onus; a certificate and recitals provide prima facie proof but do not make the certificate unassailable.
The misallocation of onus prevented the Full Court from re-exercising discretion; the matter required rehearing before a different judge.
No costs order was made because the error was a question of law and both parties had contributed to the error; costs certificates were appropriate.
uncertainties: Whether, on rehearing, the court will find the requisite s 90G(1)(b) advice was in fact provided to the wife notwithstanding the certificate and the wife's denial.
Whether s 90G(1A) may be raised and, if so, whether it would be 'unjust and inequitable' for the agreement not to be binding (disregarding changes since the agreement).
The ultimate status of the financial agreement (binding or non-binding) and any consequent property adjustment are not determined in this appeal judgment.

- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (pseudonym/publication approval)

- Uncertainties: Whether, on rehearing, the court will find the requisite s 90G(1)(b) advice was in fact provided to the wife notwithstanding the certificate and the wife's denial.
- Uncertainties: Whether s 90G(1A) may be raised and, if so, whether it would be 'unjust and inequitable' for the agreement not to be binding (disregarding changes since the agreement).
- Uncertainties: The ultimate status of the financial agreement (binding or non-binding) and any consequent property adjustment are not determined in this appeal judgment.

summary_sections.text:
- Fact: The parties commenced cohabitation in 1984 and married in 1985.
- Fact: They have two children: X born 1991 and Y born 1994.
- Fact: The parties separated on 26 September 2008; the separation was initiated by the wife who had formed a new relationship.
- Fact: Since separation the children have lived with the husband.
- Fact: During the marriage the parties operated a business, L Pty Ltd.
- Fact: On 29 September 2008 the husband transferred a large sum of money from the business account into an account in his sole name.
- Fact: The parties negotiated a property settlement after separation, including discussions that the husband retain the business and the home.

- Issue: Appeal from dismissal of wife's application to declare a s 90C financial agreement non-binding or set aside
- Issue: Whether the binding financial agreement complied with s 90G(1)(b) requirement for independent legal advice
- Issue: Allocation and operation of the onus of proof concerning whether a financial agreement is binding
- Issue: Whether reliance on a solicitor's certificate and recitals creates prima facie proof of advice and shifts an evidentiary burden
- Issue: Appropriate appellate disposition: re-exercise discretion or remit for rehearing
- Issue: Costs and costs certificates under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)

- Asset Pool: Former matrimonial home (unencumbered) allocated to husband under the agreement
- Asset Pool: Business interests: L Pty Ltd allocated to husband under the agreement
- Asset Pool: Cash in bank (remainder) allocated to husband under the agreement; wife had received $40,000 already as part-payment
- Asset Pool: Superannuation: each party retained their own superannuation under the agreement
- Asset Pool: Shares: wife retained some shares under the agreement
- Asset Pool: Motor vehicle: wife retained a motor vehicle under the agreement
- Asset Pool: Furniture and chattels divided equally (half each) under the agreement
- Asset Pool: Values stated in reasons: wife received property valued at $185,000; husband received property valued at $995,000 (approx. 15%/85% split in husband's favour)
- Contributions: The parties operated a business during the marriage (L Pty Ltd), but the appeal decision does not determine respective contributions for final property adjustment.
- Just & Equitable: The appeal did not determine a just and equitable final property division; it concerned whether the financial agreement was binding due to compliance with s 90G legal advice requirements.

- Child Ages: X born 1991
- Child Ages: Y born 1994
- Current Arrangements: Since separation the children have lived with the husband.
- Incidents: The wife alleged the husband threatened to disclose her private emails and said it would 'cost' her if she wanted 'out'; the husband denied ever threatening her.

- Agreement Date: 24 November 2008 (wife signed; agreement dated 24 November 2008)
- Legal Advice: Certificate annexed to the agreement signed by Mr York dated 24 November 2008 stating he provided the wife independent legal advice required by the Act.
- Legal Advice: Husband signed with Mr Turvey on 27 November 2008 who provided a similar certificate for the husband.
- Legal Advice: Dispute: wife asserted she did not receive the advice required by s 90G(1)(b) (effect on rights; advantages/disadvantages) before signing.
- Pressure/Duress: At first instance the wife alleged duress and unconscionable conduct; those claims were dismissed and not appealed.

- Outcome: The appeal be allowed.
- Outcome: The order made by Federal Magistrate Terry on 10 January 2012 be set aside.
- Outcome: The proceedings wherein the wife seeks a declaration that the agreement dated 24 November 2008 be declared non-binding be remitted to the Federal Circuit Court for rehearing by a judge other than Judge Terry.
- Outcome: There be no order as to costs.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the appellant wife pursuant to s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of the costs incurred by the wife in relation to the appeal.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the respondent husband pursuant to s 6 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of the costs incurred by the husband in relation to the appeal.

- Reasons: The appeal succeeded because the primary judge misapplied the onus of proof concerning whether the financial agreement was binding, rendering the decision unsafe.
- Reasons: Applying Hoult & Hoult, the party asserting the agreement is binding bears the legal onus; a certificate and recitals provide prima facie proof but do not make the certificate unassailable.
- Reasons: The misallocation of onus prevented the Full Court from re-exercising discretion; the matter required rehearing before a different judge.
- Reasons: No costs order was made because the error was a question of law and both parties had contributed to the error; costs certificates were appropriate.

- Pivotal Finding: The Federal Magistrate erred by approaching the case on the basis that the wife bore the onus of proving she had not been provided with the requisite independent legal advice.
- Pivotal Finding: In light of Hoult & Hoult, the legal onus of establishing the agreement is binding (including proof of provision of advice) lies on the party seeking to rely on the agreement (here, the husband).
- Pivotal Finding: A solicitor's certificate and supporting recitals are prima facie evidence of compliance and can satisfy the proponent's initial onus, creating an inference the advice was given and shifting an evidentiary burden to the other party to throw compliance into doubt.
- Pivotal Finding: The wife adduced evidence denying receipt of the requisite advice; the solicitor was not called; and the solicitor's file note of the signing appointment did not indicate the advice was given; the husband conceded the requisite advice was not given at meetings he attended.
- Pivotal Finding: Given the wrong onus applied below, it was not apparent how the Federal Magistrate concluded the wife's evidence was insufficient; the decision was unsafe and had to be set aside.
- Pivotal Finding: The Full Court did not determine whether s 90G(1A) could save the agreement because it was not raised at first instance and was not decided; it rejected the suggestion the Federal Magistrate effectively made a finding under s 90G(1A)(c).
- Pivotal Finding: No appeal was pursued against the Federal Magistrate's dismissal of the alternative grounds alleging duress or unconscionable conduct; the remittal was confined to the non-binding (s 90G) issue.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90C
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1)(b)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1A)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K (referred to as distinct from s 90G(1A) issues)
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (pseudonym/publication approval)

- Uncertainties: Whether, on rehearing, the court will find the requisite s 90G(1)(b) advice was in fact provided to the wife notwithstanding the certificate and the wife's denial.
- Uncertainties: Whether s 90G(1A) may be raised and, if so, whether it would be 'unjust and inequitable' for the agreement not to be binding (disregarding changes since the agreement).
- Uncertainties: The ultimate status of the financial agreement (binding or non-binding) and any consequent property adjustment are not determined in this appeal judgment.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether the Court should make consent property orders under s 79 in an intact marriage (no separation)
Whether it was 'just and equitable' under s 79(2) to alter existing property interests by consent in the circumstances
Whether the primary judge erred by characterising the application as an abuse of process to avoid stamp duty
Whether insufficient information (including superannuation details, contributions, and circumstances) prevented satisfaction of s 79 requirements
Whether making such an order would preclude future property settlement orders if the parties later separated
facts: The parties were married and their marriage was intact (not broken down) at the time of the application.
They filed an Application for Consent Orders under r 10.15 of the Family Law Rules 2004 seeking a property alteration order under s 79.
The proposed consent order sought transfer of the ACT family home from the husband's sole name to joint tenancy between husband and wife.
The home was stated to be worth $850,000 and was the parties' principal residence; they lived there with a young daughter.
The application stated the husband had a vehicle, furnishings, and $10,000 in a bank account; the wife had furnishings worth $20,000 and $10,000 in a bank account; there were no liabilities.

asset_pool: ACT family home valued at $850,000, registered in the husband's name (sought to be transferred to joint tenancy)
Husband: motor vehicle, furnishings, and $10,000 in bank funds (as stated in consent material)
Wife: furnishings worth $20,000 and $10,000 in bank funds (as stated in consent material)
Husband: defined benefit superannuation interest (appears to be in payment phase); detail not sufficiently provided for the Court to be satisfied
Liabilities: none stated
contributions: Little evidence was provided about contributions to acquisition/improvement of the home; the Court inferred the husband likely acquired the property because it was in his name.
The Court noted it could infer some homemaker/parent contributions by the wife given there was a young child, but there was no evidence provided of such contributions.
future_needs: The husband was retired and receiving/supported by superannuation (defined benefit in payment phase).
The wife was not working at the time; her earning capacity was described as potentially high but contingent upon completing Australian professional registration.
The husband stated he expected to receive substantial assets from his family in the near future, but these were not identified.
just_equitable: The Full Court held that, even with consent, the Court must be satisfied under s 79(2) that it is just and equitable to make an order.

The Court found no principled reason (per Stanford) to interfere with existing property interests during an intact marriage where the transfer could be achieved outside court with nominal duty and where there was no demonstrated utility for invoking s 79.

The Court considered the absence of independent legal advice (particularly for the wife), language/cultural vulnerability concerns raised by the husband's evidence, and lack of evidence about contributions and circumstances as weighing against making orders.
living_arrangements: The parties lived together in the family home with their young daughter.
existing_agreements: No binding financial agreement under Part VIIIA (s 90G) was in place.
The consent order application did not record completion of a statement of independent legal advice.

earning_capacity: Wife described as having high potential earning capacity dependent on Australian professional registration; not working at the time (in the consent material).
relationship_length: Wife migrated to Australia in 2009 to marry the husband; the marriage was ongoing at the time of the 2012 application.

child_ages: One 'young daughter' (exact age not stated).
current_arrangements: Child lived with both parents in the family home.
safety_concerns: No allegations of abuse or family violence were described; the Court expressed concern about the wife lacking independent legal advice and potentially limited English, relevant to informed consent rather than physical safety.

legal_advice: The consent order materials did not include a completed 'Statement of independent legal advice'.
The Full Court treated the lack of evidence of independent legal advice (especially for the wife) as a relevant concern when considering whether to make consent orders.
financial_disclosure: The application disclosed some assets and stated no liabilities, but did not sufficiently detail the husband's superannuation and did not identify expected 'substantial' family assets.

outcome_orders: The appeal against the order of Deputy Chief Justice Faulks made on 27 April 2012 was dismissed.
The Full Court declined to re-exercise discretion to make the proposed consent order transferring the family home into joint tenancy.

description: The case confirms that consent is not enough to obtain s 79 property orders, especially in an intact marriage. Following Stanford, the Court must first identify a principled reason to alter existing legal and equitable interests and must be satisfied the order is just and equitable under s 79(2) before considering s 79(4) factors. The availability of an alternative non-court mechanism (transfer under the Duties Act with nominal duty) and the absence of evidence explaining the utility of invoking s 79 were decisive. The appeal succeeded on some error findings below (stamp duty avoidance and preclusion of future orders), but was dismissed on re-exercise because the threshold 'just and equitable' requirement was not met on the evidence.
pivotal_findings: The parties' marriage was intact; they were not separated and there was no marital breakdown-related controversy requiring property adjustment.

The trial judge erred in finding the 'sole purpose' was stamp duty avoidance because the Duties Act could allow the transfer with nominal duty; nevertheless, this did not justify making the s 79 order.

The trial judge erred in stating the order would permanently preclude future property settlement; the Full Court relied on Gabel & Yardley to confirm s 79 power may not be 'spent' and can be exercised by successive orders in appropriate cases.

On re-exercise, the Full Court found no demonstrated utility or principled reason for court intervention where the parties could transfer title directly and cheaply, and where the consent order could be superseded by later events (e.g., relationship breakdown) yet still lacked justification in an intact marriage.

There was insufficient evidence on contributions and the husband's superannuation, and no evidence of independent legal advice for the wife; combined with her migrant status and possible language limitations, the Court was not satisfied it was just and equitable to make the order.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(2) (threshold: just and equitable to make any order)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) (matters to be taken into account once threshold met)
Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) r 10.15 (procedure for Application for Consent Orders)
Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) r 18.10 (review of Registrar decision; hearing de novo)
Duties Act 1999 (ACT) s 72 (concessional duty on certain partner transfers of principal place of residence)

reasons_rationale: Even if errors were identified in the primary judge's reasoning, the Full Court re-exercised discretion and asked whether it was just and equitable to make the order.
In an intact marriage, s 79 can be exercised but requires a principled reason to interfere with existing property interests; none was demonstrated on the evidence.
The proposed transfer could be achieved outside the Family Court under ACT duties legislation with only nominal duty, undermining any necessity or utility for s 79 orders.
The materials did not provide sufficient evidence of contributions or full financial context (notably superannuation details and unidentified expected family assets).

The lack of independent legal advice and concerns about the wife's understanding (including potential language limitations) weighed against granting the court's imprimatur on a significant property change.
Accordingly, the Court declined to make the consent order and dismissed the appeal.
uncertainties: Exact age of the child is not stated.
Detailed valuation and nature of the husband's superannuation and income are not set out beyond being a defined benefit interest in payment phase.
The extent of the wife's English proficiency and understanding of the proposed orders was not established by evidence; it was raised as a concern.

summary_text:
- Fact: The parties were married and their marriage was intact (not broken down) at the time of the application.
- Fact: They filed an Application for Consent Orders under r 10.15 of the Family Law Rules 2004 seeking a property alteration order under s 79.
- Fact: The proposed consent order sought transfer of the ACT family home from the husband's sole name to joint tenancy between husband and wife.
- Fact: The home was stated to be worth $850,000 and was the parties' principal residence; they lived there with a young daughter.
- Fact: The application stated the husband had a vehicle, furnishings, and $10,000 in a bank account; the wife had furnishings worth $20,000 and $10,000 in a bank account; there were no liabilities.

- Issue: Whether the Court should make consent property orders under s 79 in an intact marriage (no separation)
- Issue: Whether it was 'just and equitable' under s 79(2) to alter existing property interests by consent in the circumstances
- Issue: Whether the primary judge erred by characterising the application as an abuse of process to avoid stamp duty
- Issue: Whether insufficient information (including superannuation details, contributions, and circumstances) prevented satisfaction of s 79 requirements
- Issue: Whether making such an order would preclude future property settlement orders if the parties later separated

- Asset Pool: ACT family home valued at $850,000, registered in the husband's name (sought to be transferred to joint tenancy)
- Asset Pool: Husband: motor vehicle, furnishings, and $10,000 in bank funds (as stated in consent material)
- Asset Pool: Wife: furnishings worth $20,000 and $10,000 in bank funds (as stated in consent material)
- Asset Pool: Husband: defined benefit superannuation interest (appears to be in payment phase); detail not sufficiently provided for the Court to be satisfied
- Asset Pool: Liabilities: none stated
- Contributions: Little evidence was provided about contributions to acquisition/improvement of the home; the Court inferred the husband likely acquired the property because it was in his name.
- Contributions: The Court noted it could infer some homemaker/parent contributions by the wife given there was a young child, but there was no evidence provided of such contributions.
- Future Needs: The husband was retired and receiving/supported by superannuation (defined benefit in payment phase).
- Future Needs: The wife was not working at the time; her earning capacity was described as potentially high but contingent upon completing Australian professional registration.
- Future Needs: The husband stated he expected to receive substantial assets from his family in the near future, but these were not identified.
- Just & Equitable: The Full Court held that, even with consent, the Court must be satisfied under s 79(2) that it is just and equitable to make an order.
- Just & Equitable: The Court found no principled reason (per Stanford) to interfere with existing property interests during an intact marriage where the transfer could be achieved outside court with nominal duty and where there was no demonstrated utility for invoking s 79.
- Just & Equitable: The Court considered the absence of independent legal advice (particularly for the wife), language/cultural vulnerability concerns raised by the husband's evidence, and lack of evidence about contributions and circumstances as weighing against making orders.

- Child Ages: One 'young daughter' (exact age not stated).
- Current Arrangements: Child lived with both parents in the family home.
- Safety Concerns: No allegations of abuse or family violence were described; the Court expressed concern about the wife lacking independent legal advice and potentially limited English, relevant to informed consent rather than physical safety.

- Legal Advice: The consent order materials did not include a completed 'Statement of independent legal advice'.
- Legal Advice: The Full Court treated the lack of evidence of independent legal advice (especially for the wife) as a relevant concern when considering whether to make consent orders.
- Financial Disclosure: The application disclosed some assets and stated no liabilities, but did not sufficiently detail the husband's superannuation and did not identify expected 'substantial' family assets.

- Outcome: The appeal against the order of Deputy Chief Justice Faulks made on 27 April 2012 was dismissed.
- Outcome: The Full Court declined to re-exercise discretion to make the proposed consent order transferring the family home into joint tenancy.

- Reasons: Even if errors were identified in the primary judge's reasoning, the Full Court re-exercised discretion and asked whether it was just and equitable to make the order.
- Reasons: In an intact marriage, s 79 can be exercised but requires a principled reason to interfere with existing property interests; none was demonstrated on the evidence.
- Reasons: The proposed transfer could be achieved outside the Family Court under ACT duties legislation with only nominal duty, undermining any necessity or utility for s 79 orders.
- Reasons: The materials did not provide sufficient evidence of contributions or full financial context (notably superannuation details and unidentified expected family assets).
- Reasons: The lack of independent legal advice and concerns about the wife's understanding (including potential language limitations) weighed against granting the court's imprimatur on a significant property change.
- Reasons: Accordingly, the Court declined to make the consent order and dismissed the appeal.

- Pivotal Finding: The parties' marriage was intact; they were not separated and there was no marital breakdown-related controversy requiring property adjustment.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge erred in finding the 'sole purpose' was stamp duty avoidance because the Duties Act could allow the transfer with nominal duty; nevertheless, this did not justify making the s 79 order.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge erred in stating the order would permanently preclude future property settlement; the Full Court relied on Gabel & Yardley to confirm s 79 power may not be 'spent' and can be exercised by successive orders in appropriate cases.
- Pivotal Finding: On re-exercise, the Full Court found no demonstrated utility or principled reason for court intervention where the parties could transfer title directly and cheaply, and where the consent order could be superseded by later events (e.g., relationship breakdown) yet still lacked justification in an intact marriage.
- Pivotal Finding: There was insufficient evidence on contributions and the husband's superannuation, and no evidence of independent legal advice for the wife; combined with her migrant status and possible language limitations, the Court was not satisfied it was just and equitable to make the order.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(2) (threshold: just and equitable to make any order)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) (matters to be taken into account once threshold met)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) r 10.15 (procedure for Application for Consent Orders)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) r 18.10 (review of Registrar decision; hearing de novo)
- Statutory Pivot: Duties Act 1999 (ACT) s 72 (concessional duty on certain partner transfers of principal place of residence)

- Uncertainties: Exact age of the child is not stated.
- Uncertainties: Detailed valuation and nature of the husband's superannuation and income are not set out beyond being a defined benefit interest in payment phase.
- Uncertainties: The extent of the wife's English proficiency and understanding of the proposed orders was not established by evidence; it was raised as a concern.
