court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
parties: F Firm (appellant, former solicitors for the wife)
Mr Curtis (third respondent, former barrister for the wife)
issues: Leave to appeal from interlocutory orders concerning jurisdiction
Whether the Family Court had accrued jurisdiction to determine the wife’s damages claims against her former solicitors (and originally counsel) arising from a Part VIIIA (s 90C) financial agreement
Interaction with precedent (Noll & Noll) and whether the Full Court should depart from earlier authority
Whether the Family Court’s powers/remedies affect the scope of accrued jurisdiction
Case management/practicality arguments about when loss/damages crystallise relative to s 79 proceedings
facts: The husband commenced property settlement proceedings in June 2009.
A separated-couple financial agreement under s 90C was entered after separation; its validity was contested within the property proceedings.

Cronin J (20 November 2009) found the financial agreement was not binding due to non-compliance with s 90G, including that the husband’s advice certificate was signed by an English lawyer not a “legal practitioner” for s 90G purposes.
Cronin J ordered the wife to pay the husband’s costs of the financial agreement proceedings.

The wife pleaded claims against her former solicitors (F Firm) and later joined her former barrister (Mr Curtis), alleging breach of retainer/contract, negligence, breach of duty of care, and/or breach of fiduciary duty concerning the advice and preparation/execution steps for the agreement.
The solicitors and counsel sought to be removed as parties/claims dismissed (or struck out) on the basis the Family Court lacked jurisdiction to hear the damages claims.

Murphy J (22 May 2012) dismissed the solicitors’ application, holding the court had accrued jurisdiction to hear the joined damages claims as part of a single justiciable controversy; he listed the matter for directions and made related procedural orders.
On appeal, the husband took no part; the barrister’s cross-appeal was dismissed by consent with no order as to costs between wife and barrister.
Attorneys-General were served notices under s 78B Judiciary Act; none intervened.

future_needs: The Full Court noted that damages received by the wife from third parties could be relevant to s 79(4)(e) and may affect a s 75(2) adjustment (as discussed by Murphy J and in the appellate reasons), but no property division was determined in this appeal.
existing_agreements: A s 90C financial agreement was executed post-separation but was declared not binding by Cronin J for non-compliance with s 90G.

legal_advice: The agreement was prepared for the wife by F Firm and the wife also received advice from counsel (Mr Curtis).
The husband’s s 90G advice certificate was signed by an English lawyer; Cronin J found that person was not a “legal practitioner” for the purpose of s 90G, resulting in non-compliance.

outcome_orders: Leave to appeal the orders made by Murphy J on 22 May 2012 was granted.
The appeal was dismissed.
Parties were given liberty/timetables to file written submissions concerning any application for costs of the appeal (within 21 days; responses within 14 days; service dates to be endorsed).

description: This appellate decision confirms (on the facts) that the Family Court may exercise accrued jurisdiction to determine a damages claim against legal advisers when the claim forms part of a single justiciable controversy connected to proceedings about a Part VIIIA financial agreement and consequent s 79 proceedings. The case focuses on constitutional and jurisdictional concepts of a single “matter” and how claims with a common factual substratum may be determined together in federal jurisdiction, rather than on the merits of property settlement or negligence. It also addresses when an intermediate appellate court may depart from its own earlier decision (Noll) and highlights that accrued-jurisdiction questions are fact-sensitive.
pivotal_findings: The trial judge (Murphy J) was correct to conclude there was accrued jurisdiction to hear the wife’s claims against her former solicitors (and originally counsel) because the claims arose out of a common substratum of facts concerning the formation, validity, and aftermath of the Part VIIIA agreement and its consequences for the parties’ financial proceedings.

The appeal grounds challenging jurisdiction, including arguments about the Family Court’s limited original jurisdiction/remedies and the timing (“crystallisation”) of damages, lacked merit; no appealable error was shown in the exercise of discretion/jurisdictional evaluation.

Noll did not compel a different result on these facts; the Full Court held it could distinguish Noll factually and in any event was not persuaded Noll was plainly wrong in a way requiring departure for decision of this case.

The court noted damages paid to the wife by a third party could be relevant in the s 79 process (including s 79(4)(e) and s 75(2) considerations), reinforcing the interconnection between the damages claim and property proceedings.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 31(1)(a) (jurisdiction in respect of “matters” arising under the Act)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 39 and s 4 (definition of “matrimonial cause”, including proceedings with respect to a Part VIIIA financial agreement)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) Part VIIIA: s 90C (financial agreement after separation) and s 90G (requirements for binding agreement), including s 90G(1A) (saving provision discussed in reasons)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 and s 79(4)(e) (property settlement; effect of other resources/receipts), and s 75(2) (future needs factors referenced as potentially impacted by damages)
Judiciary Act 1903 (Cth) ss 79-80 (picked up state law remedies/powers once federal jurisdiction is attracted) and s 78B (constitutional notice)
Australian Constitution ss 75-76 (concept of “matter” and federal jurisdiction framework) as applied through authorities on accrued jurisdiction (e.g., Re Wakim; Fencott v Muller; Philip Morris)

reasons_rationale: The Full Court treated the core inquiry as whether the joined claims formed part of one justiciable controversy (“matter”), assessed by the common substratum of facts and interconnection of issues rather than by labeling causes of action.

The Full Court rejected the submission that the Family Court’s accrued jurisdiction is narrower than the Federal Court’s due to remedies, noting that once jurisdiction is attracted, the court has the powers to grant appropriate remedies (including via Judiciary Act pick-up provisions and s 34(1) FLA).

Arguments based on the timing of loss/damages and the sequencing difficulty with s 79 proceedings were considered but did not demonstrate error; the trial judge had addressed them and concluded issues could be managed within the proceeding.

On precedent, the court explained principles governing departure from earlier intermediate appellate decisions and concluded that Noll did not require allowing the appeal; the appeal failed on all grounds.
uncertainties: No determination was made of the underlying negligence/contract/fiduciary duty claims or quantum of any damages; only jurisdiction/interlocutory removal/strike-out issues were resolved.
The appeal did not resolve the parties’ substantive property settlement under s 79 or any final adjustment percentages.
Costs of the appeal were not determined in the orders; the court provided directions for written submissions on any costs application.

Some discussion in the reasons canvassed alternative jurisdictional bases (including arguments about whether damages claims may themselves “arise under” the FLA or associated jurisdiction under s 33), but the Full Court did not decide those points as necessary to outcome.

summary_text:
- Fact: The husband commenced property settlement proceedings in June 2009.
- Fact: A separated-couple financial agreement under s 90C was entered after separation; its validity was contested within the property proceedings.
- Fact: Cronin J (20 November 2009) found the financial agreement was not binding due to non-compliance with s 90G, including that the husband’s advice certificate was signed by an English lawyer not a “legal practitioner” for s 90G purposes.
- Fact: Cronin J ordered the wife to pay the husband’s costs of the financial agreement proceedings.
- Fact: The wife pleaded claims against her former solicitors (F Firm) and later joined her former barrister (Mr Curtis), alleging breach of retainer/contract, negligence, breach of duty of care, and/or breach of fiduciary duty concerning the advice and preparation/execution steps for the agreement.
- Fact: The solicitors and counsel sought to be removed as parties/claims dismissed (or struck out) on the basis the Family Court lacked jurisdiction to hear the damages claims.
- Fact: Murphy J (22 May 2012) dismissed the solicitors’ application, holding the court had accrued jurisdiction to hear the joined damages claims as part of a single justiciable controversy; he listed the matter for directions and made related procedural orders.
- Fact: On appeal, the husband took no part; the barrister’s cross-appeal was dismissed by consent with no order as to costs between wife and barrister.
- Fact: Attorneys-General were served notices under s 78B Judiciary Act; none intervened.

- Issue: Leave to appeal from interlocutory orders concerning jurisdiction
- Issue: Whether the Family Court had accrued jurisdiction to determine the wife’s damages claims against her former solicitors (and originally counsel) arising from a Part VIIIA (s 90C) financial agreement
- Issue: Interaction with precedent (Noll & Noll) and whether the Full Court should depart from earlier authority
- Issue: Whether the Family Court’s powers/remedies affect the scope of accrued jurisdiction
- Issue: Case management/practicality arguments about when loss/damages crystallise relative to s 79 proceedings

- Future Needs: The Full Court noted that damages received by the wife from third parties could be relevant to s 79(4)(e) and may affect a s 75(2) adjustment (as discussed by Murphy J and in the appellate reasons), but no property division was determined in this appeal.

- Legal Advice: The agreement was prepared for the wife by F Firm and the wife also received advice from counsel (Mr Curtis).
- Legal Advice: The husband’s s 90G advice certificate was signed by an English lawyer; Cronin J found that person was not a “legal practitioner” for the purpose of s 90G, resulting in non-compliance.

- Outcome: Leave to appeal the orders made by Murphy J on 22 May 2012 was granted.
- Outcome: The appeal was dismissed.
- Outcome: Parties were given liberty/timetables to file written submissions concerning any application for costs of the appeal (within 21 days; responses within 14 days; service dates to be endorsed).

- Reasons: The Full Court treated the core inquiry as whether the joined claims formed part of one justiciable controversy (“matter”), assessed by the common substratum of facts and interconnection of issues rather than by labeling causes of action.
- Reasons: The Full Court rejected the submission that the Family Court’s accrued jurisdiction is narrower than the Federal Court’s due to remedies, noting that once jurisdiction is attracted, the court has the powers to grant appropriate remedies (including via Judiciary Act pick-up provisions and s 34(1) FLA).
- Reasons: Arguments based on the timing of loss/damages and the sequencing difficulty with s 79 proceedings were considered but did not demonstrate error; the trial judge had addressed them and concluded issues could be managed within the proceeding.
- Reasons: On precedent, the court explained principles governing departure from earlier intermediate appellate decisions and concluded that Noll did not require allowing the appeal; the appeal failed on all grounds.

- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge (Murphy J) was correct to conclude there was accrued jurisdiction to hear the wife’s claims against her former solicitors (and originally counsel) because the claims arose out of a common substratum of facts concerning the formation, validity, and aftermath of the Part VIIIA agreement and its consequences for the parties’ financial proceedings.
- Pivotal Finding: The appeal grounds challenging jurisdiction, including arguments about the Family Court’s limited original jurisdiction/remedies and the timing (“crystallisation”) of damages, lacked merit; no appealable error was shown in the exercise of discretion/jurisdictional evaluation.
- Pivotal Finding: Noll did not compel a different result on these facts; the Full Court held it could distinguish Noll factually and in any event was not persuaded Noll was plainly wrong in a way requiring departure for decision of this case.
- Pivotal Finding: The court noted damages paid to the wife by a third party could be relevant in the s 79 process (including s 79(4)(e) and s 75(2) considerations), reinforcing the interconnection between the damages claim and property proceedings.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 31(1)(a) (jurisdiction in respect of “matters” arising under the Act)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 39 and s 4 (definition of “matrimonial cause”, including proceedings with respect to a Part VIIIA financial agreement)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) Part VIIIA: s 90C (financial agreement after separation) and s 90G (requirements for binding agreement), including s 90G(1A) (saving provision discussed in reasons)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 and s 79(4)(e) (property settlement; effect of other resources/receipts), and s 75(2) (future needs factors referenced as potentially impacted by damages)
- Statutory Pivot: Judiciary Act 1903 (Cth) ss 79-80 (picked up state law remedies/powers once federal jurisdiction is attracted) and s 78B (constitutional notice)
- Statutory Pivot: Australian Constitution ss 75-76 (concept of “matter” and federal jurisdiction framework) as applied through authorities on accrued jurisdiction (e.g., Re Wakim; Fencott v Muller; Philip Morris)

- Uncertainties: No determination was made of the underlying negligence/contract/fiduciary duty claims or quantum of any damages; only jurisdiction/interlocutory removal/strike-out issues were resolved.
- Uncertainties: The appeal did not resolve the parties’ substantive property settlement under s 79 or any final adjustment percentages.
- Uncertainties: Costs of the appeal were not determined in the orders; the court provided directions for written submissions on any costs application.
- Uncertainties: Some discussion in the reasons canvassed alternative jurisdictional bases (including arguments about whether damages claims may themselves “arise under” the FLA or associated jurisdiction under s 33), but the Full Court did not decide those points as necessary to outcome.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from property settlement orders and re-exercise of discretion under s 79
Whether it was "just and equitable" (s 79(2)) to make any order altering existing legal/equitable interests where all property was held by the wife
Effect of husband's repeated representations that wife could keep all Australian property
Effect of husband's delay in commencing proceedings close to the limitation period
facts: The parties were married for about 22 years before the husband left the relationship in 1994.

After 1994, the husband made repeated representations over many years that the wife could retain all the property in Australia (for herself and their sons) while he would build a life and acquire property elsewhere.

The wife held a power of attorney (given by the husband in 1995) and dealt with property largely as she saw fit; over time the parties ceased holding property jointly and assets were held in the wife’s name.
The parties continued some contact after 1994 including shared events and holidays; they remained intimate until about 2000; there was some intermingling of finances.

asset_pool: Trial judge found net assets and liabilities valued at $1,069,000.

On re-exercise, the Full Court largely adopted the trial judge’s approach to inclusion/exclusion of assets/liabilities (not every item required to be brought to account), but included two artworks in the pool.
Two artworks in wife’s possession were included: Rover Thomas painting (valued about $40,000-$50,000) and Jack Britten painting (valued about $15,000-$18,000).
Net assets were found to be in the region of $1,125,000 after including the artworks.
contributions: Husband made significant contributions during the 22-year marriage prior to leaving in 1994.

Post-1994: husband deposited proceeds of winding up a share portfolio into a joint account (value not established by documents; husband estimated about $400,000 plus about $20,000 residue; wife disputed amounts; court could not make definitive finding of value).
Court found insufficient evidence that the share portfolio was built up materially after 1994; more likely largely assembled while cohabiting, supporting husband’s description of it as "ours".

Husband inheritance: husband asserted about $200,000 received in 2001; wife provided documentary evidence suggesting $58,005 distributed in 2002; court accepted $58,005 in 2002 and did not accept husband’s uncorroborated higher figure.
future_needs: Husband: age 68; some health difficulties; at trial still earning a good income but nearing end of working life; had access to good accommodation with his de facto partner in England (occupation dependent on partner’s goodwill).

Wife: nearly 66; limited future earning prospects; would likely need to sell her home if required to make any substantial payment (though the court noted this is a common outcome and did not treat it as central).
Court noted the husband would be left with virtually no assets and significant liabilities for legal costs if no order were made.
just_equitable: Central threshold question: because the wife held legal title to all assets, the court first determined whether it was just and equitable to make any order altering existing interests (Stanford).

The court held it would not be just and equitable to interfere with the existing property interests, principally due to the husband’s repeated representations over many years that the wife could keep the Australian assets and the wife’s long-standing reliance/arrangement of her affairs in that context.

The husband’s substantial delay in instituting proceedings until close to expiry of the limitation period was a further factor weighing against intervention; delay impacted fairness and the ability to prove contested historical matters (e.g., inheritance and share portfolio).

The court rejected the proposition that the wife needed to establish an estoppel defence; the onus was on the husband to demonstrate a principled reason to interfere with existing interests, and the representations and acquiescence were relevant to the s 79(2) inquiry.
living_arrangements: Husband lived overseas for long periods after 1994 and later lived with a de facto partner in England from about 2006.
Wife remained in Australia and held/controlled the Australian assets, including her home in M town.
existing_agreements: No binding financial agreement under Pt VIIIA was identified.

There were informal post-separation understandings/assurances by the husband that the wife could keep the Australian assets, but these did not amount to a Pt VIIIA agreement and were treated as relevant to s 79(2) discretion.

outcome_orders: Appeal allowed.
Orders made by Acting Judge Jordan on 7 December 2012 set aside.
Husband’s application filed 20 July 2011, wife’s response filed 14 September 2011, and husband’s reply filed 2 December 2011 all dismissed.
No order as to costs.

description: The case is significant for applying Stanford & Stanford to the threshold question in s 79(2): where property is already entirely held in one party’s name after long separation, the court must identify a principled basis to interfere with existing legal/equitable interests. The Full Court treated the husband’s repeated assurances and long acquiescence, combined with late commencement near the limitation period, as defeating the s 79(2) requirement, so that the discretionary s 79(4) contribution/future-needs assessment did not proceed to an adjustment order. The appeal was re-determined under the rehearing powers in ss 93A(2) and 94(2), with discussion of the limits of re-exercising discretion and (in Finn J’s reasons) reservations about raising new asset-pool challenges absent cross-appeal.
pivotal_findings: All (or effectively all) property was legally held in the wife’s name; the wife was found to be legal owner of the artworks and the husband’s interest in them was treated as effectively gifted (perfected gift) given representations and long uncontested possession.

The husband made repeated representations over many years that the wife could retain all Australian assets, including assurances continuing after key financial events (inheritance and share portfolio liquidation).
The husband delayed commencing proceedings until 2011, with first clear notice of a property claim found to be 1 January 2011, notwithstanding separation by at least May 2006.
The husband’s evidence as to inheritance amount and timing was not accepted; the court proceeded on an inheritance of $58,005 in 2002 based on documentary support.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(2) (just and equitable threshold) and s 79 (property settlement power generally)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) and s 75(2) (relevant considerations/future needs; noted but not ultimately determinative given dismissal at s 79(2) stage)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) ss 93A(2) and 94(1)-(2) (appeal by way of rehearing and power to make the decision that ought to have been made at first instance)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6 and 9 (costs certificates)

reasons_rationale: Applying Stanford, the court treated s 79(2) as requiring a principled reason to interfere with existing legal/equitable interests; because the wife legally held the assets, the threshold question was decisive.

The husband’s long-standing representations that the wife could keep the Australian assets, and his acquiescence while she dealt with property as her own, strongly supported maintaining the status quo.

The husband’s substantial delay in bringing proceedings until close to the limitation expiry reinforced the conclusion that interference would be unjust, including due to evidentiary difficulties caused by delay.

While the husband’s historical contributions were acknowledged and the outcome left him in a difficult position, the court concluded the representations and delay outweighed those considerations in the s 79(2) assessment.
uncertainties: The precise amount realised from the share portfolio and the exact transactions/deposits were not able to be determined due to lack of documentary evidence.
The exact application of the husband’s inheritance funds (who benefited and how) was not able to be determined on the evidence.
Finn J expressed reservations (not determinative) about whether a non-cross-appealing respondent can challenge asset pool findings on a re-exercise of discretion absent further evidence.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal against property settlement orders dividing net property and superannuation 50/50
Whether the trial judge erred by failing to recognise/apply a binding principle or guideline of 'special contributions'
Whether the trial judge failed to take into account relevant considerations (husband's asserted special skills/entrepreneurial flair)
Whether the trial judge gave insufficient weight to the husband's asserted contributions
Whether there were material factual errors (separation date, asset pool size, inheritance, husband being away from home)
Costs of the appeal
facts: The parties cohabited for about 36 years and had four children.
Each party brought property into the relationship (wife had a house with a loan; husband had a flat).
During the relationship both earned income; the husband was a professional and ran a professional practice; the wife worked in that practice until 1992 and then in the Public Service.
The trial judge made property settlement orders on 11 January 2013 following reasons delivered 17 December 2012.
The combined net value of property and superannuation interests was found to be almost $10 million.

The trial judge's orders had the effect that each party would retain real property and chattels and the husband would pay the wife a cash sum of about $3 million, with two alternative payment/superannuation-splitting options.
The husband appealed, self-represented, arguing his investment skill in real property and share trading amounted to 'special contributions' warranting a larger share for him.
The Full Court considered whether there is any binding rule or legitimate guideline requiring recognition of 'special contributions' and whether any appealable error was shown.

asset_pool: Net property and superannuation pool was almost $10 million (combined net value).
Assets included real property, chattels, and superannuation interests.
The trial judge found the pool was less than $10 million (supported by the values of assets and liabilities).
Wife received an inheritance in 2010; evidence accepted that she had provided the bulk to the children and it was unlikely to be repaid.
contributions: Trial judge found nothing unusual about contributions over a long relationship with children; both worked and both contributed in different spheres.
Husband: professional work and running a practice; asserted he researched/managed investments in real property and shares; asserted physical work on properties.

Wife: worked in husband's practice until 1992; later worked in Public Service; asserted greater contributions to child care when children were young; asserted her initial property was a springboard for future wealth.
Trial judge declined to adjust for husband's physical work on properties, reasoning it likely took him away from home and increased wife's childcare burden at the time of young children.
Trial judge assessed overall contributions (financial, non-financial, homemaker/parenting) as equal.
future_needs: Not addressed in detail in the appeal reasons; the appeal focused on contributions and alleged 'special contributions'.
just_equitable: Trial judge made orders dividing property and superannuation equally (50/50).
Full Court held no error of principle or discretion was shown and the result was within the permissible range of outcomes.
living_arrangements: During periods when the husband performed physical work on properties, the wife remained at home with young children (as found by the trial judge).

relationship_length: The parties cohabited for approximately 36 years.

caregiver_history: The parties raised four children.

Wife asserted (and the trial judge accepted as relevant to contributions assessment) that she carried a greater burden of caring for the children when they were young, including a period when there were four children under seven.

outcome_orders: The appeal in EA 15 of 2013 was dismissed.
The appellant husband was ordered to pay the respondent wife's costs of the appeal in EA 15 of 2013, in an amount agreed in writing or failing agreement as assessed.
The costs of the appeal in EA 89 of 2013 were reserved.
As a consequence, the trial judge's property orders made on 11 January 2013 remained in force.

description: This Full Court decision clarifies that 'special contributions' is neither a binding rule of law nor a 'legitimate guideline' that must be applied in s 79 property cases. The Court emphasised the breadth of the s 79 discretion and the requirement to assess contributions without adjectival shortcuts; the focus is on identifying and weighing actual contributions (financial, non-financial, homemaker/parent) rather than treating asserted entrepreneurial skill as a category requiring an automatic loading. The decision also distinguishes the use of comparable cases to inform discretion from asserting any prescriptive 'special contribution' principle, and rejects attempts to confine such arguments to 'big money' pools by reference to pool size.
pivotal_findings: No binding rule of law exists requiring a court to make an adjustment for 'special contributions'; the trial judge did not err in refusing to treat it as a principle requiring application.

No clear, universally applicable 'legitimate guideline' of 'special contributions' can be articulated from the authorities; terms such as 'special', 'extra', 'exceptional' are too elusive to form a coherent guideline applicable to an identifiable class of cases.

The trial judge's reasons, read as a whole, did not reveal an impermissible presumption or starting point of equal contributions; rather, the judge made a broad-brush evaluative assessment typical of long marriages with children.

The trial judge did consider the husband’s claimed investment activities and other contributions as part of the overall contributions assessment; no failure to consider relevant contributions was shown.
The 50/50 outcome was not 'plainly wrong' and remained within the range of permissible discretionary outcomes.

Alleged factual errors (separation date, pool size, inheritance amount/effect, husband's absence from home due to property work) were not established as material errors warranting appellate intervention.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(2) (just and equitable requirement)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) (matters to be considered in altering property interests, including contributions in s 79(4)(a)-(c))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval of publication under pseudonym, as noted)

reasons_rationale: Appellate intervention in discretionary property decisions requires demonstration of error of principle or that the result is plainly wrong (House v The King; CDJ v VAJ).
Authorities do not establish a binding rule of law for 'special contributions'; s 79 discretion remains largely unfettered and must be exercised case-by-case (Mallet; Norbis).

The Court rejected that any 'special contributions' concept has crystallised into a legitimate guideline applicable to an identifiable category of cases; 'big money cases' is not a valid category and pool size is not determinative.

The trial judge’s reasons were adequate and reflected a proper broad-brush evaluation of both parties’ contributions over a long relationship, including consideration of the wife’s greater childcare burden when children were young and the husband’s asserted investment management.
The husband did not establish any material factual error, nor any relevant consideration overlooked, nor that weight was wrongly assigned such as to vitiate the exercise of discretion.
Costs followed the event for EA 15 of 2013; costs for EA 89 of 2013 were reserved due to potential interaction with later proceedings raising functus officio issues.
uncertainties: The appeal reasons do not set out a detailed itemised asset schedule or the precise alternative cash/superannuation payment figures beyond describing the cash payment as about $3 million and the net pool as almost $10 million.
The Full Court decision concerns the appeal in EA 15 of 2013 only; issues in EA 89 of 2013 and later appeal EA 52 of 2014 (including functus officio arguments) were not determined in these reasons.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from interim parenting orders involving relocation
Whether the primary judge erred by not making or addressing equal shared parental responsibility (s 61DA) and consequential considerations of time (s 65DAA)
Whether the interim approach in Goode & Goode was misunderstood by determining the matter solely on agreed facts and disregarding contested allegations
Whether the interim orders were coercive by requiring the mother to relocate
Whether alternative parenting arrangements were required if the mother did not relocate
facts: Two children: S born 2009 and L born 2011
Children lived in Town G from birth until about 15 months after separation
Father’s extended family live in Town G; mother’s parents live in Town N
In early 2014 the mother spent some months with the children in Town N without the father’s consent
In September 2014 the mother again took the children to Town N to live without the father’s consent
After discovering the move, the father commenced proceedings seeking the children live with him and orders to prevent removal
The mother opposed and sought orders that the children live with her in Town N and spend time with the father for half school holidays and other agreed occasions
At the interim hearing the mother’s position included that if the children were ordered back to Town G she would return, though submissions were also made that she could not move back

Interim orders made in December 2014 required the mother to return the children to Town G by 23 December 2014, with the children to live with her and spend time with the father on alternate weekends, every Wednesday, and special occasions
Town G and Town N are approximately 765 km apart (about 9.5 hours drive)
The parties were described as being of modest means; distance would materially impact the children’s ability to spend regular time with both parents
The father did not participate in the appeal
The interim orders were stayed; it was understood the mother and children remained in Town N and the father in Town G

child_ages: S born 2009
L born 2011
current_arrangements: At time of appeal (per understanding), children living with the mother in Town N; father living in Town G (interim orders stayed)
caregiver_history: Children lived in Town G from birth until about 15 months after separation
Mother removed the children to Town N in early 2014 for some months without the father’s consent and again in September 2014 without consent
availability: Town G and Town N separated by 765 km; travel time about 9.5 hours by car
Parties of modest means; distance would materially affect regular time and day-to-day involvement
safety_concerns: Mother asserted father was controlling or abusive; primary judge noted lack of independent evidence (appeal court criticised approach to corroboration and ignoring disputed allegations at interim stage)
allegations: Allegations raised (at least by the mother) that the father had been controlling or abusive towards the mother or the children; primary judge treated absence of independent corroboration as significant
Primary judge identified multiple topics of conflicting evidence and disregarded them, determining the interim applications solely on agreed facts
best_interests: Full Court held that in interim parenting proceedings a court may need to weigh probabilities of competing claims and likely impact on children, rather than ignore contested assertions solely because they are disputed
orders: Appeal orders set aside paragraphs 3 to 6 of the primary judge’s 15 December 2014 orders and remitted the competing parenting applications for rehearing
No final parenting arrangements determined by the Full Court; matter to be reheard in Federal Circuit Court

outcome_orders: Leave granted for solicitors for the appellant mother and respondent father to withdraw
Appeal allowed
Paragraphs 3 to 6 inclusive of the orders made on 15 December 2014 set aside
Competing applications for parenting orders remitted to the Federal Circuit Court for rehearing
No order as to costs of the appeal
Costs certificate granted to the mother under s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the appeal
Costs certificate granted to the mother under s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for the rehearing
Father at liberty for 28 days to apply for a costs certificate under s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in relation to the rehearing

description: The Full Court treated the failure to apply the statutory framework for parental responsibility and time considerations as a determinative legal error in interim parenting (including relocation) proceedings. The decision reinforces that interim hearings may require cautious evaluative judgments on contested allegations affecting a child’s welfare, rather than excluding disputed evidence simply because it is uncorroborated or conflicting.
pivotal_findings: The primary judge made no order as to parental responsibility and gave no reasons engaging s 61DA, despite both parties proposing equal shared parental responsibility (at least on a final basis) and the mother seeking such an order on an interim basis

In the absence of findings enlivening exceptions or rebuttal (s 61DA(2), (3), or (4)), the presumption of equal shared parental responsibility applied, requiring the court to make that order and then address s 65DAA considerations

The primary judge identified multiple areas of conflicting evidence and disregarded that evidence, deciding solely on agreed facts; the Full Court indicated that was a misunderstanding of the interim approach

The primary judge’s comments suggesting the mother’s allegations of controlling or abusive behaviour were deficient due to lack of independent corroboration were criticised; the Full Court noted family conduct often occurs in private and corroboration may not be available
Because the error of law was established and the father did not seek to uphold the primary orders, it was unnecessary to determine the remaining grounds
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 61DA (presumption of equal shared parental responsibility, including interim operation and exceptions)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65DAA (consideration of equal time or substantial and significant time following an order for equal shared parental responsibility)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 8 and 9 (costs certificates on appeal and rehearing)
Authorities guiding interim parenting approach: Goode & Goode (2006) FLC 93-286; Marvel v Marvel (2010) 43 Fam LR 348; references to SS v AH [2010] FamCAFC 13 on circumspection in interim findings

reasons_rationale: The Full Court found an error of law because the primary judge did not apply s 61DA and, consequently, did not engage s 65DAA, despite those provisions being central to the interim parenting determination

The Full Court emphasised that in interim parenting matters the court should not ignore contentious assertions merely because they are disputed; it may need to weigh probabilities and consider likely impacts on children
The Full Court rejected any implication that allegations of controlling/abusive behaviour require independent corroboration to be considered at interim stage
The established legal error warranted setting aside the relevant interim orders and remitting the parenting applications for rehearing
uncertainties: The content of paragraphs 3 to 6 of the primary judge’s orders is not reproduced in full in the provided text, beyond the general effect that the mother was required to return the children to Town G and the spend-time regime
The eight topics of conflicting evidence identified by the primary judge are not specified in the provided text
No expert reports, family consultant evidence, or children’s views are mentioned in the provided text
No final parenting outcome is determined; the matter was remitted for rehearing

- Fact: Two children: S born 2009 and L born 2011
- Fact: Children lived in Town G from birth until about 15 months after separation
- Fact: Father’s extended family live in Town G; mother’s parents live in Town N
- Fact: In early 2014 the mother spent some months with the children in Town N without the father’s consent
- Fact: In September 2014 the mother again took the children to Town N to live without the father’s consent
- Fact: After discovering the move, the father commenced proceedings seeking the children live with him and orders to prevent removal
- Fact: The mother opposed and sought orders that the children live with her in Town N and spend time with the father for half school holidays and other agreed occasions
- Fact: At the interim hearing the mother’s position included that if the children were ordered back to Town G she would return, though submissions were also made that she could not move back
- Fact: Interim orders made in December 2014 required the mother to return the children to Town G by 23 December 2014, with the children to live with her and spend time with the father on alternate weekends, every Wednesday, and special occasions
- Fact: Town G and Town N are approximately 765 km apart (about 9.5 hours drive)
- Fact: The parties were described as being of modest means; distance would materially impact the children’s ability to spend regular time with both parents
- Fact: The father did not participate in the appeal
- Fact: The interim orders were stayed; it was understood the mother and children remained in Town N and the father in Town G

- Issue: Appeal from interim parenting orders involving relocation
- Issue: Whether the primary judge erred by not making or addressing equal shared parental responsibility (s 61DA) and consequential considerations of time (s 65DAA)
- Issue: Whether the interim approach in Goode & Goode was misunderstood by determining the matter solely on agreed facts and disregarding contested allegations
- Issue: Whether the interim orders were coercive by requiring the mother to relocate
- Issue: Whether alternative parenting arrangements were required if the mother did not relocate

- Child Ages: S born 2009
- Child Ages: L born 2011
- Current Arrangements: At time of appeal (per understanding), children living with the mother in Town N; father living in Town G (interim orders stayed)
- Safety Concerns: Mother asserted father was controlling or abusive; primary judge noted lack of independent evidence (appeal court criticised approach to corroboration and ignoring disputed allegations at interim stage)
- Best Interests: Full Court held that in interim parenting proceedings a court may need to weigh probabilities of competing claims and likely impact on children, rather than ignore contested assertions solely because they are disputed

- Outcome: Leave granted for solicitors for the appellant mother and respondent father to withdraw
- Outcome: Appeal allowed
- Outcome: Paragraphs 3 to 6 inclusive of the orders made on 15 December 2014 set aside
- Outcome: Competing applications for parenting orders remitted to the Federal Circuit Court for rehearing
- Outcome: No order as to costs of the appeal
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the mother under s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the appeal
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the mother under s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for the rehearing
- Outcome: Father at liberty for 28 days to apply for a costs certificate under s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in relation to the rehearing

- Reasons: The Full Court found an error of law because the primary judge did not apply s 61DA and, consequently, did not engage s 65DAA, despite those provisions being central to the interim parenting determination
- Reasons: The Full Court emphasised that in interim parenting matters the court should not ignore contentious assertions merely because they are disputed; it may need to weigh probabilities and consider likely impacts on children
- Reasons: The Full Court rejected any implication that allegations of controlling/abusive behaviour require independent corroboration to be considered at interim stage
- Reasons: The established legal error warranted setting aside the relevant interim orders and remitting the parenting applications for rehearing

- Pivotal Finding: The primary judge made no order as to parental responsibility and gave no reasons engaging s 61DA, despite both parties proposing equal shared parental responsibility (at least on a final basis) and the mother seeking such an order on an interim basis
- Pivotal Finding: In the absence of findings enlivening exceptions or rebuttal (s 61DA(2), (3), or (4)), the presumption of equal shared parental responsibility applied, requiring the court to make that order and then address s 65DAA considerations
- Pivotal Finding: The primary judge identified multiple areas of conflicting evidence and disregarded that evidence, deciding solely on agreed facts; the Full Court indicated that was a misunderstanding of the interim approach
- Pivotal Finding: The primary judge’s comments suggesting the mother’s allegations of controlling or abusive behaviour were deficient due to lack of independent corroboration were criticised; the Full Court noted family conduct often occurs in private and corroboration may not be available
- Pivotal Finding: Because the error of law was established and the father did not seek to uphold the primary orders, it was unnecessary to determine the remaining grounds
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 61DA (presumption of equal shared parental responsibility, including interim operation and exceptions)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65DAA (consideration of equal time or substantial and significant time following an order for equal shared parental responsibility)
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 8 and 9 (costs certificates on appeal and rehearing)
- Statutory Pivot: Authorities guiding interim parenting approach: Goode & Goode (2006) FLC 93-286; Marvel v Marvel (2010) 43 Fam LR 348; references to SS v AH [2010] FamCAFC 13 on circumspection in interim findings

- Uncertainties: The content of paragraphs 3 to 6 of the primary judge’s orders is not reproduced in full in the provided text, beyond the general effect that the mother was required to return the children to Town G and the spend-time regime
- Uncertainties: The eight topics of conflicting evidence identified by the primary judge are not specified in the provided text
- Uncertainties: No expert reports, family consultant evidence, or children’s views are mentioned in the provided text
- Uncertainties: No final parenting outcome is determined; the matter was remitted for rehearing

court: Family Court of Australia (Full Court)
issues: Appeal from final parenting orders providing for the child to live with the mother and have no time or communication with the father
Whether trial judge erred in best interests analysis by failing to adequately explain reasons for a complete prohibition on the father having time/communication
Whether the trial judge failed to consider and explain alternatives/safeguards to ameliorate risk (including supervised reintroduction and indirect communication)
Allegations of bias/procedural unfairness (raised by father on appeal)
Whether the trial judge misapplied unacceptable risk principles and/or erred about the rationality/genuineness of the mother's fear
Whether the court erred by not seeking the child's views under s 60CC(3)(a)
facts: The parties commenced living together in late 2004, married in 2005, and separated in January 2009.
The parties have one child born in 2008.
The father has not seen, spent time with, or communicated with the child since 1 March 2009 (when the child was 11 months old).
The mother remained in the Queensland Police Service and relocated from the Wide Bay-Burnett district to South East Queensland in January 2010; the father remained in the Wide Bay-Burnett district.
The father commenced parenting proceedings on 8 September 2010; an Independent Children's Lawyer was appointed on 26 October 2010.
A Family Report dated 20 July 2011 canvassed possible supervised reintroduction and recommended delay pending resolution of a then stalking charge against the father; the charge was later withdrawn.

child_ages: Child born in 2008
Child was 11 months old at last contact on 1 March 2009
Child was five years old at conclusion of trial
current_arrangements: At first instance (30 May 2014), the child was ordered to live with the mother and to spend no time and have no communication with the father.
On appeal (23 July 2015), those orders were set aside and the matter remitted for rehearing.
caregiver_history: The mother was found to be and always had been the primary carer and had been the exclusive carer for some years prior to trial.
The father had not been involved in the child's life since infancy (no time or communication since March 2009).
availability: Mother relocated for work within Queensland Police Service; father remained in the Wide Bay-Burnett district.
safety_concerns: Mother alleged violent conduct during the relationship culminating in the January 2009 knife incident.
Trial judge found father had anger management issues and accepted the mother's fear as genuine and rational.
Risk identified at trial was psychological harm to the child arising from the mother's reaction (decompensation) to any father-child contact, rather than direct risk of the father harming the child.
Full Court noted there was no evidence from which a conclusion could properly be drawn that the father was likely to harm the child or that there was an unacceptable risk of him doing so directly.
child_views: The father argued the court ignored s 60CC(3)(a) by not seeking the child's views; the Full Court rejected this ground, noting the child's age and lack of memory of the father.
allegations: Allegations of violence by the father during the relationship, including an incident involving the father grabbing a knife and a struggle in January 2009.
Allegations relevant to anger management concerns were supported by various sources including admissions and third-party evidence (summarised by trial judge).
Stalking charge against the father relating to a third party existed at the time of the 2011 Family Report but was later withdrawn.
expert_evidence: Family Report writer (Mr J) dated 20 July 2011 canvassed supervised reintroduction and observation of father-child interaction and recommended delay until stalking charge resolved.
Psychiatric evidence was accepted by the trial judge to the effect that the mother might decompensate if the child had any involvement with the father, affecting her parenting capacity.
References in the appeal reasons to psychiatrist Dr M and psychiatrist Dr F in relation to the mother's condition and reactions.
best_interests: The case involved balancing s 60CC(2)(a) (meaningful relationship) against s 60CC(2)(b) (need to protect from harm), with s 60CC(2A) requiring greater weight to protection from harm.

Full Court held the trial judge failed to adequately expose reasoning for concluding that no safeguard short of complete prohibition could render the risk acceptable, and failed to adequately evaluate and explain alternatives.
orders: Appeal allowed; first instance parenting orders set aside; matter remitted for rehearing before a different Federal Circuit Court judge (final parenting outcomes to be determined on rehearing).

incidents: Disputed January 2009 incident involving a knife; trial judge largely accepted the mother's version including that there was a struggle after the father grabbed the knife.
Trial judge found the father had anger management issues and treated the knife incident as a serious incident underpinning the mother's fear.
police_court: The mother intended to call police officer witnesses; evidence included observations of the father's aggression/anger in a policing context.
A stalking charge against the father relating to a third party existed but was withdrawn prior to February 2012.
child_exposure: Mother alleged some violence occurred in the presence of the child (as described in appeal reasons as part of the mother's case).
safety_plan: Father proposed staged reintroduction options including supervised contact centre time and indirect communication; Full Court held trial reasons did not adequately address why such safeguards were insufficient.

outcome_orders: The appeal be allowed.
The orders made by Judge Coates on 30 May 2014 be set aside.
The matter be remitted to the Federal Circuit Court of Australia for re-hearing before a judge other than Judge Coates.
Costs certificate granted to the father pursuant to s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of appeal costs.
Costs certificates granted to the father, mother and the Independent Children's Lawyer pursuant to s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of rehearing costs.

description: This Full Court appeal turned on adequacy of reasons and the proper articulation of the pathway from findings about the mother's fear and psychological reaction to the extreme outcome of a complete severance of the child from the father. While factual findings about the January 2009 knife incident and the father's anger issues were largely left undisturbed, the discretion miscarried because the trial judge did not sufficiently explain why safeguards and less restrictive options could not ameliorate the risk, particularly given the grave consequence of orders eliminating any relationship or even knowledge of the father. The matter was remitted for a fresh exercise of discretion with updated evidence.
pivotal_findings: Trial judge's key accepted facts were not shown to be erroneous on appeal: the mother had genuine, pervasive and rational fear of the father, and the January 2009 knife incident involved a struggle after the father grabbed the knife.
The trial judge found the father had anger management issues, supported by multiple evidentiary sources including admissions and third-party observations.

The risk found was not a direct unacceptable risk of the father harming the child, but a risk of psychological harm to the child arising from the mother's anticipated decompensation and impaired parenting if any contact occurred.

The Full Court's decisive finding of appealable error was that the trial judge failed to properly expose the reasoning for concluding that the only way to avoid unacceptable risk was to order no time and no communication, and failed to evaluate and explain alternatives and safeguards (including indirect communication, supervised time, interim monitored reintroduction, and therapeutic supports).
The Full Court noted the disadvantages to the child of being wholly deprived of knowledge of the father (and older sibling) were not properly identified and weighed in the reasons.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2)(a) (benefit of a meaningful relationship with both parents)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2)(b) (need to protect the child from physical or psychological harm from being subjected or exposed to abuse, neglect or family violence)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2A) (greater weight to protection from harm consideration)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(3)(a) (any views expressed by the child; raised but rejected as an appeal ground)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(1) (costs discretion applied so each party bear own costs on appeal)
Evidence Act 1995 (Cth) s 140 (standard of proof; discussed in relation to serious allegations)

reasons_rationale: The Full Court held there was no material error of fact and no misapplication of law established regarding the mother's genuine and rational fear or the father's anger management issues.

The appeal succeeded because the trial judge did not adequately articulate why the identified risk could not be managed by safeguards and why options short of a total prohibition were not in the child's best interests.
Given the age of the existing Family Report (dated 20 July 2011) and time elapsed, the Full Court declined to re-exercise discretion and remitted the matter for rehearing before a different judge.
Allegations of bias and procedural unfairness were rejected; the Full Court found no merit in grounds alleging partiality or unfair conduct of the trial.
The complaint about not seeking the child's views was rejected due to the child's young age and lack of meaningful relationship/memory with the father.
Costs: the appeal succeeded on a question of law; each party to bear own costs, and costs certificates were issued under the relevant legislation.
uncertainties: Final parenting arrangements were not determined on appeal and were left for rehearing.
The rehearing would likely require updated evidence (including potentially updated family report/psychological evidence), as the existing report was several years old.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether a creditor retains standing to apply to set aside a marriage financial agreement under s 90K(1)(aa) after the debtor party becomes bankrupt
Whether a creditor (as an interested person) can seek ancillary orders under s 90K(3) after bankruptcy of the debtor party
Whether the scope of s 90K(3) is limited to substantially restoring the pre-agreement position (status quo) or extends more broadly
Whether a creditor invoking s 90K(1)(aa) can also rely on other set-aside grounds in s 90K(1), including unenforceability/invalidity via s 90G independent legal advice requirements
Whether summary dismissal/strike-out was appropriate in relation to the pleaded s 90K(3) relief
facts: In 2007 Mrs Grainger purchased an unencumbered property at E, Queensland, with funds provided by Mr Grainger.
From 2008 Mrs Grainger borrowed amounts totalling about $2.6 million from a bank, secured by a mortgage over the E property.
Following Queensland Supreme Court proceedings arising out of business arrangements, Mrs Grainger became a judgment debtor to Ms Bloomfield for $2,100,000 in late 2011.
A bankruptcy notice was served on Mrs Grainger on or about 14 October 2012 in respect of the judgment debt.
On 1 November 2012 Mr and Mrs Grainger entered a s 90C financial agreement during marriage.
Under the agreement, Mrs Grainger transferred her interest in the E property to Mr Grainger subject to the mortgage, and Mr Grainger was to indemnify Mrs Grainger for the mortgage.
On 28 November 2012 Ms Bloomfield filed a creditor's petition in the Federal Circuit Court (served about 12 December 2012).
Mrs Grainger became bankrupt on her own debtor's petition on 7 January 2013.
Ms Bloomfield lodged a proof of debt with the trustee in bankruptcy prior to 4 February 2013.

asset_pool: E property in Queensland (formerly unencumbered, later mortgaged to secure borrowings)
Mortgage securing loans totalling about $2.6 million over the E property
Judgment debt owed by Mrs Grainger to Ms Bloomfield of $2,100,000 (provable debt in bankruptcy)
contributions: Mr Grainger provided funds used by Mrs Grainger to purchase the E property in 2007
just_equitable: Case concerned creditor standing and statutory powers to set aside a financial agreement and make ancillary orders; it did not determine a s 79 property settlement or a percentage division between spouses
existing_agreements: Financial agreement under s 90C dated 1 November 2012 transferring Mrs Grainger's interest in the E property to Mr Grainger subject to the mortgage, with an indemnity by Mr Grainger in respect of the mortgage

legal_advice: Cross-appellant alleged the agreement was unenforceable due to non-compliance with s 90G(1)(b) independent legal advice requirements, based on an asserted lack of independence of a solicitor who advised Mrs Grainger

outcome_orders: Leave to appeal and to cross-appeal granted
Appeal dismissed
Cross-appeal dismissed
Appellant to pay respondent's costs of and incidental to the appeal (as agreed or assessed)
Cross-appellant to pay appellant's costs of and incidental to the cross-appeal (as agreed or assessed)

description: The Full Court clarified creditor standing to bring third party proceedings to set aside a financial agreement on the creditor-defeating ground despite the debtor party's subsequent bankruptcy, and confirmed that creditors are jurisdictionally confined to the specific third party ground (s 90K(1)(aa)) rather than other set-aside bases. The Court also emphasised the caution required on summary dismissal where the scope of s 90K(3) relief is not authoritatively settled and depends on facts to be found at trial.
pivotal_findings: A creditor does not cease to be a 'creditor' for s 90K(1)(aa) / s 4A purposes merely because the debtor party becomes bankrupt; bankruptcy alters remedies, not the creditor's status.
Section 58(3) of the Bankruptcy Act contemplates a creditor commencing/continuing litigation in respect of a provable debt with leave, supporting the possibility of creditor standing post-bankruptcy.

Legislative comparison: unlike s 79(10A) and s 90SM(11) (which remove creditor participation in property settlement proceedings upon bankruptcy), s 90K contains no equivalent limitation; this supported the conclusion that creditor standing under s 90K(1)(aa) does not cease on bankruptcy.

Authorities cited by the appellant (including Clyne; Lasic; Griffiths v Falck) did not establish that creditor standing is lost for purposes of s 90K; Zaravinos provided a helpful analogy recognising creditors and creditors as a whole as prejudiced despite trustee benefit.
In the context of summary dismissal, it was appropriate not to determine the ultimate scope of s 90K(3); the issue was 'triable' and required factual findings at a full hearing.

A creditor's entitlement to bring 'third party proceedings' is confined by s 4A to proceedings on the s 90K(1)(aa) ground; accrued/associated jurisdiction cannot expand statutory remedies to allow reliance on other s 90K(1) grounds such as s 90K(1)(b) via s 90G non-binding arguments.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K(1)(aa) (creditor defeating/defrauding or reckless disregard ground)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K(3) (ancillary preservation/adjustment orders after setting aside; just and equitable)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4(1) definition of 'matrimonial cause' para (eab) and s 4A definition of 'third party proceedings' (jurisdictional gateway limiting creditor challenges to s 90K(1)(aa))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1) (binding requirements; independent legal advice) (raised but held outside creditor standing in third party proceedings)
Federal Circuit Court of Australia Act 1999 (Cth) s 17A (summary judgment power applied below)
Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth) s 58(3) (leave required for proceedings in respect of provable debts after bankruptcy)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 (costs discretion; general rule noted but not applied)

reasons_rationale: Statutory text and structure: 'third party proceedings' jurisdiction is expressly confined to setting aside a financial agreement on the ground in s 90K(1)(aa), limiting a creditor to that ground.

Legislative history and subsequent amendments: Parliament expressly removed creditor standing in property settlement proceedings upon bankruptcy (s 79(10A), s 90SM(11)) but did not do so for s 90K; this supported continued creditor standing under s 90K post-bankruptcy.

Bankruptcy principles: bankruptcy changes enforcement mechanisms and requires leave under s 58(3) but does not erase creditor status for the purposes of other legislation; any benefit of recovery would in practice flow to the bankrupt estate for distribution.

Summary dismissal caution: applying High Court guidance on summary termination, the Full Court held it was not sufficiently clear that the applicant had no real prospect of success regarding the scope of s 90K(3), so the issue should go to trial.
Accrued jurisdiction cannot be used to enlarge statutory rights; it cannot permit a creditor to rely on additional s 90K(1) grounds where jurisdiction is limited by s 4A.
uncertainties: The Full Court did not determine the substantive s 90K(1)(aa) question (whether the agreement was entered to defraud/defeat or with reckless disregard of Ms Bloomfield as creditor); that remained for trial.

The Full Court did not define the ultimate scope of relief available under s 90K(3) (e.g., whether orders could require transfer free of mortgage or payment of value), holding only that it was inappropriate to decide on summary dismissal.
Whether leave under s 58(3)(b) of the Bankruptcy Act was obtained or required in practice for the creditor's s 90K proceedings was not determined on appeal.

summary_text:
- Fact: In 2007 Mrs Grainger purchased an unencumbered property at E, Queensland, with funds provided by Mr Grainger.
- Fact: From 2008 Mrs Grainger borrowed amounts totalling about $2.6 million from a bank, secured by a mortgage over the E property.
- Fact: Following Queensland Supreme Court proceedings arising out of business arrangements, Mrs Grainger became a judgment debtor to Ms Bloomfield for $2,100,000 in late 2011.
- Fact: A bankruptcy notice was served on Mrs Grainger on or about 14 October 2012 in respect of the judgment debt.
- Fact: On 1 November 2012 Mr and Mrs Grainger entered a s 90C financial agreement during marriage.
- Fact: Under the agreement, Mrs Grainger transferred her interest in the E property to Mr Grainger subject to the mortgage, and Mr Grainger was to indemnify Mrs Grainger for the mortgage.
- Fact: On 28 November 2012 Ms Bloomfield filed a creditor's petition in the Federal Circuit Court (served about 12 December 2012).
- Fact: Mrs Grainger became bankrupt on her own debtor's petition on 7 January 2013.
- Fact: Ms Bloomfield lodged a proof of debt with the trustee in bankruptcy prior to 4 February 2013.

- Issue: Whether a creditor retains standing to apply to set aside a marriage financial agreement under s 90K(1)(aa) after the debtor party becomes bankrupt
- Issue: Whether a creditor (as an interested person) can seek ancillary orders under s 90K(3) after bankruptcy of the debtor party
- Issue: Whether the scope of s 90K(3) is limited to substantially restoring the pre-agreement position (status quo) or extends more broadly
- Issue: Whether a creditor invoking s 90K(1)(aa) can also rely on other set-aside grounds in s 90K(1), including unenforceability/invalidity via s 90G independent legal advice requirements
- Issue: Whether summary dismissal/strike-out was appropriate in relation to the pleaded s 90K(3) relief

- Asset Pool: E property in Queensland (formerly unencumbered, later mortgaged to secure borrowings)
- Asset Pool: Mortgage securing loans totalling about $2.6 million over the E property
- Asset Pool: Judgment debt owed by Mrs Grainger to Ms Bloomfield of $2,100,000 (provable debt in bankruptcy)
- Contributions: Mr Grainger provided funds used by Mrs Grainger to purchase the E property in 2007
- Just & Equitable: Case concerned creditor standing and statutory powers to set aside a financial agreement and make ancillary orders; it did not determine a s 79 property settlement or a percentage division between spouses

- Agreement Date: 1 November 2012
- Legal Advice: Cross-appellant alleged the agreement was unenforceable due to non-compliance with s 90G(1)(b) independent legal advice requirements, based on an asserted lack of independence of a solicitor who advised Mrs Grainger

- Outcome: Leave to appeal and to cross-appeal granted
- Outcome: Appeal dismissed
- Outcome: Cross-appeal dismissed
- Outcome: Appellant to pay respondent's costs of and incidental to the appeal (as agreed or assessed)
- Outcome: Cross-appellant to pay appellant's costs of and incidental to the cross-appeal (as agreed or assessed)

- Reasons: Statutory text and structure: 'third party proceedings' jurisdiction is expressly confined to setting aside a financial agreement on the ground in s 90K(1)(aa), limiting a creditor to that ground.
- Reasons: Legislative history and subsequent amendments: Parliament expressly removed creditor standing in property settlement proceedings upon bankruptcy (s 79(10A), s 90SM(11)) but did not do so for s 90K; this supported continued creditor standing under s 90K post-bankruptcy.
- Reasons: Bankruptcy principles: bankruptcy changes enforcement mechanisms and requires leave under s 58(3) but does not erase creditor status for the purposes of other legislation; any benefit of recovery would in practice flow to the bankrupt estate for distribution.
- Reasons: Summary dismissal caution: applying High Court guidance on summary termination, the Full Court held it was not sufficiently clear that the applicant had no real prospect of success regarding the scope of s 90K(3), so the issue should go to trial.
- Reasons: Accrued jurisdiction cannot be used to enlarge statutory rights; it cannot permit a creditor to rely on additional s 90K(1) grounds where jurisdiction is limited by s 4A.

- Pivotal Finding: A creditor does not cease to be a 'creditor' for s 90K(1)(aa) / s 4A purposes merely because the debtor party becomes bankrupt; bankruptcy alters remedies, not the creditor's status.
- Pivotal Finding: Section 58(3) of the Bankruptcy Act contemplates a creditor commencing/continuing litigation in respect of a provable debt with leave, supporting the possibility of creditor standing post-bankruptcy.
- Pivotal Finding: Legislative comparison: unlike s 79(10A) and s 90SM(11) (which remove creditor participation in property settlement proceedings upon bankruptcy), s 90K contains no equivalent limitation; this supported the conclusion that creditor standing under s 90K(1)(aa) does not cease on bankruptcy.
- Pivotal Finding: Authorities cited by the appellant (including Clyne; Lasic; Griffiths v Falck) did not establish that creditor standing is lost for purposes of s 90K; Zaravinos provided a helpful analogy recognising creditors and creditors as a whole as prejudiced despite trustee benefit.
- Pivotal Finding: In the context of summary dismissal, it was appropriate not to determine the ultimate scope of s 90K(3); the issue was 'triable' and required factual findings at a full hearing.
- Pivotal Finding: A creditor's entitlement to bring 'third party proceedings' is confined by s 4A to proceedings on the s 90K(1)(aa) ground; accrued/associated jurisdiction cannot expand statutory remedies to allow reliance on other s 90K(1) grounds such as s 90K(1)(b) via s 90G non-binding arguments.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K(1)(aa) (creditor defeating/defrauding or reckless disregard ground)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K(3) (ancillary preservation/adjustment orders after setting aside; just and equitable)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4(1) definition of 'matrimonial cause' para (eab) and s 4A definition of 'third party proceedings' (jurisdictional gateway limiting creditor challenges to s 90K(1)(aa))
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1) (binding requirements; independent legal advice) (raised but held outside creditor standing in third party proceedings)
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Circuit Court of Australia Act 1999 (Cth) s 17A (summary judgment power applied below)
- Statutory Pivot: Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth) s 58(3) (leave required for proceedings in respect of provable debts after bankruptcy)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 (costs discretion; general rule noted but not applied)

- Uncertainties: The Full Court did not determine the substantive s 90K(1)(aa) question (whether the agreement was entered to defraud/defeat or with reckless disregard of Ms Bloomfield as creditor); that remained for trial.
- Uncertainties: The Full Court did not define the ultimate scope of relief available under s 90K(3) (e.g., whether orders could require transfer free of mortgage or payment of value), holding only that it was inappropriate to decide on summary dismissal.
- Uncertainties: Whether leave under s 58(3)(b) of the Bankruptcy Act was obtained or required in practice for the creditor's s 90K proceedings was not determined on appeal.
