court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
parties: Mr Muir (respondent, by case guardian Ms Becke)
issues: Leave to appeal and extension of time to appeal interlocutory orders
Whether the existence of an alleged binding Part VIIIAB financial agreement ousted the Court’s jurisdiction to make interlocutory orders
Power to make interlocutory asset preservation (freezing) and disclosure orders pending determination of jurisdiction/validity issues
Interim spousal maintenance (urgent) refusal on interlocutory basis
Costs of the appeal applications
facts: The respondent was 85 years old and living in a nursing home; proceedings were conducted by his case guardian (his daughter) appointed by the Guardianship Board of South Australia.
The appellant was 36 years old and arrived in Australia with her son on a temporary visa in or about January 2010.
From about January 2010 the appellant and her son began living with the respondent at his home at Suburb A; whether this constituted a de facto relationship was disputed.
On 19 February 2014 the parties signed a financial agreement said to be under s 90UC (Part VIIIAB) providing for equal division (50/50) of all properties upon breakdown, regardless of legal title.
Between 19 February 2014 and 15 April 2014 the respondent moved into a nursing home.
In May/June 2014 the appellant commenced proceedings seeking to enforce the agreement and obtain interim relief.
The respondent disputed that any de facto relationship existed and challenged the agreement’s validity on grounds including lack of mental capacity and non-disclosure by the appellant.
A property at Suburb A owned by the respondent was sold; net sale proceeds were about $176,000.

asset_pool: Net proceeds of sale of Suburb A property: approximately $176,000 (interlocutory preservation; not a final asset pool).
Bank accounts held by the appellant and/or jointly, and accounts held in the appellant’s son’s name (subject to disclosure and restraint orders).
contributions: Not determined; substantive issues of the parties’ relationship status and agreement validity were unresolved at interlocutory/appeal stage.
future_needs: Not determined in a final sense; interlocutory evidence included the respondent being in care with limited funds and the appellant having some employment but claiming financial difficulty.
just_equitable: No final determination of a just and equitable division; interlocutory preservation orders were held not to alter property interests but to preserve disputed funds pending determination.
living_arrangements: Respondent lived in a nursing home; appellant lived in the community with her son (exact arrangements not finally determined).
existing_agreements: Alleged Part VIIIAB financial agreement dated 19 February 2014 under s 90UC, providing for 50/50 division of all properties upon breakdown.
Agreement’s binding status and whether it should be set aside were contested (including disputes about de facto status, capacity, and disclosure).

need: Appellant sought urgent interim maintenance of $713.20 per fortnight.
Primary judge considered that entitlement depended first on proving a de facto relationship; appellant had obtained some employment but asserted it was insufficient.
capacity_to_pay: Primary judge found the appellant failed to establish the respondent’s capacity to pay, noting the respondent was in care and supported by limited funds.
statutory_factors: Part VIIIAB: interaction of financial agreement and maintenance (s 90SA and clause ousting maintenance, subject to s 90UI).
General maintenance considerations noted by the primary judge: needs of the applicant, capacity to support self, and respondent’s capacity to pay (no final findings).
income_expenses: Appellant had some employment; further income/expense detail not specified.
Respondent described as having limited funds while in nursing care.
earning_capacity: Primary judge inferred appellant had capacity to obtain employment, notwithstanding ongoing migration issues.
health_care: Respondent in nursing home care (suggesting health/age-related care needs).
relationship_length: Appellant asserted cohabitation from January 2010; existence and duration of any de facto relationship were disputed and not determined.

legal_advice: Not detailed; appellant was self-represented at some interlocutory stages and later retained solicitors.
financial_disclosure: Respondent alleged the appellant failed to disclose necessary assets at the time of signing the agreement.
Disclosure issues were reinforced by identification of additional accounts through migration-related proceedings, leading to expanded bank statement orders.
changed_circumstances: Respondent moved into a nursing home after signing (timing noted), but no determination of changed circumstances affecting the agreement.

outcome_orders: Oral application for extension of time to seek leave to appeal against Orders 2, 4 and 5 made on 25 June 2014 dismissed.
Application for leave to appeal orders made on 30 October 2014 dismissed.
Appellant ordered to pay the respondent’s costs of and incidental to the applications, as agreed or assessed, payable within 28 days of agreement or assessment.

description: The Full Court confirmed that, even where a Part VIIIAB financial agreement is asserted to be binding and capable of ousting jurisdiction under s 90SA, the Court may still exercise jurisdiction to determine whether it has jurisdiction (including whether a de facto relationship existed and whether the agreement is binding/should be set aside). Pending that determination, the Court has power to make interlocutory asset preservation and ancillary disclosure orders to preserve the subject matter of the dispute. The decision draws a distinction between interlocutory preservation (not an alteration of property interests) and final property/maintenance adjudication. The Court also clarified that certain specific injunction provisions (ss 114(2A) and 90SS) were not available in Division 4 agreement proceedings, but s 34 (and implied powers) provided a sufficient source of power for the preservation injunctions.
pivotal_findings: Whether the parties were in a de facto relationship and whether the financial agreement was binding had not yet been determined at first instance; therefore the appellant’s jurisdiction-ouster argument could not succeed at the interlocutory appeal stage.
The challenged orders were characterised as interlocutory asset preservation orders designed to preserve disputed funds pending final determination, not to finally alter property interests.

The primary judge had jurisdiction to hear proceedings with respect to a Part VIIIAB financial agreement (a de facto financial cause) and power to make interlocutory injunctions under s 34 and/or implied powers.

No appealable error was demonstrated in ordering preservation of half the Suburb A sale proceeds and restraining dealings with the appellant’s accounts (subject to exceptions), nor in making ancillary disclosure orders.
No error shown in refusing urgent interim maintenance where de facto status was unresolved and the respondent’s capacity to pay was not established.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4(1) (definition of de facto financial cause, including proceedings re Part VIIIAB financial agreements)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 31(1)(aa) (jurisdiction in de facto financial causes)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90UC (financial agreements during a de facto relationship)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SA (effect of binding financial agreement excluding jurisdiction for property/maintenance proceedings covered by the agreement)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90UI (limited preservation of maintenance claims notwithstanding agreement, noted as unlikely to apply on advice)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 34 (general power to make orders including interlocutory injunctions where jurisdiction exists)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 114 and s 114(2A) (considered but found not applicable to Division 4 agreement proceedings)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SS (considered but found not applicable to Division 4 agreement proceedings)

reasons_rationale: Because the existence of a de facto relationship and the binding status/validity of the financial agreement were disputed and unresolved, s 90SA could not be treated as conclusively ousting jurisdiction at the interlocutory stage.
The Family Court can preserve the status quo while determining jurisdiction, including by interlocutory injunctions to secure disputed funds and prevent dissipation.

Although specific injunction powers in ss 114(2A) and 90SS were not available for Division 4 agreement proceedings, the Court’s general power under s 34 (and implied powers) supported the making of interlocutory asset preservation orders.
Disclosure orders were treated as ancillary to preservation orders and appropriate.
Interim maintenance was refused because entitlement depended on establishing a de facto relationship and, most significantly, the appellant did not establish the respondent’s capacity to pay.
Costs followed the event given the appellant was wholly unsuccessful.
uncertainties: Whether the parties were in a de facto relationship (a jurisdictional fact) was contested and not determined in this appeal.
Whether the 19 February 2014 Part VIIIAB agreement was binding, valid, or should be set aside (capacity and non-disclosure allegations) was not determined.
Final property division and any final maintenance entitlement were not determined; the decision concerned interlocutory orders and appellate leave/time extension only.

- Issue: Power to make interlocutory asset preservation (freezing) and disclosure orders pending determination of jurisdiction/validity issues
- Issue: Interim spousal maintenance (urgent) refusal on interlocutory basis
- Issue: Costs of the appeal applications

- Asset Pool: Net proceeds of sale of Suburb A property: approximately $176,000 (interlocutory preservation; not a final asset pool).
- Asset Pool: Bank accounts held by the appellant and/or jointly, and accounts held in the appellant’s son’s name (subject to disclosure and restraint orders).
- Contributions: Not determined; substantive issues of the parties’ relationship status and agreement validity were unresolved at interlocutory/appeal stage.
- Future Needs: Not determined in a final sense; interlocutory evidence included the respondent being in care with limited funds and the appellant having some employment but claiming financial difficulty.
- Just & Equitable: No final determination of a just and equitable division; interlocutory preservation orders were held not to alter property interests but to preserve disputed funds pending determination.

- Need: Appellant sought urgent interim maintenance of $713.20 per fortnight.
- Need: Primary judge considered that entitlement depended first on proving a de facto relationship; appellant had obtained some employment but asserted it was insufficient.
- Capacity to Pay: Primary judge found the appellant failed to establish the respondent’s capacity to pay, noting the respondent was in care and supported by limited funds.
- Statutory Factors: Part VIIIAB: interaction of financial agreement and maintenance (s 90SA and clause ousting maintenance, subject to s 90UI).
- Statutory Factors: General maintenance considerations noted by the primary judge: needs of the applicant, capacity to support self, and respondent’s capacity to pay (no final findings).

- Agreement Date: 19 February 2014
- Legal Advice: Not detailed; appellant was self-represented at some interlocutory stages and later retained solicitors.
- Financial Disclosure: Respondent alleged the appellant failed to disclose necessary assets at the time of signing the agreement.
- Financial Disclosure: Disclosure issues were reinforced by identification of additional accounts through migration-related proceedings, leading to expanded bank statement orders.
- Changed Circumstances: Respondent moved into a nursing home after signing (timing noted), but no determination of changed circumstances affecting the agreement.

- Outcome: Oral application for extension of time to seek leave to appeal against Orders 2, 4 and 5 made on 25 June 2014 dismissed.
- Outcome: Application for leave to appeal orders made on 30 October 2014 dismissed.
- Outcome: Appellant ordered to pay the respondent’s costs of and incidental to the applications, as agreed or assessed, payable within 28 days of agreement or assessment.

- Reasons: Because the existence of a de facto relationship and the binding status/validity of the financial agreement were disputed and unresolved, s 90SA could not be treated as conclusively ousting jurisdiction at the interlocutory stage.
- Reasons: The Family Court can preserve the status quo while determining jurisdiction, including by interlocutory injunctions to secure disputed funds and prevent dissipation.
- Reasons: Although specific injunction powers in ss 114(2A) and 90SS were not available for Division 4 agreement proceedings, the Court’s general power under s 34 (and implied powers) supported the making of interlocutory asset preservation orders.
- Reasons: Disclosure orders were treated as ancillary to preservation orders and appropriate.
- Reasons: Interim maintenance was refused because entitlement depended on establishing a de facto relationship and, most significantly, the appellant did not establish the respondent’s capacity to pay.
- Reasons: Costs followed the event given the appellant was wholly unsuccessful.

- Pivotal Finding: Whether the parties were in a de facto relationship and whether the financial agreement was binding had not yet been determined at first instance; therefore the appellant’s jurisdiction-ouster argument could not succeed at the interlocutory appeal stage.
- Pivotal Finding: The challenged orders were characterised as interlocutory asset preservation orders designed to preserve disputed funds pending final determination, not to finally alter property interests.
- Pivotal Finding: The primary judge had jurisdiction to hear proceedings with respect to a Part VIIIAB financial agreement (a de facto financial cause) and power to make interlocutory injunctions under s 34 and/or implied powers.
- Pivotal Finding: No appealable error was demonstrated in ordering preservation of half the Suburb A sale proceeds and restraining dealings with the appellant’s accounts (subject to exceptions), nor in making ancillary disclosure orders.
- Pivotal Finding: No error shown in refusing urgent interim maintenance where de facto status was unresolved and the respondent’s capacity to pay was not established.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4(1) (definition of de facto financial cause, including proceedings re Part VIIIAB financial agreements)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 31(1)(aa) (jurisdiction in de facto financial causes)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90UC (financial agreements during a de facto relationship)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SA (effect of binding financial agreement excluding jurisdiction for property/maintenance proceedings covered by the agreement)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90UI (limited preservation of maintenance claims notwithstanding agreement, noted as unlikely to apply on advice)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 34 (general power to make orders including interlocutory injunctions where jurisdiction exists)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 114 and s 114(2A) (considered but found not applicable to Division 4 agreement proceedings)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SS (considered but found not applicable to Division 4 agreement proceedings)

- Uncertainties: Whether the parties were in a de facto relationship (a jurisdictional fact) was contested and not determined in this appeal.
- Uncertainties: Whether the 19 February 2014 Part VIIIAB agreement was binding, valid, or should be set aside (capacity and non-disclosure allegations) was not determined.
- Uncertainties: Final property division and any final maintenance entitlement were not determined; the decision concerned interlocutory orders and appellate leave/time extension only.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether a single document can validly contain a financial agreement purportedly made under both Part VIIIA (s 90B) and Part VIIIAB (s 90UC) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether there was compliance with s 90UJ(1)(b) requirement for independent legal advice (effect of agreement; advantages and disadvantages) so as to make the Part VIIIAB financial agreement binding
Whether any error in approach to s 90UJ(1A) (unjust and inequitable) discretionary basis to uphold a non-compliant agreement
Appeal challenge to trial judge's findings and declarations that agreement was binding and refusal to set aside
facts: The parties met in May 2003 and commenced a relationship in May 2004.
They became engaged in May 2005.
They were in a de facto relationship and engaged to marry, but the marriage did not occur.
The trial judge found the relationship ended in April 2010.
On 21 August 2009 the parties executed a written agreement headed as a financial agreement pursuant to s 90B and s 90UC.

asset_pool: The agreement dealt with division of parties' assets upon relationship breakdown using a CPI-indexed formula for the respondent's share.
Agreement excluded from the respondent's share: inheritance, gifts, and chattels listed in Annexure A to the First Schedule.
No total value of assets/liabilities or balance sheet was stated in the provided text.
contributions: Property contributions were not determined in this appeal; the proceeding concerned enforceability/binding nature of a financial agreement.
The trial judge considered the parties' history of signing documents dealing with property and that the appellant had an 'upper hand' in financial affairs during the relationship.
future_needs: Future needs factors under property adjustment provisions were not assessed; the dispute focused on whether a financial agreement precluded property litigation.
just_equitable: No s 79 or s 90SM 'just and equitable' property adjustment was conducted; the issue was whether the agreement was binding and thus excluded court determination.
The trial judge, in context of s 90UJ(1A), considered it would be unjust and inequitable for the parties not to be bound (if non-compliance were assumed).
living_arrangements: The relationship ended in April 2010; no further post-separation living arrangements were stated.
existing_agreements: A single agreement dated August 2009 was in issue; it purported to be made under both s 90B and s 90UC.

Trial judge noted various agreements during the relationship dealing with property and reflecting an intention that the appellant would not claim on the respondent's assets (details not specified in the provided text).

statutory_factors: s 90UJ (binding requirements for Part VIIIAB financial agreements) was central; maintenance issues were not substantively determined.
relationship_length: Relationship commenced May 2004; ended April 2010 (as found).

agreement_date: 21 August 2009 (signed by respondent); appellant signed earlier in August 2009 (7 August 2009 stated in grounds)
legal_advice: Recital N recorded that before signing each party received independent legal advice as to: effect of the agreement on rights; whether it was to the party's advantage (financially or otherwise) to make the agreement; whether it was prudent; and whether provisions were fair and reasonable in light of reasonably foreseeable circumstances.
Evidence from appellant: he was only given oral advice; he did not remember details; he believed Recital N recorded the nature of the advice he was given.

Full Court held that although the trial judge's reasoning about 'otherwise' was erroneous, the evidence permitted inference that advice about advantages and disadvantages was given (via advice on prudence and fair/reasonable).

Murphy J agreed agreement was binding but considered trial judge misdirected herself by focusing only on the phrase 'advantage, financially or otherwise' rather than all advice components in the recital/certificates.
pressure_duress: Trial judge made adverse findings about appellant's conduct in the relationship financial dealings, including findings described as unconscionable and exploitative in the context of s 90UJ(1A) discussion (not a formal set-aside determination under duress provisions in this appeal excerpt).
changed_circumstances: Change of circumstances was noted as not to be considered in the Hoult factors context (as discussed by Full Court), but no particular changes were identified.

description: Decided appellate judgment concerning enforceability of a de facto financial agreement under Part VIIIAB where a single document purported to operate under both Part VIIIA (contemplated marriage) and Part VIIIAB (de facto relationship). The appeal turned on statutory construction (whether concurrent agreements can exist in one instrument and be complementary given s 90UJ(3)) and evidentiary sufficiency regarding the content of legal advice under s 90UJ(1)(b). The Full Court emphasised that Parts VIIIA and VIIIAB are distinct but not mutually exclusive; both agreements can be binding though only one can have operative effect at a time (de facto agreement ceasing upon marriage; marriage agreement springing into operation upon marriage). A critical evidentiary pivot was whether advice about 'prudence' and 'fair and reasonable' permits inference that advantages and disadvantages were discussed, satisfying s 90UJ(1)(b) despite imperfect wording in recitals/certificates.
pivotal_findings: No statutory imperative requires s 90B and s 90UC agreements to be in separate documents; the two can exist concurrently and be contained in one instrument.
Part VIIIA exclusion in s 90B(1)(aa) does not preclude a Part VIIIAB agreement, and Part VIIIAB exclusions similarly do not preclude Part VIIIA; this supported concurrency.

The agreements are complementary: a s 90UC agreement can be binding while parties remain de facto and ceases on marriage (s 90UJ(3)), while a s 90B agreement operates only upon marriage and relevant breakdown.

Ground 2: trial judge erred in construing 'advantage, financially or otherwise' as necessarily including disadvantage; however, the Full Court inferred from advice on prudence and fair/reasonable that the appellant was advised of advantages and disadvantages, so s 90UJ(1)(b) was satisfied.

No error shown in the trial judge's approach to s 90UJ(1A); references to parties' steps and intentions were relevant and not an impermissible fairness assessment of agreement terms (as characterised on appeal).
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90UC (Part VIIIAB financial agreement while in de facto relationship)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90UJ(1) (binding requirements, including legal advice about effect and advantages/disadvantages)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90UJ(3) (Part VIIIAB agreement ceases to be binding if parties marry)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90B (Part VIIIA financial agreement before marriage) and s 90G (analogous binding requirements for Part VIIIA agreements)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90UJ(1A) (court power to declare agreement binding if unjust and inequitable for it not to be binding, raised as alternative)
Authorities referenced on strict compliance and remedial amendments: Black and Black; Wallace & Stelzer; Hoult & Hoult; J & J; Whatley & Whatley

reasons_rationale: The Full Court held there is no necessary conflict between being in a de facto relationship and contemplating marriage; both statuses can coexist and support agreements under s 90UC and s 90B.
Text and structure of the Act indicate Part VIIIA and Part VIIIAB agreements can coexist; exclusions prevent multiple agreements within the same Part, but not across Parts.
Only one agreement is operative at a time due to s 90UJ(3) and the contingent operation of s 90B agreements; therefore having both agreements in one document does not make s 90UJ(3) nugatory.

On advice: although the phrase 'advantage, financially or otherwise' does not itself equate to 'advantages and disadvantages', the evidence of advice as to prudence and whether terms were fair and reasonable permitted inference that disadvantages were also addressed.

On s 90UJ(1A) contentions: the trial judge's consideration of the parties' actions and intention to have an agreement in place was relevant, and the asserted reliance on 'fairness of terms' was not supported by the reasons.
Costs followed the event; appellant ordered to pay respondent's costs of the appeal.
uncertainties: The provided text does not set out the detailed asset values, liabilities, or the practical monetary effect of the agreement's formula.
The decision concerns enforceability rather than substantive property adjustment, so contributions and future needs were not quantified.
No detail is provided about any children or parenting issues; they appear not to be part of the appeal.

court: Family Court of Australia (Full Court) at Brisbane
issues: Leave to appeal and/or appeal as of right from summary dismissal of a de facto property application
Standing/locus standi to appeal where the appellant is an undischarged bankrupt and the trustee in bankruptcy is not a party
Whether the Federal Circuit Court had jurisdiction to make a de facto property order given relationship duration under two years and no child of the relationship (s 90SB)
Whether the appellant made 'substantial contributions' under s 90SB(c)(i) by reference to s 90SM(4)(a)-(c)
Whether failure to make an order would result in 'serious injustice' under s 90SB(c)(ii)
facts: The appellant commenced Federal Circuit Court proceedings on 28 January 2014 seeking a declaration of a de facto relationship and, if established, final de facto property orders.
The respondent applied on 10 March 2014 for summary dismissal.
The parties lived together during 2013; the relationship ended on 25 December 2013.
The relationship duration was less than two years and there was no child of the relationship.
The appellant is an undischarged bankrupt; the trustee in bankruptcy did not participate and indicated an intention to abide by any order.

asset_pool: No real property was acquired during the relationship; the parties lived in rental accommodation.
Assets discussed included chattels/household effects, a motor vehicle, superannuation, cash, and business/household equipment (including camera equipment and kitchen goods).
Appellant asserted financial contributions totalling about $52,000 (including $10,000 said to be for respondent’s business and purchase of an engagement ring and other goods/furniture).
Engagement ring purchased for $6,500; appellant conceded market value was less than half that amount (about $3,500 referenced in reasons).

At commencement: appellant asserted net assets about $91,000 (chattels, superannuation, car, cash) and credit card debt about $10,000; respondent asserted assets about $13,000 with liabilities exceeding assets.

At hearing: appellant asserted assets about $32,965 (including household effects, superannuation about $25,000, car, cash) and credit card debt about $70,000; respondent asserted assets about $27,000 (including car worth $10,000, camera equipment worth $10,000, furniture and kitchen goods) and a car debt about $15,000.
contributions: Appellant asserted financial contributions: shared rental bond, shared expenses, holidays/outings, and expenditure on household goods and an engagement ring; asserted $10,000 paid for respondent’s business equipment.
Appellant asserted homemaker/non-financial contributions including domestic duties and caring for the respondent’s children while the respondent worked on her business.

Primary judge found that, even accepting appellant’s evidence at its highest, contributions were not 'substantial' as required for s 90SB(c)(i) given the short relationship and limited asset accumulation.
Primary judge found the parties’ contributions produced little asset growth; most assets brought in by the appellant were retained by him; expenditure on holidays/dining benefited both parties.
future_needs: Appellant asserted inability to work and reliance on Centrelink; primary judge accepted depressive adjustment disorder.

Primary judge considered asserted hardship/self-sufficiency issues but found the appellant’s constrained circumstances were attributable to bankruptcy rather than absence of a de facto property order.
No detailed s 90SM(4) future needs analysis was reached because jurisdictional threshold under s 90SB was not satisfied.
just_equitable: Respondent argued alternatively that even if jurisdiction existed, it would not be just and equitable to make orders.
Primary judge’s dismissal was based on lack of jurisdictional threshold (no substantial contributions; no serious injustice), so a full just and equitable assessment was not determinative.
living_arrangements: Parties cohabited during 2013 and lived in rental accommodation.
Relationship ended 25 December 2013.

earning_capacity: Appellant asserted he was no longer able to work as a solicitor and was in receipt of Centrelink; accepted by the primary judge as part of evidence.
health_care: Primary judge accepted appellant suffered a depressive adjustment disorder.
relationship_length: Relationship was less than two years.

caregiver_history: Appellant asserted he cared for the respondent’s children at times while the respondent was absent building her business.
safety_concerns: The appellant had obtained, associated with a Temporary Protection Order in his favour, an order that the respondent return certain household and other items.

protection_orders: Temporary Protection Order in the appellant’s favour was referenced in connection with an order for return of certain items.

outcome_orders: Application for leave to appeal the orders of Judge Purdon-Sully made on 11 September 2014 dismissed.
No order as to costs.

description: The case confirms the jurisdictional gatekeeping role of s 90SB for de facto property claims where the relationship is under two years and there is no child of the relationship. The Full Court upheld summary dismissal where, even taking the applicant’s evidence at its highest, the alleged financial and non-financial contributions were found not to be 'substantial' and no serious injustice was demonstrated. Bankruptcy considerations were relevant to the 'serious injustice' inquiry because any property recovered might vest in the trustee, affecting whether an order would remedy the applicant’s position. The appeal also addressed standing issues for an undischarged bankrupt and the nature of summary dismissal orders (interlocutory vs final) in the Family Law Act context, with Murphy J holding the dismissal effectively final for res judicata purposes (thus no leave required), though all judges agreed the challenge lacked merit.
pivotal_findings: The relationship was of short duration (less than two years) and there was no child of the relationship, engaging s 90SB thresholds.

Even accepting the appellant’s evidence at its highest, his financial and non-financial contributions (including domestic/care of respondent’s children, shared expenses, alleged payments for business equipment, and purchase of ring/chattels) were not 'substantial' in the statutory sense (more than usual/ordinary; aimed at exceptional cases).
The parties acquired no real property, had limited asset accumulation, and the appellant retained most assets he brought into the relationship.

No serious injustice was shown: some claimed items were subject to a protection-order-related return order; bankruptcy, rather than lack of property orders, explained hardship; and there was no evidence any monetary order would benefit the appellant rather than vesting in the trustee.
Adequate reasons were provided and the correct summary dismissal test was applied (accepting appellant’s asserted facts).
Consideration of the trustee in bankruptcy was not undue; it was relevant to whether any order would alleviate injustice given possible vesting under bankruptcy law.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SB (particularly s 90SB(c)(i) and (ii))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SM(4)(a)-(c)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SM(15) and s 90SM(16) (bankrupt party submissions where trustee is a party; exceptional circumstances)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 94AA and Family Law Regulations 1984 (Cth) reg 15A (leave to appeal framework)
Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth) s 116(2)(b) and s 116(2)(ba) (exempt property concepts raised)
Bankruptcy Regulations 1996 (Cth) reg 6.03 and 6.03A (exempt property categories raised)

reasons_rationale: The primary judge correctly approached summary dismissal by accepting the appellant’s evidence as accurate but determining it could not satisfy s 90SB thresholds required for jurisdiction to make de facto property orders.
On the evidence, it was reasonably open to find the alleged contributions were not 'substantial' (more than usual/ordinary) and that the relationship produced little in the way of asset accumulation.
The primary judge’s reasons were adequate, disclosing the path of reasoning on the critical issues (substantial contributions and serious injustice).
Bankruptcy was relevant to serious injustice because any property recovered might vest in the trustee; thus an order might not change the appellant’s position.
No procedural unfairness occurred; the judge applied the correct test and did not base the decision on untested evidence.
uncertainties: The Full Court proceeded on an assumption (without full submissions) that the appellant had standing to pursue the appeal notwithstanding bankruptcy, noting the trustee was not a party and the appellant claimed the property sought was exempt personal/household property.

Whether leave to appeal was strictly necessary was left unresolved by May and Ainslie-Wallace JJ (though they dismissed the leave application on lack of merit); Murphy J held leave was not necessary because the dismissal was effectively final.

summary_text:
- Fact: The appellant commenced Federal Circuit Court proceedings on 28 January 2014 seeking a declaration of a de facto relationship and, if established, final de facto property orders.
- Fact: The respondent applied on 10 March 2014 for summary dismissal.
- Fact: The parties lived together during 2013; the relationship ended on 25 December 2013.
- Fact: The relationship duration was less than two years and there was no child of the relationship.
- Fact: The appellant is an undischarged bankrupt; the trustee in bankruptcy did not participate and indicated an intention to abide by any order.

- Issue: Leave to appeal and/or appeal as of right from summary dismissal of a de facto property application
- Issue: Standing/locus standi to appeal where the appellant is an undischarged bankrupt and the trustee in bankruptcy is not a party
- Issue: Whether the Federal Circuit Court had jurisdiction to make a de facto property order given relationship duration under two years and no child of the relationship (s 90SB)
- Issue: Whether the appellant made 'substantial contributions' under s 90SB(c)(i) by reference to s 90SM(4)(a)-(c)
- Issue: Whether failure to make an order would result in 'serious injustice' under s 90SB(c)(ii)

- Asset Pool: No real property was acquired during the relationship; the parties lived in rental accommodation.
- Asset Pool: Assets discussed included chattels/household effects, a motor vehicle, superannuation, cash, and business/household equipment (including camera equipment and kitchen goods).
- Asset Pool: Appellant asserted financial contributions totalling about $52,000 (including $10,000 said to be for respondent’s business and purchase of an engagement ring and other goods/furniture).
- Asset Pool: Engagement ring purchased for $6,500; appellant conceded market value was less than half that amount (about $3,500 referenced in reasons).
- Asset Pool: At commencement: appellant asserted net assets about $91,000 (chattels, superannuation, car, cash) and credit card debt about $10,000; respondent asserted assets about $13,000 with liabilities exceeding assets.
- Asset Pool: At hearing: appellant asserted assets about $32,965 (including household effects, superannuation about $25,000, car, cash) and credit card debt about $70,000; respondent asserted assets about $27,000 (including car worth $10,000, camera equipment worth $10,000, furniture and kitchen goods) and a car debt about $15,000.
- Contributions: Appellant asserted financial contributions: shared rental bond, shared expenses, holidays/outings, and expenditure on household goods and an engagement ring; asserted $10,000 paid for respondent’s business equipment.
- Contributions: Appellant asserted homemaker/non-financial contributions including domestic duties and caring for the respondent’s children while the respondent worked on her business.
- Contributions: Primary judge found that, even accepting appellant’s evidence at its highest, contributions were not 'substantial' as required for s 90SB(c)(i) given the short relationship and limited asset accumulation.
- Contributions: Primary judge found the parties’ contributions produced little asset growth; most assets brought in by the appellant were retained by him; expenditure on holidays/dining benefited both parties.
- Future Needs: Appellant asserted inability to work and reliance on Centrelink; primary judge accepted depressive adjustment disorder.
- Future Needs: Primary judge considered asserted hardship/self-sufficiency issues but found the appellant’s constrained circumstances were attributable to bankruptcy rather than absence of a de facto property order.
- Future Needs: No detailed s 90SM(4) future needs analysis was reached because jurisdictional threshold under s 90SB was not satisfied.
- Just & Equitable: Respondent argued alternatively that even if jurisdiction existed, it would not be just and equitable to make orders.
- Just & Equitable: Primary judge’s dismissal was based on lack of jurisdictional threshold (no substantial contributions; no serious injustice), so a full just and equitable assessment was not determinative.
- Safety Concerns: The appellant had obtained, associated with a Temporary Protection Order in his favour, an order that the respondent return certain household and other items.
- Protection Orders: Temporary Protection Order in the appellant’s favour was referenced in connection with an order for return of certain items.

- Outcome: Application for leave to appeal the orders of Judge Purdon-Sully made on 11 September 2014 dismissed.
- Outcome: No order as to costs.

- Reasons: The primary judge correctly approached summary dismissal by accepting the appellant’s evidence as accurate but determining it could not satisfy s 90SB thresholds required for jurisdiction to make de facto property orders.
- Reasons: On the evidence, it was reasonably open to find the alleged contributions were not 'substantial' (more than usual/ordinary) and that the relationship produced little in the way of asset accumulation.
- Reasons: The primary judge’s reasons were adequate, disclosing the path of reasoning on the critical issues (substantial contributions and serious injustice).
- Reasons: Bankruptcy was relevant to serious injustice because any property recovered might vest in the trustee; thus an order might not change the appellant’s position.
- Reasons: No procedural unfairness occurred; the judge applied the correct test and did not base the decision on untested evidence.

- Pivotal Finding: The relationship was of short duration (less than two years) and there was no child of the relationship, engaging s 90SB thresholds.
- Pivotal Finding: Even accepting the appellant’s evidence at its highest, his financial and non-financial contributions (including domestic/care of respondent’s children, shared expenses, alleged payments for business equipment, and purchase of ring/chattels) were not 'substantial' in the statutory sense (more than usual/ordinary; aimed at exceptional cases).
- Pivotal Finding: The parties acquired no real property, had limited asset accumulation, and the appellant retained most assets he brought into the relationship.
- Pivotal Finding: No serious injustice was shown: some claimed items were subject to a protection-order-related return order; bankruptcy, rather than lack of property orders, explained hardship; and there was no evidence any monetary order would benefit the appellant rather than vesting in the trustee.
- Pivotal Finding: Adequate reasons were provided and the correct summary dismissal test was applied (accepting appellant’s asserted facts).
- Pivotal Finding: Consideration of the trustee in bankruptcy was not undue; it was relevant to whether any order would alleviate injustice given possible vesting under bankruptcy law.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SB (particularly s 90SB(c)(i) and (ii))
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SM(4)(a)-(c)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SM(15) and s 90SM(16) (bankrupt party submissions where trustee is a party; exceptional circumstances)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 94AA and Family Law Regulations 1984 (Cth) reg 15A (leave to appeal framework)
- Statutory Pivot: Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth) s 116(2)(b) and s 116(2)(ba) (exempt property concepts raised)
- Statutory Pivot: Bankruptcy Regulations 1996 (Cth) reg 6.03 and 6.03A (exempt property categories raised)

- Uncertainties: The Full Court proceeded on an assumption (without full submissions) that the appellant had standing to pursue the appeal notwithstanding bankruptcy, noting the trustee was not a party and the appellant claimed the property sought was exempt personal/household property.
- Uncertainties: Whether leave to appeal was strictly necessary was left unresolved by May and Ainslie-Wallace JJ (though they dismissed the leave application on lack of merit); Murphy J held leave was not necessary because the dismissal was effectively final.

case_name: Child Support Registrar & Crowley and Anor
court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
parties: Mr Crowley by his Case Guardian (first respondent/father)
issues: Leave to appeal under s 107A(1) Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 (Cth)
Whether the Federal Circuit Court exceeded power by substituting its own decision and making departure-related orders without satisfying ss 110F and 110G of the Registration Act
Correct interpretation and application of the structured discretion and three-step process in s 117 Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) for departure from administrative assessment
Whether a departure applicant must establish only one ground under s 117(1)(b)(i) (and s 117(2) grounds) before considering s 117(4) and (5) matters
Distinction between prerequisite departure grounds (s 117(2)) and countervailing considerations (s 117(4))
Whether hardship under s 117(4)(g) requires calculation/quantification of child support arrears
facts: On 8 October 2012, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal set the father's adjusted taxable income in specified amounts for two child support periods, significantly increasing his liability for two children aged seven and five.

The father appealed the Tribunal decision to the Federal Circuit Court of Australia, which on 31 July 2014 allowed the appeal and set aside the Tribunal decision and purported to substitute its own assessment-related orders.
The mother was in receipt of a Centrelink benefit; the Tribunal found her lack of remunerative employment was unconnected with child support issues.

The father suffered a brain injury from a pre-marriage car accident and received two pensions from former armed forces employment: a taxable Military Super pension and a non-taxable Veterans’ Entitlements Act total and permanent disability pension.
The father deposited about $400 per week into a superannuation account intended to provide for future residential care when his parents could no longer assist with his care.
The Tribunal found the weekly superannuation contribution was not a 'necessary' commitment in the sense explained in Gyselman.

The Tribunal treated the case as 'out of the ordinary' because a sizeable component of the father's overall income did not form part of adjusted taxable income and found a departure ground (Reason 8) established under s 117(2)(c).

child_ages: Two children aged seven and five at the time of the Tribunal decision (8 October 2012).

outcome_orders: Leave to appeal the decision of Judge Coates made on 31 July 2014 granted.
Appeal allowed.
Orders of Judge Coates made on 31 July 2014 set aside.
Each party to bear their own costs of and incidental to the appeal.
Costs certificate granted to the first respondent (Mr Crowley) pursuant to s 6 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
Effect of setting aside the FCCA orders: the Tribunal decision of 8 October 2012 stands.

description: The decision clarifies the 'highly structured discretion' for child support departure under s 117 of the Assessment Act and the limited scope of judicial review from SSAT to the FCCA (questions of law only). It corrects the FCCA’s conflation of the threshold task of establishing a departure ground (s 117(2), engaged via s 117(1)(b)(i)) with the separate evaluative stage of justice/equity and other countervailing considerations (s 117(1)(b)(ii), s 117(4), s 117(5)). The Full Court also confirms that quantifying arrears is not a necessary precondition to assessing hardship under s 117(4)(g) and that courts must act within power when substituting decisions under the Registration Act.
pivotal_findings: The FCCA erred by substituting its own departure-related decision without making/adopting all necessary factual findings required by ss 110F and 110G of the Registration Act and without applying the strict three-step process under s 117 of the Assessment Act.
The FCCA made an ultra vires order purporting to exclude the father’s Veterans’ pension entitlements from child support income on an ongoing basis; no legislative provision empowered that order.

An applicant for departure is required to establish one ground of departure under s 117(1)(b)(i) (and relevant s 117(2) ground); it is not necessary to establish additional grounds merely because other factual circumstances exist.

The FCCA failed to distinguish prerequisite grounds under s 117(2) from countervailing considerations relevant to the non-applicant parent under s 117(4), producing erroneous conclusions that the Tribunal made errors of law.
The Tribunal did not err by not referring to s 117(2)(a)(iii) because that ground was not relied upon; the Tribunal instead considered 'necessary commitments' at the appropriate stage under s 117(4).
The FCCA misread the Tribunal’s treatment of superannuation and hardship; the Tribunal did not decide that the father must access superannuation to pay arrears and did consider hardship.

It is not necessary to calculate arrears of child support for the purpose of considering hardship under s 117(4)(g); a broad assessment can be taken and the Tribunal’s approach was open on the evidence.
statutory_pivots: Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 (Cth) s 107A(1) and s 107A(5) (leave requirement and Full Court power to make decision that ought to have been made)
Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 (Cth) s 110B (appeal to FCCA on a question of law only)
Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 (Cth) ss 110F and 110G (powers/requirements when dealing with Tribunal decisions and substituting decisions)
Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(1)(b)(i) and s 117(1)(b)(ii) (departure ground prerequisite and just/equitable/otherwise proper stages)
Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(2) (grounds/special circumstances framework)
Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(4) including s 117(4)(e) (necessary commitments) and s 117(4)(g) (hardship consideration)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval of publication under pseudonym)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) s 6 (costs certificate)

reasons_rationale: Leave to appeal was granted because important matters of principle arose, including misapprehension of the statutory process for departing from administrative assessment.

The FCCA’s substituted departure-related orders were set aside because the FCCA did not make the factual findings necessary to exercise substitution powers and did not apply s 117’s structured discretion.
The FCCA erred in law by conflating the establishment of a departure ground with the later justice/equity and countervailing consideration stages; only one ground is required to be established.
The FCCA incorrectly treated s 117(2)(a)(iii) as mandatory in circumstances where it was not a ground relied upon and no legal issue about it arose before the Tribunal.
The FCCA misinterpreted the Tribunal’s handling of the father's medical condition and superannuation evidence; the Tribunal properly evaluated necessary commitments and hardship within s 117(4).
The FCCA wrongly held arrears must be calculated for hardship; the Full Court held quantification is not necessary for s 117(4)(g) and the Tribunal’s broad approach was permissible.
Because the Full Court could not make essential factual findings itself on the materials, it set aside the FCCA orders with the result that the Tribunal’s 8 October 2012 decision remained in force.
uncertainties: The precise adjusted taxable income figures set by the Tribunal for the two child support periods are not stated in the provided text excerpt.
The exact terms of all FCCA orders beyond the quoted substituted income assessment and exclusion of veterans pension are not fully reproduced in the excerpt.
The exact child support periods and specific dates for the Tribunal’s departure effect are only partially described (including reference to 1 July 2010 to 30 June 2013 and 'thereafter').

- Issue: Leave to appeal under s 107A(1) Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 (Cth)
- Issue: Whether the Federal Circuit Court exceeded power by substituting its own decision and making departure-related orders without satisfying ss 110F and 110G of the Registration Act
- Issue: Correct interpretation and application of the structured discretion and three-step process in s 117 Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) for departure from administrative assessment
- Issue: Whether a departure applicant must establish only one ground under s 117(1)(b)(i) (and s 117(2) grounds) before considering s 117(4) and (5) matters
- Issue: Distinction between prerequisite departure grounds (s 117(2)) and countervailing considerations (s 117(4))
- Issue: Whether hardship under s 117(4)(g) requires calculation/quantification of child support arrears
- Child Ages: Two children aged seven and five at the time of the Tribunal decision (8 October 2012).

- Outcome: Leave to appeal the decision of Judge Coates made on 31 July 2014 granted.
- Outcome: Appeal allowed.
- Outcome: Orders of Judge Coates made on 31 July 2014 set aside.
- Outcome: Each party to bear their own costs of and incidental to the appeal.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the first respondent (Mr Crowley) pursuant to s 6 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
- Outcome: Effect of setting aside the FCCA orders: the Tribunal decision of 8 October 2012 stands.

- Reasons: Leave to appeal was granted because important matters of principle arose, including misapprehension of the statutory process for departing from administrative assessment.
- Reasons: The FCCA’s substituted departure-related orders were set aside because the FCCA did not make the factual findings necessary to exercise substitution powers and did not apply s 117’s structured discretion.
- Reasons: The FCCA erred in law by conflating the establishment of a departure ground with the later justice/equity and countervailing consideration stages; only one ground is required to be established.
- Reasons: The FCCA incorrectly treated s 117(2)(a)(iii) as mandatory in circumstances where it was not a ground relied upon and no legal issue about it arose before the Tribunal.
- Reasons: The FCCA misinterpreted the Tribunal’s handling of the father's medical condition and superannuation evidence; the Tribunal properly evaluated necessary commitments and hardship within s 117(4).
- Reasons: The FCCA wrongly held arrears must be calculated for hardship; the Full Court held quantification is not necessary for s 117(4)(g) and the Tribunal’s broad approach was permissible.
- Reasons: Because the Full Court could not make essential factual findings itself on the materials, it set aside the FCCA orders with the result that the Tribunal’s 8 October 2012 decision remained in force.

- Pivotal Finding: The FCCA erred by substituting its own departure-related decision without making/adopting all necessary factual findings required by ss 110F and 110G of the Registration Act and without applying the strict three-step process under s 117 of the Assessment Act.
- Pivotal Finding: The FCCA made an ultra vires order purporting to exclude the father’s Veterans’ pension entitlements from child support income on an ongoing basis; no legislative provision empowered that order.
- Pivotal Finding: An applicant for departure is required to establish one ground of departure under s 117(1)(b)(i) (and relevant s 117(2) ground); it is not necessary to establish additional grounds merely because other factual circumstances exist.
- Pivotal Finding: The FCCA failed to distinguish prerequisite grounds under s 117(2) from countervailing considerations relevant to the non-applicant parent under s 117(4), producing erroneous conclusions that the Tribunal made errors of law.
- Pivotal Finding: The Tribunal did not err by not referring to s 117(2)(a)(iii) because that ground was not relied upon; the Tribunal instead considered 'necessary commitments' at the appropriate stage under s 117(4).
- Pivotal Finding: The FCCA misread the Tribunal’s treatment of superannuation and hardship; the Tribunal did not decide that the father must access superannuation to pay arrears and did consider hardship.
- Pivotal Finding: It is not necessary to calculate arrears of child support for the purpose of considering hardship under s 117(4)(g); a broad assessment can be taken and the Tribunal’s approach was open on the evidence.
- Statutory Pivot: Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 (Cth) s 107A(1) and s 107A(5) (leave requirement and Full Court power to make decision that ought to have been made)
- Statutory Pivot: Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 (Cth) s 110B (appeal to FCCA on a question of law only)
- Statutory Pivot: Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 (Cth) ss 110F and 110G (powers/requirements when dealing with Tribunal decisions and substituting decisions)
- Statutory Pivot: Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(1)(b)(i) and s 117(1)(b)(ii) (departure ground prerequisite and just/equitable/otherwise proper stages)
- Statutory Pivot: Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(2) (grounds/special circumstances framework)
- Statutory Pivot: Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(4) including s 117(4)(e) (necessary commitments) and s 117(4)(g) (hardship consideration)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval of publication under pseudonym)
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) s 6 (costs certificate)

- Uncertainties: The precise adjusted taxable income figures set by the Tribunal for the two child support periods are not stated in the provided text excerpt.
- Uncertainties: The exact terms of all FCCA orders beyond the quoted substituted income assessment and exclusion of veterans pension are not fully reproduced in the excerpt.
- Uncertainties: The exact child support periods and specific dates for the Tribunal’s departure effect are only partially described (including reference to 1 July 2010 to 30 June 2013 and 'thereafter').

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia (Perth) (appeal from Family Court of Western Australia)
issues: Whether the Family Court of Western Australia (FCWA) has power to grant an anti-suit injunction restraining a party from taking further steps in foreign proceedings
Whether the primary judge erred in exercising discretion to grant an anti-suit injunction in circumstances of parallel proceedings in Singapore and WA
Forum/non conveniens: whether FCWA was a clearly inappropriate forum
Whether Singapore proceedings were vexatious or oppressive and interfered with FCWA proceedings
Interaction of deed governed by Singapore law and FCWA proceedings, including s 106B application to set aside disposition and s 79 property settlement
facts: The parties married in Singapore in 1984 and separated in 2010.
They have three adult children.
The wife lives in Perth and is an Australian citizen.
The husband lives about seven months each year in Perth and the remainder in Singapore.

In February 2012 the parties and their children executed a Deed of Family Arrangement governed by Singapore law, said to regulate ownership of assets in Australia and Singapore and to settle all claims, including purportedly excluding future matrimonial property claims.
The deed contemplated an equal sharing among the five signatories; the wife was said to receive a S$2 million share by instalments, and had received S$1 million by the time of the FCWA filing.
In December 2013 the wife commenced proceedings in the FCWA seeking property settlement and to set aside the deed under s 106B of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

On 28 February 2014 the husband commenced proceedings in the High Court of Singapore seeking declarations that the deed was binding, orders requiring the wife to withdraw/cease the FCWA proceedings, and an injunction restraining her from continuing them.
The Singapore summons was returnable on 11 March 2014 but was sent to the wife’s solicitors only the day before the hearing; the wife did not participate in Singapore proceedings.
On 25 March 2014 the wife applied in the FCWA for an injunction restraining the husband from taking further steps in the Singapore proceedings.

asset_pool: Assets located in both Australia and Singapore were the subject of the Deed of Family Arrangement; no total value of the asset pool is stated in the appeal reasons.
The deed contemplated equal sharing among the parties and children; the wife’s share was described as S$2 million payable by instalments, with S$1 million already received.
contributions: Contributions (financial/non-financial, homemaker/parenting) were not determined in this appeal; substantive property settlement under s 79 was not decided.
future_needs: Future needs factors were not determined in this appeal.
just_equitable: No just and equitable determination under s 79 was made in this appeal; proceedings concerned interlocutory anti-suit restraint and jurisdiction/discretion issues.
living_arrangements: Husband spends substantial time in Perth and Singapore; wife lives in Perth.
existing_agreements: Deed of Family Arrangement executed February 2012 by the parties and their adult children, governed by Singapore law, with clauses asserting full and final settlement of claims and choice of law (Singapore).
Wife sought to set aside the deed in FCWA under s 106B; deed was conceded not to bar FCWA property proceedings (subject to any trial issues such as estoppel).

relationship_length: Marriage from 1984; separation in 2010.

child_ages: Three children were adults at the time of proceedings.

outcome_orders: Leave to appeal granted.
Appeal against the orders of Duncanson J made on 8 April 2014 dismissed.
Appellant (husband) to pay the respondent’s (wife’s) costs of and incidental to the appeal, as agreed or assessed in default of agreement.

description: The case confirms that the FCWA, as a State court invested with federal family law jurisdiction, has power to grant an anti-suit injunction as an incident of controlling its own processes and preventing abuse, notwithstanding it is not a superior court of record and lacks a general equitable jurisdiction. The Full Court treated the injunction as justified where foreign proceedings were brought to stifle existing FCWA property proceedings involving the same controversy (property settlement and a challenge to a deed), and where FCWA was not a clearly inappropriate forum. The decision also highlights that s 114(3) may provide an additional statutory footing for anti-suit relief in family law proceedings, though the appeal was resolved primarily on implied/incidental powers and legislative intention of parity of powers between FCWA and the Family Court of Australia.
pivotal_findings: FCWA has implied/incidental power to prevent abuse of process and protect the integrity of its proceedings; this includes power to grant an anti-suit injunction restraining continuation of foreign proceedings that interfere with FCWA proceedings.

There is a clear statutory intention (considering the federal Act structure including s 41 and s 42(1), and the WA State Act framework) that FCWA should have the same practical powers as the Family Court of Australia when exercising federal family law jurisdiction.

The primary judge had power to make the anti-suit injunction; any mischaracterisation as 'inherent' or reliance on an equitable jurisdiction did not invalidate the order because the power existed as implied/incidental to jurisdiction.

Singapore proceedings were found to interfere with FCWA proceedings and to be vexatious or oppressive, particularly because they sought to compel the wife to cease FCWA proceedings and restrain her from bringing property proceedings.

The FCWA could determine all aspects necessary for the family law controversy (including considering the deed under s 106B and determining s 79 property proceedings) despite the deed’s Singapore choice of law clause and the location of some property in Singapore; foreign law could be applied if required under private international law principles and s 42(2).
The FCWA was not a clearly inappropriate forum; the primary judge’s exercise of discretion to grant the injunction was not shown to be in error.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 41 (State Family Courts and investment of jurisdiction)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 42(1) (jurisdiction to be exercised in accordance with the Act and applicable rules) and s 42(2) (application of foreign law where appropriate)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 106B (setting aside dispositions; relevance to deeds affecting property/trust interests)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 114(3) (injunction power; identified as arguably supporting anti-suit relief)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 (property settlement proceedings forming the substantive controversy)
Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) r 6.02 (joinder of parties; relevance to adult children as necessary parties to substantive proceedings)

reasons_rationale: The Full Court held that, as a statutory court invested with federal jurisdiction, FCWA has implied/incidental powers reasonably required to exercise its jurisdiction and to control its own processes, including preventing abuse and protecting pending proceedings from interference by foreign litigation.

It would be inconsistent with legislative intention for litigants in WA to lack a remedy (anti-suit relief) that is available in other Australian jurisdictions exercising the same family law jurisdiction.
The injunction was directed in personam against the husband and did not purport to bind the Singapore court; it therefore did not involve impermissible extraterritorial exercise of jurisdiction.

The existence of the deed’s Singapore governing law clause did not preclude FCWA from adjudicating; FCWA could apply Singapore law if required, and the deed could be set aside under Australian statutory provisions (s 106B) which expressly includes dispositions creating trust interests.

The husband’s Singapore proceedings were properly characterised as interfering with the FCWA proceedings and as vexatious/oppressive because they sought to stop the wife’s FCWA claim; the primary judge did not err in discretion.

While the primary judge referred to equitable jurisdiction, FCWA cannot grant equitable relief absent statutory authority; however, this did not warrant setting aside the injunction because a valid implied/incidental power existed and supported the order.
uncertainties: No final determination was made of the parties’ property adjustment under s 79 or of the merits of setting aside the deed under s 106B; those matters were for substantive trial in FCWA.
The Full Court described it as arguable (but not necessary to decide) that s 114(3) independently authorises anti-suit injunctions; the precise scope of s 114(3) in this context was not fully argued.
