court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal against final parenting orders made by consent (alleged coercion/undue influence; allegations of family violence; challenges to expert evidence and ICL conduct)
Appeal against parenting orders refusing change of the children's surname (request for hyphenation; restraint on using any other name)
Application for leave to appeal interlocutory property/chattels procedural orders
facts: The parties are parents of two children aged nine and six at the time of the appeal.

Final parenting orders were made by consent in the Federal Circuit Court on 12 December 2014 after several days of hearing and negotiations; the children live with the mother and spend time with the father on alternate weekends and in school holidays.
The surname issue was excluded from the consent parenting orders and later determined by the trial judge with reasons delivered on 16 February 2015.

Interlocutory property orders were made on 15 December 2014 requiring each party to identify chattels they wished to retain at values set by a single expert valuer (as a preliminary narrowing exercise).

Before final hearing, there were multiple interim hearings and interim parenting orders over approximately 18 months; the father's time progressed from supervised to unsupervised and then alternate weekends/holiday time.

asset_pool: Chattels were the subject of interim procedural orders; a single expert valuer had attributed values to chattels (specific items/total pool not stated in the appeal reasons).
Broader property dispute was outstanding for later determination (details not stated).

child_ages: Two children aged 9 and 6 years at the time of appeal.
current_arrangements: Consent final orders: equal shared parental responsibility; children live with the mother; time with the father each alternate weekend and specified holiday periods (with additional detailed conditions).
caregiver_history: Interim arrangements changed over time from supervised time for the father (June 2013) to unsupervised day time (December 2013) and later to alternate weekend and holiday time (June 2014), culminating in consent final orders (December 2014).
safety_concerns: Mother alleged family violence by the father toward her and the children and asserted related safety concerns.

Consent parenting orders included safeguards/conditions such as prohibiting the father from smoking near the children and requirements about sun protection material, and restraining involvement in a named community organisation activity/event.
child_views: Family report observations indicated the children engaged positively with the father during observed time and showed no signs of being scared of him (as recorded by the family report writer).
allegations: Mother alleged the father perpetrated family violence and physical harm toward the children (including allegations of physical discipline).
Father alleged the mother engaged in conduct designed to undermine and harm his relationship with the children.
Mother alleged coercion/undue influence by the trial judge (and implicitly the ICL) leading to consent parenting orders.
expert_evidence: Two family reports by single expert Ms F; reports raised concern about which parent would support the children's relationship with the other parent and noted the mother appeared fearful/anxious about the children being unsafe with the father.
Ms F reported observed interaction of the father with the children as positive and described the mother's perceptions as potentially influenced by unresolved childhood experiences.

Psychiatric reports by single expert Dr G noted the mother's personality vulnerabilities in the obsessive-compulsive range and possible somatisation; referred to GP records of high anxiety about health and to indications of possible 'coaching' and that the children wished to have contact with the father.
best_interests: Full Court emphasised that because the orders were made by consent, the trial judge was not asked to adjudicate contested best-interests findings underpinning allegations and counter-allegations; appeal could not challenge the merits of the consent outcome.

In the surname decision, the trial judge's discretionary best-interests assessment focused on the children’s established identity with the father's surname, the mother retaining 'Darley', lack of evidence of embarrassment/discrimination, and likely negative impact on the father if the name were changed; Full Court found the decision open on the evidence.
orders: 12 December 2014 (consent): equal shared parental responsibility; children live with mother; spend time with father alternate weekends and specified holiday nights; additional detailed conditions (including no smoking near children and adherence to sun protection recommendations).
16 February 2015 (surname): children to retain surname 'Darley'; mother restrained from referring to children by any other name.

incidents: Mother alleged family violence by the father toward her and the children (details not finally adjudicated in these appeal reasons due to consent orders).
protection_orders: Mother referred to having a domestic violence order during discussion of changeover in the consent orders context.
Mother sought to adduce a copy of a protection order obtained against the father apparently after the proceedings below; Full Court did not admit the affidavit material (only transcripts).
child_exposure: Allegations included that the children were subject to or exposed to violence; competing allegations were identified as potentially involving physical or psychological harm, but were not adjudicated due to consent resolution.
safety_plan: Changeover arrangements and other detailed conditions in consent orders addressed practical issues raised by the mother, including in the context of her domestic violence order.

outcome_orders: Leave granted to the mother to adduce further evidence in the appeal limited to transcripts of hearings on 13 May 2013, 3 June 2013, 10 December 2013 and 14 February 2014.
Application for leave to appeal orders made on 15 December 2014 (interlocutory chattels orders; Appeal NA3 of 2015) dismissed/refused.
Appeal against final parenting orders made by consent on 12 December 2014 (Appeal NA2 of 2015) dismissed.
Appeal against parenting orders about the children’s surnames made on 16 February 2015 (Appeal NA18 of 2015) dismissed.
Each party to bear their own costs of and incidental to each appeal.

description: The Full Court treated the parenting appeal as constrained by the legal nature of consent orders: absent vitiating factors such as duress, mistake, fraud, or jurisdictional error, an appeal cannot be used to re-litigate merits or alleged factual findings that were never made because the court was asked not to adjudicate. The surname appeal was analysed as an exercise of discretion where the appellant largely challenged weight and reasoning; the Full Court upheld the trial judge’s evaluative findings grounded in the children’s established identity and lack of evidence of detriment. The chattels leave application turned on interlocutory leave principles: no error of principle or substantial injustice, and the orders were characterised as procedural narrowing steps rather than determinative allocation or forced acceptance of valuations.
pivotal_findings: No foundation in transcript/record for the claim the trial judge exerted undue pressure or improper influence to procure the mother’s consent; the mother did not raise coercion, pressure, or prejudgment concerns at trial or when consent orders were made.

The mother actively engaged with the making of consent orders by raising specific issues (changeover location in light of a domestic violence order; holiday pick-up/return arrangements) which were accommodated in the final consent orders, supporting the conclusion of informed consent.

Grounds attempting to attack the merits of the consent parenting orders (family violence findings, credibility findings, expert report weight, ICL conduct) were not available because the trial judge did not adjudicate those matters once the parties sought orders by consent.

On surname: findings open on the evidence that the children had always been known as 'Darley', identified with that name, the mother would retain 'Darley', and there was no evidence of embarrassment/discrimination; also open that the father would likely be unable to conceal resentment from the children if the name changed.

On interlocutory chattels orders: they were procedural, intended to identify items each party wished to keep at the valuer’s figures and potentially narrow disputes; they did not compel acceptance of particular chattels or valuations.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 93A(2) (Full Court power to admit further evidence on appeal; applied to admit transcripts only).
Part VII objects/principles including s 60B (encouraging parents to agree about parenting) (referred to in context of judicial encouragement of settlement).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC (best interests considerations) (relevant background to parenting/surname discretion though merits of consent orders not appealable).
Division 12A (child-related proceedings; active case management principles referenced as context for judicial encouragement/remarks).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 69ZT and s 69ZT(3) (evidence rules in child-related proceedings; referenced to rebut admissibility complaints).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (publication under pseudonym noted).

reasons_rationale: Consent orders can be appealed only on limited grounds (e.g., duress, fraud, mistake, jurisdiction), not on the correctness/merits of an adjudication that did not occur; thus grounds 2-10 were untenable.

The record did not support coercion or prejudgment; the judge’s comments about settlement and risks of litigation were within proper judicial case management and consistent with legislative encouragement for parental agreement.

The surname decision involved a discretionary judgment; the appellant’s complaints largely went to weight and lacked evidentiary support (including no evidence of likely embarrassment at school); the trial judge considered relevant factors and made findings open on the evidence.

Leave to appeal interlocutory chattels orders was refused because no error of principle or substantial injustice was shown and the orders were misconstrued by the appellant; they were preliminary steps to narrow disputes pending the property trial.
uncertainties: The detailed factual allegations of family violence and the father’s counter-allegations were not adjudicated in the consent parenting determination and therefore remain untested in these reasons.
The overall asset pool, liabilities, and final property outcome are not contained in this appeal decision; only interlocutory chattels process orders are described.
Specific terms of the domestic violence/protection order (and timing relative to proceedings) are not set out, beyond references in the reasons.

summary_text:
- Fact: The parties are parents of two children aged nine and six at the time of the appeal.
- Fact: Final parenting orders were made by consent in the Federal Circuit Court on 12 December 2014 after several days of hearing and negotiations; the children live with the mother and spend time with the father on alternate weekends and in school holidays.
- Fact: The surname issue was excluded from the consent parenting orders and later determined by the trial judge with reasons delivered on 16 February 2015.
- Fact: Interlocutory property orders were made on 15 December 2014 requiring each party to identify chattels they wished to retain at values set by a single expert valuer (as a preliminary narrowing exercise).
- Fact: Before final hearing, there were multiple interim hearings and interim parenting orders over approximately 18 months; the father's time progressed from supervised to unsupervised and then alternate weekends/holiday time.

- Issue: Appeal against final parenting orders made by consent (alleged coercion/undue influence; allegations of family violence; challenges to expert evidence and ICL conduct)
- Issue: Appeal against parenting orders refusing change of the children's surname (request for hyphenation; restraint on using any other name)
- Issue: Application for leave to appeal interlocutory property/chattels procedural orders

- Asset Pool: Chattels were the subject of interim procedural orders; a single expert valuer had attributed values to chattels (specific items/total pool not stated in the appeal reasons).
- Asset Pool: Broader property dispute was outstanding for later determination (details not stated).

- Child Ages: Two children aged 9 and 6 years at the time of appeal.
- Current Arrangements: Consent final orders: equal shared parental responsibility; children live with the mother; time with the father each alternate weekend and specified holiday periods (with additional detailed conditions).
- Safety Concerns: Mother alleged family violence by the father toward her and the children and asserted related safety concerns.
- Safety Concerns: Consent parenting orders included safeguards/conditions such as prohibiting the father from smoking near the children and requirements about sun protection material, and restraining involvement in a named community organisation activity/event.
- Best Interests: Full Court emphasised that because the orders were made by consent, the trial judge was not asked to adjudicate contested best-interests findings underpinning allegations and counter-allegations; appeal could not challenge the merits of the consent outcome.
- Best Interests: In the surname decision, the trial judge's discretionary best-interests assessment focused on the children’s established identity with the father's surname, the mother retaining 'Darley', lack of evidence of embarrassment/discrimination, and likely negative impact on the father if the name were changed; Full Court found the decision open on the evidence.

- Incidents: Mother alleged family violence by the father toward her and the children (details not finally adjudicated in these appeal reasons due to consent orders).
- Protection Orders: Mother referred to having a domestic violence order during discussion of changeover in the consent orders context.
- Protection Orders: Mother sought to adduce a copy of a protection order obtained against the father apparently after the proceedings below; Full Court did not admit the affidavit material (only transcripts).

- Outcome: Leave granted to the mother to adduce further evidence in the appeal limited to transcripts of hearings on 13 May 2013, 3 June 2013, 10 December 2013 and 14 February 2014.
- Outcome: Application for leave to appeal orders made on 15 December 2014 (interlocutory chattels orders; Appeal NA3 of 2015) dismissed/refused.
- Outcome: Appeal against final parenting orders made by consent on 12 December 2014 (Appeal NA2 of 2015) dismissed.
- Outcome: Appeal against parenting orders about the children’s surnames made on 16 February 2015 (Appeal NA18 of 2015) dismissed.
- Outcome: Each party to bear their own costs of and incidental to each appeal.

- Reasons: Consent orders can be appealed only on limited grounds (e.g., duress, fraud, mistake, jurisdiction), not on the correctness/merits of an adjudication that did not occur; thus grounds 2-10 were untenable.
- Reasons: The record did not support coercion or prejudgment; the judge’s comments about settlement and risks of litigation were within proper judicial case management and consistent with legislative encouragement for parental agreement.
- Reasons: The surname decision involved a discretionary judgment; the appellant’s complaints largely went to weight and lacked evidentiary support (including no evidence of likely embarrassment at school); the trial judge considered relevant factors and made findings open on the evidence.
- Reasons: Leave to appeal interlocutory chattels orders was refused because no error of principle or substantial injustice was shown and the orders were misconstrued by the appellant; they were preliminary steps to narrow disputes pending the property trial.

- Pivotal Finding: No foundation in transcript/record for the claim the trial judge exerted undue pressure or improper influence to procure the mother’s consent; the mother did not raise coercion, pressure, or prejudgment concerns at trial or when consent orders were made.
- Pivotal Finding: The mother actively engaged with the making of consent orders by raising specific issues (changeover location in light of a domestic violence order; holiday pick-up/return arrangements) which were accommodated in the final consent orders, supporting the conclusion of informed consent.
- Pivotal Finding: Grounds attempting to attack the merits of the consent parenting orders (family violence findings, credibility findings, expert report weight, ICL conduct) were not available because the trial judge did not adjudicate those matters once the parties sought orders by consent.
- Pivotal Finding: On surname: findings open on the evidence that the children had always been known as 'Darley', identified with that name, the mother would retain 'Darley', and there was no evidence of embarrassment/discrimination; also open that the father would likely be unable to conceal resentment from the children if the name changed.
- Pivotal Finding: On interlocutory chattels orders: they were procedural, intended to identify items each party wished to keep at the valuer’s figures and potentially narrow disputes; they did not compel acceptance of particular chattels or valuations.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 93A(2) (Full Court power to admit further evidence on appeal; applied to admit transcripts only).
- Statutory Pivot: Part VII objects/principles including s 60B (encouraging parents to agree about parenting) (referred to in context of judicial encouragement of settlement).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC (best interests considerations) (relevant background to parenting/surname discretion though merits of consent orders not appealable).
- Statutory Pivot: Division 12A (child-related proceedings; active case management principles referenced as context for judicial encouragement/remarks).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 69ZT and s 69ZT(3) (evidence rules in child-related proceedings; referenced to rebut admissibility complaints).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (publication under pseudonym noted).

- Uncertainties: The detailed factual allegations of family violence and the father’s counter-allegations were not adjudicated in the consent parenting determination and therefore remain untested in these reasons.
- Uncertainties: The overall asset pool, liabilities, and final property outcome are not contained in this appeal decision; only interlocutory chattels process orders are described.
- Uncertainties: Specific terms of the domestic violence/protection order (and timing relative to proceedings) are not set out, beyond references in the reasons.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from interim parenting orders
Whether the trial judge erred in treating disputed allegations of family violence in interim proceedings
Whether the trial judge failed to have regard to and apply s 61DA(3) (interim application of presumption of equal shared parental responsibility)
Whether the trial judge erred by removing a recently-made consent requirement that paternal relatives be present during the father's time (monitoring/presence) without adequate reasons
Adequacy of reasons for rejecting supervision/presence condition and for applying the presumption
facts: The parties married in 2010 and separated in 2015.
There are three children: C (born 2011), B (born 2012), and A (born 2013).
Since separation the children lived predominantly with the mother.
Child A has significant health and developmental problems, including epilepsy with daily seizures, developmental delay, poor eyesight, and extensive medical consultations.
The mother alleged significant family violence by the father (coercive/control, verbal/emotional abuse, alleged punching and property damage), sometimes in the presence of the children.

child_ages: C born 2011 (aged about 5 at the time of the interim hearing period)
B born 2012 (aged about 4)
A born 2013 (aged about 3)
current_arrangements: Children lived with the mother.
Interim arrangements for father's time were in dispute; the July 2015 consent orders included paternal relative presence during father's time.
caregiver_history: Mother was predominantly responsible for A's care, including managing significant medical needs.
safety_concerns: Allegations of family violence by both parents, including alleged exposure of children to conflict/violence.
Mother asserted father lacked capacity to care for children without family support, including concerns about cooking, bathing, and (for A) medical care and medication.
A's fragile health (epilepsy and daily seizures) raised risk management concerns during time with the father.
allegations: Mother alleged coercive and controlling family violence, verbal and emotional abuse, physical assault (punching), and property damage by father, sometimes in the presence of the children.
Father denied physical violence, conceded heated arguments, and alleged mother yelled, hit him in front of the children, and was physically violent to the children when frustrated.
Mother alleged father and paternal family asked children inappropriate/frightening questions and criticised her to the children.
expert_evidence: Reference to treating psychologist for C and B continuing appointments as recommended by GP (per consent orders); no family report or expert recommendation described in the provided text.
best_interests: Full Court emphasised that in interim parenting proceedings disputed allegations of family violence cannot simply be ignored because they are contested; the court must consider risk and apply a cautious approach.
Full Court noted s 60CG requires ensuring a parenting order does not expose a person to an unacceptable risk of family violence.
Full Court accepted that the trial judge's approach effectively disregarded significant allegations of family violence and improperly treated the presumption and risk assessment.
orders: On appeal, interim orders were made (until further order) effectively reinstating/replicating the 8 July 2015 consent parenting orders pending rehearing, including living with mother and structured time with father plus presence of paternal relatives during father's time.
The Full Court set aside the 13 August 2015 interim orders and remitted the interim application for rehearing before a different Federal Circuit Court judge.

incidents: Mother alleged a pattern of coercive/control and episodes including alleged punching and property damage.
Father alleged mother hit him and was physically violent to the children when frustrated.
Police involvement on 7 June 2015 in relation to arrangements/time with the children; police reportedly imposed a regime that day regulating time.
protection_orders: Mother sought an Apprehended Violence Order; application dismissed.
police_court: Police were involved on 7 June 2015; AVO application dismissed.
child_exposure: Mother alleged some violence occurred in the presence of the children.
Both parties alleged physical/verbal conflict in front of the children.
safety_plan: July 2015 consent orders (re-made on appeal) provided a protective measure: paternal grandparent and/or paternal aunt present during father's time and to assist/facilitate changeovers.
Orders restrained removal of the children from Australia and requested AFP to place children on the Family Law Watchlist.
Orders restrained physical discipline by either party or third parties.

outcome_orders: Appeal allowed.
Orders made on 13 August 2015 set aside.
Matter remitted for rehearing by a judge other than Judge Dunkley.

Until further order: interim parenting orders made in the terms of (and to remove any doubt, re-making) the 8 July 2015 consent orders, including: children live with mother; mother authorised to make urgent health decisions for A with notification/consultation obligations; structured time for father with C and B (alternate weekends and alternate Wednesdays plus special days/holidays); structured time for father with A (shorter blocks across alternate weekends and alternate Wednesdays plus special days/holidays); father to collect/deliver children as specified; father to administer A's medication as directed and confirm by text; paternal grandparents/aunt to be present during father's time and assist with changeovers; telephone contact; non-denigration and encouragement of relationships; continuation of C and B attending treating psychologist with notification and attendance rights; restraint on physical discipline; restrictions on changing school/daycare/activities without consent; injunction restraining removal of children from Australia and AFP Watchlist request; parties to undertake a post-separation parenting course; father to deliver and deposit passports to the court.

Costs certificates granted: to the mother under s 9 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for appeal costs; to the father under s 6 for appeal costs; and to each party under s 8 for costs of the rehearing.

description: The Full Court held that the interim parenting discretion miscarried because the trial judge treated contested family violence allegations as 'conjecture' and effectively disregarded them, improperly applied the presumption of equal shared parental responsibility in interim proceedings without engaging s 61DA(3), and failed to give adequate reasons for removing a recently agreed protective condition requiring paternal relatives to be present. The decision underscores that in interim hearings the court must assess and manage risk (including under s 60CG and s 60CC(2)(b)) even when findings of family violence cannot be finally made, and that absence of corroboration is not a proper basis to discount family violence allegations.
pivotal_findings: The July 2015 consent order requiring a paternal grandparent/aunt to be present during the father's time was an enforceable parenting order within s 64B, despite being expressed as 'without admissions'.

The trial judge erred by requiring, in effect, corroboration or proof to the civil standard of disputed family violence allegations at an interim stage and by stating the presumption of equal shared parental responsibility 'still applicable' without considering s 61DA(3).

The trial judge's approach neutralised the legislative risk pathway by ignoring significant allegations once he concluded he could not make findings, rather than weighing probabilities and considering likely impact on children and risk management.
The trial judge failed to consider the significance of the very recent consent orders and gave no adequate reasons for departing from them by removing the monitoring/presence condition.

The inadequacy of reasons prevented the mother from understanding why modest protective restrictions were rejected in circumstances involving significant disputed family violence allegations and A's uncontroversial medical vulnerabilities.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 61DA(1)-(4), particularly s 61DA(3) (interim orders and when presumption applies).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2)(b) (primary consideration: protection from harm from abuse/neglect/family violence).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CG (court to ensure parenting order does not expose a person to unacceptable risk of family violence).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 64B (definition/scope of parenting orders, relevant to enforceability of the 'presence' order).
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9 (costs certificates).

reasons_rationale: In interim parenting proceedings, factual disputes are common and may be untested; the court should not ignore contested allegations solely because they cannot be finally determined.

The trial judge applied an inapt approach by referring to failure to meet the civil standard of proof and by treating allegations as requiring corroboration; this was inconsistent with the legislative framework for interim risk assessment.
Failure to address and apply s 61DA(3) led to erroneous application of the presumption and triggered further statutory consequences within the Act on an incorrect basis.

The trial judge erred by failing to consider the recent consent orders, including the father's agreement that the orders were in the children's best interests and the enforceable condition requiring paternal relatives to be present, and by failing to give reasons for departing from that protective regime.
Given material errors of law and no party contribution, costs certificates (rather than inter partes costs) were appropriate.
uncertainties: No final parenting determination was made; orders were interim pending rehearing and ultimate trial.
The Full Court did not determine the truth of the family violence allegations; it identified errors in how they were treated at the interim stage.
Details of any property proceedings mentioned in the background were not addressed in the provided text and no property orders were made in this appeal.

- Issue: Whether the trial judge erred in treating disputed allegations of family violence in interim proceedings
- Issue: Whether the trial judge failed to have regard to and apply s 61DA(3) (interim application of presumption of equal shared parental responsibility)
- Issue: Whether the trial judge erred by removing a recently-made consent requirement that paternal relatives be present during the father's time (monitoring/presence) without adequate reasons
- Issue: Adequacy of reasons for rejecting supervision/presence condition and for applying the presumption

- Child Ages: C born 2011 (aged about 5 at the time of the interim hearing period)
- Child Ages: B born 2012 (aged about 4)
- Child Ages: A born 2013 (aged about 3)
- Current Arrangements: Children lived with the mother.
- Current Arrangements: Interim arrangements for father's time were in dispute; the July 2015 consent orders included paternal relative presence during father's time.
- Safety Concerns: Allegations of family violence by both parents, including alleged exposure of children to conflict/violence.
- Safety Concerns: Mother asserted father lacked capacity to care for children without family support, including concerns about cooking, bathing, and (for A) medical care and medication.
- Safety Concerns: A's fragile health (epilepsy and daily seizures) raised risk management concerns during time with the father.
- Best Interests: Full Court emphasised that in interim parenting proceedings disputed allegations of family violence cannot simply be ignored because they are contested; the court must consider risk and apply a cautious approach.
- Best Interests: Full Court noted s 60CG requires ensuring a parenting order does not expose a person to an unacceptable risk of family violence.
- Best Interests: Full Court accepted that the trial judge's approach effectively disregarded significant allegations of family violence and improperly treated the presumption and risk assessment.

- Incidents: Mother alleged a pattern of coercive/control and episodes including alleged punching and property damage.
- Incidents: Father alleged mother hit him and was physically violent to the children when frustrated.
- Incidents: Police involvement on 7 June 2015 in relation to arrangements/time with the children; police reportedly imposed a regime that day regulating time.
- Protection Orders: Mother sought an Apprehended Violence Order; application dismissed.

- Outcome: Appeal allowed.
- Outcome: Orders made on 13 August 2015 set aside.
- Outcome: Matter remitted for rehearing by a judge other than Judge Dunkley.
- Outcome: Until further order: interim parenting orders made in the terms of (and to remove any doubt, re-making) the 8 July 2015 consent orders, including: children live with mother; mother authorised to make urgent health decisions for A with notification/consultation obligations; structured time for father with C and B (alternate weekends and alternate Wednesdays plus special days/holidays); structured time for father with A (shorter blocks across alternate weekends and alternate Wednesdays plus special days/holidays); father to collect/deliver children as specified; father to administer A's medication as directed and confirm by text; paternal grandparents/aunt to be present during father's time and assist with changeovers; telephone contact; non-denigration and encouragement of relationships; continuation of C and B attending treating psychologist with notification and attendance rights; restraint on physical discipline; restrictions on changing school/daycare/activities without consent; injunction restraining removal of children from Australia and AFP Watchlist request; parties to undertake a post-separation parenting course; father to deliver and deposit passports to the court.
- Outcome: Costs certificates granted: to the mother under s 9 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for appeal costs; to the father under s 6 for appeal costs; and to each party under s 8 for costs of the rehearing.

- Reasons: In interim parenting proceedings, factual disputes are common and may be untested; the court should not ignore contested allegations solely because they cannot be finally determined.
- Reasons: The trial judge applied an inapt approach by referring to failure to meet the civil standard of proof and by treating allegations as requiring corroboration; this was inconsistent with the legislative framework for interim risk assessment.
- Reasons: Failure to address and apply s 61DA(3) led to erroneous application of the presumption and triggered further statutory consequences within the Act on an incorrect basis.
- Reasons: The trial judge erred by failing to consider the recent consent orders, including the father's agreement that the orders were in the children's best interests and the enforceable condition requiring paternal relatives to be present, and by failing to give reasons for departing from that protective regime.
- Reasons: Given material errors of law and no party contribution, costs certificates (rather than inter partes costs) were appropriate.

- Pivotal Finding: The July 2015 consent order requiring a paternal grandparent/aunt to be present during the father's time was an enforceable parenting order within s 64B, despite being expressed as 'without admissions'.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge erred by requiring, in effect, corroboration or proof to the civil standard of disputed family violence allegations at an interim stage and by stating the presumption of equal shared parental responsibility 'still applicable' without considering s 61DA(3).
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge's approach neutralised the legislative risk pathway by ignoring significant allegations once he concluded he could not make findings, rather than weighing probabilities and considering likely impact on children and risk management.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge failed to consider the significance of the very recent consent orders and gave no adequate reasons for departing from them by removing the monitoring/presence condition.
- Pivotal Finding: The inadequacy of reasons prevented the mother from understanding why modest protective restrictions were rejected in circumstances involving significant disputed family violence allegations and A's uncontroversial medical vulnerabilities.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 61DA(1)-(4), particularly s 61DA(3) (interim orders and when presumption applies).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2)(b) (primary consideration: protection from harm from abuse/neglect/family violence).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CG (court to ensure parenting order does not expose a person to unacceptable risk of family violence).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 64B (definition/scope of parenting orders, relevant to enforceability of the 'presence' order).
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9 (costs certificates).

- Uncertainties: No final parenting determination was made; orders were interim pending rehearing and ultimate trial.
- Uncertainties: The Full Court did not determine the truth of the family violence allegations; it identified errors in how they were treated at the interim stage.
- Uncertainties: Details of any property proceedings mentioned in the background were not addressed in the provided text and no property orders were made in this appeal.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal in property settlement: treatment of prospective taxation arising from Division 7A loan arrangements within corporate/trust business structure
Whether trial judge erred by refusing to deduct a calculated future taxation liability from the net asset pool
Whether trial judge erred in dealing with the prospective taxation issue under s 79(4)(e) / s 75(2) without adequate consideration
Re-exercise of discretion by Full Court and adjustment of percentage entitlements and cash adjustment
facts: The parties cohabited from about 1985, married in 2003, separated in 2010; relationship duration about 25 years (cohabitation/marriage) and financial relationship about 30 years to trial.
The net value of property and superannuation found at trial was about $4.922 million; on re-exercise the Full Court adopted about $4.9 million (rounded).
Property comprised real property/chattels, an investment trust, and a successful tourism business operated through a corporate/trust structure.
The parties controlled two corporations: M Pty Ltd (trustee of the family trust operating the tourism business and trustee of an investment trust) and B Pty Ltd (a 'bucket company').

asset_pool: Total net assets and superannuation: about $4,900,000 (rounded) on re-exercise; trial figure stated as $4,922,309.
Real property including unencumbered former matrimonial home at Town P valued at $1,350,000 (retained by wife).
Tourism business operated via Rodgers Family Trust and related entities (principal asset retained by husband).
Rodgers Investment Trust (retained by husband).
contributions: Husband: brought initial interest in marine business and equipment; sale proceeds in 1994 (about $940,000) traced to that initial property and used as a 'springboard' to establish the tourism business and fund property acquisitions; described as a highly significant capital contribution.
Husband: significant role in management/directorship and asset/maintenance functions of business; owner-builder activities; arranged finance and acquisitions; worked away for periods in early years.

Wife: minimal initial assets; received about $14,500 property settlement from prior marriage; primary homemaker and caregiver, especially when children young; did bookwork in early business; later central role in tourism business sales/marketing/administration and operational management; performed domestic and business labour over a long relationship.
Wife: inheritance in 2003 ($241,000) partly applied to business expenses (about $150,000) and other uses including jewellery (valued $25,000).
future_needs: Wife: aged about 67 at trial; reduced future earning capacity and limited longevity in workforce; limited experience in open market outside the family business.

Husband: mid-50s (found 54 at trial; later referred to as 56) in reasonable health; qualifications/experience enabling continuation of business; capacity to draw expenses and control remuneration through business structure.

Prospective Division 7A tax impost: burden likely to be borne solely by husband due to retention and control of entities; the amount uncertain but significant; wife freed from this burden despite having benefitted from past distributions.
Husband’s past voluntary financial/practical assistance in supporting wife’s children from prior relationship was considered as relevant to s 79(4)(e).
just_equitable: Orders altering property interests were found clearly just and equitable given separation and necessity to restructure informal and formal (trust/corporate) arrangements.
Full Court held it was within discretion not to deduct the calculated prospective tax from the asset pool; instead treat it under s 79(4)(e) as part of just and equitable assessment.

Full Court found trial judge erred by failing to adequately consider relevant matters in s 79(4)(e), particularly the real impact of the prospective taxation impost relative to contributions outcomes and its numerical significance.
Full Court re-exercised discretion: adjusted from contributions 52.5/47.5 to final overall 55% husband / 45% wife (a 2.5% adjustment to husband, influenced materially by prospective tax burden).
living_arrangements: Wife to retain unencumbered former matrimonial home at Town P valued at $1,350,000.
Husband to retain and operate the tourism business through the trust/corporate structure and associated investment trust.
existing_agreements: Both parties’ trial positions ultimately assumed husband would retain business and wife be removed from corporations, with wife indemnified against future liabilities including tax.
No binding financial agreement (prenup/postnup) described.

outcome_orders: Appeal allowed.
Orders of Crisford J (22 January 2015) varied: husband to pay wife $532,701 (replacing $648,758).
To give effect to variation, wife to pay (or cause to be paid) husband $116,057 within 14 days (reflecting that trial orders had already been carried into effect).
Final property division determined by Full Court: husband entitled to 55% and wife to 45% of net assets and superannuation (pool about $4.9 million, rounded).

description: This Full Court appeal clarifies that the common practice of deducting liabilities to form a 'net pool' is not a binding rule of law; treatment of liabilities (including prospective taxation) depends on what is just and equitable. In particular, Division 7A-related future taxation based on assumed dividend strategies was not required to be deducted as a present liability; it could properly be addressed under s 79(4)(e). However, where a trial judge elects to deal with such a prospective impost in the s 79(4)(e) assessment, the judge must still consider the practical and numerical significance of the impost and its effect on the outcome; failure to do so can constitute appealable discretionary error. The case also illustrates appellate re-exercise of discretion on the record, rejection of new evidence on re-exercise (Allesch principles), and recalibration of contributions and s 79(4)(e) adjustments to reach a final 55/45 split.
pivotal_findings: Prospective Division 7A tax amounts were not immediately payable and depended on future management decisions (e.g., dividends versus alternatives), and were not equivalent to an assessed and presently due tax debt.
It was within discretion for the trial judge not to deduct a lump sum for prospective Division 7A tax from the pool and to treat the matter under s 79(4)(e).

Trial judge’s s 79(4)(e) reasons did not adequately engage with relevant considerations concerning the prospective taxation impost’s significance and the real dollar effect when adjusting from the contributions-based outcome.

Full Court contributions assessment: husband’s contributions greater primarily due to substantial early capital and parental loans operating as a springboard for later wealth; assessed at 52.5%/47.5%.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(2) (just and equitable requirement)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) including s 79(4)(e) (matters including those in s 75(2))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors as applied through s 79(4)(e))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(1) (costs discretion)

reasons_rationale: The Full Court held that while deducting liabilities to establish a net pool is common practice, it is not mandated by statute and failure to deduct a prospective taxation calculation is not, by itself, an error of law.

The prospective taxation calculations were aggregates based on assumptions (including dividend declarations, franking credits, possible deductions, and no present-value discount), and did not represent a presently due tax assessment.

Treating the prospective tax as a s 79(4)(e) matter avoided requiring the wife to share in a quantified lump sum that might never be incurred in that form and might be managed differently by the husband who would control the entities.

Nonetheless, once the trial judge decided to treat the prospective tax under s 79(4)(e), she was required to properly consider its practical and numerical significance and the real effect of the adjustment relative to the contributions outcome; the reasons did not do so, constituting discretionary error.
uncertainties: Exact future tax ultimately payable from Division 7A compliance was uncertain and dependent on future management decisions, possible deductions, amendments, and timing; no discounting to present value was evidenced.

Some historical factual disputes about post-separation roles and conflict in the business were not resolved with specific findings; Full Court treated post-separation contributions as broadly neutral.

Amounts and timing of interest-free loans from the husband’s mother were unclear in the trial reasons; Full Court assumed a single 1994 loan of approximately $150,000–$155,000 based on the wife’s evidence.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Competence of appeal/time limit: whether appeal was filed out of time where ex tempore reasons preceded formal orders
Parenting: relocation and whether the trial judge erred in making a coercive order requiring the mother (primary carer) to live within a specified radius
Whether the trial judge failed to consider alternatives to a coercive relocation order
Whether the trial judge made errors in fact-finding (including alleged judicial notice of road safety and speculative findings about support networks)
Whether the trial judge erred in application of the Family Law Act best interests pathway (s 60CC) including risk assessment
Whether the trial judge erred in application of s 65DAA (reasonable practicability) principles
facts: The parties have three children: K (born 2008), Y (born 2012) and Z (born 2014).
The parents separated on 9 March 2015 and the mother relocated with the children to Town B, where they had lived for about a year by the time of trial.
The father remained living at the former family property at Town A.
The distance between Town A and Town B was about 285 km (approximately three hours by car), via Town C and a highway route.
Post-separation, the children lived with the mother and spent time with the father each alternate weekend, involving the mother travelling to facilitate time.
At trial, it was not in dispute that the mother should remain the children’s primary carer; the father did not seek primary care as an alternative.

child_ages: K born 2008
Y born 2012
Z born 2014
current_arrangements: At trial: children lived with the mother in Town B; father spent time each alternate weekend, involving substantial travel.
caregiver_history: Mother was the primary carer throughout the children’s lives including post-separation; this was not in issue at trial.
availability: Arrangements involved the mother undertaking return travel between Town B and Town A on alternate weekends to facilitate the father’s time.
safety_concerns: Trial judge considered the highway travel between Town B and Town C/Town A unsafe and not practicable long-term (based in part on his own views).
Risk of parental drug relapse (particularly the mother if required to return to the Town C region) as a potential risk to children’s welfare.
Trial judge expressed doubts about the father’s frankness regarding drug use, past and possibly present.
allegations: Historical methamphetamine use by both parents; concerns about past and possible present use.
Incident in March 2015 involving the mother taking up a knife and threatening self-harm and/or the father (as found).

Evidence that the father’s drug use disclosures were incomplete until after the mother’s disclosures; evidence that the father’s mother regarded it as not out of the ordinary for the father to roll a joint in the kitchen with children present.
expert_evidence: Family report writer/psychologist (Mr R) gave oral evidence that maximising the mother’s prospects of staying off drugs was extremely important; relapse could have catastrophic consequences for the children (emotional unavailability, exposure to conflict/violence, neglect, foster care risk).
best_interests: Full Court held the trial judge failed to properly apply s 60CC considerations as the means to determine best interests, including inadequate treatment of risk of harm (s 60CC(2)(b)) given drug history and relapse risk.
Full Court emphasised coercive relocation orders are at the extreme end of discretion and require rare/extreme circumstances; alternatives must be explored before restricting freedom of movement.

Full Court held proper risk assessment required evaluating nature/magnitude of relapse risk and whether it was unacceptable, rather than treating it as a credibility issue or requiring proof on balance of probabilities of a 'high risk'.
orders: Appeal allowed; trial parenting orders (24 May 2016) set aside; matter remitted for rehearing before a different Federal Circuit Court judge.
Coercive relocation order was set aside.

incidents: March 2015 incident where the mother took up a knife and threatened self-harm and/or the father (as found by the trial judge).
Historical drug use by both parents (particularly methamphetamine) found harmful for children.
child_exposure: Expert evidence indicated relapse into drug use could expose children to increased conflict/violence and serious neglect; trial judge also noted evidence of drug use in the home environment (rolling a joint in kitchen with children present).

outcome_orders: The appeal against the orders of Judge Young made on 24 May 2016 is allowed and those orders are set aside.
The matter be remitted for hearing by a judge in the Federal Circuit Court of Australia other than Judge Young.
There is no order as to costs as between the parties.
Costs certificate granted to the appellant mother pursuant to s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
Costs certificate granted to the respondent father pursuant to s 6 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
Costs certificate granted to each party pursuant to s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of costs incurred in relation to the rehearing ordered.

description: This is an appellate decision setting aside coercive relocation parenting orders and remitting for rehearing. The Full Court treated coercive relocation as an exceptional exercise of discretion requiring careful consideration of realistic alternatives, and emphasised proper best-interests risk assessment (particularly drug relapse risk) and correct application of the 'reasonable practicability' inquiry under s 65DAA. The case also clarifies appeal competence: reasons are not a decree; formal orders are.
pivotal_findings: Appeal was competent because the notice of appeal was filed within 28 days of the formal orders (a 'decree'), and ex tempore reasons were not a decree for s 94AAA purposes.

The mother’s proposal was mischaracterised by the trial judge as competing coercive proposals; this framing wrongly excluded non-coercive alternatives (modified time arrangements, father travelling, holiday blocks, avoiding night travel).
The trial judge erred by failing to explore and consider alternatives before making a coercive order restricting the primary carer’s freedom of movement.

The trial judge relied on unsupported or questionable fact-finding, including personal assessment of the highway’s safety and speculative findings that the mother would find equivalent emotional support if forced to return.

The trial judge’s treatment of s 60CC was inadequate, including an inconsistent assertion that protection from harm was 'not an issue' despite drug history and expert evidence of catastrophic relapse consequences.
The trial judge incorrectly approached future risk by focusing on credibility and a 'high risk' standard rather than assessing nature/magnitude of risk and whether it was unacceptable.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 94AAA(1), s 94AAA(5) (appeal jurisdiction and time limit; decree concept)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CA (paramountcy of best interests)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2) and s 60CC(3) (best interests considerations; primary/additional considerations including risk of harm)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65DAA (equal time/substantial and significant time; reasonable practicability)
Evidence Act 1995 (Cth) s 144 (judicial notice; knowledge not reasonably open to question)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9 (costs certificates)

reasons_rationale: Reasons for judgment do not constitute a 'decree'; the formal orders dispose of the matter and are the appealable decree, so the appeal was in time.

Coercive relocation orders are only justified in rare/extreme circumstances and require consideration of alternatives to restricting a parent’s freedom of movement, especially where that parent is the unchallenged primary carer.
The trial judge’s reasoning was infected by factual errors and speculation (road safety assessment without proper evidentiary basis; assumption of equivalent emotional support on return).
The trial judge did not properly undertake a best-interests evaluation under s 60CC, particularly in relation to protection from harm and drug-related risk to the children.
The trial judge failed to properly apply s 65DAA by not undertaking the practical 'reasonable practicability' assessment grounded in the parents’ real circumstances.
uncertainties: The Full Court set aside the parenting orders and remitted for rehearing; final parenting arrangements were not determined in this appeal.
Details of the interim arrangements after the appeal were noted to be governed by orders made 24 June 2016, but those interim orders are not fully set out in the provided text.
The case text uses pseudonyms and anonymised locations; specific locality characteristics beyond distances and travel time are not determinatively found.

summary_text:
- Fact: The parties have three children: K (born 2008), Y (born 2012) and Z (born 2014).
- Fact: The parents separated on 9 March 2015 and the mother relocated with the children to Town B, where they had lived for about a year by the time of trial.
- Fact: The father remained living at the former family property at Town A.
- Fact: The distance between Town A and Town B was about 285 km (approximately three hours by car), via Town C and a highway route.
- Fact: Post-separation, the children lived with the mother and spent time with the father each alternate weekend, involving the mother travelling to facilitate time.
- Fact: At trial, it was not in dispute that the mother should remain the children’s primary carer; the father did not seek primary care as an alternative.

- Issue: Competence of appeal/time limit: whether appeal was filed out of time where ex tempore reasons preceded formal orders
- Issue: Parenting: relocation and whether the trial judge erred in making a coercive order requiring the mother (primary carer) to live within a specified radius
- Issue: Whether the trial judge failed to consider alternatives to a coercive relocation order
- Issue: Whether the trial judge made errors in fact-finding (including alleged judicial notice of road safety and speculative findings about support networks)
- Issue: Whether the trial judge erred in application of the Family Law Act best interests pathway (s 60CC) including risk assessment
- Issue: Whether the trial judge erred in application of s 65DAA (reasonable practicability) principles

- Child Ages: K born 2008
- Child Ages: Y born 2012
- Child Ages: Z born 2014
- Current Arrangements: At trial: children lived with the mother in Town B; father spent time each alternate weekend, involving substantial travel.
- Safety Concerns: Trial judge considered the highway travel between Town B and Town C/Town A unsafe and not practicable long-term (based in part on his own views).
- Safety Concerns: Risk of parental drug relapse (particularly the mother if required to return to the Town C region) as a potential risk to children’s welfare.
- Safety Concerns: Trial judge expressed doubts about the father’s frankness regarding drug use, past and possibly present.
- Best Interests: Full Court held the trial judge failed to properly apply s 60CC considerations as the means to determine best interests, including inadequate treatment of risk of harm (s 60CC(2)(b)) given drug history and relapse risk.
- Best Interests: Full Court emphasised coercive relocation orders are at the extreme end of discretion and require rare/extreme circumstances; alternatives must be explored before restricting freedom of movement.
- Best Interests: Full Court held proper risk assessment required evaluating nature/magnitude of relapse risk and whether it was unacceptable, rather than treating it as a credibility issue or requiring proof on balance of probabilities of a 'high risk'.

- Incidents: March 2015 incident where the mother took up a knife and threatened self-harm and/or the father (as found by the trial judge).
- Incidents: Historical drug use by both parents (particularly methamphetamine) found harmful for children.

- Outcome: The appeal against the orders of Judge Young made on 24 May 2016 is allowed and those orders are set aside.
- Outcome: The matter be remitted for hearing by a judge in the Federal Circuit Court of Australia other than Judge Young.
- Outcome: There is no order as to costs as between the parties.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the appellant mother pursuant to s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the respondent father pursuant to s 6 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to each party pursuant to s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of costs incurred in relation to the rehearing ordered.

- Reasons: Reasons for judgment do not constitute a 'decree'; the formal orders dispose of the matter and are the appealable decree, so the appeal was in time.
- Reasons: Coercive relocation orders are only justified in rare/extreme circumstances and require consideration of alternatives to restricting a parent’s freedom of movement, especially where that parent is the unchallenged primary carer.
- Reasons: The trial judge’s reasoning was infected by factual errors and speculation (road safety assessment without proper evidentiary basis; assumption of equivalent emotional support on return).
- Reasons: The trial judge did not properly undertake a best-interests evaluation under s 60CC, particularly in relation to protection from harm and drug-related risk to the children.
- Reasons: The trial judge failed to properly apply s 65DAA by not undertaking the practical 'reasonable practicability' assessment grounded in the parents’ real circumstances.

- Pivotal Finding: Appeal was competent because the notice of appeal was filed within 28 days of the formal orders (a 'decree'), and ex tempore reasons were not a decree for s 94AAA purposes.
- Pivotal Finding: The mother’s proposal was mischaracterised by the trial judge as competing coercive proposals; this framing wrongly excluded non-coercive alternatives (modified time arrangements, father travelling, holiday blocks, avoiding night travel).
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge erred by failing to explore and consider alternatives before making a coercive order restricting the primary carer’s freedom of movement.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge relied on unsupported or questionable fact-finding, including personal assessment of the highway’s safety and speculative findings that the mother would find equivalent emotional support if forced to return.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge’s treatment of s 60CC was inadequate, including an inconsistent assertion that protection from harm was 'not an issue' despite drug history and expert evidence of catastrophic relapse consequences.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge incorrectly approached future risk by focusing on credibility and a 'high risk' standard rather than assessing nature/magnitude of risk and whether it was unacceptable.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 94AAA(1), s 94AAA(5) (appeal jurisdiction and time limit; decree concept)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CA (paramountcy of best interests)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2) and s 60CC(3) (best interests considerations; primary/additional considerations including risk of harm)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65DAA (equal time/substantial and significant time; reasonable practicability)
- Statutory Pivot: Evidence Act 1995 (Cth) s 144 (judicial notice; knowledge not reasonably open to question)
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9 (costs certificates)

- Uncertainties: The Full Court set aside the parenting orders and remitted for rehearing; final parenting arrangements were not determined in this appeal.
- Uncertainties: Details of the interim arrangements after the appeal were noted to be governed by orders made 24 June 2016, but those interim orders are not fully set out in the provided text.
- Uncertainties: The case text uses pseudonyms and anonymised locations; specific locality characteristics beyond distances and travel time are not determinatively found.

case_name: Mankiewicz AND anor v Swallow AND anor
court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
parties: Mr Mankiewicz (first appellant; maternal great grandfather)
Mrs Mankiewicz (second appellant; maternal great grandmother)
issues: Appeal against dismissal of maternal great grandparents' application to spend time with their great grandchildren
Appeal against vexatious proceedings order made under s 102QB(2)(b) restraining further parenting proceedings without leave
Whether the primary judge had jurisdiction/power to dismiss the proceedings and make a vexatious proceedings order before determining standing
Whether appellants had standing under s 65C(c) as persons concerned with the care, welfare or development of the children
Whether appellants acted in concert with their son (maternal grandfather) for purposes of s 102QB(1)(b)
Procedural fairness in making the vexatious proceedings order
Costs on appeal, including whether indemnity costs were justified
facts: The appellants are the maternal great grandparents of four children of the respondents (an intact family who opposed the application).

The appellants previously filed an application in 2008 seeking time with the children; it was summarily dismissed in January 2009 by Watts J, who found they lacked standing to apply for parenting orders.
The appellants commenced fresh parenting proceedings in October 2013 seeking similar relief on substantially the same facts.

On 25 July 2014, Watts J dismissed the 2013 application and, of the court’s own motion (at respondents’ suggestion), made a vexatious proceedings order under s 102QB(2)(b) requiring leave to institute further parenting proceedings concerning these children.

The vexatious proceedings order was based on the finding that the appellants acted in concert with their son (the maternal grandfather), who had frequently instituted vexatious proceedings and had been declared a vexatious litigant in NSW Supreme Court in 2005.
The appellants appealed in August 2014 and sought to adduce further evidence on appeal and sought appointment of an Independent Children’s Lawyer.

The Full Court majority (Ryan and Austin JJ) dismissed the appeal and upheld the orders; Murphy J dissented on validity of the primary judge’s orders but would still dismiss the parenting application.

child_ages: Four great grandchildren (ages not stated)
current_arrangements: Children living with both parents in an intact family; parents opposed time with the appellants.
caregiver_history: No findings of the appellants having a caregiving role sufficient to confer standing; prior 2009 decision found they were not persons concerned with the care, welfare or development of the children.
safety_concerns: Appellants asserted mental health concerns about the mother and coping issues for the father; the Full Court held the factual premise was not established and, in any event, irrelevant to the appeal issues.
allegations: Appellants alleged the mother was not of sound mind and suffered PTSD; allegations were not made out and treated as irrelevant to the legal questions on appeal.
Appellants challenged an AVO extended in 2013; Full Court held other proceedings could be taken into account for s 102QB purposes.
expert_evidence: No family report or expert evidence discussed; application for an Independent Children’s Lawyer on appeal was dismissed (no argument advanced).
best_interests: The appeal did not turn on a best-interests assessment; it turned on standing, abuse of process/vexatiousness, and validity of s 102QB orders.
orders: Primary judge dismissed the appellants’ parenting application to spend time with the children.

Primary judge made a vexatious proceedings order prohibiting the appellants from instituting parenting proceedings in respect of the children without leave (and not to serve any leave application unless ordered).

protection_orders: Reference to an AVO extended on 25 June 2013 for 10 years (details not stated); appellants challenged its extension but the court held it was permissible to consider other proceedings.
police_court: Local Court proceedings relating to the AVO were referenced (magistrate extended the AVO); no further detail stated.

outcome_orders: All outstanding Applications in an Appeal be dismissed.
The appeal be dismissed.
The appellants pay the respondents’ indemnity costs in the amount of $15,000 within three (3) months of the date of these orders.

description: The decision confirms the operation of the Family Law Act’s vexatious proceedings regime in parenting matters and the breadth of material a court may consider when deciding whether s 102QB is enlivened, including prior proceedings and state court vexatious-litigant findings. It also addresses (with a split court) the relationship between standing under s 65C(c), the court’s jurisdiction, and the capacity to make interim/dispositive orders such as dismissal and vexatious proceedings restraints. The majority treated the court as having jurisdiction to determine whether standing existed and as able to exercise s 102QB power while doing so; the dissent regarded standing as a jurisdictional fact not satisfied, rendering the s 102QB orders invalid (though the parenting application would still be dismissed).
pivotal_findings: The appellants’ 2013 parenting application sought substantially similar relief on substantially the same facts as the 2009 application that had been summarily dismissed with a finding they lacked standing.

The appellants acted in concert with their son (the maternal grandfather) for s 102QB(1)(b) purposes, based on evidence including: affidavits stating they were prepared/settled by him, his proposed role as McKenzie Friend (later withdrawn), shared residence, and close similarity of relief sought to prior litigation involving him.
The maternal grandfather had frequently instituted vexatious proceedings, including a 2005 NSW Supreme Court vexatious litigant declaration and a 2009 Family Law Act order against him.

Procedural fairness was afforded: appellants had notice of the acting-in-concert allegation and the respondents’ detailed written submissions; the primary judge was not obliged to conduct inquisitorial questioning of appellants or their son.

Further evidence on appeal (hearsay conversations with the son and the second appellant’s autobiography) was refused; it would not have produced a different result and/or was inconsistent with finality.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65C (who may apply for parenting orders; standing of persons concerned with care, welfare or development)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) ss 102Q, 102QB, 102QE (definitions and powers for vexatious proceedings orders; leave requirements and affidavit obligations)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 (costs, including considerations under s 117(2A))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 118 (abuse of process power referenced as an available basis to dismiss)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 93A(2) (application to adduce further evidence on appeal)

reasons_rationale: No appellable error was shown in the primary judge’s discretionary decision to make a vexatious proceedings order; the findings supporting ‘acting in concert’ were open on the evidence.
The court could consider proceedings and orders in any Australian court or tribunal for s 102QB purposes, including a state court vexatious litigant declaration and AVO proceedings.
The appellants’ attempt to re-litigate substantially the same case after the 2009 standing determination was characterised as an abuse of process and vexatious; the dismissal was well justified.
Procedural fairness complaints failed because the appellants had an opportunity to be heard and could have adduced evidence on the issues they said required questioning.

Indemnity costs were justified given the nature of the appeal, appellants’ complete lack of success, and the vexatious character of the underlying proceedings; costs were fixed to avoid further litigation.
uncertainties: Children’s ages, schooling, and any detailed parenting arrangements were not stated in the provided text.

The Full Court reasons include a dissent (Murphy J) asserting the primary judge’s orders were invalid due to lack of standing as a jurisdictional fact; however, the operative outcome is the majority orders dismissing the appeal and awarding indemnity costs.
Details of the referenced AVO (protected persons, factual basis) and any alleged family violence incidents were not set out.
