- Reasons: The appellants’ attempt to re-litigate substantially the same case after the 2009 standing determination was characterised as an abuse of process and vexatious; the dismissal was well justified.
- Reasons: Procedural fairness complaints failed because the appellants had an opportunity to be heard and could have adduced evidence on the issues they said required questioning.
- Reasons: Indemnity costs were justified given the nature of the appeal, appellants’ complete lack of success, and the vexatious character of the underlying proceedings; costs were fixed to avoid further litigation.

- Pivotal Finding: The appellants’ 2013 parenting application sought substantially similar relief on substantially the same facts as the 2009 application that had been summarily dismissed with a finding they lacked standing.
- Pivotal Finding: The appellants acted in concert with their son (the maternal grandfather) for s 102QB(1)(b) purposes, based on evidence including: affidavits stating they were prepared/settled by him, his proposed role as McKenzie Friend (later withdrawn), shared residence, and close similarity of relief sought to prior litigation involving him.
- Pivotal Finding: The maternal grandfather had frequently instituted vexatious proceedings, including a 2005 NSW Supreme Court vexatious litigant declaration and a 2009 Family Law Act order against him.
- Pivotal Finding: Procedural fairness was afforded: appellants had notice of the acting-in-concert allegation and the respondents’ detailed written submissions; the primary judge was not obliged to conduct inquisitorial questioning of appellants or their son.
- Pivotal Finding: Further evidence on appeal (hearsay conversations with the son and the second appellant’s autobiography) was refused; it would not have produced a different result and/or was inconsistent with finality.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 65C (who may apply for parenting orders; standing of persons concerned with care, welfare or development)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) ss 102Q, 102QB, 102QE (definitions and powers for vexatious proceedings orders; leave requirements and affidavit obligations)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 (costs, including considerations under s 117(2A))
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 118 (abuse of process power referenced as an available basis to dismiss)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 93A(2) (application to adduce further evidence on appeal)

- Uncertainties: Children’s ages, schooling, and any detailed parenting arrangements were not stated in the provided text.
- Uncertainties: The Full Court reasons include a dissent (Murphy J) asserting the primary judge’s orders were invalid due to lack of standing as a jurisdictional fact; however, the operative outcome is the majority orders dismissing the appeal and awarding indemnity costs.
- Uncertainties: Details of the referenced AVO (protected persons, factual basis) and any alleged family violence incidents were not set out.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether leave to appeal was required for an appeal against an order setting aside a binding financial agreement (BFA) and/or an interim spousal maintenance order

Whether the primary judge erred in setting aside a s 90C binding financial agreement under s 90K(1)(d) (material change in circumstances relating to care/welfare/development of a child causing hardship if not set aside)
Proper construction of s 90K(1)(d), including the causal requirement that hardship be 'as a result of the change' and the meaning of 'hardship'
facts: The parties commenced cohabitation in 2004 and married in January 2006.
The husband was born in 1942 and the wife in 1967.
At the commencement of cohabitation, the wife owned a property at Suburb J, furniture, jewellery and cash on deposit.

asset_pool: The BFA contained schedules listing each party's property as at December 2006 (specific items in the schedules not detailed in the appeal reasons).
Pre-relationship/at cohabitation: wife owned Suburb J property, furniture, jewellery, cash; husband owned Suburb C property, furniture, superannuation, life policy.

Trust-related interests: D Town property owned by a trust structure associated with the Fewster Family Trust; corporate trustee later replaced; husband had control roles and later relinquished some claims.
contributions: The primary judge accepted the wife's role as primary carer and homemaker was not in contest.
The wife had worked on the parties’ property and in the husband’s business (non-financial contributions).

The BFA operated on a 'separate property' approach with retention of scheduled assets and a contributions-based approach to jointly acquired real property (including reimbursements with 10% interest).
future_needs: The primary judge treated the BFA as silent as to s 75(2) future needs matters; on appeal, the Full Court emphasised that unfairness alone is not a basis to set aside a BFA and hardship must be proved per s 90K(1)(d).
Children were in the full-time care of the wife, with the husband spending defined time with them (as recorded in primary judge’s findings recited on appeal).
just_equitable: The appeal concerned whether the BFA should be set aside; the Full Court held the statutory test in s 90K(1)(d) was not satisfied on the evidence and dismissed the wife's set-aside application.
No final property settlement under s 79 was determined in this appeal.
living_arrangements: Children were in the full-time care of the wife; both children attended the local school; the husband spent defined time with them.
The wife resided in a property purchased in January 2015 which required repair/renovation.
existing_agreements: A binding financial agreement under s 90C was signed on 22 December 2006.

Key features included each party retaining their scheduled assets and after-acquired property derived from those assets/gifts/inheritances; jointly acquired real property to be sold with reimbursement of contributions plus 10% interest and division proportional to contributions; division of jointly acquired personalty by two-lists method; and a purported release of claims under NSW family provision legislation (with contemplated Supreme Court approval).
The agreement preserved the wife’s right to seek spousal maintenance (it did not exclude maintenance).

need: The primary judge found the wife was unable to support herself adequately 'without recourse to capital' and assessed reasonable weekly expenses at $2,052.

On appeal, the Full Court held the primary judge did not properly consider whether it was reasonable for the wife to draw on significant available cash resources over the relevant period and did not properly address the wife's conceded earning capacity.
capacity_to_pay: The husband conceded capacity to meet a spousal maintenance order (as recorded in the primary judge’s reasons and referred to on appeal).
statutory_factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 72 (threshold: inability to support oneself adequately and other party's capacity)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 74(1) and s 74(8) (maintenance order and finality/interlocutory nature)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (matters to consider, including property and financial resources and standard of living)
income_expenses: Wife's asserted art business income was modest (about $5,000 in 2015 financial year).
Primary judge assessed wife's reasonable weekly expenses at $2,052, excluding claimed $1,500 per week for repairs as capital.
Wife had access to about $250,000 in bank funds (as found by the primary judge and recited on appeal).
earning_capacity: The wife conceded an unexercised capacity for part-time employment of up to about $600 per week; the primary judge did not refer to this concession and the Full Court treated that as an error requiring rehearing.
relationship_length: Cohabitation commenced in 2004; marriage in January 2006; proceedings followed separation (date not stated in appeal reasons).
standard_of_living: The Full Court noted the standard of living and the other party’s financial circumstances are relevant under s 75(2) when assessing whether an applicant must draw down capital, but no specific standard-of-living findings were finally made on appeal.

child_ages: First child born in 2007.
Second child born in 2009.
current_arrangements: Children were in the full-time care of the wife, with the husband spending defined time with them.
Both children attended the local school.
caregiver_history: Wife's evidence that she was primary carer/homemaker and had overwhelming care physically and financially since separation was not contested (as recorded by the primary judge and referenced on appeal).
availability: The wife conceded there was some time during the day when she could seek paid employment.
allegations: The wife sought to adduce evidence on appeal alleging the husband was dilatory in paying spousal maintenance and irregular in child support payments; this was not admitted as appellate evidence.

legal_advice: The agreement was negotiated through solicitors for each party; drafts were exchanged and amendments made before signing.
financial_disclosure: The wife’s solicitor confirmed receipt of a list of the husband’s assets from the husband’s accountant; the agreement recited full and fair disclosure (as noted by the primary judge and referenced on appeal).
changed_circumstances: The wife relied on s 90K(1)(d), contending the birth of the second child and related caring responsibilities after separation constituted a material change relating to care, welfare and development of a child; the Full Court accepted the birth/care could be a material change but found no evidentiary link establishing hardship 'as a result of the change' and no proper comparative analysis of hardship if the agreement remained.

outcome_orders: The Application in an Appeal filed on 8 August 2016 is dismissed.
The appeal is allowed.
Order 1 made by Foster J on 28 July 2015 (setting aside the binding financial agreement) is set aside.

description: The case clarifies appellate treatment of (1) finality/interlocutory character of orders in financial agreement and maintenance contexts, and (2) the strict statutory construction of s 90K(1)(d) for setting aside binding financial agreements. The Full Court held that an order setting aside a financial agreement finally determines rights in the distinct 'financial agreement' matrimonial cause (s 4), so leave is not required. It also emphasised that s 90K(1)(d) demands a causal link: hardship must result from the post-agreement material change in child-related circumstances, and the court must compare the position if the agreement remains versus if it is set aside. For spousal maintenance, the decision highlights errors where interim maintenance reasoning is infected by assumptions about imminent property proceedings and where capital resources and conceded earning capacity are not properly evaluated under s 75(2).
pivotal_findings: The order setting aside a financial agreement is a final order determining the parties’ rights in proceedings with respect to a financial agreement (s 4 matrimonial cause (eaa)), so leave to appeal was not required.
The interim spousal maintenance order was interlocutory; leave to appeal was required and granted.
A birth of a child can, depending on circumstances, constitute a 'material change in circumstances' relating to the care, welfare and development of a child for s 90K(1)(d).

The primary judge erred by applying an incorrect test for s 90K(1)(d), effectively treating hardship as arising from the agreement’s terms/unfairness rather than hardship 'as a result of the change' and by failing to undertake a necessary comparative analysis of hardship if the agreement was not set aside.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K(1)(d) (material change relating to child care/welfare/development and hardship 'as a result of the change' if agreement not set aside)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90C (financial agreements during marriage)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4 (definition of 'matrimonial cause', including proceedings with respect to a financial agreement)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 94AA (leave to appeal for interlocutory decrees)

reasons_rationale: The Full Court held s 90K(1)(d) requires proof that hardship would be suffered because of the material change in child-related circumstances; unfairness or the agreement’s silence about homemaker contributions/future needs is insufficient.
The causal words 'as a result of the change' were treated as critical; the primary judge’s adoption of reasoning from Pascot omitted that link and led to error.
The Court held the statutory phrase 'if the court does not set the agreement aside' requires a comparison between the position if the agreement remains and if it is set aside to determine hardship.
Hardship was held to mean something more than mere unfairness; the Court referred to ordinary meaning and authority describing hardship as a substantial detriment.
uncertainties: The appeal reasons do not state the parties’ separation date or the detailed asset values in the BFA schedules.
No final determination of spousal maintenance entitlement/quantum was made; the maintenance application was remitted for rehearing.
Parenting arrangements were only described in general terms and were not the subject of substantive parenting orders in this appeal.

court: Family Court of Australia (Full Court)
issues: Appeal from parenting order concerning child's surname (whether hyphenated surname should be ordered)
Whether primary judge took into account irrelevant considerations or failed to take into account relevant considerations in determining best interests
Whether primary judge improperly prevented/unfairly constrained the mother’s cross-examination of the father (procedural fairness)
Costs of the appeal under s 117 Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
facts: The child C was born in 2013.
The parties’ relationship lasted about one month; they never lived together.
Since birth, the child has lived with the mother.

Consent parenting orders were made on 23 October 2014 providing equal shared parental responsibility and the child to live with the mother, with the father spending time initially supervised and later unsupervised on specified days.
The parties agreed to undertake family dispute resolution when the child turned three to consider overnight time with the father.
The parents could not agree about the child’s surname: the mother sought 'Reynolds' and the father sought a hyphenated surname 'Reynolds-Sherman'.

This was the second time the child-name issue came before the Full Court; earlier orders that the child be known as 'Sherman-Reynolds' were set aside and remitted for rehearing (Reynolds & Sherman [2015] FamCAFC 128).
At first instance on 29 January 2016 (FCCA), Judge Baumann ordered the child be known as 'C Reynolds-Sherman'.

child_ages: Child born in 2013 (approximately 30 months old at the time of the primary judge’s reasons).
current_arrangements: Child lived with the mother.

From consent orders (23 October 2014): equal shared parental responsibility; father to spend supervised daytime time Monday/Wednesday/Saturday; from March 2015 unsupervised time Mondays, Wednesdays and alternating Saturdays/Sundays.
Planned family dispute resolution at age three regarding overnights.
caregiver_history: Mother has been primary carer since the child’s birth.
availability: Father’s commitment included extensive travel to spend time with the child (as found by the primary judge and referenced on appeal).
safety_concerns: Mother alleged bullying, cyber/internet harassment by father and his family; father denied many allegations.
Mother held concerns about father’s parenting and possible sexual abuse; primary judge noted these concerns were not supported by departmental investigations.
allegations: Mother alleged father initially denied paternity when contacted by Child Support Agency; father disputed denial but accepted he did not initially acknowledge paternity and wanted to see a birth certificate; paternity ultimately not in dispute.
Mother alleged breaches of the Domestic Violence Order; primary judge found no evidence of any enforcement action being taken.
expert_evidence: Family Report dated 29 August 2014: report writer observed father as caring and supportive, keen to parent, willing to be guided; did not present as putting his own needs above the child’s.

Family Report noted: if father would be important in child’s life, a hyphenated name would seem reasonable; also speculated a hyphenated name might reduce risk of father disengaging; primary judge gave this speculative opinion little weight due to unclear foundation and no cross-examination.
best_interests: Full Court confirmed that an order about the child’s name is a 'parenting order' under s 64B(2)(i) and must be decided with best interests paramount (s 60CA) considering s 60CC factors.

Primary judge’s best-interests reasoning (upheld): a hyphenated surname reflecting both parents’ heritage would enhance the child’s sense of identity and connection with both parents and extended families.
Primary judge rejected claims that hyphenation would confuse the child, create data/passport problems, or that differences in surnames with the primary carer would likely cause confusion.
Family violence issues were considered to have little significance to the surname issue in the context of existing parenting arrangements and the nature of the name dispute.
orders: Parenting order at first instance (subject of appeal): child to be known as 'C Reynolds-Sherman'.
Appeal outcome: no change to the child’s surname order (appeal dismissed).

incidents: Mother alleged bullying, cyber and internet harassment by father and his family; father denied many allegations.
Mother alleged breaches of Domestic Violence Order but evidence did not establish action taken by authorities.
protection_orders: Domestic Violence Order obtained by mother against father in March 2013 for two years; extended for a further two years on 19 March 2015.
police_court: Mother said she reported alleged DVO breaches to police; no evidence of police response or enforcement outcomes.
Mother initiated domestic violence proceedings against paternal grandmother; application dismissed; primary judge found evidence insufficient to make findings about that matter.

outcome_orders: Appeal dismissed.
Appellant mother to pay respondent father’s costs of the appeal assessed in the sum of $8000, payable within 12 months.

description: The decision confirms that a dispute about a child’s surname is determined as a parenting order under the Family Law Act, engaging the paramountcy of best interests and the s 60CC considerations. On appeal, the Full Court applied established appellate restraint for discretionary decisions (House v The King), and rejected alleged errors about evidentiary weight, relevance, and procedural fairness in a self-represented context. The case illustrates that allegations of family violence or parental conflict may be given limited weight in a naming dispute where they do not materially bear on the child’s welfare in the context of existing parenting orders, and that speculative expert commentary without a clear evidentiary foundation may be discounted.
pivotal_findings: Orders about a child’s name are parenting orders within s 64B(2)(i) and 'major long-term issues' include the child’s name (s 4(1)), so best interests under s 60CA and s 60CC apply.
No appealable error was shown in the primary judge’s conclusion that a hyphenated surname reflecting both parents’ heritage was in the child’s best interests and would enhance identity/connection.

The primary judge was entitled to reject as unlikely the mother’s assertions that a hyphenated surname would confuse the child or create practical administrative difficulties, particularly given the child’s young age and limited 'social footprint'.

The primary judge was entitled to give little weight to a Family Consultant’s speculative statement about reducing the risk of the father disengaging, given unclear foundation and lack of exploration in cross-examination.

The Full Court found the mother was not prevented from cross-examining about domestic violence; the trial judge advised it may not assist but permitted the line of questioning, and the mother did not pursue it.

The Full Court accepted the primary judge’s approach that the existence/extent of alleged family violence had little relevance to the surname determination given the parenting orders in place and the issue being the child’s name rather than time or safety arrangements.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CA (best interests paramount)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC (best interests considerations)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 64B(1)-(3) (parenting orders; care/welfare/development; parental responsibility decisions)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 61B (definition of parental responsibility)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4(1) (major long-term issues include child’s name)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(2A)(a) (costs—financial circumstances)
Births, Deaths and Marriages Registration Act 2003 (Qld) s 8(2)(c) (raised by mother but found irrelevant to the surname dispute)

reasons_rationale: The appeal challenged a discretionary parenting decision; appellate intervention required demonstration of error rather than a different preferred outcome (House v The King principles).

The primary judge was found to have considered the mother’s submissions (including keepsakes/social footprint, confusion, alleged antagonism/proprietorial motives, paternity concerns, and family violence) but was entitled to reject them on the evidence.

The Full Court held that differences in the father’s informal usage of names or social media references were not materially relevant to determining the child’s best interests regarding future surname.

A minor factual error alleged by the mother (being prevented from correcting father’s claim about a magistrate calling proceedings frivolous) did not arise; the primary judge did not make such a finding and found evidence insufficient to make findings about that matter.
The mother’s reliance on Queensland birth registration provisions did not bear on the family law best-interests determination for a parenting order about the child’s name.

Costs were ordered against the mother as the appeal was wholly unsuccessful; her Centrelink income was relevant but not a bar to costs; costs were fixed at $8000 as modest and undisputed, with 12 months to pay.
uncertainties: Exact terms of the Domestic Violence Order and the specific alleged incidents underpinning it were not detailed in the appeal reasons.
No detail was provided about any police action (if any) following the mother’s reports of alleged DVO breaches.
The child’s full first name and precise birth date were not stated (only year of birth).

summary_text:
- Fact: The child C was born in 2013.
- Fact: The parties’ relationship lasted about one month; they never lived together.
- Fact: Since birth, the child has lived with the mother.
- Fact: Consent parenting orders were made on 23 October 2014 providing equal shared parental responsibility and the child to live with the mother, with the father spending time initially supervised and later unsupervised on specified days.
- Fact: The parties agreed to undertake family dispute resolution when the child turned three to consider overnight time with the father.
- Fact: The parents could not agree about the child’s surname: the mother sought 'Reynolds' and the father sought a hyphenated surname 'Reynolds-Sherman'.
- Fact: This was the second time the child-name issue came before the Full Court; earlier orders that the child be known as 'Sherman-Reynolds' were set aside and remitted for rehearing (Reynolds & Sherman [2015] FamCAFC 128).
- Fact: At first instance on 29 January 2016 (FCCA), Judge Baumann ordered the child be known as 'C Reynolds-Sherman'.

- Issue: Appeal from parenting order concerning child's surname (whether hyphenated surname should be ordered)
- Issue: Whether primary judge took into account irrelevant considerations or failed to take into account relevant considerations in determining best interests
- Issue: Whether primary judge improperly prevented/unfairly constrained the mother’s cross-examination of the father (procedural fairness)
- Issue: Costs of the appeal under s 117 Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)

- Child Ages: Child born in 2013 (approximately 30 months old at the time of the primary judge’s reasons).
- Current Arrangements: Child lived with the mother.
- Current Arrangements: From consent orders (23 October 2014): equal shared parental responsibility; father to spend supervised daytime time Monday/Wednesday/Saturday; from March 2015 unsupervised time Mondays, Wednesdays and alternating Saturdays/Sundays.
- Current Arrangements: Planned family dispute resolution at age three regarding overnights.
- Safety Concerns: Mother alleged bullying, cyber/internet harassment by father and his family; father denied many allegations.
- Safety Concerns: Mother held concerns about father’s parenting and possible sexual abuse; primary judge noted these concerns were not supported by departmental investigations.
- Best Interests: Full Court confirmed that an order about the child’s name is a 'parenting order' under s 64B(2)(i) and must be decided with best interests paramount (s 60CA) considering s 60CC factors.
- Best Interests: Primary judge’s best-interests reasoning (upheld): a hyphenated surname reflecting both parents’ heritage would enhance the child’s sense of identity and connection with both parents and extended families.
- Best Interests: Primary judge rejected claims that hyphenation would confuse the child, create data/passport problems, or that differences in surnames with the primary carer would likely cause confusion.
- Best Interests: Family violence issues were considered to have little significance to the surname issue in the context of existing parenting arrangements and the nature of the name dispute.

- Incidents: Mother alleged bullying, cyber and internet harassment by father and his family; father denied many allegations.
- Incidents: Mother alleged breaches of Domestic Violence Order but evidence did not establish action taken by authorities.
- Protection Orders: Domestic Violence Order obtained by mother against father in March 2013 for two years; extended for a further two years on 19 March 2015.

- Outcome: Appeal dismissed.
- Outcome: Appellant mother to pay respondent father’s costs of the appeal assessed in the sum of $8000, payable within 12 months.

- Reasons: The appeal challenged a discretionary parenting decision; appellate intervention required demonstration of error rather than a different preferred outcome (House v The King principles).
- Reasons: The primary judge was found to have considered the mother’s submissions (including keepsakes/social footprint, confusion, alleged antagonism/proprietorial motives, paternity concerns, and family violence) but was entitled to reject them on the evidence.
- Reasons: The Full Court held that differences in the father’s informal usage of names or social media references were not materially relevant to determining the child’s best interests regarding future surname.
- Reasons: A minor factual error alleged by the mother (being prevented from correcting father’s claim about a magistrate calling proceedings frivolous) did not arise; the primary judge did not make such a finding and found evidence insufficient to make findings about that matter.
- Reasons: The mother’s reliance on Queensland birth registration provisions did not bear on the family law best-interests determination for a parenting order about the child’s name.
- Reasons: Costs were ordered against the mother as the appeal was wholly unsuccessful; her Centrelink income was relevant but not a bar to costs; costs were fixed at $8000 as modest and undisputed, with 12 months to pay.

- Pivotal Finding: Orders about a child’s name are parenting orders within s 64B(2)(i) and 'major long-term issues' include the child’s name (s 4(1)), so best interests under s 60CA and s 60CC apply.
- Pivotal Finding: No appealable error was shown in the primary judge’s conclusion that a hyphenated surname reflecting both parents’ heritage was in the child’s best interests and would enhance identity/connection.
- Pivotal Finding: The primary judge was entitled to reject as unlikely the mother’s assertions that a hyphenated surname would confuse the child or create practical administrative difficulties, particularly given the child’s young age and limited 'social footprint'.
- Pivotal Finding: The primary judge was entitled to give little weight to a Family Consultant’s speculative statement about reducing the risk of the father disengaging, given unclear foundation and lack of exploration in cross-examination.
- Pivotal Finding: The Full Court found the mother was not prevented from cross-examining about domestic violence; the trial judge advised it may not assist but permitted the line of questioning, and the mother did not pursue it.
- Pivotal Finding: The Full Court accepted the primary judge’s approach that the existence/extent of alleged family violence had little relevance to the surname determination given the parenting orders in place and the issue being the child’s name rather than time or safety arrangements.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CA (best interests paramount)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC (best interests considerations)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 64B(1)-(3) (parenting orders; care/welfare/development; parental responsibility decisions)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 61B (definition of parental responsibility)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4(1) (major long-term issues include child’s name)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(2A)(a) (costs—financial circumstances)
- Statutory Pivot: Births, Deaths and Marriages Registration Act 2003 (Qld) s 8(2)(c) (raised by mother but found irrelevant to the surname dispute)

- Uncertainties: Exact terms of the Domestic Violence Order and the specific alleged incidents underpinning it were not detailed in the appeal reasons.
- Uncertainties: No detail was provided about any police action (if any) following the mother’s reports of alleged DVO breaches.
- Uncertainties: The child’s full first name and precise birth date were not stated (only year of birth).

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from dismissal of de facto property settlement application for lack of jurisdiction under the geographical requirement in s 90SK(1)(b)(ii) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether contributions made before the formal commencement of the de facto relationship can be 'substantial contributions in relation to the de facto relationship' for s 90SK
Whether the appellant's contributions (including proceeds of a NSW house sale) were made 'in' New South Wales (a participating jurisdiction) for the purpose of s 90SK
Meaning and application of 'in relation to' and 'substantial contributions' in s 90SK, by reference to contributions described in s 90SM(4)
facts: The parties met in Sydney in April 1999; the respondent lived in Vanuatu and was visiting Australia.
During 1999 the parties spent periods in the same residence in New South Wales and Vanuatu.
They commenced living together full-time in Vanuatu in January 2000 and lived there until separation in 2011.
Before moving to Vanuatu, the appellant sold her home in New South Wales for $240,000 and received $80,000 net proceeds.
The respondent owned a property in New South Wales and still owns it.
The appellant kept her Sydney employment 'on hold' when moving to Vanuatu and resigned about three years later.
To facilitate the move, the appellant applied to vary parenting orders for her child from another relationship, resulting in significantly reduced time with that child.
After about a year living together in Vanuatu, the parties acquired a business; the appellant paid $30,000 from the NSW house-sale proceeds to buy her half share.
In 2003, the parties bought a home in Vanuatu for $120,000; the appellant paid $30,000 from the NSW house-sale proceeds and the balance was funded by a joint mortgage.
The parties acquired other property in Vanuatu; the appellant asserted the remaining $20,000 from the NSW sale diminished while she was away.

asset_pool: Proceeds of sale of appellant's New South Wales home: $240,000 sale price; $80,000 net proceeds received by appellant
Respondent's New South Wales property (still owned by respondent)
Vanuatu business acquired after about one year of cohabitation (appellant paid $30,000 for half share)
Vanuatu home purchased in 2003 for $120,000 (appellant contributed $30,000; remainder funded by joint mortgage)
Other property in Vanuatu (not itemised in the text)
contributions: Appellant's initial property/financial contribution comprised the net proceeds ($80,000) from sale of her NSW home, held in NSW at commencement of cohabitation/de facto relationship and later partly applied to acquisitions in Vanuatu
Appellant paid $30,000 from the NSW proceeds towards purchase of her half interest in the Vanuatu business
Appellant paid $30,000 from the NSW proceeds towards purchase of the Vanuatu home

Appellant took steps in Australia connected with relocation (sale of home; holding job; varying parenting orders), advanced as contributions to welfare/relationship (court did not need to determine whether these were contributions for s 90SK once financial contribution found sufficient)
just_equitable: No final property adjustment determination was made; appeal concerned only jurisdiction under s 90SK and remittal for further conduct.
living_arrangements: Cohabitation in Vanuatu from January 2000 to separation in 2011
Appellant returned to Sydney in 2011

relationship_length: De facto relationship in Vanuatu from 2000 to 2011 (approx. 11 years)

current_arrangements: The appellant varied parenting orders for a child from another relationship before moving to Vanuatu, resulting in greatly reduced time with the child.

outcome_orders: The appeal was allowed.
The Federal Circuit Court order of 16 October 2013 dismissing the property application was set aside.
The proceedings were remitted to the Federal Circuit Court of Australia for directions in relation to the future conduct of the proceedings.
No order as to costs.
Costs certificate granted to the appellant under s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the appeal.
Costs certificate granted to the respondent under s 6 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the appeal.

description: This appeal clarified the construction of the s 90SK geographical gateway for de facto property jurisdiction. The Full Court held that the trial judge erred by treating pre-relationship acts as incapable of being contributions 'in relation to' the relationship. The phrase 'in relation to' was treated as broad, requiring a sufficient nexus rather than strict simultaneity. The appellant's NSW-held sale proceeds were an 'initial contribution' made in New South Wales, satisfying s 90SK(1)(b)(ii) and enabling the Federal Circuit Court to exercise de facto property jurisdiction under s 90SM.
pivotal_findings: The trial judge misdirected himself by asking whether contributions were made during the relationship, rather than whether they were made 'in relation to' the relationship.

The expression 'in relation to' in s 90SK(1)(b)(ii) is broad and should not be read down; contributions made before commencement of the de facto relationship can qualify if there is a sufficient nexus to the relationship.

The appellant's $80,000 net proceeds from sale of her NSW home constituted a contribution of the kind in s 90SM(4) and was made in New South Wales because the proceeds were held in that State at the commencement of the de facto relationship; later use of the funds in Vanuatu was immaterial to where the contribution was made for s 90SK.
The contribution was 'substantial' in context; the respondent effectively conceded substantiality (though disputing location).
Because substantial contributions were made in a participating jurisdiction, the s 90SK geographical requirement was satisfied and the property application should not have been dismissed.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SK(1)(b)(ii) (geographical requirement: substantial contributions in participating jurisdiction)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SM(4)(a)-(c) (kinds of contributions referenced by s 90SK) and s 90SM(3) (just and equitable requirement, not reached on the merits)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4AA (definition of de facto relationship; date finding upheld as open but not determinative to jurisdiction outcome)
Australian Constitution s 51(xxxvii) (referral of State powers enabling de facto property jurisdiction)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6 and 9 (costs certificates)

reasons_rationale: Jurisdiction turned on satisfying s 90SK because the parties were not ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction for the requisite period and were not ordinarily resident in such a jurisdiction at breakdown.

The Full Court rejected the narrow approach that a contribution must be made while the relationship exists; it accepted pre-commencement contributions can be 'in relation to' the relationship if sufficiently connected.
The appellant's sale of her NSW home in anticipation of relocation to live with the respondent supplied a clear nexus between the contribution and the relationship.

The Court reasoned that treating 'contributed' as meaning only 'applied' would produce an untenable result (e.g., a party's existing NSW property would not be a contribution merely because it was retained), despite being property available for distribution under the Act.
Given the jurisdictional error, the proper course was to set aside the dismissal and remit for further case management and determination on the merits.
uncertainties: No final determination of the property pool, valuations, liabilities, percentage division, or just and equitable outcome; the matter was remitted for further proceedings.

The Full Court did not finally determine whether the appellant's non-financial steps (career arrangements and parenting-order changes) were 'contributions' for s 90SK, as the financial contribution was sufficient.
The precise scope and value of 'other property in Vanuatu' was not specified.

summary_text:
- Fact: The parties met in Sydney in April 1999; the respondent lived in Vanuatu and was visiting Australia.
- Fact: During 1999 the parties spent periods in the same residence in New South Wales and Vanuatu.
- Fact: They commenced living together full-time in Vanuatu in January 2000 and lived there until separation in 2011.
- Fact: Before moving to Vanuatu, the appellant sold her home in New South Wales for $240,000 and received $80,000 net proceeds.
- Fact: The respondent owned a property in New South Wales and still owns it.
- Fact: The appellant kept her Sydney employment 'on hold' when moving to Vanuatu and resigned about three years later.
- Fact: To facilitate the move, the appellant applied to vary parenting orders for her child from another relationship, resulting in significantly reduced time with that child.
- Fact: After about a year living together in Vanuatu, the parties acquired a business; the appellant paid $30,000 from the NSW house-sale proceeds to buy her half share.
- Fact: In 2003, the parties bought a home in Vanuatu for $120,000; the appellant paid $30,000 from the NSW house-sale proceeds and the balance was funded by a joint mortgage.
- Fact: The parties acquired other property in Vanuatu; the appellant asserted the remaining $20,000 from the NSW sale diminished while she was away.

- Issue: Appeal from dismissal of de facto property settlement application for lack of jurisdiction under the geographical requirement in s 90SK(1)(b)(ii) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
- Issue: Whether contributions made before the formal commencement of the de facto relationship can be 'substantial contributions in relation to the de facto relationship' for s 90SK
- Issue: Whether the appellant's contributions (including proceeds of a NSW house sale) were made 'in' New South Wales (a participating jurisdiction) for the purpose of s 90SK
- Issue: Meaning and application of 'in relation to' and 'substantial contributions' in s 90SK, by reference to contributions described in s 90SM(4)

- Asset Pool: Proceeds of sale of appellant's New South Wales home: $240,000 sale price; $80,000 net proceeds received by appellant
- Asset Pool: Respondent's New South Wales property (still owned by respondent)
- Asset Pool: Vanuatu business acquired after about one year of cohabitation (appellant paid $30,000 for half share)
- Asset Pool: Vanuatu home purchased in 2003 for $120,000 (appellant contributed $30,000; remainder funded by joint mortgage)
- Asset Pool: Other property in Vanuatu (not itemised in the text)
- Contributions: Appellant's initial property/financial contribution comprised the net proceeds ($80,000) from sale of her NSW home, held in NSW at commencement of cohabitation/de facto relationship and later partly applied to acquisitions in Vanuatu
- Contributions: Appellant paid $30,000 from the NSW proceeds towards purchase of her half interest in the Vanuatu business
- Contributions: Appellant paid $30,000 from the NSW proceeds towards purchase of the Vanuatu home
- Contributions: Appellant took steps in Australia connected with relocation (sale of home; holding job; varying parenting orders), advanced as contributions to welfare/relationship (court did not need to determine whether these were contributions for s 90SK once financial contribution found sufficient)
- Just & Equitable: No final property adjustment determination was made; appeal concerned only jurisdiction under s 90SK and remittal for further conduct.
- Current Arrangements: The appellant varied parenting orders for a child from another relationship before moving to Vanuatu, resulting in greatly reduced time with the child.

- Outcome: The appeal was allowed.
- Outcome: The Federal Circuit Court order of 16 October 2013 dismissing the property application was set aside.
- Outcome: The proceedings were remitted to the Federal Circuit Court of Australia for directions in relation to the future conduct of the proceedings.
- Outcome: No order as to costs.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the appellant under s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the appeal.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the respondent under s 6 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the appeal.

- Reasons: Jurisdiction turned on satisfying s 90SK because the parties were not ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction for the requisite period and were not ordinarily resident in such a jurisdiction at breakdown.
- Reasons: The Full Court rejected the narrow approach that a contribution must be made while the relationship exists; it accepted pre-commencement contributions can be 'in relation to' the relationship if sufficiently connected.
- Reasons: The appellant's sale of her NSW home in anticipation of relocation to live with the respondent supplied a clear nexus between the contribution and the relationship.
- Reasons: The Court reasoned that treating 'contributed' as meaning only 'applied' would produce an untenable result (e.g., a party's existing NSW property would not be a contribution merely because it was retained), despite being property available for distribution under the Act.
- Reasons: Given the jurisdictional error, the proper course was to set aside the dismissal and remit for further case management and determination on the merits.

- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge misdirected himself by asking whether contributions were made during the relationship, rather than whether they were made 'in relation to' the relationship.
- Pivotal Finding: The expression 'in relation to' in s 90SK(1)(b)(ii) is broad and should not be read down; contributions made before commencement of the de facto relationship can qualify if there is a sufficient nexus to the relationship.
- Pivotal Finding: The appellant's $80,000 net proceeds from sale of her NSW home constituted a contribution of the kind in s 90SM(4) and was made in New South Wales because the proceeds were held in that State at the commencement of the de facto relationship; later use of the funds in Vanuatu was immaterial to where the contribution was made for s 90SK.
- Pivotal Finding: The contribution was 'substantial' in context; the respondent effectively conceded substantiality (though disputing location).
- Pivotal Finding: Because substantial contributions were made in a participating jurisdiction, the s 90SK geographical requirement was satisfied and the property application should not have been dismissed.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SK(1)(b)(ii) (geographical requirement: substantial contributions in participating jurisdiction)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SM(4)(a)-(c) (kinds of contributions referenced by s 90SK) and s 90SM(3) (just and equitable requirement, not reached on the merits)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4AA (definition of de facto relationship; date finding upheld as open but not determinative to jurisdiction outcome)
- Statutory Pivot: Australian Constitution s 51(xxxvii) (referral of State powers enabling de facto property jurisdiction)
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6 and 9 (costs certificates)

- Uncertainties: No final determination of the property pool, valuations, liabilities, percentage division, or just and equitable outcome; the matter was remitted for further proceedings.
- Uncertainties: The Full Court did not finally determine whether the appellant's non-financial steps (career arrangements and parenting-order changes) were 'contributions' for s 90SK, as the financial contribution was sufficient.
- Uncertainties: The precise scope and value of 'other property in Vanuatu' was not specified.

- Contributions: Appellant took steps in Australia connected with relocation (sale of home; holding job; varying parenting orders), advanced as contributions to welfare/relationship (court did not need to determine whether these were contributions for s 90SK once financial contribution found sufficient)
- Just & Equitable: No final property adjustment determination was made; appeal concerned only jurisdiction under s 90SK and remittal for further conduct.
- Current Arrangements: The appellant varied parenting orders for a child from another relationship before moving to Vanuatu, resulting in greatly reduced time with the child.

- Outcome: The appeal was allowed.
- Outcome: The Federal Circuit Court order of 16 October 2013 dismissing the property application was set aside.
- Outcome: The proceedings were remitted to the Federal Circuit Court of Australia for directions in relation to the future conduct of the proceedings.
- Outcome: No order as to costs.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the appellant under s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the appeal.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the respondent under s 6 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the appeal.

- Reasons: Jurisdiction turned on satisfying s 90SK because the parties were not ordinarily resident in a participating jurisdiction for the requisite period and were not ordinarily resident in such a jurisdiction at breakdown.
- Reasons: The Full Court rejected the narrow approach that a contribution must be made while the relationship exists; it accepted pre-commencement contributions can be 'in relation to' the relationship if sufficiently connected.
- Reasons: The appellant's sale of her NSW home in anticipation of relocation to live with the respondent supplied a clear nexus between the contribution and the relationship.
- Reasons: The Court reasoned that treating 'contributed' as meaning only 'applied' would produce an untenable result (e.g., a party's existing NSW property would not be a contribution merely because it was retained), despite being property available for distribution under the Act.
- Reasons: Given the jurisdictional error, the proper course was to set aside the dismissal and remit for further case management and determination on the merits.

- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge misdirected himself by asking whether contributions were made during the relationship, rather than whether they were made 'in relation to' the relationship.
- Pivotal Finding: The expression 'in relation to' in s 90SK(1)(b)(ii) is broad and should not be read down; contributions made before commencement of the de facto relationship can qualify if there is a sufficient nexus to the relationship.
- Pivotal Finding: The appellant's $80,000 net proceeds from sale of her NSW home constituted a contribution of the kind in s 90SM(4) and was made in New South Wales because the proceeds were held in that State at the commencement of the de facto relationship; later use of the funds in Vanuatu was immaterial to where the contribution was made for s 90SK.
- Pivotal Finding: The contribution was 'substantial' in context; the respondent effectively conceded substantiality (though disputing location).
- Pivotal Finding: Because substantial contributions were made in a participating jurisdiction, the s 90SK geographical requirement was satisfied and the property application should not have been dismissed.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SK(1)(b)(ii) (geographical requirement: substantial contributions in participating jurisdiction)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SM(4)(a)-(c) (kinds of contributions referenced by s 90SK) and s 90SM(3) (just and equitable requirement, not reached on the merits)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4AA (definition of de facto relationship; date finding upheld as open but not determinative to jurisdiction outcome)
- Statutory Pivot: Australian Constitution s 51(xxxvii) (referral of State powers enabling de facto property jurisdiction)
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6 and 9 (costs certificates)

- Uncertainties: No final determination of the property pool, valuations, liabilities, percentage division, or just and equitable outcome; the matter was remitted for further proceedings.
- Uncertainties: The Full Court did not finally determine whether the appellant's non-financial steps (career arrangements and parenting-order changes) were 'contributions' for s 90SK, as the financial contribution was sufficient.
- Uncertainties: The precise scope and value of 'other property in Vanuatu' was not specified.

court: Family Court of Australia (Appellate Jurisdiction)
issues: Appeal from interim parenting-related orders made in the Federal Circuit Court
Whether the primary judge erred in refusing to replace the Independent Children’s Lawyer (ICL)
Whether the primary judge erred in restraining the mother from leaving Australia and placing her on the Airport Watch List
Procedural fairness concerning an injunction made on the court’s own motion
Adequacy of reasons for making the injunction
facts: The parties have a son (C) born in 2008 in China.
The father has lived in Australia since 2001; he returned to China in January 2008 and met the mother.
The mother and child came to Australia in 2009; the parties married and lived together until March 2010.
The mother and child returned to China in October 2010; the child has not seen the father since October 2010.
The father commenced parenting proceedings in April 2011; they were dismissed in September 2012 because the mother and child’s whereabouts were unknown.
The mother remarried in China and later returned to Australia with her new partner and another child (half-sibling) before November 2013.
In March 2014 orders were made placing the child on the Airport Watch List and restraining the mother from removing the child from Australia.
An ICL was appointed in July 2014; the mother’s earlier challenge to that appointment was unsuccessful.
In September 2014 interim orders were made for supervised time between the child and father at a contact centre and for therapeutic services to assist reintroduction.
Those September 2014 orders were not complied with; despite unsuccessful appeals by the mother (including unsuccessful special leave), there was still no contact years later.

A family consultant report (April 2016) recommended it would benefit the child to spend some time with his biological father, that the mother tell the child of his paternity, and that reintroduction occur with contact centre assistance.
Orders in April 2016 required the mother to bring the child to Child Dispute Services and that a family consultant inform the child of his paternity.
A later memorandum (May 2016) expressed concern it would be detrimental for the child to receive paternity information from a stranger and recommended against proceeding at that stage.
In June/July 2016 the court made orders for reintroduction therapy with a nominated practitioner (eventually Ms F) and for attendance at specified appointments.
In August 2016 the mother travelled to China for an extended period and returned in October 2016; she did not inform the father or ICL beforehand and left the child in the care of the stepfather.
During the mother’s absence she missed two court events; the ICL issued multiple subpoenas and obtained a location order to ascertain the child’s whereabouts.

child_ages: Child C born in 2008 (approximately 8-9 years old at time of appeal)
current_arrangements: Child living with the mother in Australia.
At the time of the December 2016 hearing, the household included the maternal grandmother and the child’s younger half-sister.
caregiver_history: Mother has been primary carer since separation; child had not seen father since 2010.
Mother previously removed/returned to China with the child in 2010 during earlier proceedings.
In 2016 mother left the child with the stepfather while she was in China.
availability: Mother travelled to China from August to October 2016 without notifying father/ICL, affecting compliance with reintroduction therapy arrangements.
safety_concerns: Court and parties were concerned about the child’s whereabouts and welfare when the mother travelled to China without notification and missed court events.
Concern that the mother may again leave Australia, defeating existing parenting/reintroduction orders.
allegations: Mother alleged ICL was not independent and acted improperly, but provided no supporting evidence accepted by the court.
expert_evidence: Family consultant report (6 April 2016) recommended the child be told of paternity and that reintroduction with father occur assisted by contact centre staff.
A different family consultant memorandum (23 May 2016) warned it could be detrimental for the child to be told paternity by a stranger and recommended against proceeding at that stage.
The appellate reasons state the ICL’s position aligned with recommendations of the family consultants supporting reintroduction.
best_interests: Primary judge and appellate judge treated the reintroduction/paternity disclosure process as directed to the child’s best interests and required mother’s involvement in therapeutic support.
Injunction restraining the mother from leaving Australia was found to be in the best interests of the child to ensure compliance with existing parenting-related orders.
orders: Primary judge (8 December 2016) refused to replace the ICL.
Primary judge (8 December 2016) restrained the mother from leaving Australia until further order and requested AFP place her on the Airport Watch List (to give effect to the injunction).
On appeal (1 June 2017), the appeal against those orders was dismissed.

police_court: Australian Federal Police requested to place the mother on the Airport Watch List to give effect to the injunction.

outcome_orders: Appeal against the orders of Judge Monahan made on 8 December 2016 dismissed.
No order as to costs.

description: This appellate decision confirms that an interim injunction restraining a parent from leaving Australia can be made under s 114(3) in parenting proceedings, including on the court’s own motion, where it is necessary to secure compliance with existing parenting/reintroduction orders and is connected to the child’s best interests. It also emphasises an appellant’s burden to identify specific appealable error and supports the continued appointment of an ICL absent evidence of lack of independence or misconduct.
pivotal_findings: The mother’s evidence and submissions did not establish any objective basis to replace the ICL; the application lacked supporting evidence.
The mother had a history of non-compliance with orders directed to reintroduction and paternity disclosure, and the child had no contact with the father for many years.
The mother travelled to China without notice, missed court events, and her actions caused uncertainty about the child’s whereabouts, prompting subpoenas and a location order.
The mother stated she went to China such that no one could take the child to the therapeutic practitioner, supporting a concern she would avoid compliance by leaving Australia again.

The injunction was necessary to ensure the mother’s presence in Australia so she could participate in the therapeutic process and comply with extant orders, and was appropriately made as a temporary measure subject to review.
Procedural fairness was afforded because the basis for the injunction arose during the hearing, the mother could make submissions, and adjournment risked the injunction being defeated by departure.
Although ex tempore and brief, the primary judge’s reasons were adequate when read with the hearing exchanges to reveal the reasoning process.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 114(3) (injunctions in relation to a child/party; power to restrain relocation/freedom of movement where necessary and connected to parenting orders and child’s best interests).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 94AAA(3) (single judge hearing of appeal by direction).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 96AA (summary dismissal; raised but not heard due to lack of notice).

reasons_rationale: No appellable error was shown in the refusal to replace the ICL because the mother presented no evidence establishing lack of independence or inappropriate conduct.
The ICL’s advocacy for reintroduction was consistent with expert recommendations and the ICL’s duty to act in the child’s best interests rather than adopt the mother’s preferred outcome.

The injunction restraining the mother from leaving Australia was within power under s 114(3) and was justified by the unusual features: long-term non-compliance, past removal, undisclosed travel, missed court events, and risk of defeating existing orders.
The injunction was found to be necessary to ensure compliance and in the child’s best interests, with concern about the child’s welfare and the need for certainty.
Procedural fairness was not denied because the issues emerged during the hearing, the mother could respond, and delaying could undermine effectiveness.
Reasons were sufficient when read in context of the transcript; the basis for the decision was clear.
Costs were not sought by father or ICL; no costs order made.
uncertainties: No final parenting determination was made; the appeal concerned only interim orders, and the substantive parenting case remained unresolved with no final hearing date stated.
The decision references competing expert views (April 2016 report vs May 2016 memorandum) without resolving the broader therapeutic/paternity disclosure dispute as a fresh issue on this appeal.
The precise duration and ongoing review timing of the mother’s Airport Watch List/injunction was not fixed in the order (it operated until further order).

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia (Melbourne)
issues: Appeal from dismissal of the mother’s post-consent parenting application at a preliminary stage under the rule in Rice & Asplund
Whether the mother established a prima facie significant change in circumstances since final consent parenting orders (including proposed interstate relocation)
Whether the primary judge misapplied the Rice & Asplund test by not assuming acceptance of the applicant’s evidence at the preliminary stage
Whether the primary judge’s conclusion (no significant change) was reasonably open on the evidence
Costs of the appeal and entitlement to costs certificates under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)
facts: The parties separated about two years before May 2015.
There are three children: twins X and Y (then aged 7 in 2015) and Z (then aged 5 in 2015).
Final consent parenting orders were made on 25 May 2015.
Under the consent orders the children lived with the mother and spent time with the father for five nights per fortnight (1 night one week and 4 nights the other) plus school holiday blocks.
On 5 September 2016 the mother filed an application seeking different final parenting orders, centrally proposing relocation with the children from Melbourne to South East Queensland.
The mother sought an interim order for a family report pursuant to s 62G of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).
The father opposed the family report and sought dismissal of the mother’s application, seeking the 25 May 2015 orders remain in effect.
The parties agreed the Rice & Asplund issue would be determined as a preliminary matter in the Federal Circuit Court.
On 9 December 2016 Judge Harland dismissed the mother’s parenting application, finding no prima facie significant change of circumstances.
The mother appealed to the Full Court.

existing_agreements: Property settlement negotiated around the time of the 2015 parenting consent orders; financial orders made 4 June 2015 (details referred to only insofar as relevant to the mother’s asserted financial change).

child_ages: Twins X and Y: 7 years old in May 2015
Z: 5 years old in May 2015
current_arrangements: Under 25 May 2015 consent orders: children lived with the mother; father spent time five nights per fortnight (1/4 night pattern) and block holiday time.
caregiver_history: Mother described herself as the children’s primary carer; her evidence about increased work reducing her availability was unchallenged at the preliminary hearing.
availability: Mother asserted she was required to work one full-time job and two part-time jobs, impacting her availability and requiring regular before/after school care.
Mother asserted relocation would improve financial security and reduce her paid work, increasing her time available to care for the children.
Father had periods of unemployment and sporadic income (per his affidavit) and later obtained full-time employment (as stated to the Full Court).
safety_concerns: Earlier (pre-2015) parenting litigation involved concerns following the father’s alleged ‘mental breakdown’ and hospitalisation and the mother’s expressed anxiety about his capacity to care for the children; the appeal decision did not determine merits of those concerns.
allegations: Each parent alleged the other had not complied with the consent orders to the children’s detriment.
Mother acknowledged three occasions of not facilitating father-child time; father alleged additional missed time (said to be about four weeks).
Mother alleged erratic/non-payment of child support affected children and increased her stress and work commitments.
expert_evidence: A family report dated 16 September 2014 existed and was said to underpin the 2015 agreement; it included commentary that neither parent should relocate so as to render time with the other parent ‘virtually impossible’ (the Full Court criticised the lack of factual foundation for relocation commentary and emphasised relocation is a matter for the court).
Mother sought a further family report under s 62G; the father opposed it; the Full Court did not order a report but referred the matter for trial preparation.
best_interests: The Full Court reiterated that Rice & Asplund is a manifestation of the best interests principle, aimed at avoiding harmful repetitive litigation, but distinguished this from circumstances where a consent-based arrangement breaks down due to asserted post-order changes.
At a preliminary Rice & Asplund hearing the court must assume acceptance of the applicant’s evidence when assessing whether there is a sufficient change to justify embarking on a hearing.
orders: Appeal orders set aside the dismissal of the mother’s application and referred the mother’s initiating application and father’s response to another Federal Circuit Court judge for directions to prepare for trial.

outcome_orders: The appeal be allowed.
The orders of Judge Harland made on 9 December 2016 be set aside.
The father’s interim application in paragraphs 1 and 2 of his Response filed 18 November 2016 be dismissed.

The mother’s Initiating Application filed 5 September 2016 and the father’s Response filed 18 November 2016 be referred to a judge of the Federal Circuit Court other than Judge Harland for orders and directions to prepare the matter for trial.
Each party bear their own costs of and incidental to this appeal.
Costs certificate granted to the mother pursuant to s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth).

description: This appellate decision clarifies the correct application of the Rice & Asplund ‘change of circumstances’ rule when determined as a preliminary matter in parenting proceedings following final consent orders. The Full Court held the primary judge erred by concluding there was no prima facie significant change without an evidentiary foundation and by effectively engaging with merits-based concerns (such as facilitation post-relocation) rather than applying the preliminary-stage test. The appeal’s practical significance is that the mother’s relocation application was revived and sent back for trial preparation, rather than being shut out at the threshold.
pivotal_findings: At a preliminary Rice & Asplund hearing, the court must assume the applicant’s evidence is accepted and ask whether, on that assumed acceptance, there is a sufficient change to justify embarking on a hearing; the primary judge’s reasons did not do this.

The primary judge’s conclusion that many issues were raised previously or could have been raised lacked identification and evidentiary foundation; relocation to South East Queensland was not shown to have been an issue at the time of the 2015 consent orders.

The consent orders were predicated on close geographical proximity in Melbourne; the mother’s proposed permanent interstate relocation represented a fundamental alteration to the premise underpinning the prior orders.

Evidence of progression of the mother’s relationship (including cohabitation plan and intention to expand the family) and evidence of changed financial circumstances (work patterns, child care impacts, child support irregularity) supported a compelling prima facie case of substantial change.

The primary judge’s reliance on concerns about the mother’s future willingness/capacity to facilitate time after relocation was treated as a misapplication of the preliminary inquiry, because the merits of relocation were not the issue being determined at that stage.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 62G (family report) (raised by the mother as an interim request).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(1) and s 117(2A) (costs principles applied to the appeal).
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) s 6 and s 9 (costs certificates granted to both parties).
Rice & Asplund (1979) FLC 90-725 (threshold for re-opening parenting arrangements after final orders).
SPS & PLS (2008) FLC 93-363, Miller & Harrington (2008) FLC 93-383, Marsden & Winch (2009) 42 Fam LR 1 (authorities guiding preliminary-stage formulation of the Rice & Asplund inquiry).

reasons_rationale: The primary judge’s finding of no prima facie significant change was not reasonably open on the evidence and lacked an evidentiary foundation for key conclusions.
The primary judge failed to properly apply the preliminary-stage Rice & Asplund test by not assuming the acceptance of the mother’s evidence and by moving into merits-based considerations.

The mother’s evidence, if accepted, demonstrated substantial changes since the consent orders (relationship progression, relocation proposal, financial pressures and work commitments impacting care, and difficulties implementing the existing arrangements).

Given the error, the Full Court re-exercised the discretion by setting aside the dismissal and referring the matter to a different Federal Circuit Court judge for trial preparation; this avoided possible recusal issues given remarks in the primary reasons.
No order for costs was made (each to bear own) applying s 117(1), with costs certificates granted due to the appeal succeeding on an error of law.
uncertainties: No final determination was made about whether relocation should occur or what final parenting orders will be in the children’s best interests; the matter was referred for trial preparation.
The children’s views were not stated.
No final findings were made on contested allegations of non-compliance with parenting orders or on the merits of any mental health-related parenting concerns.

summary_text:
- Fact: The parties separated about two years before May 2015.
- Fact: There are three children: twins X and Y (then aged 7 in 2015) and Z (then aged 5 in 2015).
- Fact: Final consent parenting orders were made on 25 May 2015.
- Fact: Under the consent orders the children lived with the mother and spent time with the father for five nights per fortnight (1 night one week and 4 nights the other) plus school holiday blocks.
- Fact: On 5 September 2016 the mother filed an application seeking different final parenting orders, centrally proposing relocation with the children from Melbourne to South East Queensland.
- Fact: The mother sought an interim order for a family report pursuant to s 62G of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).
- Fact: The father opposed the family report and sought dismissal of the mother’s application, seeking the 25 May 2015 orders remain in effect.
- Fact: The parties agreed the Rice & Asplund issue would be determined as a preliminary matter in the Federal Circuit Court.
- Fact: On 9 December 2016 Judge Harland dismissed the mother’s parenting application, finding no prima facie significant change of circumstances.
- Fact: The mother appealed to the Full Court.

- Issue: Appeal from dismissal of the mother’s post-consent parenting application at a preliminary stage under the rule in Rice & Asplund
- Issue: Whether the mother established a prima facie significant change in circumstances since final consent parenting orders (including proposed interstate relocation)
- Issue: Whether the primary judge misapplied the Rice & Asplund test by not assuming acceptance of the applicant’s evidence at the preliminary stage
- Issue: Whether the primary judge’s conclusion (no significant change) was reasonably open on the evidence
- Issue: Costs of the appeal and entitlement to costs certificates under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)

- Child Ages: Twins X and Y: 7 years old in May 2015
- Child Ages: Z: 5 years old in May 2015
- Current Arrangements: Under 25 May 2015 consent orders: children lived with the mother; father spent time five nights per fortnight (1/4 night pattern) and block holiday time.
- Safety Concerns: Earlier (pre-2015) parenting litigation involved concerns following the father’s alleged ‘mental breakdown’ and hospitalisation and the mother’s expressed anxiety about his capacity to care for the children; the appeal decision did not determine merits of those concerns.
- Best Interests: The Full Court reiterated that Rice & Asplund is a manifestation of the best interests principle, aimed at avoiding harmful repetitive litigation, but distinguished this from circumstances where a consent-based arrangement breaks down due to asserted post-order changes.
- Best Interests: At a preliminary Rice & Asplund hearing the court must assume acceptance of the applicant’s evidence when assessing whether there is a sufficient change to justify embarking on a hearing.

- Outcome: The appeal be allowed.
- Outcome: The orders of Judge Harland made on 9 December 2016 be set aside.
- Outcome: The father’s interim application in paragraphs 1 and 2 of his Response filed 18 November 2016 be dismissed.
- Outcome: The mother’s Initiating Application filed 5 September 2016 and the father’s Response filed 18 November 2016 be referred to a judge of the Federal Circuit Court other than Judge Harland for orders and directions to prepare the matter for trial.
- Outcome: Each party bear their own costs of and incidental to this appeal.
- Outcome: Costs certificate granted to the mother pursuant to s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth).

- Reasons: The primary judge’s finding of no prima facie significant change was not reasonably open on the evidence and lacked an evidentiary foundation for key conclusions.
- Reasons: The primary judge failed to properly apply the preliminary-stage Rice & Asplund test by not assuming the acceptance of the mother’s evidence and by moving into merits-based considerations.
- Reasons: The mother’s evidence, if accepted, demonstrated substantial changes since the consent orders (relationship progression, relocation proposal, financial pressures and work commitments impacting care, and difficulties implementing the existing arrangements).
- Reasons: Given the error, the Full Court re-exercised the discretion by setting aside the dismissal and referring the matter to a different Federal Circuit Court judge for trial preparation; this avoided possible recusal issues given remarks in the primary reasons.
- Reasons: No order for costs was made (each to bear own) applying s 117(1), with costs certificates granted due to the appeal succeeding on an error of law.

- Pivotal Finding: At a preliminary Rice & Asplund hearing, the court must assume the applicant’s evidence is accepted and ask whether, on that assumed acceptance, there is a sufficient change to justify embarking on a hearing; the primary judge’s reasons did not do this.
- Pivotal Finding: The primary judge’s conclusion that many issues were raised previously or could have been raised lacked identification and evidentiary foundation; relocation to South East Queensland was not shown to have been an issue at the time of the 2015 consent orders.
- Pivotal Finding: The consent orders were predicated on close geographical proximity in Melbourne; the mother’s proposed permanent interstate relocation represented a fundamental alteration to the premise underpinning the prior orders.
- Pivotal Finding: Evidence of progression of the mother’s relationship (including cohabitation plan and intention to expand the family) and evidence of changed financial circumstances (work patterns, child care impacts, child support irregularity) supported a compelling prima facie case of substantial change.
- Pivotal Finding: The primary judge’s reliance on concerns about the mother’s future willingness/capacity to facilitate time after relocation was treated as a misapplication of the preliminary inquiry, because the merits of relocation were not the issue being determined at that stage.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 62G (family report) (raised by the mother as an interim request).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(1) and s 117(2A) (costs principles applied to the appeal).
- Statutory Pivot: Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) s 6 and s 9 (costs certificates granted to both parties).
- Statutory Pivot: Rice & Asplund (1979) FLC 90-725 (threshold for re-opening parenting arrangements after final orders).
- Statutory Pivot: SPS & PLS (2008) FLC 93-363, Miller & Harrington (2008) FLC 93-383, Marsden & Winch (2009) 42 Fam LR 1 (authorities guiding preliminary-stage formulation of the Rice & Asplund inquiry).

- Uncertainties: No final determination was made about whether relocation should occur or what final parenting orders will be in the children’s best interests; the matter was referred for trial preparation.
- Uncertainties: The children’s views were not stated.
- Uncertainties: No final findings were made on contested allegations of non-compliance with parenting orders or on the merits of any mental health-related parenting concerns.
