court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from property settlement decision under s 79 Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether it was just and equitable to alter property interests where only the husband's property could be identified and valued due to the wife's non-disclosure
Procedural fairness: whether the trial judge wrongly relied on the wife's trial case outline document
Whether the trial judge misapprehended evidence about the husband's initial contributions
facts: The parties commenced cohabitation in 1992, married in 1993, and separated in March 2014.
There were three children aged 18, 17 and 13 at the time of the trial.
The parties acquired a hotel business in 1997 and operated it until ceasing operations in 2005; it was sold in September 2008 for about $1.1 million.
The husband suffered an accident in 2003 which precluded employment; he assumed the primary care role for the children thereafter.

asset_pool: Husband's identified property interests totalled $793,000, comprising: B Street ($295,000), husband's cash ($436,000), husband's prepaid legal fees ($35,000), Mr G loan ($27,000).
Wife's superannuation interest approximately $35,000.
Wife was found to have property interests in Country A, but they were not capable of identification and valuation due to non-disclosure and lack of valuation evidence.
The wife had access to and disposed of or retained funds in the period around separation totalling amounts probably exceeding $250,000; precise quantification was not possible.
contributions: The husband was found to have made a significant initial contribution of $55,000 savings toward purchase of the first property (C Street) in 1993; later sale proceeds ($310,000) were applied to reduce the hotel mortgage.
Both parties worked as a unit in the hotel business until it ended; the wife was found to have contributed to the profit on sale of the hotel.
From 2003 (after accident) the husband could not work and assumed primary caregiving and homemaker role; later he had sole parenting role since May 2015.
The husband's inheritances totalling about $241,192 were applied for family support, affecting the preservation of other capital.
future_needs: The husband had ongoing obligations to support the children and was caring for them.
The husband lacked capacity to engage in employment due to his accident.
The wife was found to have better employability and capacity to obtain employment.
There was uncertainty as to the wife's assets (including land in Country A and unexplained funds exceeding $250,000), caused by her failure to disclose and to obtain valuations.
The husband asserted lack of child support from the wife was relevant to s 75(2) considerations.
just_equitable: The trial judge, applying Stanford principles, concluded it was not just and equitable to alter the husband's identified property interests in favour of the wife because only the husband's assets were identifiable/valued and any alteration could only be one-way (husband did not seek orders against wife's property).
The trial judge reasoned that awarding the wife a share of known assets on top of what she had or had access to (including unexplained funds and overseas land) would not be just and equitable.

The trial judge considered a notional approach (e.g., adding $250,000 to known assets) and indicated that, on a view of both known and notional assets, the outcome would effectively leave the husband with what he had and the wife with what she had or had had; nonetheless concluded the just and equitable result was to make no adjustment of the husband's assets.
living_arrangements: Following separation, the husband purchased B Street as a home for himself and the children.
The husband was found to have sole parenting responsibility from May 2015.

relationship_length: Relationship/marriage from 1992/1993 to separation in March 2014.

child_ages: 18 years at trial
17 years at trial
13 years at trial
current_arrangements: Husband caring for the children; found to have sole parenting responsibility since May 2015.
caregiver_history: After the husband's 2003 accident precluding work, he assumed the primary care role for the children.
availability: Husband unable to work due to accident; wife found to have capacity to work.

outcome_orders: Appeal dismissed.
Appellant wife to pay the respondent husband's costs of and incidental to the appeal, such costs to be assessed in default of agreement.

description: This appeal confirms the centrality of the 'just and equitable' threshold in s 79 property proceedings, particularly where one party's serious non-disclosure prevents identification and valuation of their own interests. The Full Court treated the trial judge's adverse credibility and disclosure findings as decisive context: because only the husband's assets could be quantified and any adjustment would be one-way, the trial judge was entitled to conclude no alteration should be made. The appeal also illustrates the limited utility of procedural fairness complaints where the impugned reference (to a case outline) is immaterial to the dispositive findings, and clarifies that the trial judge's reasoning was not an impermissible 'double count' add-back but an assessment against known and notional assets in line with Full Court guidance.
pivotal_findings: The wife's 'abject' failure to make full and frank disclosure and deliberately misleading evidence meant her property (including in Country A) could not be identified or valued, aside from about $35,000 superannuation.

The wife had access to and dealt with funds probably exceeding $250,000 around separation and did not provide a plausible explanation; the trial judge doubted she had truly given away all transferred funds.
The husband was found a credible witness whose evidence was accepted; the wife was found unreliable and evasive.

The wife did not challenge the husband's evidence of an initial $55,000 contribution in cross-examination; acceptance of that evidence was open and any reference to a case outline was not determinative.

The trial judge did not in fact 'add back' $250,000 in the conventional sense; rather he considered justice and equity against known assets and potential/notional figures given uncertainty, and then concluded no adjustment of the husband's assets was just and equitable.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 (alteration of property interests; just and equitable requirement per Stanford).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) (contributions and other considerations; referenced as including s 79(4)(e) and (f)).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors; including reference to s 75(2)(n) and (o)).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 (costs; justifying circumstances for costs order).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval for publication under pseudonym noted).

reasons_rationale: No material error was shown in the trial judge's reliance on evidence regarding the husband's initial contribution; the husband gave direct evidence and was not challenged, and the trial judge preferred his evidence.
Any reference to the wife's case outline document was not decisive and did not cause procedural unfairness; even if an error, it was immaterial to the ultimate finding.

The trial judge's approach to the wife's dealings with funds and undisclosed property was consistent with authority requiring consideration of known and notional assets where there is unexplained depletion or non-disclosure (citing Chang v Su; Weir & Weir).

The trial judge's decision that it was not just and equitable to alter the husband's property interests was open given that only the husband's assets were capable of valuation and the wife had undisclosed/uncertain interests and unexplained funds.
Costs were awarded against the wife because the appeal was wholly unsuccessful, devoid of merit, and the wife's true financial position remained unknown due to her non-disclosure.
uncertainties: The nature, extent, and value of the wife's property interests in Country A were not identified or valued due to non-disclosure.
The precise total amount of funds accessed/used/retained by the wife around separation could not be quantified, though found probably to exceed $250,000.
The wife's ultimate asset position (including whether she retained transferred funds) remained uncertain due to adverse findings about disclosure and credibility.

- Child Ages: 18 years at trial

- Current Arrangements: Husband caring for the children; found to have sole parenting responsibility since May 2015.

- Reasons: The trial judge's approach to the wife's dealings with funds and undisclosed property was consistent with authority requiring consideration of known and notional assets where there is unexplained depletion or non-disclosure (citing Chang v Su; Weir & Weir).
- Reasons: The trial judge's decision that it was not just and equitable to alter the husband's property interests was open given that only the husband's assets were capable of valuation and the wife had undisclosed/uncertain interests and unexplained funds.

- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) (contributions and other considerations; referenced as including s 79(4)(e) and (f)).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors; including reference to s 75(2)(n) and (o)).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 (costs; justifying circumstances for costs order).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (approval for publication under pseudonym noted).

- Uncertainties: The nature, extent, and value of the wife's property interests in Country A were not identified or valued due to non-disclosure.
- Uncertainties: The precise total amount of funds accessed/used/retained by the wife around separation could not be quantified, though found probably to exceed $250,000.
- Uncertainties: The wife's ultimate asset position (including whether she retained transferred funds) remained uncertain due to adverse findings about disclosure and credibility.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether the parties were in a de facto relationship within the meaning of s 4AA Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) (a jurisdictional fact)
Whether the Federal Circuit Court had jurisdiction to entertain a de facto financial cause and property settlement application absent a de facto relationship
Whether s 90SB (including serious injustice/substantial contributions) must be considered where a de facto relationship is not established
Appellate challenge to primary judge's factual findings and alleged errors of statutory interpretation/application
facts: The parties met in 1977, resumed contact and began dating regularly in August 1998; relationship continued until late 2012; appellant moved out of respondent's home in early 2013.
There were no children of the relationship.
Until May 2011 the parties lived in separate residences.
At the relationship’s commencement the respondent lived with her two children (from a prior relationship) in property owned/occupied by her mother; the appellant lived with his mother.
In August 1999 the appellant, his mother and the respondent purchased a unit as tenants in common (appellant 40%, mother 40%, respondent 20%) funded by joint borrowing for their respective interests.

The respondent paid one third of monthly mortgage instalments and in July 2007 transferred her 20% interest to the appellant for $85,000; the primary judge found it was at market value and a commercial decision.
The appellant continued to live with his mother in that unit until her death in February 2011.
The respondent purchased a unit in the same building in 2007 but later sold it; she purchased another property in 2009.

After the appellant’s mother died, the jointly occupied unit was sold and proceeds distributed among the appellant and family members; around May 2011 the appellant moved into the respondent’s Sydney home.
From May 2011 to March 2013 (approx.) the parties shared the respondent’s home; the respondent paid all outgoings; the appellant paid no rent/board; he paid the Foxtel account.

asset_pool: No property pool was assessed because the primary judge dismissed the application after finding no de facto relationship (no jurisdiction for de facto property settlement).

Assets referenced in evidence included: a unit purchased in 1999 by appellant, appellant's mother and respondent (later respondent sold her share to appellant); respondent's Sydney home where appellant lived 2011-2013; respondent's Town Y property purchased in 2011; appellant's Suburb R property purchased in 2012.
Financial transactions referenced included the appellant's temporary deposits totalling $145,000 into respondent's mortgage offset account and the respondent retaining $25,000 on repayment.
contributions: Respondent contributed to the 1999 unit purchase by holding a 20% share, borrowing jointly for that interest, and paying one third of the monthly mortgage instalments until transferring her share in 2007 for $85,000 (found to be commercial/market value).
During cohabitation (May 2011-March 2013) respondent paid all property outgoings; appellant paid no rent/board and paid Foxtel.

Appellant deposited $145,000 into respondent's offset account in 2011 to reduce interest; funds were repaid save $25,000 retained with consent; primary judge treated the $25,000 as reasonable given free accommodation and not evidence of financial dependence/interdependence.
future_needs: Not determined; the matter was resolved on jurisdiction (no de facto relationship) rather than s 90SM merits.
just_equitable: Not reached; no de facto relationship found, so no s 90SM adjustment and no 'just and equitable' assessment.
living_arrangements: Parties lived separately until May 2011; then cohabited in respondent’s home until early 2013 with separate bedrooms for most of that period; separated late 2012 and appellant moved out in early 2013.
Respondent travelled frequently to Town Y without the appellant during the cohabitation period and later moved to Town Y in 2014 after selling her Sydney property.
existing_agreements: No binding financial agreement was identified.
Primary judge treated the 2007 transfer of the respondent’s interest in the 1999 unit for $85,000 as a commercial transaction.
There was an informal arrangement regarding return of the $145,000 deposits with respondent retaining $25,000 with appellant’s consent.

outcome_orders: Leave granted to rely on the Further Amended Notice of Appeal annexed to the affidavit filed 15 June 2017.
Appeal against the orders of Judge Sexton made on 30 June 2016 dismissed.
Appellant ordered to pay the respondent’s costs of and incidental to the appeal, to be agreed or assessed and paid within 28 days from agreement or assessment.

description: This appeal turned on jurisdiction in de facto financial causes: whether a de facto relationship existed is a jurisdictional fact under s 4AA, and s 90SB threshold conditions only become relevant after that relationship is established. The Full Court rejected an argument that 'serious injustice' and 'substantial contributions' under s 90SB could themselves supply or influence the jurisdictional finding of a de facto relationship. Appellate intervention was denied because the appellant conceded the primary judge’s factual findings were open on the evidence, failing the 'plainly wrong' threshold for disturbing findings of fact.
pivotal_findings: Primary judge’s finding that the parties were never in a relationship as a couple living together on a genuine domestic basis at any time between August 1998 and March 2013.

Findings supporting absence of a genuine domestic basis, including: separate residences until May 2011; separate bedrooms for most of May 2011-March 2013; respondent’s frequent travel to Town Y without appellant; absence of financial dependence/interdependence; separate property acquisitions without mutual contribution; and third-party documentation not describing each other as partners.
Accepted evidence of a May 2011 conversation indicating respondent did not treat her home/property as shared and appellant accepted he was permitted to stay.

On appeal, the appellant did not assert the primary judge’s factual findings were unavailable on the evidence; counsel conceded they were open, defeating the appeal grounds challenging factual conclusions.
The Full Court held s 90SB 'has no work to do' unless a de facto relationship is first established; contributions/injustice under s 90SB are irrelevant until that threshold is met.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4AA (definition/criteria for de facto relationship; central jurisdictional fact).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90RD (power to declare a de facto relationship existed or never existed in proceedings).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SB (preconditions for the court to make specified orders/declarations in relation to a de facto relationship; engaged only after de facto relationship established).
Appellate principles on findings of fact (including 'plainly wrong' threshold as discussed with reference to Edwards v Noble).
Authorities on jurisdictional facts and limited jurisdiction: DMW v CGW; Yunghanns; and Norton & Locke (applied to reject jurisdictional arguments premised on the ultimate outcome/contributions).

reasons_rationale: A de facto relationship finding is a necessary jurisdictional foundation for de facto financial causes; absent that, the court cannot make property settlement orders.

The primary judge separately considered the cohabitation period and then weighed all s 4AA considerations; her global conclusion that no de facto relationship existed was supported by detailed factual findings.
The appellant’s challenge to factual findings failed because it was conceded those findings were open on the evidence; appellate intervention requires showing findings were plainly wrong.

The construction advanced by the appellant (that s 90SB serious injustice/substantial contributions required a separate assessment capable of affecting the de facto relationship determination) was rejected; s 90SB conditions are only relevant once a de facto relationship is established and cannot confer jurisdiction based on the prospective merits.
Costs followed the event; appellant conceded a costs order would be appropriate if the appeal failed.
uncertainties: Precise frequency and duration of the respondent’s overnight stays at the appellant’s home before May 2011 was disputed; the primary judge could not make more precise findings beyond general acceptance of some regular overnight stays.
The Full Court decision summary does not quantify any overall asset pool or address merits-based contribution/future needs adjustments because jurisdiction was not established.

- Asset Pool: No property pool was assessed because the primary judge dismissed the application after finding no de facto relationship (no jurisdiction for de facto property settlement).

- Asset Pool: Financial transactions referenced included the appellant's temporary deposits totalling $145,000 into respondent's mortgage offset account and the respondent retaining $25,000 on repayment.
- Contributions: Respondent contributed to the 1999 unit purchase by holding a 20% share, borrowing jointly for that interest, and paying one third of the monthly mortgage instalments until transferring her share in 2007 for $85,000 (found to be commercial/market value).

- Reasons: The construction advanced by the appellant (that s 90SB serious injustice/substantial contributions required a separate assessment capable of affecting the de facto relationship determination) was rejected; s 90SB conditions are only relevant once a de facto relationship is established and cannot confer jurisdiction based on the prospective merits.
- Reasons: Costs followed the event; appellant conceded a costs order would be appropriate if the appeal failed.

- Pivotal Finding: Primary judge’s finding that the parties were never in a relationship as a couple living together on a genuine domestic basis at any time between August 1998 and March 2013.
- Pivotal Finding: Findings supporting absence of a genuine domestic basis, including: separate residences until May 2011; separate bedrooms for most of May 2011-March 2013; respondent’s frequent travel to Town Y without appellant; absence of financial dependence/interdependence; separate property acquisitions without mutual contribution; and third-party documentation not describing each other as partners.
- Pivotal Finding: Accepted evidence of a May 2011 conversation indicating respondent did not treat her home/property as shared and appellant accepted he was permitted to stay.
- Pivotal Finding: On appeal, the appellant did not assert the primary judge’s factual findings were unavailable on the evidence; counsel conceded they were open, defeating the appeal grounds challenging factual conclusions.
- Pivotal Finding: The Full Court held s 90SB 'has no work to do' unless a de facto relationship is first established; contributions/injustice under s 90SB are irrelevant until that threshold is met.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4AA (definition/criteria for de facto relationship; central jurisdictional fact).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90RD (power to declare a de facto relationship existed or never existed in proceedings).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SB (preconditions for the court to make specified orders/declarations in relation to a de facto relationship; engaged only after de facto relationship established).

- Uncertainties: The Full Court decision summary does not quantify any overall asset pool or address merits-based contribution/future needs adjustments because jurisdiction was not established.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether an inheritance received by the husband about four years after separation was property available for division under s 79(1) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether the trial magistrate erred in approach/reasons by including the inheritance in the calculation of net assets/resources as the basis for assessing s 79(4) factors
Whether requiring the husband to implement the property orders within 28 days involved error, including alleged procedural unfairness
Appeal costs
facts: The parties married on 2 February 2002, separated on 9 April 2010, and divorced on 2 August 2011.
The relationship lasted about eight years.
They have one child, B, born in 2005.
Since separation, the child has been cared for equally by both parties in a week-about arrangement.
The wife commenced property proceedings on 21 January 2015 and obtained leave under s 44(3) to proceed out of time.
At the commencement of the relationship the wife had nominal assets; the husband had two properties, a motor vehicle, shares, superannuation, and personal effects.
During the marriage the husband's two properties were sold and properties at Suburb C and Town D were acquired.
At the hearing the Suburb C property was valued at $619,333 and the Town D property at $72,500, with a mortgage of $111,115.
Other assets were agreed at $39,099 and total superannuation entitlements were $289,816 (wife $5,606; husband $186,958 and $97,252).
In January 2014, about four years after separation, the husband received an inheritance from his father's estate.

asset_pool: Real property: Suburb C property valued at $619,333; Town D property valued at $72,500.
Mortgage liability: $111,115 over the properties (as at hearing).
Other assets agreed at $39,099.
Superannuation: total $289,816 (wife $5,606; husband $186,958 and $97,252).
After-acquired inheritance: remaining portion represented by assets in husband's control totalling $430,686.
Net assets/resources found by trial magistrate: $1,340,319 (inheritance about 32% of this net figure).
contributions: Initial contributions: husband brought significantly more property into the relationship than the wife; trial magistrate found husband's initial financial contributions 'far outweighed' the wife's.
During marriage: trial magistrate accepted the husband's submissions that contributions during the marriage under s 79(4)(a), (b) and (c) were equal.
Post-separation parenting/financial: despite equal care of the child, the husband met a greater proportion of the child's financial needs because he was in a position to do so.
Inheritance: treated as the overwhelming financial contribution post-separation into the current net assets/resources.
Overall contributions assessment at trial: 75% husband, 25% wife.
future_needs: Adjustment of 10% in the wife's favour under s 75(2), particularly reflecting disparity in income and earning capacity between the wife and the husband.
just_equitable: Trial magistrate found it was just and equitable to make a property settlement order given the long separation and circumstances falling within the type identified in Stanford v Stanford.

Full Court held the inheritance formed part of existing property at the hearing and could be included in the pool; whether to include or treat separately is discretionary subject to s 79(2) just and equitable requirement.
living_arrangements: Separated since April 2010.
Child in equal time week-about arrangement post-separation.
existing_agreements: No binding financial agreement under Pt VIIIA was identified in the reasons.

earning_capacity: Income and earning capacity disparity was referred to in the context of a s 75(2) adjustment in property proceedings.
relationship_length: Relationship/marriage lasted about eight years; separated in 2010.

child_ages: B born in 2005 (about 11-12 years old at the 2016 hearing; about 12 at the 2017 appeal).
current_arrangements: Equal shared care in a week-about arrangement since separation.
caregiver_history: Post-separation care described as equal.

outcome_orders: Appeal against the orders made by Magistrate Calverley on 17 November 2016 dismissed.
Appellant (husband) to pay the respondent’s (wife’s) costs of the appeal as agreed or in default of agreement as assessed.

description: The decision confirms that, in s 79 property proceedings, the 'property' to be identified at the time of hearing includes after-acquired property such as an inheritance received years after separation. The key legal significance is that Stanford v Stanford does not impose a separate threshold requiring a specific nexus between each after-acquired asset and the marriage; instead, the principled reason for interference concerns whether it is just and equitable to make any order altering interests, after identifying existing legal and equitable interests. The treatment of after-acquired property remains a discretionary question typically managed through contribution findings and/or s 79(2) just and equitable reasoning, rather than exclusion from the pool by default.
pivotal_findings: The husband's inheritance received about four years after separation remained property in his control at hearing and was part of the existing property capable of alteration under s 79.
The trial magistrate had discretion to include the inheritance in the asset pool rather than quarantining it; no appealable discretionary error was shown.
The trial magistrate’s reasons were sufficient to satisfy the Stanford requirement to consider whether it was just and equitable to make a property settlement order at all.

While the trial magistrate erred in stating that without including the inheritance he could not appropriately assess s 79(4) matters, that error was not material because the inheritance was properly included and the ground was only adjunct to the main challenge.

No procedural unfairness was established in relation to the 28-day compliance period because the parties were given an opportunity to comment on the form of orders before delivery (consistent with usual practice), and 28 days was not unreasonably short given expected refinancing and available equity.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4 (definitions including 'property' and 'matrimonial cause')
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 31 (jurisdiction)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(1) (power to alter property interests)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(2) (just and equitable threshold)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) (contributions and relevant considerations)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors applied via s 79)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 44(3) (leave to institute property proceedings out of time)

reasons_rationale: The Court held that the legislation and authorities permit orders affecting all property held at the time of hearing, regardless of when acquired, including after-acquired inheritances.

Stanford concerns the need to separately consider whether it is just and equitable to make a property settlement order at all; it does not require a separate principled reason to interfere with each individual asset or exclude after-acquired property absent a special nexus.
The husband's arguments were treated as an invitation to re-argue discretionary matters contrary to established Full Court authority; no appealable error was demonstrated.

The 28-day timeframe was short but not unreasonable given the husband’s expectation of refinancing to remove the wife from the mortgages, and the equity available to facilitate borrowing; procedural fairness complaint failed.
Costs followed the event because the appeal was wholly unsuccessful.
uncertainties: The reasons do not set out a complete itemised schedule of all assets and liabilities beyond the values and figures stated, nor the detailed composition of the inheritance assets.
No detailed findings are provided in the excerpt as to the parties’ incomes, specific budgets, or precise earning capacities beyond noting a disparity for s 75(2) purposes.

- Reasons: Stanford concerns the need to separately consider whether it is just and equitable to make a property settlement order at all; it does not require a separate principled reason to interfere with each individual asset or exclude after-acquired property absent a special nexus.
- Reasons: The husband's arguments were treated as an invitation to re-argue discretionary matters contrary to established Full Court authority; no appealable error was demonstrated.
- Reasons: The 28-day timeframe was short but not unreasonable given the husband’s expectation of refinancing to remove the wife from the mortgages, and the equity available to facilitate borrowing; procedural fairness complaint failed.
- Reasons: Costs followed the event because the appeal was wholly unsuccessful.

- Pivotal Finding: The husband's inheritance received about four years after separation remained property in his control at hearing and was part of the existing property capable of alteration under s 79.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial magistrate had discretion to include the inheritance in the asset pool rather than quarantining it; no appealable discretionary error was shown.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial magistrate’s reasons were sufficient to satisfy the Stanford requirement to consider whether it was just and equitable to make a property settlement order at all.
- Pivotal Finding: While the trial magistrate erred in stating that without including the inheritance he could not appropriately assess s 79(4) matters, that error was not material because the inheritance was properly included and the ground was only adjunct to the main challenge.
- Pivotal Finding: No procedural unfairness was established in relation to the 28-day compliance period because the parties were given an opportunity to comment on the form of orders before delivery (consistent with usual practice), and 28 days was not unreasonably short given expected refinancing and available equity.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4 (definitions including 'property' and 'matrimonial cause')
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 31 (jurisdiction)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(1) (power to alter property interests)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(2) (just and equitable threshold)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) (contributions and relevant considerations)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors applied via s 79)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 44(3) (leave to institute property proceedings out of time)

- Uncertainties: The reasons do not set out a complete itemised schedule of all assets and liabilities beyond the values and figures stated, nor the detailed composition of the inheritance assets.
- Uncertainties: No detailed findings are provided in the excerpt as to the parties’ incomes, specific budgets, or precise earning capacities beyond noting a disparity for s 75(2) purposes.

summary_sections.text:
- Fact: The parties married on 2 February 2002, separated on 9 April 2010, and divorced on 2 August 2011.
- Fact: The relationship lasted about eight years.
- Fact: They have one child, B, born in 2005.
- Fact: Since separation, the child has been cared for equally by both parties in a week-about arrangement.
- Fact: The wife commenced property proceedings on 21 January 2015 and obtained leave under s 44(3) to proceed out of time.
- Fact: At the commencement of the relationship the wife had nominal assets; the husband had two properties, a motor vehicle, shares, superannuation, and personal effects.
- Fact: During the marriage the husband's two properties were sold and properties at Suburb C and Town D were acquired.
- Fact: At the hearing the Suburb C property was valued at $619,333 and the Town D property at $72,500, with a mortgage of $111,115.
- Fact: Other assets were agreed at $39,099 and total superannuation entitlements were $289,816 (wife $5,606; husband $186,958 and $97,252).
- Fact: In January 2014, about four years after separation, the husband received an inheritance from his father's estate.

- Issue: Whether an inheritance received by the husband about four years after separation was property available for division under s 79(1) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
- Issue: Whether the trial magistrate erred in approach/reasons by including the inheritance in the calculation of net assets/resources as the basis for assessing s 79(4) factors
- Issue: Whether requiring the husband to implement the property orders within 28 days involved error, including alleged procedural unfairness
- Issue: Appeal costs

- Asset Pool: Real property: Suburb C property valued at $619,333; Town D property valued at $72,500.
- Asset Pool: Mortgage liability: $111,115 over the properties (as at hearing).
- Asset Pool: Other assets agreed at $39,099.
- Asset Pool: Superannuation: total $289,816 (wife $5,606; husband $186,958 and $97,252).
- Asset Pool: After-acquired inheritance: remaining portion represented by assets in husband's control totalling $430,686.
- Asset Pool: Net assets/resources found by trial magistrate: $1,340,319 (inheritance about 32% of this net figure).
- Contributions: Initial contributions: husband brought significantly more property into the relationship than the wife; trial magistrate found husband's initial financial contributions 'far outweighed' the wife's.
- Contributions: During marriage: trial magistrate accepted the husband's submissions that contributions during the marriage under s 79(4)(a), (b) and (c) were equal.
- Contributions: Post-separation parenting/financial: despite equal care of the child, the husband met a greater proportion of the child's financial needs because he was in a position to do so.
- Contributions: Inheritance: treated as the overwhelming financial contribution post-separation into the current net assets/resources.
- Contributions: Overall contributions assessment at trial: 75% husband, 25% wife.
- Future Needs: Adjustment of 10% in the wife's favour under s 75(2), particularly reflecting disparity in income and earning capacity between the wife and the husband.
- Just & Equitable: Trial magistrate found it was just and equitable to make a property settlement order given the long separation and circumstances falling within the type identified in Stanford v Stanford.
- Just & Equitable: Full Court held the inheritance formed part of existing property at the hearing and could be included in the pool; whether to include or treat separately is discretionary subject to s 79(2) just and equitable requirement.

- Child Ages: B born in 2005 (about 11-12 years old at the 2016 hearing; about 12 at the 2017 appeal).
- Current Arrangements: Equal shared care in a week-about arrangement since separation.

- Outcome: Appeal against the orders made by Magistrate Calverley on 17 November 2016 dismissed.
- Outcome: Appellant (husband) to pay the respondent’s (wife’s) costs of the appeal as agreed or in default of agreement as assessed.

- Reasons: The Court held that the legislation and authorities permit orders affecting all property held at the time of hearing, regardless of when acquired, including after-acquired inheritances.
- Reasons: Stanford concerns the need to separately consider whether it is just and equitable to make a property settlement order at all; it does not require a separate principled reason to interfere with each individual asset or exclude after-acquired property absent a special nexus.
- Reasons: The husband's arguments were treated as an invitation to re-argue discretionary matters contrary to established Full Court authority; no appealable error was demonstrated.
- Reasons: The 28-day timeframe was short but not unreasonable given the husband’s expectation of refinancing to remove the wife from the mortgages, and the equity available to facilitate borrowing; procedural fairness complaint failed.
- Reasons: Costs followed the event because the appeal was wholly unsuccessful.

- Pivotal Finding: The husband's inheritance received about four years after separation remained property in his control at hearing and was part of the existing property capable of alteration under s 79.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial magistrate had discretion to include the inheritance in the asset pool rather than quarantining it; no appealable discretionary error was shown.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial magistrate’s reasons were sufficient to satisfy the Stanford requirement to consider whether it was just and equitable to make a property settlement order at all.
- Pivotal Finding: While the trial magistrate erred in stating that without including the inheritance he could not appropriately assess s 79(4) matters, that error was not material because the inheritance was properly included and the ground was only adjunct to the main challenge.
- Pivotal Finding: No procedural unfairness was established in relation to the 28-day compliance period because the parties were given an opportunity to comment on the form of orders before delivery (consistent with usual practice), and 28 days was not unreasonably short given expected refinancing and available equity.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4 (definitions including 'property' and 'matrimonial cause')
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 31 (jurisdiction)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(1) (power to alter property interests)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(2) (just and equitable threshold)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) (contributions and relevant considerations)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors applied via s 79)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 44(3) (leave to institute property proceedings out of time)

- Uncertainties: The reasons do not set out a complete itemised schedule of all assets and liabilities beyond the values and figures stated, nor the detailed composition of the inheritance assets.
- Uncertainties: No detailed findings are provided in the excerpt as to the parties’ incomes, specific budgets, or precise earning capacities beyond noting a disparity for s 75(2) purposes.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from property settlement orders under s 79 Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether trial judge erred in assessment of contributions (s 79(4))
Effect of significant delay between trial and judgment on quality of reasons and consideration of evidence
Whether trial judge wrongly treated a purchased property as part of gifts by husband's father and overlooked wife's inheritance as a contribution
facts: The parties married in March 1983 in their late teens and separated in August 2010 after a 27 year marriage.
They had three children, all adults by the end of the marriage.
The parties lived on and operated a farming business (cropping) for most of the marriage, involving rural properties and water licences.
Trial of property issues concluded about three years before the primary judge delivered reasons (29 September 2015), with final property orders made 4 November 2015.

asset_pool: Total pool (including superannuation) assumed for re-exercise: $1,963,686.
Non-superannuation assets total: $3,153,556.62; liabilities total: $1,236,340; total superannuation: $46,470.

Major assets: rural properties (Property G half share; Property W half share; Property N), plant and equipment, valuable water licences (Property G and Property W), stored produce and produce sale/contract proceeds.
Wife retained/owned: M Street property in Town B ($230,000) with ANZ mortgage ($182,458), vehicle, modest bank account, some shares, addback $20,000, and superannuation (F Fund and Westpac).

Husband retained/owned: Property G half share ($281,420), Property N ($250,000), Property G water licences (values totalling about $700,000), livestock, boat, some shares, legal fees addback ($27,000), Westpac account ($25,000), stored produce, produce sale/contract proceeds.
contributions: Husband’s father gifted to the husband/parties: half share of Property N (around 1985) and half share of Property G with associated water licences (about 1986); treated as indirect financial contributions on behalf of the husband.
The parties purchased the other half share of Property N from the husband’s paternal aunt in 1985.

Property W was not a gift from the husband’s father; it was purchased in 1998 with the paternal grandfather, with the parties buying a half share; the trial judge confused acquisition and treated it as part of gifts in contributions reasoning.
Wife contributed an inheritance of $34,500 (2006) into joint account; trial judge omitted this in contributions assessment.

Both parties made substantial ongoing contributions during the marriage: husband primarily farm work, improvements and machinery; wife as homemaker/parent and as bookkeeper for many years, and by off-farm paid work especially during 1990s hardship/drought.
future_needs: Full Court adopted primary judge’s findings: wife had a bad back and depression affecting employment capacity; husband able to work farm profitably with established business, experience, and ongoing family support.
Husband’s financial future stronger than wife’s; wife felt moral obligation to support youngest child with diabetes.
Wife’s earning capacity adversely affected by 27 year marriage and loss of ongoing benefit from the farm/business to which she contributed (s 75(2)(j) and (k) considerations via s 79(4)(e)).
Full Court applied a further adjustment of $150,000 (7.5%) for s 79(4)(e)/s 75(2) factors.
just_equitable: Full Court found it was just and equitable to alter property interests (s 79(2)) because the parties’ long-standing use and mutual assumptions underlying property arrangements ended with separation, consistent with Stanford v Stanford principles.

After re-exercising discretion, Full Court’s combined assessment resulted in an equal division overall (50/50) notwithstanding contributions assessed 57.5/42.5, due to 7.5% future-needs adjustment to wife.
living_arrangements: Wife resided in a town property in New South Wales (M Street, Town B).
Husband to retain the farming land, water licences, and business associated with the farm.
existing_agreements: No formal or informal agreements governing property interests were identified; property interests governed by the parties’ mutuality and unstated assumptions during marriage.

child_ages: Three children, all adults by end of marriage
caregiver_history: Primary judge found wife performed more parenting and husband more work outside the home.
Wife relocated to support youngest child with diabetes when the child transitioned to boarding school in 2005.

outcome_orders: Appeal allowed.
Property settlement orders made by Judge Demack on 4 November 2015 set aside.
Parties to provide agreed minutes of order within 21 days to give effect to Full Court reasons and to account for any steps already taken to implement the primary orders.

Husband to pay the sum required by the Full Court’s reasons to the wife within 60 days of the appeal orders (Full Court indicated payment rounded to $890,500, subject to adjustment if prior orders partly implemented).
No order as to the costs of the appeal.

description: The decision demonstrates appellate correction of a s 79 contributions assessment where inordinate delay led to demonstrable misapprehension/omission of key evidence, and clarifies that merely asserting an outcome is 'outside the range' does not of itself establish House v The King error. It also affirms that genuinely comparable cases can inform (but not fetter) the s 79 discretion, aligning with the High Court’s guidance in Barbaro about the limited utility of 'ranges' and the proper use of comparable decisions as raw material for consistency.
pivotal_findings: The primary judge’s inordinate delay (about three years) contributed to errors in the contributions reasoning, warranting closer scrutiny of whether relevant evidence was properly considered.
The primary judge confused acquisition of Property W (purchased in 1998) with gifts from the husband’s father, inflating the weight of the husband’s father’s gifts in the contributions assessment.
The primary judge failed to include the wife’s 2006 inheritance ($34,500) as a contribution in the contributions assessment.
The Full Court rejected the proposition that an 'outside the range' assertion alone can establish discretionary error without identifying how the discretion miscarried.
On re-exercise, contributions were assessed at 57.5% husband / 42.5% wife, and s 75(2) factors justified an additional 7.5% adjustment to the wife, producing an equal overall division.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(2) (just and equitable requirement)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4) (contributions and other factors, including s 79(4)(e) incorporating s 75(2))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors relevant via s 79(4)(e))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 (costs)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6 and 9 (costs certificates)

reasons_rationale: Delay is not itself appealable error, but requires special care and closer scrutiny; here it manifested in concrete errors/omissions in the contributions assessment.

The contributions assessment miscarried because of mischaracterisation of a purchased asset as a gift and omission of the wife’s inheritance, in a case where gifts were treated as the central driver of the adjustment.
A mere claim that the result is 'outside the range' is inadequate without identifying error in principle, facts, or reasoning.
Comparable cases may guide consistency but cannot fix a tariff or bind the discretion; the Full Court used comparable farming/long-marriage cases to inform its own re-exercise.

Given both parties sought re-exercise and agreed to proceed on assumed values/facts as at appeal, the Full Court re-exercised rather than remit, and made orders intended to bring finality (agreed minutes).
uncertainties: The judgment noted discomfort in proceeding on assumed 2012-2013 values/facts due to elapsed time; re-exercise proceeded by parties’ agreement rather than updated evidence.
The court did not determine how the husband would practically raise the cash payment; parties were directed to provide agreed minutes to implement the outcome.
It was unclear whether the primary orders had already been implemented; the final payable amount could vary depending on steps already taken.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal against parenting order permitting and expanding the father's time with the child who lives with the maternal grandmother
Whether the primary judge misapprehended the Family Consultant's recommendations/evidence
Whether procedural fairness was denied regarding an order conditioning overnight time on counselling/therapy
Whether the primary judge misapplied the 'unacceptable risk' test in a family violence context
Whether the primary judge gave adequate reasons for permitting unsupervised time given the father's history of serious violence
facts: The child C was aged 10 at the time of the appeal.
The mother and father separated in 2007.
In 2014 an order was made for the child to live with the maternal grandmother due to significant uncertainty about the parents' ability to provide a safe and protective environment.
Dawe J made orders on 13 May 2015 for the father to spend time with the child each alternate Saturday.
The matter proceeded to a six-day trial in March 2016 before Berman J (primary judge).

child_ages: Child C aged 10 at the time of the appeal
current_arrangements: Child lived with the maternal grandmother (since 2014 orders).
As at the appeal, the father had not spent time with the child since April 2016.
caregiver_history: After separation (2007) the child lived with the mother.
In 2014, the child was ordered to live with the maternal grandmother due to uncertainty about the parents' capacity to provide a safe/protective environment.
safety_concerns: Father had an extensive and proven history of violence, including family violence, established by criminal convictions.
The grandmother alleged unacceptable risk of the child being subjected to family violence and/or exposed to the father perpetrating family violence and/or exposed to violent attitudes/propensity.

Primary judge made findings indicating the father was dismissive of his propensity to violence, displayed anger and aggression in evidence, and was not a truthful witness about aspects of his criminal history and engagement with the mother.
Primary judge accepted the grandmother and mother were entitled to be fearful and feel threatened by the father.
The child had autism and considerable special needs; negative inter-party attitudes were considered likely to impact the child.
allegations: Allegations and evidence of coercive, controlling family violence by the father, including evidence from the father's adult daughter and evidence attributed to the mother and the mother's teenage daughter (via the Family Consultant's report).
expert_evidence: Family Consultant provided reports (January 2015 and February 2016).
Family Consultant gave oral evidence that her recommendations were unclear and she prepared a clearer recommendation document (Exhibit 3).

Exhibit 3 contained a third recommendation that if coercive controlling family violence was found and there was current risk, the father's time should be no more than one hour a month professionally supervised and consideration be given to stopping time.
best_interests: The Full Court held that where unacceptable risk is alleged, the court must give real and substantial consideration to the facts and evaluate the nature, magnitude and potential effect of the risks before balancing against relationship benefits.

The Full Court found it difficult to discern from the primary reasons how risk evaluation and the balancing exercise were performed, including why daylight unsupervised time was acceptable while overnight time was treated as requiring counselling/therapy.
orders: Appeal allowed and primary order permitting father's time (Order 4) set aside; issue of father's time with the child remitted for rehearing before a different judge.

incidents: Father had an extensive and proven history of violence against others, including family violence within the Family Law Act definition.
Primary judge accepted evidence of a consistent pattern of violence towards the mother over years (as recorded by the Full Court when describing primary findings).
An incident occurred in April 2016 after trial which prompted an unsuccessful re-opening application; father then had no time with the child from April 2016.
police_court: Father's history of violence was proven via criminal convictions.
child_exposure: The grandmother's case included risk of the child being exposed to the father perpetrating family violence and/or exposed to violent attitudes and propensity.

outcome_orders: The appeal be allowed.
Paragraph 4 of the orders made by Berman J on 5 August 2016 be set aside.
The issue relating to the first respondent father's time with the child be remitted to the Family Court of Australia for rehearing by a judge other than Berman J.
Costs certificates granted to the appellant and the Independent Children's Lawyer under ss 6 and 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for appeal costs.
Costs certificates granted to the appellant and the Independent Children's Lawyer under s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the rehearing.
The father's Application in an Appeal filed 7 February 2017 be dismissed (application to adduce further evidence).

description: This appellate decision turned on whether the primary judge properly evaluated family-violence-related risk in parenting orders and whether the process and reasons met required legal standards. The Full Court identified that the trial judge's approach was compromised by overlooking a materially different expert recommendation (Exhibit 3), making a significant conditional-therapy order without hearing submissions (procedural fairness), and failing to give a discernible, balanced analysis of the nature and degree of risk (and whether and how it could be ameliorated) as required by the unacceptable risk jurisprudence. The remedy was to set aside the key time-with-father order and remit the father's time issue for rehearing before a different judge, leaving interim arrangements to be pursued by separate application if sought.
pivotal_findings: The primary judge misapprehended the Family Consultant's evidence by overlooking Exhibit 3, which included a third recommendation contemplating professionally supervised time (or consideration of stopping time) if coercive controlling family violence and current risk were found.

The Family Consultant's revised/clarified recommendation was fundamental, and the primary judge's stated understanding that the consultant supported continuation of time (without appreciating the third option) demonstrated error.

Procedural fairness was denied because the parties were not given notice or opportunity to make submissions about the therapy/counselling condition (Order 10), including the identity of the provider and what constituted a 'successful course', and neither party sought such an order.

The primary judge's reasons did not show 'real and substantial consideration' of the alleged risks; the appellate court could not discern evaluation of the nature, magnitude and potential effect of risks flowing from the father's violent history in permitting unsupervised time.

The reasons did not clearly explain the balancing of benefit of a meaningful relationship against risk, nor how risk would be ameliorated, particularly given findings about the father's lack of insight, courtroom aggression, and adverse credibility.

The reasons did not reconcile findings that the grandmother was genuinely fearful and that her capacity as primary carer (including managing the child's autism/special needs) might be compromised by time with the father, with the ordered time regime.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2)(a) (benefit of meaningful relationship)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60CC(2)(b) (need to protect the child from physical or psychological harm, including exposure to abuse, neglect or family violence)
Unacceptable risk principles from M v M (1988) 166 CLR 69 (as applied to family violence via A v A and Amador v Amador)
Procedural fairness principles (including U v U (2002) 211 CLR 238; SZGUR (2011) 241 CLR 594)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9 (costs certificates)

reasons_rationale: Appeal allowed because the primary judge's decision was reached on a misapprehension of expert evidence: he treated the Family Consultant as only providing two recommendations and overlooked Exhibit 3's materially different third recommendation.
The Family Consultant evidence was treated by the primary judge as important, making the oversight material to outcome.

Order 10 (therapy/counselling precondition for overnight time) was made without parties being heard on that issue, amounting to denial of procedural fairness; the order was also considered vague as to what would constitute a successful course.

The primary judge misapplied the unacceptable risk test and gave inadequate reasons, failing to identify and evaluate the relevant risks (nature, magnitude, potential effect) arising from the father's proven violent history and other evidence, and failing to explain the balancing exercise.
The father's application to adduce further evidence was dismissed because it had no utility; it could not overcome the identified deficiencies in reasons and approach.
Remitter was confined to the issue of the father's time with the child; other orders were not under appeal.
uncertainties: The precise content of all other (non-appealed) parenting orders made at first instance is not set out in the provided text.
Details of the April 2016 incident prompting the re-opening application are not described.
No final determination on the substantive parenting dispute (appropriate time regime) was made by the Full Court; it was remitted for rehearing.

summary_text:
- Fact: The child C was aged 10 at the time of the appeal.
- Fact: The mother and father separated in 2007.
- Fact: In 2014 an order was made for the child to live with the maternal grandmother due to significant uncertainty about the parents' ability to provide a safe and protective environment.
- Fact: Dawe J made orders on 13 May 2015 for the father to spend time with the child each alternate Saturday.
- Fact: The matter proceeded to a six-day trial in March 2016 before Berman J (primary judge).

- Issue: Appeal against parenting order permitting and expanding the father's time with the child who lives with the maternal grandmother
- Issue: Whether the primary judge misapprehended the Family Consultant's recommendations/evidence
- Issue: Whether procedural fairness was denied regarding an order conditioning overnight time on counselling/therapy
- Issue: Whether the primary judge misapplied the 'unacceptable risk' test in a family violence context
- Issue: Whether the primary judge gave adequate reasons for permitting unsupervised time given the father's history of serious violence

- Child Ages: Child C aged 10 at the time of the appeal
- Current Arrangements: Child lived with the maternal grandmother (since 2014 orders).
- Current Arrangements: As at the appeal, the father had not spent time with the child since April 2016.
- Safety Concerns: Father had an extensive and proven history of violence, including family violence, established by criminal convictions.
- Safety Concerns: The grandmother alleged unacceptable risk of the child being subjected to family violence and/or exposed to the father perpetrating family violence and/or exposed to violent attitudes/propensity.
- Safety Concerns: Primary judge made findings indicating the father was dismissive of his propensity to violence, displayed anger and aggression in evidence, and was not a truthful witness about aspects of his criminal history and engagement with the mother.
- Safety Concerns: Primary judge accepted the grandmother and mother were entitled to be fearful and feel threatened by the father.
- Safety Concerns: The child had autism and considerable special needs; negative inter-party attitudes were considered likely to impact the child.
- Best Interests: The Full Court held that where unacceptable risk is alleged, the court must give real and substantial consideration to the facts and evaluate the nature, magnitude and potential effect of the risks before balancing against relationship benefits.
- Best Interests: The Full Court found it difficult to discern from the primary reasons how risk evaluation and the balancing exercise were performed, including why daylight unsupervised time was acceptable while overnight time was treated as requiring counselling/therapy.

- Incidents: Father had an extensive and proven history of violence against others, including family violence within the Family Law Act definition.
- Incidents: Primary judge accepted evidence of a consistent pattern of violence towards the mother over years (as recorded by the Full Court when describing primary findings).
- Incidents: An incident occurred in April 2016 after trial which prompted an unsuccessful re-opening application; father then had no time with the child from April 2016.

- Outcome: Costs certificates granted to the appellant and the Independent Children's Lawyer under s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for costs of the rehearing.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from property settlement orders under s 79 Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether an inherited property acquired post-separation was wrongly 'excluded' from the asset pool and mischaracterised as a 'financial resource'
Whether the trial judge erred in approach to assessing contributions (including post-separation contributions) and in giving reasons
Whether the trial judge conflated contributions (s 79(4)(a)-(c)) with future needs factors (s 79(4)(e) applying s 75(2))
facts: The parties cohabited for approximately 17 years and separated in July 2007; divorce was in January 2012.
There were two children aged 17 and 14 at trial.
The former matrimonial home at Property L (Victoria) was purchased in August 2000 for $160,000 with a mortgage; paternal grandparents advanced $31,000 which was repaid within three years.
Mortgage at separation was about $132,332; by 1 November 2015 it was about $138,383.

asset_pool: Former matrimonial home at Property L (mortgaged; mortgage about $138,383 as at 1 November 2015).
Husband's inherited real property at Property W, Victoria (unencumbered at trial; agreed value $715,000).
Net asset pool referred to in the trial reasons (excluding Property W) of $373,713 (as recited in appeal reasons).
Superannuation interests referred to in trial reasons (wife entitlement noted as $9,353; husband entitlement noted as $44,360) (figures quoted in appeal reasons).
Jointly owned motor vehicle (used as part of payment for renovations, per trial finding).
contributions: During cohabitation, trial judge found contributions equal overall to separation (finding recorded in appeal reasons).
Wife was primary carer for the children during the relationship.
Wife performed administration/book work for the parties' business partnership; the parties disputed the extent of her contribution to the business.

Post-separation, wife undertook renovations to the former matrimonial home to enable rental; trial judge accepted contributions to conservation and improvement of the asset and assumed value increase over time.
Post-separation, husband paid mortgage until about April 2009; wife thereafter was responsible for mortgage payments, funded in part by rental income and line of credit arrangements.
future_needs: Trial judge considered husband had benefit of inherited unencumbered Property W and lived in it, and it was at least twice the value of the equity in the former matrimonial home.

Wife was in casual employment and obtaining certificates to enable full-time employment; trial judge accepted she required time to obtain suitable employment and that her earning capacity was diminished by homemaker role.
Husband had ongoing capacity to generate income and derive benefits from his business and income was likely to increase.
Children were teenagers at trial and in shared care arrangements, with wife seeking to secure housing for herself and the children.

Trial judge made a 12% adjustment in favour of the wife under s 75(2) considerations (as described in appeal reasons), but Full Court found the reasoning and weighting (especially as to Property W) could not be adequately discerned and was insufficient.
just_equitable: Trial judge made s 79 orders transferring the former matrimonial home to the wife on payment of $90,000 to the husband, with each otherwise retaining property in their possession (described in Full Court reasons).
Full Court held it is wrong in principle to 'exclude' any existing legal/equitable interest in property from s 79 consideration and that Property W was property (not a financial resource).

Full Court held the trial judge's errors (exclusion/mischaracterisation, conflation of contributions and s 75(2), and inability to discern reasoning path) constituted error of principle requiring appellate intervention.
living_arrangements: Post-separation: wife lived in other accommodation from about 2009 and later in rental accommodation (from March 2015); husband lived with his brother and later in the inherited property.
At trial: children lived in shared care arrangements with time divided between parents as described in the factual summary.
existing_agreements: Private child support arrangements existed initially, later replaced by Child Support Agency assessment from October 2011.

child_ages: 17 years (at trial)
14 years (at trial)
current_arrangements: Shared care arrangements at time of trial: one child spent approximately three weeks per month with the wife and one week with the husband (with one stated exception); the other child spent about two weeks with each parent each month (as set out in the factual summary).
caregiver_history: Wife was primary carer for the children during the relationship.

outcome_orders: Appeal allowed.
Orders made by Judge Jones on 24 June 2016 set aside.
Proceedings remitted for rehearing before a judge of the Federal Circuit Court of Australia other than Judge Jones.
No order as to costs of the appeal (each party to bear their own costs).
Costs certificate granted to the appellant pursuant to s 9 Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) for appeal costs.

description: The Full Court clarified that all existing legal and equitable interests of either party are 'property' for s 79 and cannot be 'excluded' from consideration; an inheritance received post-separation remains property to be identified and considered, though it may be treated separately for contribution assessment. Mischaracterising vested property as a 'financial resource' and excluding it from the asset pool infected the contribution and s 75(2) analyses. The decision also emphasised the need to distinctly assess contributions (including post-separation contributions) and then separately assess s 75(2) factors, with reasons exposing the reasoning path and real (dollar) impact, especially where a major asset dwarfs the rest of the pool.
pivotal_findings: The inherited Property W was a vested legal interest of the husband and therefore 'property' within s 79, not a 'financial resource'.
It was an error of principle to refer to existing property interests as being 'excluded' or immune from s 79 consideration.
The trial judge excluded Property W from the asset pool and did not conduct the foreshadowed asset-by-asset contributions assessment including that property.
The trial judge conflated matters relevant to contributions with matters relevant to s 75(2) future needs in discussing post-separation contributions and capacity to earn.

The trial judge did not adequately quantify or explain the effect of the post-separation contribution finding ('slightly greater') and the s 75(2) adjustment such that the reasoning path to the outcome could be discerned.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(1) (identification of property interests) and s 79(2) (just and equitable threshold)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4)(a)-(c) (contributions) and s 79(4)(e) incorporating s 75(2) (future needs factors including financial resources)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4 (definition of 'property')
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(1) (costs presumption)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 6, 8, 9 (costs certificates)

reasons_rationale: Property W was wrongly treated as a financial resource and excluded from the property pool; as a vested interest it was property under the Act.
Excluding existing property interests from s 79 consideration is an error of principle.

The trial judge stated an asset-by-asset approach but did not then assess contributions separately to the inheritance and the remaining pool, and effectively excluded the inheritance from contributions assessment.
The reasons disclosed conflation between contributions and s 75(2) matters and did not allow the appellate court to discern the reasoning path to the final percentages and dollar outcomes.

Because the inherited property was of very large value relative to the rest of the pool, the weighting and dollar impact of s 75(2) considerations required clear articulation, which was not possible on the reasons provided.
uncertainties: No final property division outcome after rehearing is stated in this decision; the matter was remitted.
Detailed composition and valuation of the full asset/liability pool (including any superannuation splitting mechanics) beyond the figures quoted is not fully set out in the provided text.
No parenting orders are determined in this appeal decision; only factual context about care arrangements is included.
