court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from property settlement orders: whether the primary judge erred in assessing contributions (wife 20%, husband 80%)
Whether the primary judge failed to give adequate reasons for the contributions assessment
Appellate restraint in discretionary assessments (whether outcome was plainly wrong / unjust)
facts: The parties commenced cohabitation in May 2005, married in 2014, and separated late in 2014 (separation also referred to as June 2014 in the reasons).
There are two children: X born 2005 and Y born 2008.
At the trial, the children lived with the husband and spent weekends and holidays with the wife; the trial judge made parenting orders broadly consistent with that.
The husband appealed only the property orders; parenting orders were not appealed.
At commencement of the relationship, the wife’s net assets were about $500,000.
The husband asserted his initial contribution was about $4,974,512; the primary judge accepted that valuation (despite dispute by the wife).
During the relationship, the wife worked in paid positions and earned income from share trading.
The husband earned income from personal exertion and business investments.
The primary judge found that the parties conducted their financial affairs independently, but each invested in properties owned by the other to the advantage of the family enterprise.
The primary judge found total net assets of $12,524,921 excluding superannuation; husband superannuation $342,351 and wife $83,618.
Neither party sought a superannuation splitting order; the superannuation disparity was considered as a s 75(2) factor.
At trial the husband was 47 and the wife 44.
Post-separation, the parties continued to invest and obtain profits; the primary judge assessed contributions after initial contributions as equal up to trial.

asset_pool: Net non-superannuation property pool found: $12,524,921 (excluding superannuation).
Superannuation interests excluded from pool (no splitting sought): husband $342,351; wife $83,618.
On separation the wife held superannuation, cash of about $184,454 and shares valued at $108,500 (as noted in appeal reasons).
contributions: Initial contributions: wife about $500,000 net; husband about $4,974,512 (accepted by the primary judge).
During cohabitation the primary judge found each contributed money and efforts to the family enterprise.
The parties generally managed finances independently but invested both formally and informally in properties owned by the other.
Post-separation, except for initial contributions, contributions were assessed as equal up to trial.
Primary judge ultimately quantified contributions at 80% husband and 20% wife, reflecting disparity in initial contributions while recognising other contributions.
future_needs: Section 75(2) adjustment of 10% in the wife’s favour (not challenged on appeal).
Factors included: husband would have assets capable of earning vastly more income than the wife.
Husband had greater superannuation entitlements than the wife (treated as a s 75(2) factor given no splitting order).
Husband would have greater care of the children and provide greater financial support, though the wife would provide financial support as well.
just_equitable: Primary judge determined wife entitled to 30% of net assets (after contributions and s 75(2) adjustment), quantified at $3,757,476.
Payment order made to achieve the entitlement: husband to pay wife $2,565,113 (with interest, payment deferred one year at husband’s request).
On appeal, Full Court held the 20% contributions assessment and resulting outcome were open on the evidence and not plainly unjust.
living_arrangements: Children lived with the husband at time of trial; wife spent weekends/holidays and additional school term time per orders.
Care arrangements were relevant to s 75(2) assessment (husband to have greater proportion of care and financial support).

child_ages: X born 2005
Y born 2008
current_arrangements: At trial, children lived with the husband and spent weekends and holidays with the wife.
caregiver_history: After separation in June 2014 the children were initially in shared care.
After that period, the children lived primarily with the wife and from June 2017 primarily with the husband.
best_interests: Parenting orders were made by the primary judge and were not challenged on appeal.
orders: Sole parental responsibility to the husband, with an obligation to advise the wife of major long-term decisions prior to implementation.
Children to live with the husband.
Children to spend time with the wife on weekends and weekdays during school term, during school holidays, and on special occasions.

outcome_orders: Appeal against the orders of a Judge of the Family Court made on 4 December 2018 dismissed.
No order as to costs.

description: This was a discretionary property appeal focused on whether the contributions assessment (20/80) and the adequacy of reasons disclosed appellable error. The Full Court applied appellate restraint principles, finding the primary judge’s evaluative ‘leap’ from qualitative findings to a percentage outcome was supported by the evidence and reasons, and that the result was not plainly unjust. Parenting orders were background only and not in issue.
pivotal_findings: The primary judge accepted the husband’s asserted initial contribution of about $4,974,512 and the wife’s initial net assets of about $500,000, establishing a very large disparity at commencement.
Except for initial contributions, contributions up to trial were assessed as equal, including post-separation investment activity and mutual (formal/informal) investment in each other’s property.

The 20% attribution to the wife for contributions was within the permissible range and open on the evidence; the appeal was characterised as disagreement with the figure rather than demonstration of error.

Reasons were adequate: the primary judge identified the significant disparity, the parties’ financial conduct, and post-separation asset growth dynamics; the reasoning process was discernible and not arbitrary.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 (contributions-based property adjustment and discretionary evaluation) (implicitly central though not expressly cited in the excerpt).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs adjustment; superannuation disparity and income-earning capacity; care of children).
Appellate standards for discretionary error (House v The King; CDJ v VAJ) and adequacy of reasons (Soulemezis; Steinbrenner; Babett & Falconer).

reasons_rationale: The contributions complaint sought impermissible substitution of the appellate court’s view for the trial judge’s discretionary assessment; no wrong principle or plainly unjust result was shown.
The contributions conclusion was open on the evidence given the disparity in initial contributions and the finding of broadly equal contributions thereafter.

Adequate reasons were provided: the primary judge addressed the parties’ financial and parenting circumstances, independent financial management with cross-investment, and post-separation asset increases; the ‘leap’ to a percentage did not render reasoning defective.
No challenge was made to the 10% s 75(2) adjustment, which remained undisturbed.
uncertainties: The appeal reasons summarise (rather than reproduce) the detailed asset schedule; individual assets and liabilities comprising the $12,524,921 pool are not specified in the provided text.
The excerpt references separation as both late 2014 and June 2014; the precise separation date is unclear from the appeal reasons alone.
The detailed content of the primary judge’s parenting orders (beyond the summary provided) is not set out in full.

- Pivotal Finding: The 20% attribution to the wife for contributions was within the permissible range and open on the evidence; the appeal was characterised as disagreement with the figure rather than demonstration of error.
- Pivotal Finding: Reasons were adequate: the primary judge identified the significant disparity, the parties’ financial conduct, and post-separation asset growth dynamics; the reasoning process was discernible and not arbitrary.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 (contributions-based property adjustment and discretionary evaluation) (implicitly central though not expressly cited in the excerpt).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs adjustment; superannuation disparity and income-earning capacity; care of children).
- Statutory Pivot: Appellate standards for discretionary error (House v The King; CDJ v VAJ) and adequacy of reasons (Soulemezis; Steinbrenner; Babett & Falconer).

- Uncertainties: The appeal reasons summarise (rather than reproduce) the detailed asset schedule; individual assets and liabilities comprising the $12,524,921 pool are not specified in the provided text.
- Uncertainties: The excerpt references separation as both late 2014 and June 2014; the precise separation date is unclear from the appeal reasons alone.
- Uncertainties: The detailed content of the primary judge’s parenting orders (beyond the summary provided) is not set out in full.

court: Family Court of Australia (Full Court/Appellate jurisdiction exercised by a single judge)
issues: Whether the Federal Circuit Court erred by hearing and making parenting-related procedural orders without a valid s 60I family dispute resolution certificate and without finding any s 60I(9) exception applied
Operation and effect of s 60I(7), s 60I(9) exceptions, and s 60I(11) (validity of proceedings/orders despite non-compliance)
Adequacy of reasons in relation to the s 60I issue

facts: The parties commenced cohabitation on 1 June 1999, married on 2 February 2001, and finally separated on 16 January 2008
They have two children: S (born 2002) and M (born 2003)
Consent parenting orders were made on 26 November 2008 providing equal shared parental responsibility and a progression to week-about care from February 2009

Over time the arrangements changed informally, including S moving to a two-weeks-about pattern between households

description: This is a procedural parenting appeal centring on the mandatory pre-filing requirement in s 60I: absent a valid family dispute resolution certificate or a proven exception, the court 'must not hear' a Part VII parenting application. The decision clarifies that non-compliance does not necessarily strip jurisdiction (given s 60I(11)), but it is legal error to proceed without determining the applicability of a s 60I(9) exception; resulting orders are liable to be set aside on appeal and the initiating application dismissed.
pivotal_findings: It was not in issue that no valid s 60I certificate accompanied the father’s initiating application
The certificate dated 7 April 2017 was not a valid certificate for the 19 October 2018 initiating application and did not satisfy the relevant exception relied on
The primary judge made orders (including s 11F family consultant conference and adjournment) without making findings that any s 60I(9) exception applied
The primary judge provided no reasons engaging with the s 60I issue squarely raised by the mother; this supported the appeal
Section 60I(11) meant the error was not characterised as a want of jurisdiction, but as legal error warranting appellate intervention
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 60I(1), s 60I(7), s 60I(9), s 60I(10), s 60I(11)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 11F (family consultant conference order made at first instance)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 94AAA(3) (appellate jurisdiction basis)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) s 9 (costs certificate)

reasons_rationale: Section 60I(7) imposes a mandatory bar: the court must not hear a parenting application unless a certificate is filed, subject to s 60I(9) exceptions
The primary judge focused on pragmatic solutions but did not determine whether any s 60I(9) exception applied; proceeding in the absence of a certificate and without such findings was legal error
Section 60I(11) preserves validity of proceedings/orders despite failure to comply, meaning the problem was not jurisdictional invalidity but appealable legal error
Given success due to error of law and self-representation, no costs order under s 117 was made; instead a costs certificate under s 9 was appropriate
uncertainties: The appeal did not determine the substantive parenting merits (best interests, final living arrangements, or how allegations of violence/abuse were to be resolved)
No findings were made about whether any s 60I(9) exception (e.g., urgency, family violence risk) could have applied on the evidence; the error was that no such findings were made before proceeding
The primary judge did not publish reasons; the appellate court relied on transcript as the only source of reasoning

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Whether a pre-marriage document titled “Pre-Nuptial Agreement” could be rectified under s 90KA to operate as a s 90B financial agreement
Whether, once rectified, the agreement was a binding financial agreement under s 90G(1)
Whether the agreement should be set aside (including arguments framed as ambiguity/uncertainty, and asserted unfairness/unjustness)
Whether leave to appeal was required (interlocutory vs final determination of a matrimonial cause)
Costs of the appeal (indemnity vs party/party; fixing costs in a lump sum under the Rules)
facts: The parties executed an agreement on 9 July 2008, the day before their marriage, titled “Pre-Nuptial Agreement”.
The parties married on 10 July 2008 and finally separated in November 2015.
The wife owned and operated a small business before marriage and was concerned to protect it as her sole source of income if the relationship ended.
The husband had pre-marital assets including joint proprietary interests in two Southeast Asian properties.
In early July 2008, the wife instructed her lawyers to prepare the agreement; its terms were not negotiated or amended once prepared.
Each party received independent legal advice from their respective solicitors; certificates of advice formed part of the executed document.

The agreement purported to deal with assets each party brought into the marriage and to exclude claims including “alimony, spousal support or maintenance” regarding those pre-marital assets; it did not purport to deal with post-marriage acquisitions.

asset_pool: Pre-marital assets were scheduled in the agreement (wife’s small business; husband’s assets including joint interests in two Southeast Asian properties).
Post-marital assets/property adjustment issues were expressly not resolved in this appeal and would require further hearing.
contributions: The husband asserted in the appeal context that after marriage he worked in the wife’s business and the parties bore and raised a son, as part of an argument about fairness; these matters were not determinative of whether the agreement was binding.
just_equitable: The husband argued rectification or enforcement would be unjust/inequitable or unfair in light of later events and his contributions; the Court held fairness/just and equitable outcomes under Part VIII are not a requirement for a financial agreement and are generally displaced by Part VIIIA agreements.
existing_agreements: A document titled “Pre-Nuptial Agreement” executed 9 July 2008, taking effect on solemnisation of marriage, purporting to quarantine pre-marital assets and exclude maintenance claims in respect of those assets, but not covering post-marital property.
Primary judge rectified the agreement to state it was made under s 90B and to correct clause 17 so it was governed by the Family Law Act rather than Victorian law.

relationship_length: Married from 10 July 2008 to final separation in November 2015.
standard_of_living: The agreement purported to exclude claims for “alimony, spousal support or maintenance” in respect of the parties’ respective pre-marital assets.

legal_advice: Each party received independent legal advice from their respective solicitors before signing; solicitors certified advice and the certificates formed part of the agreement.
No evidence was adduced about the content of the advice and neither solicitor was called as a witness.
changed_circumstances: The husband asserted subsequent circumstances rendered the agreement not “fair and reasonable” and relied on post-marriage contributions and having/raising a child; the Court held this did not provide a basis to avoid rectification or binding effect and did not establish a statutory ground to set aside.

outcome_orders: The appeal was dismissed.
The appellant (husband) was ordered to pay the respondent’s (wife’s) costs of and incidental to the appeal fixed in the sum of $31,539.50.

description: This Full Court appeal confirms that, via s 90KA, courts can rectify an erroneously drafted pre-marriage agreement to reflect the parties’ common intention that it operate as a Part VIIIA financial agreement (here, a s 90B agreement), and that once rectified the agreement can be declared binding if the formal requirements in s 90G(1) are met. The Court treated the determination of the agreement’s binding status as a final determination of a distinct matrimonial cause (validity/enforceability of a financial agreement), meaning leave to appeal was not required. It also re-emphasised that “fairness” or “just and equitable” standards under Part VIII do not apply to financial agreements absent a statutory set-aside ground under s 90K.
pivotal_findings: It was open to infer the parties had a common intention to enter a binding and enforceable agreement to quarantine the assets each introduced to the marriage (including protecting the wife’s business), notwithstanding the document’s poor drafting and absence of express reference to the Act.
The clause purporting to apply Victorian law and exclusive Victorian jurisdiction was “nonsense” in the matrimonial context and required correction to align with federal jurisdiction under the Act.

The husband did not demonstrate error in the primary judge’s rejection of arguments that the agreement was void/unenforceable for uncertainty or ambiguity; delineation of what property fell within/outside the agreement was left to the final trial.
Once rectified to include s 90B, the agreement satisfied the conjunctive requirements of s 90G(1); no issue was raised about the certification process, and the declaration of binding effect followed.

Post-marriage contributions and later events (including work in the wife’s business and raising a child) did not establish that the agreement should be denied binding effect; there is no general legal requirement that a financial agreement be fair or just and equitable.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90KA (court’s power applying law and equity principles to determine validity/enforceability, including rectification)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90B and s 90B(1)(b) (pre-marriage financial agreements and requirement the agreement specify it is made under the section)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1) (requirements for a financial agreement to be binding)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K (grounds to set aside a financial agreement)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 71A (effect of binding financial agreements on Part VIII property proceedings)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4(1) (definition of “matrimonial cause”) and s 94AA plus Family Law Regulations 1984 (Cth) reg 15A (leave to appeal for interlocutory orders)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 and s 117(2A) (costs factors)

reasons_rationale: Rectification requires clear and convincing proof that the written instrument does not embody the parties’ common intention; the primary judge’s inference of common intention to create a binding agreement to quarantine pre-marital assets was available on the evidence.

The lack of negotiation of terms and the absence of evidence from the lawyers about instructions/advice did not prevent the inference of common intention, and did not require a Jones v Dunkel adverse inference.
The agreement could not operate as a financial agreement without express reference to s 90B; insertion of the reference was necessary to give effect to the parties’ objective.

The Victorian law/exclusive jurisdiction clause was incompatible with the Act’s exclusive federal jurisdiction over matrimonial causes and required correction to render the agreement intelligible and aligned to the Act.

Set-aside arguments based on fairness/just and equitable principles under Part VIII were misplaced because parties may contract out of Part VIII via Part VIIIA, subject only to statutory set-aside grounds.
Once rectified, the unchallenged existence of signed advice certificates meant the s 90G(1) requirements were met and the agreement was binding.
Leave to appeal was not required because the orders finally determined the distinct matrimonial cause concerning the status of the financial agreement.
uncertainties: The content of the independent legal advice given to each party was not in evidence and neither solicitor was called.
The precise identification/characterisation of assets falling within and outside the agreement was left for the final property trial.

The case text contains differing judicial views on whether appeal costs should be fixed or assessed (Strickland J preferred assessment; Kent & Austin JJ fixed costs), but the formal orders recorded fixed costs at $31,539.50.

summary_text:
- Fact: The parties executed an agreement on 9 July 2008, the day before their marriage, titled “Pre-Nuptial Agreement”.
- Fact: The parties married on 10 July 2008 and finally separated in November 2015.
- Fact: The wife owned and operated a small business before marriage and was concerned to protect it as her sole source of income if the relationship ended.
- Fact: The husband had pre-marital assets including joint proprietary interests in two Southeast Asian properties.
- Fact: In early July 2008, the wife instructed her lawyers to prepare the agreement; its terms were not negotiated or amended once prepared.
- Fact: Each party received independent legal advice from their respective solicitors; certificates of advice formed part of the executed document.
- Fact: The agreement purported to deal with assets each party brought into the marriage and to exclude claims including “alimony, spousal support or maintenance” regarding those pre-marital assets; it did not purport to deal with post-marriage acquisitions.

- Issue: Whether a pre-marriage document titled “Pre-Nuptial Agreement” could be rectified under s 90KA to operate as a s 90B financial agreement
- Issue: Whether, once rectified, the agreement was a binding financial agreement under s 90G(1)
- Issue: Whether the agreement should be set aside (including arguments framed as ambiguity/uncertainty, and asserted unfairness/unjustness)
- Issue: Whether leave to appeal was required (interlocutory vs final determination of a matrimonial cause)
- Issue: Costs of the appeal (indemnity vs party/party; fixing costs in a lump sum under the Rules)

- Asset Pool: Pre-marital assets were scheduled in the agreement (wife’s small business; husband’s assets including joint interests in two Southeast Asian properties).
- Asset Pool: Post-marital assets/property adjustment issues were expressly not resolved in this appeal and would require further hearing.
- Contributions: The husband asserted in the appeal context that after marriage he worked in the wife’s business and the parties bore and raised a son, as part of an argument about fairness; these matters were not determinative of whether the agreement was binding.
- Just & Equitable: The husband argued rectification or enforcement would be unjust/inequitable or unfair in light of later events and his contributions; the Court held fairness/just and equitable outcomes under Part VIII are not a requirement for a financial agreement and are generally displaced by Part VIIIA agreements.

- Agreement Date: 9 July 2008
- Legal Advice: Each party received independent legal advice from their respective solicitors before signing; solicitors certified advice and the certificates formed part of the agreement.
- Legal Advice: No evidence was adduced about the content of the advice and neither solicitor was called as a witness.
- Changed Circumstances: The husband asserted subsequent circumstances rendered the agreement not “fair and reasonable” and relied on post-marriage contributions and having/raising a child; the Court held this did not provide a basis to avoid rectification or binding effect and did not establish a statutory ground to set aside.

- Outcome: The appeal was dismissed.
- Outcome: The appellant (husband) was ordered to pay the respondent’s (wife’s) costs of and incidental to the appeal fixed in the sum of $31,539.50.

- Reasons: Rectification requires clear and convincing proof that the written instrument does not embody the parties’ common intention; the primary judge’s inference of common intention to create a binding agreement to quarantine pre-marital assets was available on the evidence.
- Reasons: The lack of negotiation of terms and the absence of evidence from the lawyers about instructions/advice did not prevent the inference of common intention, and did not require a Jones v Dunkel adverse inference.
- Reasons: The agreement could not operate as a financial agreement without express reference to s 90B; insertion of the reference was necessary to give effect to the parties’ objective.
- Reasons: The Victorian law/exclusive jurisdiction clause was incompatible with the Act’s exclusive federal jurisdiction over matrimonial causes and required correction to render the agreement intelligible and aligned to the Act.
- Reasons: Set-aside arguments based on fairness/just and equitable principles under Part VIII were misplaced because parties may contract out of Part VIII via Part VIIIA, subject only to statutory set-aside grounds.
- Reasons: Once rectified, the unchallenged existence of signed advice certificates meant the s 90G(1) requirements were met and the agreement was binding.
- Reasons: Leave to appeal was not required because the orders finally determined the distinct matrimonial cause concerning the status of the financial agreement.

- Pivotal Finding: It was open to infer the parties had a common intention to enter a binding and enforceable agreement to quarantine the assets each introduced to the marriage (including protecting the wife’s business), notwithstanding the document’s poor drafting and absence of express reference to the Act.
- Pivotal Finding: The clause purporting to apply Victorian law and exclusive Victorian jurisdiction was “nonsense” in the matrimonial context and required correction to align with federal jurisdiction under the Act.
- Pivotal Finding: The husband did not demonstrate error in the primary judge’s rejection of arguments that the agreement was void/unenforceable for uncertainty or ambiguity; delineation of what property fell within/outside the agreement was left to the final trial.
- Pivotal Finding: Once rectified to include s 90B, the agreement satisfied the conjunctive requirements of s 90G(1); no issue was raised about the certification process, and the declaration of binding effect followed.
- Pivotal Finding: Post-marriage contributions and later events (including work in the wife’s business and raising a child) did not establish that the agreement should be denied binding effect; there is no general legal requirement that a financial agreement be fair or just and equitable.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90KA (court’s power applying law and equity principles to determine validity/enforceability, including rectification)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90B and s 90B(1)(b) (pre-marriage financial agreements and requirement the agreement specify it is made under the section)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1) (requirements for a financial agreement to be binding)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K (grounds to set aside a financial agreement)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 71A (effect of binding financial agreements on Part VIII property proceedings)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4(1) (definition of “matrimonial cause”) and s 94AA plus Family Law Regulations 1984 (Cth) reg 15A (leave to appeal for interlocutory orders)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 and s 117(2A) (costs factors)

- Uncertainties: The content of the independent legal advice given to each party was not in evidence and neither solicitor was called.
- Uncertainties: The precise identification/characterisation of assets falling within and outside the agreement was left for the final property trial.
- Uncertainties: The case text contains differing judicial views on whether appeal costs should be fixed or assessed (Strickland J preferred assessment; Kent & Austin JJ fixed costs), but the formal orders recorded fixed costs at $31,539.50.

summary_sections.text:
- Fact: The parties executed an agreement on 9 July 2008, the day before their marriage, titled “Pre-Nuptial Agreement”.
- Fact: The parties married on 10 July 2008 and finally separated in November 2015.
- Fact: The wife owned and operated a small business before marriage and was concerned to protect it as her sole source of income if the relationship ended.
- Fact: The husband had pre-marital assets including joint proprietary interests in two Southeast Asian properties.
- Fact: In early July 2008, the wife instructed her lawyers to prepare the agreement; its terms were not negotiated or amended once prepared.
- Fact: Each party received independent legal advice from their respective solicitors; certificates of advice formed part of the executed document.
- Fact: The agreement purported to deal with assets each party brought into the marriage and to exclude claims including “alimony, spousal support or maintenance” regarding those pre-marital assets; it did not purport to deal with post-marriage acquisitions.

- Issue: Whether a pre-marriage document titled “Pre-Nuptial Agreement” could be rectified under s 90KA to operate as a s 90B financial agreement
- Issue: Whether, once rectified, the agreement was a binding financial agreement under s 90G(1)
- Issue: Whether the agreement should be set aside (including arguments framed as ambiguity/uncertainty, and asserted unfairness/unjustness)
- Issue: Whether leave to appeal was required (interlocutory vs final determination of a matrimonial cause)
- Issue: Costs of the appeal (indemnity vs party/party; fixing costs in a lump sum under the Rules)

- Asset Pool: Pre-marital assets were scheduled in the agreement (wife’s small business; husband’s assets including joint interests in two Southeast Asian properties).
- Asset Pool: Post-marital assets/property adjustment issues were expressly not resolved in this appeal and would require further hearing.
- Contributions: The husband asserted in the appeal context that after marriage he worked in the wife’s business and the parties bore and raised a son, as part of an argument about fairness; these matters were not determinative of whether the agreement was binding.
- Just & Equitable: The husband argued rectification or enforcement would be unjust/inequitable or unfair in light of later events and his contributions; the Court held fairness/just and equitable outcomes under Part VIII are not a requirement for a financial agreement and are generally displaced by Part VIIIA agreements.

- Agreement Date: 9 July 2008
- Legal Advice: Each party received independent legal advice from their respective solicitors before signing; solicitors certified advice and the certificates formed part of the agreement.
- Legal Advice: No evidence was adduced about the content of the advice and neither solicitor was called as a witness.
- Changed Circumstances: The husband asserted subsequent circumstances rendered the agreement not “fair and reasonable” and relied on post-marriage contributions and having/raising a child; the Court held this did not provide a basis to avoid rectification or binding effect and did not establish a statutory ground to set aside.

- Outcome: The appeal was dismissed.
- Outcome: The appellant (husband) was ordered to pay the respondent’s (wife’s) costs of and incidental to the appeal fixed in the sum of $31,539.50.

- Reasons: Rectification requires clear and convincing proof that the written instrument does not embody the parties’ common intention; the primary judge’s inference of common intention to create a binding agreement to quarantine pre-marital assets was available on the evidence.
- Reasons: The lack of negotiation of terms and the absence of evidence from the lawyers about instructions/advice did not prevent the inference of common intention, and did not require a Jones v Dunkel adverse inference.
- Reasons: The agreement could not operate as a financial agreement without express reference to s 90B; insertion of the reference was necessary to give effect to the parties’ objective.
- Reasons: The Victorian law/exclusive jurisdiction clause was incompatible with the Act’s exclusive federal jurisdiction over matrimonial causes and required correction to render the agreement intelligible and aligned to the Act.
- Reasons: Set-aside arguments based on fairness/just and equitable principles under Part VIII were misplaced because parties may contract out of Part VIII via Part VIIIA, subject only to statutory set-aside grounds.
- Reasons: Once rectified, the unchallenged existence of signed advice certificates meant the s 90G(1) requirements were met and the agreement was binding.
- Reasons: Leave to appeal was not required because the orders finally determined the distinct matrimonial cause concerning the status of the financial agreement.

- Pivotal Finding: It was open to infer the parties had a common intention to enter a binding and enforceable agreement to quarantine the assets each introduced to the marriage (including protecting the wife’s business), notwithstanding the document’s poor drafting and absence of express reference to the Act.
- Pivotal Finding: The clause purporting to apply Victorian law and exclusive Victorian jurisdiction was “nonsense” in the matrimonial context and required correction to align with federal jurisdiction under the Act.
- Pivotal Finding: The husband did not demonstrate error in the primary judge’s rejection of arguments that the agreement was void/unenforceable for uncertainty or ambiguity; delineation of what property fell within/outside the agreement was left to the final trial.
- Pivotal Finding: Once rectified to include s 90B, the agreement satisfied the conjunctive requirements of s 90G(1); no issue was raised about the certification process, and the declaration of binding effect followed.
- Pivotal Finding: Post-marriage contributions and later events (including work in the wife’s business and raising a child) did not establish that the agreement should be denied binding effect; there is no general legal requirement that a financial agreement be fair or just and equitable.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90KA (court’s power applying law and equity principles to determine validity/enforceability, including rectification)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90B and s 90B(1)(b) (pre-marriage financial agreements and requirement the agreement specify it is made under the section)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90G(1) (requirements for a financial agreement to be binding)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K (grounds to set aside a financial agreement)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 71A (effect of binding financial agreements on Part VIII property proceedings)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 4(1) (definition of “matrimonial cause”) and s 94AA plus Family Law Regulations 1984 (Cth) reg 15A (leave to appeal for interlocutory orders)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117 and s 117(2A) (costs factors)

- Uncertainties: The content of the independent legal advice given to each party was not in evidence and neither solicitor was called.
- Uncertainties: The precise identification/characterisation of assets falling within and outside the agreement was left for the final property trial.
- Uncertainties: The case text contains differing judicial views on whether appeal costs should be fixed or assessed (Strickland J preferred assessment; Kent & Austin JJ fixed costs), but the formal orders recorded fixed costs at $31,539.50.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
parties: Ms Barnett, Mr B Simonds & Mr C Simonds as executors of the estate of Mr A Simonds (deceased) (appellants)
issues: Whether the Federal Circuit Court had jurisdiction to grant leave (nunc pro tunc) to institute de facto property proceedings out of time after the de facto husband's death
Whether r 1.09 of the Family Law Rules 2004 could be used to overcome a jurisdictional defect / create jurisdiction
Whether s 90SM(8) (continuation of proceedings after death) applied when no valid property settlement proceedings had been instituted before death
Whether an application for leave under s 44(6) can be characterised as 'property settlement proceedings' or a 'de facto financial cause' capable of being instituted after death
Costs of the appeal and entitlement to a costs certificate
facts: The parties commenced cohabitation in 2000 and lived in a de facto relationship.
There was a dispute about the date of final separation: the respondent alleged 29 December 2015; the deceased alleged 9 October 2013.
The respondent (de facto wife, aged 53) filed an Initiating Application on 10 May 2017 seeking property adjustment orders under s 90SM.
The deceased (aged 75) died in late July 2017, after the application was filed but before any determination of leave to proceed out of time.
A Response was filed on 27 July 2017 on behalf of the deceased's personal representatives asserting the relationship ended in 2013 and the application was out of time under s 44(5).
Personal legal representatives/executors were substituted into the proceedings by orders made 30 October 2017.

At trial before Judge Egan (commenced 10 May 2018), the separation date was heard; the matter was adjourned to allow the respondent to obtain legal advice and file an amended application seeking leave under s 44(6).
The respondent filed an Amended Initiating Application on 25 May 2018 seeking leave pursuant to s 44(6) to institute proceedings out of time.
The trial judge found the relationship ended on 9 October 2013 and the application filed 10 May 2017 was out of time.
On 8 June 2018 the trial judge purported to grant leave nunc pro tunc (referencing r 1.09) to make the property application and to continue it against the executors.

just_equitable: No substantive property adjustment determination was made by the Full Court; the proceedings were dismissed for want of jurisdiction.

relationship_length: De facto relationship commenced in 2000; separation date was disputed and found at trial level to be 9 October 2013.

outcome_orders: Leave to appeal granted.
Appeal allowed.
Orders made by Judge Egan on 8 June 2018 set aside.
Initiating Application filed 10 May 2017 and Amended Initiating Application filed 25 May 2018 dismissed.
Costs certificate granted to the appellants under s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of costs of the appeal.
No order for costs otherwise; each party to bear their own costs pursuant to s 117(1) of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).

description: This appeal turned on jurisdictional limits in de facto property matters when a party dies before valid proceedings are instituted. The Full Court held that an out-of-time property application filed without prior leave under s 44(6) was not a competent 'de facto financial cause' and therefore did not enliven jurisdiction under s 39B(1). Because no valid 'property settlement proceedings' existed at the date of death, s 90SM(8) (continuation after death) could not operate. The decision reinforces that procedural rules (including r 1.09 and the use of nunc pro tunc orders) cannot create substantive jurisdiction or revive abated rights; any right to seek a property adjustment abates on death unless proceedings were already validly instituted.
pivotal_findings: The trial judge found the de facto relationship ended on 9 October 2013, rendering the 10 May 2017 property application out of time under s 44(5).
The respondent had not obtained leave under s 44(6) before the deceased's death; accordingly, no valid or competent de facto property proceedings had been instituted prior to death.
The trial judge did not address jurisdiction and incorrectly purported to use r 1.09 and nunc pro tunc orders to grant leave and permit continuation against the estate.

An application for leave under s 44(6) is not itself 'property settlement proceedings' (it is proceedings for leave to institute such proceedings), applying reasoning from authorities on analogous provisions.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 39B(1): jurisdiction of the Federal Circuit Court with respect to matters where de facto financial causes are instituted
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 44(5): two-year limitation period for de facto property applications
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 44(6): leave to institute out of time
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SM and s 90SM(8): de facto property adjustment power and continuation after death only where proceedings existed
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(1): costs discretion (each party bear own costs)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) s 9: costs certificates on appeal
Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) r 1.09: power to make orders for practice/procedure where legislative gap or procedural difficulty (held not to supply jurisdiction)
Federal Circuit Court Rules 2001 (Cth) r 1.05: application of Family Law Rules where relevant

reasons_rationale: The Court's jurisdiction is statutory and depends on a valid 'de facto financial cause' being instituted; without leave under s 44(6), the out-of-time initiating application was void/ineffective and did not institute proceedings.

A right to seek a property settlement generally abates on death unless statute expressly provides otherwise; s 90SM(8) only permits continuation of existing property settlement proceedings, which did not exist here.

Rule-making powers and procedural devices (including r 1.09 and nunc pro tunc orders) cannot create jurisdiction or alter substantive rights; nunc pro tunc can regularise records, not confer jurisdiction retrospectively.
Because the trial judge lacked jurisdiction to entertain the amended application filed after death, the appropriate disposition was to set aside the orders and dismiss both initiating applications.

Although the appellants succeeded, the Court exercised the s 117(1) discretion not to order costs against the self-represented respondent; instead it granted the appellants a costs certificate given the appeal succeeded on an error of law not caused by the parties.
uncertainties: The substantive property pool, contributions, and any proposed adjustment were not addressed because the matter was disposed of on jurisdictional grounds.
The exact factual basis for the separation date dispute beyond the competing asserted dates is not detailed in the provided text.
No detail is provided about any children of the relationship or parenting issues.

- Pivotal Finding: The respondent had not obtained leave under s 44(6) before the deceased's death; accordingly, no valid or competent de facto property proceedings had been instituted prior to death.
- Pivotal Finding: The trial judge did not address jurisdiction and incorrectly purported to use r 1.09 and nunc pro tunc orders to grant leave and permit continuation against the estate.
- Pivotal Finding: An application for leave under s 44(6) is not itself 'property settlement proceedings' (it is proceedings for leave to institute such proceedings), applying reasoning from authorities on analogous provisions.

- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SM and s 90SM(8): de facto property adjustment power and continuation after death only where proceedings existed

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal costs under s 117 Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether costs should be ordered despite the general rule each party bears own costs
Whether costs should be awarded on an indemnity basis or on another 'special' basis (fixed sum exceeding party/party but less than indemnity)
Effect of an offer of compromise on costs
Relevance of conduct of the appeal including abandoned grounds and outlandish/false submissions
Non-compliance with r 22.53(3) Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) in an indemnity costs application
Fixing costs in a lump sum rather than assessment
facts: The Full Court dismissed the substantive appeal on 21 September 2018 and then dealt with the respondent's costs application.
The respondent filed costs submissions on 8 November 2018 and relied on an April 2018 offer of compromise to settle the appeal.
The respondent sought indemnity costs, alternatively party and party costs; she did not pursue costs against the appellant's lawyers.
The appellant opposed any costs order and filed submissions on 28 November 2018.
The Court directed the respondent to comply with r 22.53(3) and to file a schedule of costs; a schedule was filed but not further submissions and the r 22.53(3) compliance was not provided.
The Court directed the appellant to file any responsive submissions about quantum; none were filed.

The offer to settle the appeal proposed a payment of $580,000 with no order as to costs; the primary judge's order remained $588,726 payable by the appellant by way of final property settlement (as described in the costs reasons).
The appeal was wholly unsuccessful and the appellant abandoned much of his case on the day of the appeal.

The appellant's original Summary of Argument contained numerous outlandish, indefensible and reckless submissions and also included false/misconceived assertions requiring the respondent to prepare to meet them.

Some serious allegations of fraud were raised; the primary judge had found the respondent deceived the appellant into signing a mortgage, but ultimately to no financial disadvantage to him (as described by the Full Court in the costs reasons).
The respondent's schedule of costs totalled $21,985.83 inclusive of GST.

existing_agreements: A written 'Agreement' made in October 2014 was referred to in the appeal materials; the Full Court noted it was not a deed because it was not sealed or attested and did not conform to s 38 Conveyancing Act 1919 (NSW) (in the context of costs and the appellant's submissions).

outcome_orders: The appellant is to pay the respondent's costs fixed in the sum of $17,500.00.

description: This decision concerns the exercise of the Full Court's discretion to award appeal costs under s 117 of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth). The Court treated the appeal's lack of success, the unaccepted compromise offer, and the appellant's conduct (including abandonment of grounds and the making of reckless/false submissions) as justifying a departure from the usual rule that each party bears their own costs. While not satisfied that the high threshold for indemnity costs was met (especially in light of some fraud-related findings at trial and the respondent's non-compliance with r 22.53(3)), the Court used its power to fashion an intermediate 'special costs order' by fixing costs at a sum higher than party/party but less than full indemnity, thereby reflecting litigation conduct without granting a 'blank cheque'.
pivotal_findings: The appeal was wholly unsuccessful, supporting a costs order against the appellant.
The appellant abandoned much of his case on the day of the appeal, indicating unreasonable conduct and wasted preparation costs.

The appellant's original Summary of Argument contained outlandish, indefensible and reckless submissions, and also false/misconceived assertions, requiring the respondent to incur unnecessary costs responding.
The respondent made an offer of compromise (payment of $580,000, no costs) which was not accepted; the appellant remained bound by the primary judge's order ($588,726) after the appeal failed.

Indemnity costs were not ordered: the Court was not satisfied the offer rejection alone warranted indemnity and some fraud allegations were not wholly groundless given the primary judge's finding of deception regarding the mortgage.

The respondent failed to comply with r 22.53(3) (disclosure of any costs agreement for an indemnity application), but the Court proceeded to fix costs given the modest claim and the filed costs schedule.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(1) (general rule each party bears own costs)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(2) (discretion to order costs if circumstances justify, and to make such order as is just)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(2A) (mandatory considerations, including success, offers of compromise, and conduct)
Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) r 22.53(3) (requirement to disclose costs agreement when seeking indemnity costs)
Conveyancing Act 1919 (NSW) s 38 (requirements for deeds; relevant to rejecting the appellant's 'deed' submission as part of conduct analysis)

reasons_rationale: The Court applied s 117: although costs do not automatically follow the event in family law, the combination of an unsuccessful appeal, a reasonable compromise offer not accepted, and unreasonable conduct in the appeal justified ordering costs.
The Court accepted that indemnity costs are exceptional and declined to make an indemnity order, but emphasised it could make an intermediate or 'special' costs order under s 117(2).

The appellant's outlandish, indefensible and reckless submissions, false assertions, and last-minute abandonment of grounds caused unnecessary expense and supported an order for costs above party and party.

The respondent's non-compliance with r 22.53(3) weighed against an indemnity approach and highlighted the need for proportionality and transparency; however, a fixed-sum order was still appropriate given the filed schedule and the modest overall costs.
Fixing costs at $17,500 avoided further costs of assessment and reflected a proportionate response to the conduct and circumstances.
uncertainties: The costs reasons summarise aspects of the underlying property proceedings and appeal (including the $588,726 property settlement figure and mortgage/deception findings), but the substantive property orders and reasoning from the lower court judgment and the appeal dismissal reasons are not included in the provided text.
No information is provided about children, parenting arrangements, or spousal maintenance in this costs judgment.

- Fact: The appellant opposed any costs order and filed submissions on 28 November 2018.
- Fact: The Court directed the respondent to comply with r 22.53(3) and to file a schedule of costs; a schedule was filed but not further submissions and the r 22.53(3) compliance was not provided.
- Fact: The Court directed the appellant to file any responsive submissions about quantum; none were filed.
- Fact: The offer to settle the appeal proposed a payment of $580,000 with no order as to costs; the primary judge's order remained $588,726 payable by the appellant by way of final property settlement (as described in the costs reasons).
- Fact: The appeal was wholly unsuccessful and the appellant abandoned much of his case on the day of the appeal.
- Fact: The appellant's original Summary of Argument contained numerous outlandish, indefensible and reckless submissions and also included false/misconceived assertions requiring the respondent to prepare to meet them.
- Fact: Some serious allegations of fraud were raised; the primary judge had found the respondent deceived the appellant into signing a mortgage, but ultimately to no financial disadvantage to him (as described by the Full Court in the costs reasons).
- Fact: The respondent's schedule of costs totalled $21,985.83 inclusive of GST.

- Issue: Appeal costs under s 117 Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
- Issue: Whether costs should be ordered despite the general rule each party bears own costs
- Issue: Whether costs should be awarded on an indemnity basis or on another 'special' basis (fixed sum exceeding party/party but less than indemnity)
- Issue: Effect of an offer of compromise on costs
- Issue: Relevance of conduct of the appeal including abandoned grounds and outlandish/false submissions
- Issue: Non-compliance with r 22.53(3) Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) in an indemnity costs application
- Issue: Fixing costs in a lump sum rather than assessment
- Outcome: The appellant is to pay the respondent's costs fixed in the sum of $17,500.00.

- Reasons: The Court applied s 117: although costs do not automatically follow the event in family law, the combination of an unsuccessful appeal, a reasonable compromise offer not accepted, and unreasonable conduct in the appeal justified ordering costs.
- Reasons: The Court accepted that indemnity costs are exceptional and declined to make an indemnity order, but emphasised it could make an intermediate or 'special' costs order under s 117(2).
- Reasons: The appellant's outlandish, indefensible and reckless submissions, false assertions, and last-minute abandonment of grounds caused unnecessary expense and supported an order for costs above party and party.
- Reasons: The respondent's non-compliance with r 22.53(3) weighed against an indemnity approach and highlighted the need for proportionality and transparency; however, a fixed-sum order was still appropriate given the filed schedule and the modest overall costs.
- Reasons: Fixing costs at $17,500 avoided further costs of assessment and reflected a proportionate response to the conduct and circumstances.

- Pivotal Finding: The appeal was wholly unsuccessful, supporting a costs order against the appellant.
- Pivotal Finding: The appellant abandoned much of his case on the day of the appeal, indicating unreasonable conduct and wasted preparation costs.
- Pivotal Finding: The appellant's original Summary of Argument contained outlandish, indefensible and reckless submissions, and also false/misconceived assertions, requiring the respondent to incur unnecessary costs responding.
- Pivotal Finding: The respondent made an offer of compromise (payment of $580,000, no costs) which was not accepted; the appellant remained bound by the primary judge's order ($588,726) after the appeal failed.
- Pivotal Finding: Indemnity costs were not ordered: the Court was not satisfied the offer rejection alone warranted indemnity and some fraud allegations were not wholly groundless given the primary judge's finding of deception regarding the mortgage.
- Pivotal Finding: The respondent failed to comply with r 22.53(3) (disclosure of any costs agreement for an indemnity application), but the Court proceeded to fix costs given the modest claim and the filed costs schedule.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(1) (general rule each party bears own costs)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(2) (discretion to order costs if circumstances justify, and to make such order as is just)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 117(2A) (mandatory considerations, including success, offers of compromise, and conduct)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) r 22.53(3) (requirement to disclose costs agreement when seeking indemnity costs)
- Statutory Pivot: Conveyancing Act 1919 (NSW) s 38 (requirements for deeds; relevant to rejecting the appellant's 'deed' submission as part of conduct analysis)

- Uncertainties: The costs reasons summarise aspects of the underlying property proceedings and appeal (including the $588,726 property settlement figure and mortgage/deception findings), but the substantive property orders and reasoning from the lower court judgment and the appeal dismissal reasons are not included in the provided text.
- Uncertainties: No information is provided about children, parenting arrangements, or spousal maintenance in this costs judgment.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal from property settlement orders under s 79 Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether the primary judge erred in the approach to assessing contributions in a long marriage where a major asset increased in value due to rezoning
Whether the primary judge erred by quarantining a major asset and searching for a nexus between contributions and that asset
Whether findings about post-separation contributions were open on the evidence and/or involved denial of procedural fairness
facts: The parties met in 1988 and married in 1991.
They had three children, all adults at the time of the property hearing.
They separated on 3 December 2013, reconciled in February 2015, and finally separated on 25 May 2015.

The husband owned a significant landholding (Property A in Suburb A) prior to the relationship; he had acquired an interest as a child and later became sole owner of the remaining 44 acres by late 2001 after transactions involving a co-owner.

asset_pool: Net non-superannuation property assessed at $9,033,912.58 (first instance figure referenced on appeal).
Property A (Suburb A land) valued at $10,350,000 at trial; described as the major asset and almost 90% of the non-superannuation pool including interim distributions.
Superannuation interests totalled $371,686; parties sought equalisation and a splitting order was made (left undisturbed).
Interim property settlements totalling $1,000,000 had already been received by the parties prior to final determination.
contributions: Marriage contributions: parties conceded and the primary judge found that contributions during the relationship were equal; both worked hard in their occupations and raised three children; business ventures/investments largely did not produce significant returns.
Initial contributions: husband brought into the relationship (a) Property A and (b) the property used as the matrimonial home (net $70,000 at commencement, per appeal court summary).

Property A ownership history: husband ultimately became sole owner by late 2001; sale of another block in 2001 for $215,000 with proceeds split between family purposes ($105,000) and acquiring the co-owner's interest in the remaining block ($105,000).

Rezoning/windfall: increase in value of Property A due to rezoning was not attributable to either party; Full Court treated the rezoning-related increase as not favouring one party over the other (a windfall/serendipitous revaluation concept).
future_needs: No adjustment was sought or made pursuant to s 75(2) at first instance; the Full Court proceeded on the basis that no s 75(2) adjustment was required.
The Full Court noted it was not obvious a further adjustment would be required given the amount of property retained by each party, even accepting the husband had some recent health difficulties.
just_equitable: The Full Court held the primary judge erred by quarantining Property A from the holistic assessment of contributions and by giving undue weight to the fortuitous rezoning increase as part of the husband's initial contribution.

On re-exercise, the Full Court assessed contributions at 53% husband and 47% wife for non-superannuation property, reflecting the husband's initial contributions but giving proper weight to equal contributions over a long marriage and to the rezoning windfall not favouring either party.
The Full Court stated the resulting differential ($542,035) appropriately reflected the various contributions and the outcome was just and equitable.
living_arrangements: Children were adults at the time of hearing; no parenting arrangements required determination.

There was reference to occupation arrangements for Property C post-separation under earlier interim orders (husband had sole occupation pending payout/sale on the basis he paid outgoings), relevant to whether outgoings were a post-separation contribution.
existing_agreements: Interim property settlement distributions totalling $1,000,000 had been made.

Interim orders by Judge Turner on 8 October 2014 (referenced in appeal reasons) required the husband to pay $135,000 to the wife by 30 November 2014 in relation to Property C, with the wife relinquishing her interest upon payment; husband to have sole occupation pending payment or sale and to pay all outgoings during that period.

relationship_length: Relationship/marriage length discussed as 27 years for property contributions analysis.
standard_of_living: Evidence referenced that the parties lived a modest lifestyle until borrowing $400,000 in anticipation of sale (contextual to property, not maintenance).

child_ages: Three children were adults at the time of the hearing (exact ages not stated).
caregiver_history: Parties raised three children during the marriage; contributions as parents treated as part of equal contributions.

outcome_orders: Appeal allowed.
Orders 6 and 7 of 25 May 2018 varied by replacing 66%/34% with 53% (husband) and 47% (wife) division of non-superannuation assets.
Order 5(c) set aside; parties directed to forward within 7 days an agreed replacement order giving effect to the 53/47 division of non-superannuation assets.
By consent: from the sum to be received by the wife under Order 5(c) as varied, the wife to pay the husband $100,000.
Husband to pay the wife's costs of and incidental to the appeal in the amount of $35,536.91.

description: The Full Court clarified that contribution assessment under s 79(4) must be holistic and must not quarantine an initial asset (or require a causal nexus between contributions and a specific asset) in a long marriage, particularly where the asset’s increase is due to external windfall factors such as rezoning. It also reinforced procedural fairness requirements where a trial judge proposes to rely on post-separation contributions not advanced by a party.
pivotal_findings: Primary judge accepted parties' concession that contributions during the marriage were equal, but treated Property A separately and credited the husband heavily for its trial value, leading to a 66/34 split.

Property A’s major increase in value resulted from a fortuitous 2010 rezoning; this increase did not favour one party over the other and should not have been treated as a unilateral contribution outcome.
The trial approach impermissibly sought a nexus between contributions and the asset and effectively quarantined Property A from the 'myriad of other contributions' over a 27-year marriage.

Post-separation contribution findings were partly unsupported by quantified evidence (child support overpayment; property outgoings; holidays/children’s expenses), and the wife was denied procedural fairness because the husband did not advance a post-separation contributions case and the issue was not squarely raised for her response.
On re-exercise, only the husband’s initial contributions (Property A and the former matrimonial home) justified any departure from equality, resulting in a modest adjustment to 53/47.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 and s 79(4) (assessment of contributions; holistic evaluation; avoidance of quarantining/nexus requirement).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future needs factors; noted as not relied upon/adjusted).
Procedural fairness principles (administrative/common law fairness) applied via authorities such as Kioa v West and Stead v State Government Insurance Commission.
Appellate intervention in discretionary decisions per House v The King.

reasons_rationale: Adequacy of reasons: Full Court held the primary judge's reasoning path to 66/34 was intelligible, so the adequacy-of-reasons challenge failed.

Error of principle: Primary judge misdirected herself by quarantining Property A and searching for a nexus between contributions and that specific asset, contrary to s 79(4) jurisprudence (including Dickons, Singerson & Joans, Wallis, Hurst).

Windfall increase: Rezoning-related increase in value was a windfall not attributable to either party and should not have been credited as enhancing the husband's initial contribution at the expense of the wife's equal contributions over the long marriage.

Post-separation contributions: Procedural fairness was denied because post-separation contributions were not advanced by the husband but were relied upon by the primary judge; several findings lacked quantified evidentiary foundation and were disproportionately minor relative to the pool.

Re-exercise: Considering the long marriage, equal marital contributions, and the husband's initial contributions (including the former matrimonial home as a practical contribution), the Full Court determined 53/47 was just and equitable.
uncertainties: The value of Property A at the commencement of cohabitation was not in evidence.
Exact quantum of several asserted post-separation contributions (child support overpayment, outgoings, holiday/children expenses) was not quantified in the evidence.
Exact ages of the adult children were not stated.
