court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal against refusal to set aside a binding financial agreement
Whether the primary judge erred in assessing hardship under s 90K(1)(d) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether the primary judge erred by giving no weight to the husband's evidence of current asset values relevant to the hardship comparison
facts: The parties' first child X was born in 2005 and second child Y was born in 2007.
The parties married in 2007 and entered a binding financial agreement dated 5 February 2007.
On 2 March 2009, X was diagnosed with atypical autism and mild functional/adaptive impairment and later with pica, requiring a high level of care due to challenging and unsafe behaviours.

asset_pool: Binding Financial Agreement schedule assets: Property A valued at $2,200,000 (unencumbered) at 2007.

Binding Financial Agreement schedule assets: Husband's 2 of 2 shares in Business A holding Property B NSW valued at $1,700,000 with Westpac mortgage $159,846 at 2007, and Property C NSW valued at $500,000 with Commonwealth Bank mortgage $102,745 at 2007.
Other scheduled items (a bank account and a motor cruiser) were referred to as relatively small and no longer existed at hearing; husband said he no longer held the bank account.
contributions: The Full Court accepted the wife's case (for hardship comparison purposes) that the relationship was about 10 years with two children and that a significant share of the care, including care of a child with significant disability, fell upon the wife and was likely to continue.
The Full Court considered that the wife's contributions, taken together with s 75(2) considerations, could not be adequately satisfied from the smaller pool if the agreement remained in place.
future_needs: Changed circumstances: X's disability created much more onerous care responsibilities and increased costs; the primary judge found hardship to both parties from these care responsibilities and costs.
The Full Court treated the wife's ongoing caring role for X in particular as central to the hardship assessment and the s 75(2) considerations relevant to her position.
just_equitable: This appeal did not determine a final s 79 property division; it determined whether the financial agreement should be set aside under s 90K(1)(d).

The Full Court held that for s 90K(1)(d) the court must make a comparative assessment of the position if the agreement stands versus if set aside, and that the husband's value evidence should be given some weight to enable that comparison.
The Full Court concluded hardship was established because the wife's contributions and s 75(2) considerations could not be adequately met from the limited property available under the agreement.
living_arrangements: The Full Court noted the wife's case assumed she cared for X and Y on an almost full-time basis and worked part-time; the primary judge considered relative care responsibilities but the Full Court held that approach was misplaced in the way it was used.
existing_agreements: Binding Financial Agreement dated 5 February 2007.
Clause 3 limited wife's entitlement to scheduled assets to any increase in value of (including matrimonial home or replacement asset) and excluded husband's gifts/inheritances from claims.
Clause 5 excluded wife's entitlement to property acquired by husband in his sole name with money accumulated from his sole earnings or other income.

need: At first instance, the wife did not make a spousal maintenance claim; the primary judge treated the absence of such a claim as significant to hardship, but the Full Court held this was misplaced because maintenance and property are not substitutes and property is to be dealt with first when both are sought.
statutory_factors: s 75(2) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) was discussed in relation to care of children and its relevance to property/financial hardship comparison, not to making a maintenance order.
earning_capacity: The primary judge referred to the wife's assertion that she worked part-time due to care responsibilities and lack of financial support; the Full Court indicated hardship from caring responsibilities can include loss of opportunity to earn income.
relationship_length: The Full Court referred to the wife's case of a 10-year relationship with two children.

child_ages: X born 2005.
Y born 2007.
current_arrangements: The primary judge found both parents had 'caring responsibility' for X within s 90K(2).
caregiver_history: X's diagnoses (autism-related impairment and pica) led to high care needs and challenging/unsafe behaviours; these needs were found to create onerous care responsibilities.
safety_concerns: X's condition involved challenging and unsafe behaviours and required a high level of care.
expert_evidence: No family consultant evidence or parenting expert evidence was discussed in the provided text; the case focused on financial agreement hardship.
best_interests: The case concerned s 90K(1)(d) hardship due to circumstances relating to the care, welfare and development of a child rather than making parenting orders.

legal_advice: The agreement was drafted typewritten and the wife's solicitor made handwritten alterations later adopted by the husband (details of advice content not set out).
financial_disclosure: The Full Court rejected an argument that failure to adduce valuation evidence equated to lack of disclosure; it noted the husband disclosed his assets and his view of their worth in his Financial Statement.
pressure_duress: At first instance the wife raised undue influence and unconscionable conduct as grounds to set aside, but the appeal proceeded only on s 90K(1)(d).
changed_circumstances: X's disability diagnoses after the agreement were found to be a material change in circumstances relating to care, welfare and development of a child.

outcome_orders: The appeal was allowed and the orders made on 28 June 2018 were set aside.
Pursuant to s 90K(1)(d) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth), the Financial Agreement dated 5 February 2007 was set aside.
Any party seeking a costs order was directed to file and serve written submissions within 14 days, with responses and replies on specified further 14-day timetables.

description: The Full Court clarified that the hardship inquiry under s 90K(1)(d) requires a comparative assessment of positions if the agreement stands versus if set aside, and that the comparison is preliminary rather than a full final-property trial. The decision turned on evidentiary treatment: the primary judge's refusal to give any weight to the husband's own value estimates prevented the required comparison and led to an erroneous dismissal. The Full Court also rejected importing child support and spousal maintenance considerations into the s 90K(1)(d) hardship test in the manner used below, and confirmed that scheduled asset values in a binding financial agreement can operate as binding benchmarks for assessing 'increase in value' by objective construction and estoppel by convention.
pivotal_findings: X's post-agreement diagnoses and resulting care needs constituted a material change in circumstances relating to the care, welfare and development of a child.
Both parties had caring responsibility for X, and the changed circumstances caused and would continue to cause hardship to both parties through more onerous care responsibilities and increased costs.
The husband's evidence of current asset values (Financial Statement and oral admissions) was relevant, admissible, and should have been given some weight; it was more than conjecture.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K(1)(d) (material change in child-related circumstances and resulting hardship test for setting aside a financial agreement).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future-needs considerations referenced in assessing whether hardship would result if agreement not set aside).
Evidence Act 1995 (Cth) ss 55 and 56 (relevance/admissibility of the husband's evidence of asset values).

reasons_rationale: The primary judge's approach was erroneous because he gave no weight to admitted and relevant evidence (the husband's own value estimates/admissions) which was capable of supporting the comparative assessment required by s 90K(1)(d).

The hardship comparison under s 90K(1)(d) is not a final property hearing requiring formal valuations; some weight can be given to an owner’s evidence in a preliminary assessment, especially where no other evidence exists.

The primary judge wrongly relied on the wife's lack of child support assessment and the possibility of spousal maintenance as reasons to find the hardship evidence deficient; these matters do not substitute for the hardship to a carer contemplated by s 90K(1)(d), and property and maintenance are distinct.
uncertainties: The judgment did not finally determine the parties' property adjustment under s 79 or any specific percentage division; it only set aside the financial agreement.

The precise current valuations of the properties were not determined by formal valuation evidence; the Full Court relied on giving some weight to the husband's estimates and his Financial Statement for the s 90K(1)(d) comparison.

Whether the husband's asset increase of $583,599 was attributable to inheritance and thus excluded if the agreement stood was not conclusively resolved; the Full Court noted that even if divisible it would not obviously alleviate hardship.

summary_text:
- Fact: The parties' first child X was born in 2005 and second child Y was born in 2007.
- Fact: The parties married in 2007 and entered a binding financial agreement dated 5 February 2007.
- Fact: On 2 March 2009, X was diagnosed with atypical autism and mild functional/adaptive impairment and later with pica, requiring a high level of care due to challenging and unsafe behaviours.

- Issue: Appeal against refusal to set aside a binding financial agreement
- Issue: Whether the primary judge erred in assessing hardship under s 90K(1)(d) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
- Issue: Whether the primary judge erred by giving no weight to the husband's evidence of current asset values relevant to the hardship comparison

- Asset Pool: Binding Financial Agreement schedule assets: Property A valued at $2,200,000 (unencumbered) at 2007.
- Asset Pool: Binding Financial Agreement schedule assets: Husband's 2 of 2 shares in Business A holding Property B NSW valued at $1,700,000 with Westpac mortgage $159,846 at 2007, and Property C NSW valued at $500,000 with Commonwealth Bank mortgage $102,745 at 2007.
- Asset Pool: Other scheduled items (a bank account and a motor cruiser) were referred to as relatively small and no longer existed at hearing; husband said he no longer held the bank account.
- Contributions: The Full Court accepted the wife's case (for hardship comparison purposes) that the relationship was about 10 years with two children and that a significant share of the care, including care of a child with significant disability, fell upon the wife and was likely to continue.
- Contributions: The Full Court considered that the wife's contributions, taken together with s 75(2) considerations, could not be adequately satisfied from the smaller pool if the agreement remained in place.
- Future Needs: Changed circumstances: X's disability created much more onerous care responsibilities and increased costs; the primary judge found hardship to both parties from these care responsibilities and costs.
- Future Needs: The Full Court treated the wife's ongoing caring role for X in particular as central to the hardship assessment and the s 75(2) considerations relevant to her position.
- Just & Equitable: This appeal did not determine a final s 79 property division; it determined whether the financial agreement should be set aside under s 90K(1)(d).
- Just & Equitable: The Full Court held that for s 90K(1)(d) the court must make a comparative assessment of the position if the agreement stands versus if set aside, and that the husband's value evidence should be given some weight to enable that comparison.
- Just & Equitable: The Full Court concluded hardship was established because the wife's contributions and s 75(2) considerations could not be adequately met from the limited property available under the agreement.

- Need: At first instance, the wife did not make a spousal maintenance claim; the primary judge treated the absence of such a claim as significant to hardship, but the Full Court held this was misplaced because maintenance and property are not substitutes and property is to be dealt with first when both are sought.
- Statutory Factors: s 75(2) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) was discussed in relation to care of children and its relevance to property/financial hardship comparison, not to making a maintenance order.

- Child Ages: X born 2005.
- Child Ages: Y born 2007.
- Current Arrangements: The primary judge found both parents had 'caring responsibility' for X within s 90K(2).
- Safety Concerns: X's condition involved challenging and unsafe behaviours and required a high level of care.
- Best Interests: The case concerned s 90K(1)(d) hardship due to circumstances relating to the care, welfare and development of a child rather than making parenting orders.

- Agreement Date: 2007-02-05
- Legal Advice: The agreement was drafted typewritten and the wife's solicitor made handwritten alterations later adopted by the husband (details of advice content not set out).
- Financial Disclosure: The Full Court rejected an argument that failure to adduce valuation evidence equated to lack of disclosure; it noted the husband disclosed his assets and his view of their worth in his Financial Statement.
- Pressure/Duress: At first instance the wife raised undue influence and unconscionable conduct as grounds to set aside, but the appeal proceeded only on s 90K(1)(d).
- Changed Circumstances: X's disability diagnoses after the agreement were found to be a material change in circumstances relating to care, welfare and development of a child.

- Outcome: The appeal was allowed and the orders made on 28 June 2018 were set aside.
- Outcome: Pursuant to s 90K(1)(d) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth), the Financial Agreement dated 5 February 2007 was set aside.
- Outcome: Any party seeking a costs order was directed to file and serve written submissions within 14 days, with responses and replies on specified further 14-day timetables.

- Reasons: The primary judge's approach was erroneous because he gave no weight to admitted and relevant evidence (the husband's own value estimates/admissions) which was capable of supporting the comparative assessment required by s 90K(1)(d).
- Reasons: The hardship comparison under s 90K(1)(d) is not a final property hearing requiring formal valuations; some weight can be given to an owner’s evidence in a preliminary assessment, especially where no other evidence exists.
- Reasons: The primary judge wrongly relied on the wife's lack of child support assessment and the possibility of spousal maintenance as reasons to find the hardship evidence deficient; these matters do not substitute for the hardship to a carer contemplated by s 90K(1)(d), and property and maintenance are distinct.

- Pivotal Finding: X's post-agreement diagnoses and resulting care needs constituted a material change in circumstances relating to the care, welfare and development of a child.
- Pivotal Finding: Both parties had caring responsibility for X, and the changed circumstances caused and would continue to cause hardship to both parties through more onerous care responsibilities and increased costs.
- Pivotal Finding: The husband's evidence of current asset values (Financial Statement and oral admissions) was relevant, admissible, and should have been given some weight; it was more than conjecture.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90K(1)(d) (material change in child-related circumstances and resulting hardship test for setting aside a financial agreement).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (future-needs considerations referenced in assessing whether hardship would result if agreement not set aside).
- Statutory Pivot: Evidence Act 1995 (Cth) ss 55 and 56 (relevance/admissibility of the husband's evidence of asset values).

- Uncertainties: The judgment did not finally determine the parties' property adjustment under s 79 or any specific percentage division; it only set aside the financial agreement.
- Uncertainties: The precise current valuations of the properties were not determined by formal valuation evidence; the Full Court relied on giving some weight to the husband's estimates and his Financial Statement for the s 90K(1)(d) comparison.
- Uncertainties: Whether the husband's asset increase of $583,599 was attributable to inheritance and thus excluded if the agreement stood was not conclusively resolved; the Full Court noted that even if divisible it would not obviously alleviate hardship.

court: Family Court of Australia (Full Court)
issues: Leave to appeal from an interim spousal maintenance order
Whether the primary judge gave adequate reasons for fixing interim spousal maintenance at $1,000 per week
Whether the respondent established the threshold for de facto spousal maintenance under s 90SF(1) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Assessment of the respondent's reasonable weekly needs for interim maintenance
facts: The parties were in a de facto relationship and have one child born in 2016.
At the time of the interim hearing, the child was about 2 years old and in the respondent's full-time care.
The parties lived in different states, limiting the appellant's capacity to assist with day-to-day care.
The respondent lived with her parents and did not pay rent; she wished to establish a home independently but said she could not afford to do so.

asset_pool: Not a final property settlement; evidence of appellant's assets considered for capacity to pay maintenance.
Appellant: three parcels of real estate (estimated total around $1.425 million on his estimates), five motor vehicles, and a 50% share in a UK business (value not in evidence).

Appellant: liabilities said to be around $435,000 (including a $250,000 mortgage over one property and other personal liabilities/loans), producing net assets in the vicinity of $1 million (most unencumbered).
Respondent: savings around $29,000 to $35,000; otherwise no assets of value identified.
future_needs: Respondent had full-time care of a very young child and limited ability to work; relied on parents for accommodation and some support.
Appellant had a higher lifestyle, international travel, and significant assets; the Court inferred unutilised earning capacity.
living_arrangements: Respondent lived with her parents rent-free with the child.
Appellant lived independently and travelled frequently between Australia and the UK.

need: Primary judge found the respondent required $617 per week to support herself (based on Part N of her updated Financial Statement), but nevertheless ordered $1,000 per week without explaining the additional component.
On re-exercise, the plurality assessed the respondent's reasonable needs at $617 per week on the basis she would continue living rent-free with her parents for the foreseeable future.

Watts J (dissenting on outcome) considered it reasonable on an interim basis to allow an additional $383 per week toward accommodation/electricity (total $1,000 per week), having regard to a reasonable standard of living and the respondent's dependence on parents for accommodation.
capacity_to_pay: The primary judge and Full Court accepted the appellant had capacity to pay, relying on inferred earning capacity and inferences drawn from inadequate disclosure and lifestyle evidence.
The plurality inferred the appellant would earn significantly more if he worked longer in his profession and found his actual income likely understated.
The plurality noted appellant's assets (real estate, vehicles, business interest) and ability to travel internationally, supporting a finding of financial capacity.
statutory_factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SE (interim maintenance jurisdiction and disregard of Centrelink income for threshold assessment under s 90SE(4))
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SF(1) (threshold: applicant unable to support herself adequately for specified reasons; payer reasonably able)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SF(3) (matters to be considered in determining maintenance; plurality gave greatest weight to s 90SF(3)(c), (g) and (l))

Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(2)(b)(ib) and s 117(3B) (high costs of child care as a child support consideration; relevant to whether child care costs were improperly folded into spouse maintenance)
income_expenses: Respondent: welfare benefits were her only income but were disregarded; claimed weekly expenses of $617; parents contributed amounts including for living expenses and legal fees; rent not paid while living with parents.
Appellant: disclosed income around $825 per week and expenses about $1,238 per week including legal fees; expenses did not clearly account for regular international travel.
earning_capacity: Appellant found to be highly qualified and not fulfilling his earning capacity; Court accepted earning capacity may be considered rather than only actual income.
Respondent: not required to pursue full-time employment given full-time care of a very young child and costs/constraints of child care; limited success obtaining part-time work; studying part-time.
relationship_length: The parties gave different versions of relationship history; on the respondent's version the relationship lasted from about 2007 to June 2017 (recounted in the appeal reasons via reference to primary judge's discussion).
standard_of_living: Plurality noted respondent's standard of living was less than the appellant's and less than during the relationship, even with maintenance, attributable to childcare responsibilities and inability to live independently.
Watts J emphasised the statutory requirement to consider a reasonable standard of living and the accommodation history during the relationship.

child_ages: One child born in 2016 (about 2 years old at the time of the interim hearing; not yet 3 at re-exercise).
current_arrangements: Respondent had full-time care of the child.
Appellant lived interstate from the child and could assist only infrequently due to geography.
caregiver_history: Respondent gave up full-time work prior to the child's birth to care for the child.
availability: Respondent's availability for work constrained by sole care of a very young child; reliance on paid childcare or parents' assistance.
Appellant's availability for caregiving limited by interstate residence and travel pattern.
best_interests: Maintenance assessment accepted it was reasonable for the respondent to prioritise personally caring for the very young child rather than placing the child in full-time childcare for employment purposes.

outcome_orders: Leave to appeal granted from Order 5 dated 9 July 2018.
Appeal allowed in part.
Order 5 varied by deleting '$1,000' and inserting '$617' per week as interim spousal maintenance (commencing 16 July 2018 and continuing weekly).
Directions made for any costs application to be dealt with by written submissions within specified timeframes.

description: The Full Court treated the appeal as turning on the adequacy and internal consistency of reasons for an interim de facto spousal maintenance amount. While accepting the interim 'broad-brush' approach, the Court held the primary judge must still explain the path from findings about need to the quantum ordered. The decision also illustrates the role of inferred earning capacity and adverse inferences from inadequate disclosure in assessing capacity to pay, and distinguishes between spouse maintenance and child-related expenses (notably child care costs) which are ordinarily addressed through child support mechanisms.
pivotal_findings: The primary judge made an express finding that the respondent required $617 per week to support herself, but did not explain why $1,000 per week was ordered; the $1,000 figure was not available on the reasons and was inconsistent with the $617 finding (Ground 3 established).

The respondent satisfied the s 90SF(1)(b)(i) threshold: she was unable to support herself adequately by reason of having care and control of a very young child, with the other parent living interstate and unable to assist other than infrequently (Ground 4 rejected).

The appellant had capacity to pay assessed by reference to unutilised earning capacity and lifestyle/asset evidence, with the Court entitled to draw robust inferences because of incomplete disclosure (Grounds 5 and 6 rejected).

On re-exercise (plurality), respondent's reasonable needs for interim maintenance were $617 per week on the basis she would continue living rent-free with parents; maintenance should not be used to pay legal fees or to indirectly meet child support-type expenses without analysis.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SE
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SF(1)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SF(3)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (pseudonym/publication approval noted)

reasons_rationale: Leave to appeal was granted because the interim maintenance decision was attended by sufficient doubt (inadequate reasons and inconsistency about quantum) and substantial injustice would result if leave were refused.

The respondent met the maintenance threshold due to sole care of a very young child; the Court rejected the proposition that she must seek full-time work or compel grandparents to provide childcare to qualify.

The $1,000 weekly figure could not be justified on the primary judge's stated findings; potential explanations (childcare costs, parental contributions, future rent) were speculative and not articulated, raising risk of error (including possible double-counting) and procedural fairness concerns.

Capacity to pay was upheld based on earning capacity and adverse inferences from the appellant's inadequate disclosure, unexplained travel funding, and lifestyle inconsistent with reported income; the Court endorsed a robust approach where non-disclosure impedes precise findings.

On re-exercise, the plurality fixed maintenance at the respondent's assessed reasonable needs ($617/week), whereas Watts J would have allowed an additional interim accommodation component to reach $1,000/week.
uncertainties: The value of the appellant's 50% interest in the UK business was not in evidence.
The precise amount of any child care rebate and family tax benefits referenced was not fully specified in the plurality reasons (Watts J referenced a $500/week childcare rebate).
The parties' relationship history/duration was disputed; only the respondent's version (2007 to June 2017) is mentioned in the appeal reasons.

- Current Arrangements: Appellant lived interstate from the child and could assist only infrequently due to geography.
- Best Interests: Maintenance assessment accepted it was reasonable for the respondent to prioritise personally caring for the very young child rather than placing the child in full-time childcare for employment purposes.

- Outcome: Leave to appeal granted from Order 5 dated 9 July 2018.
- Outcome: Appeal allowed in part.
- Outcome: Order 5 varied by deleting '$1,000' and inserting '$617' per week as interim spousal maintenance (commencing 16 July 2018 and continuing weekly).
- Outcome: Directions made for any costs application to be dealt with by written submissions within specified timeframes.

- Reasons: Leave to appeal was granted because the interim maintenance decision was attended by sufficient doubt (inadequate reasons and inconsistency about quantum) and substantial injustice would result if leave were refused.
- Reasons: The respondent met the maintenance threshold due to sole care of a very young child; the Court rejected the proposition that she must seek full-time work or compel grandparents to provide childcare to qualify.
- Reasons: The $1,000 weekly figure could not be justified on the primary judge's stated findings; potential explanations (childcare costs, parental contributions, future rent) were speculative and not articulated, raising risk of error (including possible double-counting) and procedural fairness concerns.
- Reasons: Capacity to pay was upheld based on earning capacity and adverse inferences from the appellant's inadequate disclosure, unexplained travel funding, and lifestyle inconsistent with reported income; the Court endorsed a robust approach where non-disclosure impedes precise findings.
- Reasons: On re-exercise, the plurality fixed maintenance at the respondent's assessed reasonable needs ($617/week), whereas Watts J would have allowed an additional interim accommodation component to reach $1,000/week.

- Pivotal Finding: The primary judge made an express finding that the respondent required $617 per week to support herself, but did not explain why $1,000 per week was ordered; the $1,000 figure was not available on the reasons and was inconsistent with the $617 finding (Ground 3 established).
- Pivotal Finding: The respondent satisfied the s 90SF(1)(b)(i) threshold: she was unable to support herself adequately by reason of having care and control of a very young child, with the other parent living interstate and unable to assist other than infrequently (Ground 4 rejected).
- Pivotal Finding: The appellant had capacity to pay assessed by reference to unutilised earning capacity and lifestyle/asset evidence, with the Court entitled to draw robust inferences because of incomplete disclosure (Grounds 5 and 6 rejected).
- Pivotal Finding: On re-exercise (plurality), respondent's reasonable needs for interim maintenance were $617 per week on the basis she would continue living rent-free with parents; maintenance should not be used to pay legal fees or to indirectly meet child support-type expenses without analysis.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SE
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SF(1)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SF(3)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (pseudonym/publication approval noted)

- Uncertainties: The value of the appellant's 50% interest in the UK business was not in evidence.
- Uncertainties: The precise amount of any child care rebate and family tax benefits referenced was not fully specified in the plurality reasons (Watts J referenced a $500/week childcare rebate).
- Uncertainties: The parties' relationship history/duration was disputed; only the respondent's version (2007 to June 2017) is mentioned in the appeal reasons.

summary_sections.text:
- Fact: The parties were in a de facto relationship and have one child born in 2016.
- Fact: At the time of the interim hearing, the child was about 2 years old and in the respondent's full-time care.
- Fact: The parties lived in different states, limiting the appellant's capacity to assist with day-to-day care.
- Fact: The respondent lived with her parents and did not pay rent; she wished to establish a home independently but said she could not afford to do so.

- Issue: Leave to appeal from an interim spousal maintenance order
- Issue: Whether the primary judge gave adequate reasons for fixing interim spousal maintenance at $1,000 per week
- Issue: Whether the respondent established the threshold for de facto spousal maintenance under s 90SF(1) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
- Issue: Assessment of the respondent's reasonable weekly needs for interim maintenance

- Asset Pool: Not a final property settlement; evidence of appellant's assets considered for capacity to pay maintenance.
- Asset Pool: Appellant: three parcels of real estate (estimated total around $1.425 million on his estimates), five motor vehicles, and a 50% share in a UK business (value not in evidence).
- Asset Pool: Appellant: liabilities said to be around $435,000 (including a $250,000 mortgage over one property and other personal liabilities/loans), producing net assets in the vicinity of $1 million (most unencumbered).
- Asset Pool: Respondent: savings around $29,000 to $35,000; otherwise no assets of value identified.
- Future Needs: Respondent had full-time care of a very young child and limited ability to work; relied on parents for accommodation and some support.
- Future Needs: Appellant had a higher lifestyle, international travel, and significant assets; the Court inferred unutilised earning capacity.

- Need: Primary judge found the respondent required $617 per week to support herself (based on Part N of her updated Financial Statement), but nevertheless ordered $1,000 per week without explaining the additional component.
- Need: On re-exercise, the plurality assessed the respondent's reasonable needs at $617 per week on the basis she would continue living rent-free with her parents for the foreseeable future.
- Need: Watts J (dissenting on outcome) considered it reasonable on an interim basis to allow an additional $383 per week toward accommodation/electricity (total $1,000 per week), having regard to a reasonable standard of living and the respondent's dependence on parents for accommodation.
- Capacity to Pay: The primary judge and Full Court accepted the appellant had capacity to pay, relying on inferred earning capacity and inferences drawn from inadequate disclosure and lifestyle evidence.
- Capacity to Pay: The plurality inferred the appellant would earn significantly more if he worked longer in his profession and found his actual income likely understated.
- Capacity to Pay: The plurality noted appellant's assets (real estate, vehicles, business interest) and ability to travel internationally, supporting a finding of financial capacity.
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SE (interim maintenance jurisdiction and disregard of Centrelink income for threshold assessment under s 90SE(4))
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SF(1) (threshold: applicant unable to support herself adequately for specified reasons; payer reasonably able)
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SF(3) (matters to be considered in determining maintenance; plurality gave greatest weight to s 90SF(3)(c), (g) and (l))
- Statutory Factors: Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 (Cth) s 117(2)(b)(ib) and s 117(3B) (high costs of child care as a child support consideration; relevant to whether child care costs were improperly folded into spouse maintenance)

- Child Ages: One child born in 2016 (about 2 years old at the time of the interim hearing; not yet 3 at re-exercise).
- Current Arrangements: Respondent had full-time care of the child.
- Current Arrangements: Appellant lived interstate from the child and could assist only infrequently due to geography.
- Best Interests: Maintenance assessment accepted it was reasonable for the respondent to prioritise personally caring for the very young child rather than placing the child in full-time childcare for employment purposes.

- Outcome: Leave to appeal granted from Order 5 dated 9 July 2018.
- Outcome: Appeal allowed in part.
- Outcome: Order 5 varied by deleting '$1,000' and inserting '$617' per week as interim spousal maintenance (commencing 16 July 2018 and continuing weekly).
- Outcome: Directions made for any costs application to be dealt with by written submissions within specified timeframes.

- Reasons: Leave to appeal was granted because the interim maintenance decision was attended by sufficient doubt (inadequate reasons and inconsistency about quantum) and substantial injustice would result if leave were refused.

- Reasons: The $1,000 weekly figure could not be justified on the primary judge's stated findings; potential explanations (childcare costs, parental contributions, future rent) were speculative and not articulated, raising risk of error (including possible double-counting) and procedural fairness concerns.
- Reasons: Capacity to pay was upheld based on earning capacity and adverse inferences from the appellant's inadequate disclosure, unexplained travel funding, and lifestyle inconsistent with reported income; the Court endorsed a robust approach where non-disclosure impedes precise findings.
- Reasons: On re-exercise, the plurality fixed maintenance at the respondent's assessed reasonable needs ($617/week), whereas Watts J would have allowed an additional interim accommodation component to reach $1,000/week.

- Pivotal Finding: The primary judge made an express finding that the respondent required $617 per week to support herself, but did not explain why $1,000 per week was ordered; the $1,000 figure was not available on the reasons and was inconsistent with the $617 finding (Ground 3 established).
- Pivotal Finding: The respondent satisfied the s 90SF(1)(b)(i) threshold: she was unable to support herself adequately by reason of having care and control of a very young child, with the other parent living interstate and unable to assist other than infrequently (Ground 4 rejected).
- Pivotal Finding: The appellant had capacity to pay assessed by reference to unutilised earning capacity and lifestyle/asset evidence, with the Court entitled to draw robust inferences because of incomplete disclosure (Grounds 5 and 6 rejected).
- Pivotal Finding: On re-exercise (plurality), respondent's reasonable needs for interim maintenance were $617 per week on the basis she would continue living rent-free with parents; maintenance should not be used to pay legal fees or to indirectly meet child support-type expenses without analysis.
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SE
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SF(1)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 90SF(3)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (pseudonym/publication approval noted)

- Uncertainties: The value of the appellant's 50% interest in the UK business was not in evidence.
- Uncertainties: The precise amount of any child care rebate and family tax benefits referenced was not fully specified in the plurality reasons (Watts J referenced a $500/week childcare rebate).
- Uncertainties: The parties' relationship history/duration was disputed; only the respondent's version (2007 to June 2017) is mentioned in the appeal reasons.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal against property settlement orders under s 79 of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether the primary judge erred in assessing contributions by giving separate/quarantined weight to the husband's initial property contribution (the 'B Property')
Whether factual error was made about 'common ground' regarding contributions to conservation of the B Property
Whether the contributions assessment (62.5/37.5) and ultimate division (55/45) was unjust or unreasonable
Whether to re-exercise discretion on appeal or remit for rehearing
Costs certificates under the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth)
facts: The parties commenced cohabitation in early 1995 and married in 1996.
They had two children: X (born 1998) and Y (born 2003).
They separated under one roof in November 2016 and physically separated in March 2017 when the wife and children left the home; the husband remained in the former matrimonial home.
At trial, both children were living with the wife.
The husband was the primary breadwinner and the wife was the primary caregiver and homemaker across the relationship.
The net property pool at trial (including modest superannuation interests) was found to be $941,096.

A central dispute concerned the impact of the husband's initial capital contribution of an unimproved property at Suburb B (the 'B Property') that he owned at the start of cohabitation and retained throughout.
The B Property was agreed to be worth $340,000 at trial; there was no admissible evidence of its value at cohabitation.

asset_pool: Net property pool at trial: $941,096 (including modest superannuation interests).
B Property (Suburb B land): agreed value at trial $340,000; unimproved and unencumbered at relationship commencement; remained unimproved.
Former matrimonial home ('home property'): husband occupied post-separation; remained in pool; mortgage reduced during marriage including by gifts from wife's parents.
Superannuation interests: described as modest; included in net pool.
Other chattels/vehicle: husband purchased a work vehicle for $8,700 pre-marriage period from earlier land sale proceeds (context of initial contribution).
contributions: Husband: primary breadwinner throughout relationship.
Wife: primary homemaker and parent; contributions treated as equal in nature to husband's breadwinning within the marriage partnership.
Husband: initial equity in the home property at cohabitation agreed at $58,000.
Husband: brought in and retained the B Property; treated by primary judge as the sole distinguishing contributions factor.

Wife's parents: gifts totalling about $70,000 during marriage (plus unspecified total of $1,000 Christmas gifts), including about $29,500 applied to reduce home mortgage (2004), $10,880 to purchase family car, and $5,000 for appliances (2002); treated as contributions by/on behalf of the wife.

Primary judge rejected husband's claim to extra credit for renovations performed as a registered builder, finding renovations made wife's homemaker/parent role more arduous and each contributed according to skills.
future_needs: Primary judge made a 7.5% adjustment in favour of the wife for s 79(4)(d)-(g) factors (details of those factors not set out in the provided text).
just_equitable: Primary judge considered the impact of the husband's initial financial contribution central to achieving a just and equitable outcome.

Full Court held the primary judge erred by effectively quarantining the B Property and giving it discrete, distinguishing weight rather than treating it as part of the 'myriad of contributions' in a long marriage.
living_arrangements: At trial, children lived with the wife.
Post-separation, the husband continued to occupy the former matrimonial home while servicing mortgage and outgoings; wife and children vacated in March 2017.

relationship_length: Cohabitation about 22 years; about 24 years from commencement of cohabitation to trial/final orders in the lower court.

child_ages: X born 1998 (22 at time of appeal reasons)
Y born 2003 (16 at time of appeal reasons)
current_arrangements: As at trial, both children were living with the wife.
caregiver_history: Wife was primary caregiver and homemaker during the relationship; husband was primary breadwinner.

outcome_orders: The appeal from Orders 1 to 10 made on 22 February 2019 was allowed and those orders were set aside.
The proceedings were remitted for rehearing by a judge other than the primary judge.
A costs certificate was granted to the wife under s 9 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of the costs incurred in relation to the appeal.
Costs certificates were granted to each party under s 8 of the Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) in respect of the costs incurred in relation to the rehearing.

description: The Full Court intervened because the primary judge's contributions assessment under s 79 miscarried by isolating ('quarantining') the husband's initial asset (the B Property) and treating its present value as a dominant differentiator, rather than assessing all contributions holistically across a long marriage. The decision reinforces that contributions are not to be causally linked to the current value of a particular asset in a way that sidelines non-financial and indirect contributions, especially where asset growth is due to market forces.
pivotal_findings: The primary judge treated the husband's introduction of the B Property as the only distinguishing factor and derived a 25% contributions differential (62.5/37.5) on that basis.
The primary judge relied on the B Property being 36% of the trial pool and regarded a 25% differential as justified because it was less than 36%, evidencing discrete weight given to that asset.
There was no evidence that the increase in value of the B Property was due to either party's efforts; any increase was attributable to market forces.

The Full Court found the primary judge's approach amounted to quarantining the B Property and gave the wife's myriad contributions a subsidiary role, constituting error of principle in contributions assessment.
Because both parties sought remitter and wished to adduce evidence of current circumstances, the Full Court remitted rather than re-exercised discretion.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79 (property settlement discretion and assessment of contributions and other factors)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4)(a)-(c) (direct/indirect financial and non-financial contributions, including homemaker/parent contributions)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 79(4)(d)-(g) (future needs / other relevant matters adjustment applied by the primary judge)
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981 (Cth) ss 8 and 9 (costs certificates)
Appellate discretion principles: House v The King (error of principle / miscarriage of discretion) referenced by the Court

reasons_rationale: The Full Court held the primary judge misapplied contributions principles by isolating the husband's initial property (B Property) and effectively weighing it against the remainder of the marriage contributions rather than treating it as one contribution among many in a long relationship.

The Full Court relied on authorities emphasising holistic contributions assessment and rejecting causal linkage between contributions and the 'financial product' of particular assets, including Lovine & Connor and Dickons v Dickons.

The Full Court considered the approach adopted at first instance analogous to the errors identified in Hurst and Jabour, where quarantining a significant external asset improperly minimised other contributions over a long marriage.
Given the identified legal error, the s 79 discretion miscarried, requiring the orders to be set aside.
Remitter was ordered because current circumstances and disputed further evidence made re-exercise of discretion inappropriate, consistent with the need for current evidence (Allesch v Maunz).
Costs certificates were granted because the appeal succeeded due to errors of law.
uncertainties: No admissible evidence established the value of the B Property at the commencement of cohabitation; only the trial value ($340,000) was agreed.
The total amount of the 'regular Christmas gifts of $1,000' from the wife's parents was unspecified.
The specific factual matters underpinning the 7.5% s 79(4)(d)-(g) adjustment were not set out in the provided text.

court: Full Court of the Family Court of Australia
issues: Appeal against spousal maintenance order (weekly amount and duration)
Whether primary judge gave adequate reasons for spousal maintenance
Whether respondent met threshold for spousal maintenance under s 72(1) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
Whether appellant had capacity to pay spousal maintenance (including effect of child support and alleged employment insecurity)
facts: The parties had three children; at appeal two were under 18 and the eldest had reached majority.
Final parenting and property orders were made in the Federal Circuit Court of Australia on 31 January 2019.
The parenting orders provided that the two younger children live with the respondent and that she have sole parental responsibility.
The middle child was to spend time with the appellant in accordance with the child's wishes.

asset_pool: Known assets found by primary judge: $498,241.
Property division of known assets: 70% to respondent, 30% to appellant.
Respondent’s entitlement: $348,769, comprised of $212,162 superannuation and $136,607 publicly listed shares.
Primary judge found appellant retained unknown assets, including gold bullion valued at about $96,000 (May 2013).
contributions: Respondent ceased work in 2000 to care for the parties’ first child and did not return to full-time work.
Respondent was found to have been the primary carer for the children.
future_needs: Primary judge found respondent had significantly lower earning capacity than appellant.
Respondent had and would continue to have primary care of the parties’ children.
Superannuation component received by respondent was not readily accessible.
Primary judge accepted property orders would allow respondent to repay some debts but not re-establish financial independence.
just_equitable: Primary judge made property settlement based on known assets and adjusted 70/30 in respondent’s favour, noting difficulties in determining the pool due to appellant’s disclosure failures.
living_arrangements: Two younger children lived with the respondent under final parenting orders; the adult child also lived with the respondent.

need: Primary judge found respondent was unable to support herself adequately due to care and control of children under 18 and incapacity for appropriate gainful employment.
Respondent had been out of the full-time workforce for about 18–19 years and had made reasonable but unsuccessful attempts to obtain employment.
Spousal maintenance for two years was accepted as facilitating retraining and re-entry into the workforce.
The Court rejected the contention that child support payments removed the respondent’s need for spousal maintenance (child support is for children, not the spouse; and arrears existed).
capacity_to_pay: Primary judge found appellant had capacity to pay $450 per week based on income of about $200,000 gross per annum and spending patterns.
Primary judge found some of appellant’s claimed expenses were unreasonable and found issues with appellant’s claimed tax estimates and rejected evidence of borrowing from relatives.
Appeal court accepted inferences in respondent’s favour were available due to appellant’s failure to make full and frank disclosure and findings that he retained gold bullion/unknown assets.
Appellant’s child support obligations were taken into account as relevant to capacity to pay (s 75(2)(na)), but did not negate need.
statutory_factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 72(1) (threshold for spousal maintenance: inability to support adequately due to child care/incapacity/other adequate reason).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 74(1) (power to make maintenance orders).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (matters to consider including earning capacity, care of children, and child support).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(3) (income-tested benefits to be disregarded in exercising jurisdiction under s 74).
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 83 (variation/discharge/suspension of maintenance orders).
income_expenses: Appellant’s income found at about $200,000 gross per annum.
Primary judge described appellant’s personal expenses of about $500 per week as unreasonable.

Appeal reasons note respondent’s Financial Statement reflected weekly living expenses about $353 plus rent $275, CTP insurance $18 and TAFE $100 (total about $746) and that her claimed needs exceeded $450 per week.
Respondent’s only income aside from child support was income-tested government benefits of about $403 per week, which were to be disregarded under s 75(3).
Child support assessment stated as $805.62 per week; appellant asserted he was paying higher amounts at times, but significant arrears were agreed.
earning_capacity: Primary judge found respondent had significantly lower earning capacity; she lacked qualifications and had been out of the workforce for many years.
Appellant was found to have a high income and ongoing earning capacity; health assertions were not supported by evidence at trial.
health_care: Appellant asserted diabetes and monitoring for possible recurrence of skin cancer on appeal; the Court found diabetes was not in evidence and skin cancer issue was not raised at trial and was not shown to affect earning capacity.
relationship_length: Not expressly stated; evidence indicates first child born in 2000 and respondent left full-time work then.
standard_of_living: Appellant argued respondent’s lifestyle/schedule showed reasonable standard of living; Court held lifestyle on income-tested benefits was not relevant and that respondent’s need and inability to support herself were established.

child_ages: Eldest child born in 2000 and was over 18 at time of appeal judgment.
Two younger children were under 18 at time of the primary judge’s orders and appeal.
current_arrangements: Two younger children to live with the respondent.
Respondent to have sole parental responsibility.
Middle child to spend time with the appellant in accordance with the child’s wishes.
Youngest child to spend time with the appellant on alternate weekends and Wednesday afternoons during school terms and half school holidays.
caregiver_history: Respondent found to have always been the primary carer.
Appellant found to have had little involvement in the children’s lives.
child_views: Middle child to spend time with the appellant in accordance with the child’s wishes.
orders: Final parenting orders as summarised: live with respondent; sole parental responsibility to respondent; time with appellant for middle child per wishes and youngest child as specified.

outcome_orders: Appeal against Order 31 (spousal maintenance of $450 per week for two years) dismissed.

Order 17 concerning the children’s bank accounts (funds held on trust) set aside by consent/concession; remedial orders made to restore children’s trust accounts (including respondent’s oral undertaking), limited to the two younger children as the eldest was an adult.
Appellant ordered to pay respondent’s costs fixed at $10,290.30.

description: The decision illustrates the Full Court’s reluctance to interfere with a discretionary spousal maintenance order where the s 72(1) threshold (need) and payer capacity are supported by evidence, and where the primary judge’s reasons—though brief—explain the essential pathway. It also confirms that money held on trust for children is not property of the parties for division, and highlights that non-disclosure can justify robust inferences and a less cautious approach in favour of the innocent party. The appeal emphasised proper construction of s 75(2)(f) and mandatory disregard of income-tested benefits under s 75(3), and that variation mechanisms are provided by statute (s 83) rather than needing bespoke clauses in orders.
pivotal_findings: Primary judge’s reasons for spousal maintenance, read as a whole with earlier findings about disclosure and resources, were adequate to reveal the basis for the $450 per week for two years.

Respondent met s 72(1) threshold: inability to support herself adequately due to care of children under 18 and limited capacity for appropriate gainful employment after long absence from workforce and unsuccessful job-seeking attempts.

Appellant had capacity to pay: income about $200,000 gross; some expenses found unreasonable; tax and loan assertions not accepted; and inference available that his true financial position was better than disclosed, including retained gold/unknown assets.
Child support did not negate spousal maintenance need; it is for children and, while relevant to capacity, did not remove respondent’s entitlement especially given arrears.
Government income-tested benefits were required to be disregarded under s 75(3), defeating appellant’s reliance on s 75(2)(f).
statutory_pivots: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 72(1)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 74(1)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(3)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 83

reasons_rationale: Adequacy of reasons assessed in context; spousal maintenance issues were straightforward and the reasons, though brief, sufficiently disclosed the path of reasoning.
Findings about appellant’s lack of disclosure, unreliability of claimed tax expenses, rejection of alleged loans, and retention of gold supported the conclusion that he could pay.
Respondent’s long absence from workforce, primary care responsibilities, and unsuccessful employment efforts supported need and s 72(1) threshold.
Child support is conceptually distinct from spousal maintenance; it may affect capacity but does not replace maintenance for the spouse.
Income-tested government benefits must be disregarded in maintenance determinations under s 75(3).
uncertainties: Exact weekly child support paid at the time of trial was disputed in submissions, though assessment and substantial arrears were accepted.
Details of respondent’s liabilities and the full asset pool were not precisely found due to lack of agreed pool and disclosure issues; only known assets were quantified in appeal reasons.
Respondent’s exact age at trial/appeal is stated inconsistently in the reasons (47 at primary judgment; 49 referred to in appeal reasons).

summary_text:
- Fact: The parties had three children; at appeal two were under 18 and the eldest had reached majority.
- Fact: Final parenting and property orders were made in the Federal Circuit Court of Australia on 31 January 2019.
- Fact: The parenting orders provided that the two younger children live with the respondent and that she have sole parental responsibility.
- Fact: The middle child was to spend time with the appellant in accordance with the child's wishes.

- Issue: Appeal against spousal maintenance order (weekly amount and duration)
- Issue: Whether primary judge gave adequate reasons for spousal maintenance
- Issue: Whether respondent met threshold for spousal maintenance under s 72(1) Family Law Act 1975 (Cth)
- Issue: Whether appellant had capacity to pay spousal maintenance (including effect of child support and alleged employment insecurity)

- Asset Pool: Known assets found by primary judge: $498,241.
- Asset Pool: Property division of known assets: 70% to respondent, 30% to appellant.
- Asset Pool: Respondent’s entitlement: $348,769, comprised of $212,162 superannuation and $136,607 publicly listed shares.
- Asset Pool: Primary judge found appellant retained unknown assets, including gold bullion valued at about $96,000 (May 2013).
- Contributions: Respondent ceased work in 2000 to care for the parties’ first child and did not return to full-time work.
- Contributions: Respondent was found to have been the primary carer for the children.
- Future Needs: Primary judge found respondent had significantly lower earning capacity than appellant.
- Future Needs: Respondent had and would continue to have primary care of the parties’ children.
- Future Needs: Superannuation component received by respondent was not readily accessible.
- Future Needs: Primary judge accepted property orders would allow respondent to repay some debts but not re-establish financial independence.
- Just & Equitable: Primary judge made property settlement based on known assets and adjusted 70/30 in respondent’s favour, noting difficulties in determining the pool due to appellant’s disclosure failures.

- Need: Primary judge found respondent was unable to support herself adequately due to care and control of children under 18 and incapacity for appropriate gainful employment.
- Need: Respondent had been out of the full-time workforce for about 18–19 years and had made reasonable but unsuccessful attempts to obtain employment.
- Need: Spousal maintenance for two years was accepted as facilitating retraining and re-entry into the workforce.
- Need: The Court rejected the contention that child support payments removed the respondent’s need for spousal maintenance (child support is for children, not the spouse; and arrears existed).
- Capacity to Pay: Primary judge found appellant had capacity to pay $450 per week based on income of about $200,000 gross per annum and spending patterns.
- Capacity to Pay: Primary judge found some of appellant’s claimed expenses were unreasonable and found issues with appellant’s claimed tax estimates and rejected evidence of borrowing from relatives.
- Capacity to Pay: Appeal court accepted inferences in respondent’s favour were available due to appellant’s failure to make full and frank disclosure and findings that he retained gold bullion/unknown assets.
- Capacity to Pay: Appellant’s child support obligations were taken into account as relevant to capacity to pay (s 75(2)(na)), but did not negate need.
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 72(1) (threshold for spousal maintenance: inability to support adequately due to child care/incapacity/other adequate reason).
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 74(1) (power to make maintenance orders).
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2) (matters to consider including earning capacity, care of children, and child support).
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(3) (income-tested benefits to be disregarded in exercising jurisdiction under s 74).
- Statutory Factors: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 83 (variation/discharge/suspension of maintenance orders).

- Child Ages: Eldest child born in 2000 and was over 18 at time of appeal judgment.
- Child Ages: Two younger children were under 18 at time of the primary judge’s orders and appeal.
- Current Arrangements: Two younger children to live with the respondent.
- Current Arrangements: Respondent to have sole parental responsibility.
- Current Arrangements: Middle child to spend time with the appellant in accordance with the child’s wishes.
- Current Arrangements: Youngest child to spend time with the appellant on alternate weekends and Wednesday afternoons during school terms and half school holidays.

- Outcome: Appeal against Order 31 (spousal maintenance of $450 per week for two years) dismissed.
- Outcome: Order 17 concerning the children’s bank accounts (funds held on trust) set aside by consent/concession; remedial orders made to restore children’s trust accounts (including respondent’s oral undertaking), limited to the two younger children as the eldest was an adult.
- Outcome: Appellant ordered to pay respondent’s costs fixed at $10,290.30.

- Reasons: Adequacy of reasons assessed in context; spousal maintenance issues were straightforward and the reasons, though brief, sufficiently disclosed the path of reasoning.
- Reasons: Findings about appellant’s lack of disclosure, unreliability of claimed tax expenses, rejection of alleged loans, and retention of gold supported the conclusion that he could pay.
- Reasons: Respondent’s long absence from workforce, primary care responsibilities, and unsuccessful employment efforts supported need and s 72(1) threshold.
- Reasons: Child support is conceptually distinct from spousal maintenance; it may affect capacity but does not replace maintenance for the spouse.
- Reasons: Income-tested government benefits must be disregarded in maintenance determinations under s 75(3).

- Pivotal Finding: Primary judge’s reasons for spousal maintenance, read as a whole with earlier findings about disclosure and resources, were adequate to reveal the basis for the $450 per week for two years.
- Pivotal Finding: Respondent met s 72(1) threshold: inability to support herself adequately due to care of children under 18 and limited capacity for appropriate gainful employment after long absence from workforce and unsuccessful job-seeking attempts.
- Pivotal Finding: Appellant had capacity to pay: income about $200,000 gross; some expenses found unreasonable; tax and loan assertions not accepted; and inference available that his true financial position was better than disclosed, including retained gold/unknown assets.
- Pivotal Finding: Child support did not negate spousal maintenance need; it is for children and, while relevant to capacity, did not remove respondent’s entitlement especially given arrears.
- Pivotal Finding: Government income-tested benefits were required to be disregarded under s 75(3), defeating appellant’s reliance on s 75(2)(f).
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 72(1)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 74(1)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(2)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 75(3)
- Statutory Pivot: Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 83

- Uncertainties: Exact weekly child support paid at the time of trial was disputed in submissions, though assessment and substantial arrears were accepted.
- Uncertainties: Details of respondent’s liabilities and the full asset pool were not precisely found due to lack of agreed pool and disclosure issues; only known assets were quantified in appeal reasons.
- Uncertainties: Respondent’s exact age at trial/appeal is stated inconsistently in the reasons (47 at primary judgment; 49 referred to in appeal reasons).

court: Family Court of Australia (Appellate Jurisdiction, Brisbane)
issues: Extension of time to serve Notice of Appeal (r 22.05 Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth))
Dismissal of appeal/application for non-compliance or delay (r 22.45 Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth))
Whether the primary judge properly used the slip rule to amend a costs order (r 16.05(2) Federal Circuit Court Rules 2001 (Cth))
Whether costs should be assessed on Federal Circuit Court scale (Schedule 1 FCC Rules) or Family Law Rules scale (Schedule 3 Family Law Rules) via taxation under Chapter 19
facts: The parties were involved in litigation since 2012 as de facto partners.
On 10 January 2018, the Federal Circuit Court made property settlement orders under Pt VIIIAB of the Family Law Act 1975 (Cth).
The de facto wife received/retained property interests valued at $859,649 (28%) and the de facto husband $2,185,371 (72%) out of a total pool found to be $3,045,020.
The de facto wife's spousal maintenance application was dismissed; no appeal was filed from the 10 January 2018 orders.

The de facto husband sought a costs order after the substantive proceedings; on 19 April 2018 the primary judge ordered the de facto wife pay the de facto husband's costs on a party and party basis from 27 August 2014 to 10 January 2018 (excluding appeal costs).
A costs assessment was undertaken on the Family Law Rules basis, producing an assessed amount of $278,407.24 (served 31 August 2018).
The de facto wife disputed the costs assessment on the basis that the FCC scale should apply (asserted to be approximately $23,000).

On 22 May 2019 the primary judge varied the April 2018 costs orders, relying on the slip rule, so the costs were to be referred to taxation under Chapter 19 of the Family Law Rules (effectively the Schedule 3 scale).
The practical difference between scales was described as about $278,000 (Family Law Rules Schedule) versus about $23,000 (FCC Rules Schedule), a disparity of about $250,000.
The de facto wife filed her Notice of Appeal within time on 18 June 2019 but did not serve it within the 14 days required by r 22.05.

asset_pool: Total property pool found in the substantive proceedings: $3,045,020 (per 10 January 2018 FCC orders).
Division under 10 January 2018 orders: de facto wife $859,649 (28%); de facto husband $2,185,371 (72%).
The appeal decision primarily concerns costs rather than re-opening the asset pool.
contributions: Not detailed in this appeal judgment; substantive property orders were made 10 January 2018 and not appealed.
future_needs: Not detailed in this appeal judgment; substantive property decision not under appeal.
just_equitable: Substantive property orders were final and unappealed; this decision concerns procedural issues regarding a costs-order amendment.
living_arrangements: Not stated.
existing_agreements: Not stated.

need: The de facto wife's spousal maintenance application in the substantive proceedings was dismissed (10 January 2018); not the subject of this appeal application.

outcome_orders: The time within which the applicant de facto wife had to serve the Notice of Appeal filed by her on 18 June 2019 was extended to 26 July 2019.
The respondent de facto husband's application for dismissal of the applicant de facto wife's Notice of Appeal pursuant to r 22.45 of the Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) was dismissed.
Each party's costs of and incidental to the application were reserved.

description: This appellate decision is an interlocutory determination in an appeal: it does not decide the merits of whether the primary judge correctly applied the slip rule to alter the costs-assessment pathway. Its legal significance lies in maintaining access to appellate review where a notice of appeal was filed in time but service was late, and where the proposed appeal raised a substantial question about the permissible scope of the slip rule in changing the practical effect of a costs order (including a large financial disparity between competing scales).
pivotal_findings: The Notice of Appeal was filed within time; the default concerned service, not filing.
The delay in service did not demonstrate sufficient prejudice to justify dismissal where the appeal was not clearly bound to fail.
The de facto wife's explanation for non-service (loss of representation/being overwhelmed) was found not adequate, but was not determinative once merit and justice were considered.

There was a substantial issue to be raised on appeal regarding whether the slip rule could be used to amend the costs order to achieve assessment under the Family Law Rules scale, particularly given the absence of any reference in the original reasons/orders to the scale, the presumption in r 21.10 FCC Rules, and the need (per Pawley) to consider surrounding circumstances including transcript.
The primary judge's later assertion of intention was not, by itself, sufficient to establish proper slip-rule application; full surrounding circumstances (including transcript) may be required.
The size of the alleged disparity between costs scales (about $250,000) reinforced the importance of appellate review.
statutory_pivots: Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) r 22.05 (service of notice of appeal time requirement)
Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) r 22.45 (dismissal for non-compliance/delay)
Family Law Rules 2004 (Cth) r 1.14 (power to extend time, referenced via authorities)
Federal Circuit Court Rules 2001 (Cth) r 16.05(2)(e) and r 16.05(2)(h) (slip rule/variation after entry)
Federal Circuit Court Rules 2001 (Cth) rr 21.10 and 21.11 (costs scale default and taxation in family law proceedings)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s 121(9)(g) (publication approval noted)
Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) Pt VIIIAB (context of underlying property orders)
Federal Circuit Court of Australia Act 1999 (Cth) s 5 (definition of 'judgment' relevant to critique of varying reasons)

reasons_rationale: An extension of time is granted to prevent injustice and enable the court to do justice between parties, requiring consideration of history, conduct, consequences, and whether there is a substantial issue to be raised on appeal (authorities including Gallo v Dawson and Pendleton).

Dismissal under r 22.45 is not warranted where the appeal was instituted within time and it is not clear the appeal would fail; lack of prejudice and the respondent not being required to take steps before the appeal index was relevant (Jackamarra v Krakouer principle).

The proposed appeal had sufficient substance because slip-rule application to convert the practical operation of a costs order is legally contestable and requires examination of surrounding circumstances (Pawley), not just reliance on the primary judge's later stated intention.
Costs of the extension/dismissal application were reserved as more appropriately considered with the substantive appeal.
uncertainties: The merits of the substantive slip-rule appeal were not determined; the court only assessed whether there was a substantial issue.

The transcript and full surrounding circumstances of the 19 April 2018 hearing were not before the court at this interlocutory stage; those materials may be critical to determining slip-rule applicability.

The basis for the primary judge's reference to an indemnity-cost figure of $265,187.48 (when the application sought $345,803.81) was described as unclear and potentially relevant to interpretation of intention.
